One you\u2019ll probably recognize if you\u2019re a fan of comic books, but the other three are real-life figures who can stand next to any larger-than-life superhero. \u2014 Alan Henry, Smarter Living editor", "title": "What We\u2019re Reading", "authors": ["Andrea Kannapell"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "But there\u2019s something else in this Gospel story that I\u2019d rather honor. What does it mean to wander in the wilderness for 40 days and nights and face your demons? How would I do that today? How do you give up all distractions and listen to that inner voice that tells you what you need to be doing but you can\u2019t quite face yet? The idea fills me with a weird combination of joy and dread.\n\nYears ago a wise friend \u2014 O.K., he happened to be an Episcopal priest \u2014 told me that when religious norms start excluding an essential practice, it pops up elsewhere, often in a secular garb. I feel like that\u2019s one reason meditation has boomed recently, practiced by everybody from Silicon Valley executives to kindergartners. The church forgot how important a regular discipline of emptiness is, something so easy to do in prayer \u2014 but its flock didn\u2019t.\n\nI guess it\u2019s not unlike something I do already. I started praying regularly on my morning commute on the subway. I discovered how the external stimuli of doors opening and closing and wheels creaking on the tracks could be channels for some of my own inner doors opening. As long as I kept my eyes closed (funny about that).\n\nThen I took up the practice sitting on the sofa at home. When you get silent you hear a lot of the noise in your head. Sometimes it will masquerade as a fabulous idea that you have to pursue right now, or some item on your to-do list that if you don\u2019t get up from that sofa and log on to your computer, you\u2019ll forget.\n\nYou won\u2019t. In fact, what I look to is the forgetting. In the 14th century an anonymous author wrote a wonderful book on contemplative prayer called \u201cThe Cloud of Unknowing.\u201d \u201cWhatever you don\u2019t know and whatever you\u2019ve forgotten are \u2018dark\u2019 to you,\u201d he says, \u201cbecause you don\u2019t see them with your spiritual eyes.\u201d (This translation of the original Middle English is by Carmen Acevedo Butcher.) Emptiness is this process of unknowing.", "title": "Opinion | What Will You Give Up for Lent?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWill you watch any of the 2018 Winter Olympics, which begin Feb. 8 in Pyeongchang, South Korea?\n\nWhich competitions interest you? Which sports will you follow in the news, if any, and why?\n\nIn \u201c\u2018Big-Air Snowboarding\u2019 to Make Its Big Olympic Debut,\u201d John Jeremiah Sullivan writes:\n\nSnowboarding comes from the same place surfing does: Hawaii. By which I mean it was invented by someone from Hawaii. Or at least, by a person who had relocated to Hawaii and later become a cultural figure there. The island never gets credit. People have done research on the sport\u2019s early history, but somehow this all-important first chapter has been lost. The people in Hawaii went through hell a couple of weeks ago, as many readers know. For about 40 minutes they lived with the belief that a ballistic missile was coming to wipe them out. They started calling one another to say goodbye. Hawaii: Accept this small restoration of roots as a gesture of solidarity, an arm around your shoulder on the curb outside the gas station as we say, \u201cWhat happened in there was not cool.\u201d The history of snowboarding, or as it was known then, \u201csnurfing\u201d (i.e., snow-surfing), does not begin in Michigan in the 1960s with boards made by a guy named Sherman Poppen. It does not even begin, as revisionists will tell you, in Colorado in 1939, with a thing called the Bunker Sno-Surf. It happened a full year before, in 1938, in Yosemite National Park. A slight young man named Robert Trumbull, a Honolulu newspaper editor who wrote a weather column under the byline Sol Pluvius (Rainy Sun), was on vacation. Chicago-born, Trumbull had seen plenty of snow, and he had been surfing. That was the all-important crossing of the wires. \u201cYesterday Sol showed the natives a new trick,\u201d reported The Honolulu Advertiser, \u201csnow-surfing, or as Sol called it, \u2018snurfing.\u2019 \u201d He coined the word. That may all be sports trivia, but it\u2019s about to become important trivia, because soon, in this very winter of 2018 \u2014 80 years after Trumbull\u2019s breakthrough \u2014 will occur the Olympic debut of a sport known as \u201cbig-air snowboarding,\u201d which is the snurfing equivalent of big-wave surfing. It is best described as the most beautiful, insane, stupid, dangerous, death-wishing, insane and beautiful sport ever perpetrated on innocent spectators. Big air works like this: You stand at the top of a high, steep slope. You get going down it exceptionally fast. You hit a ramp, the kind of ramp you might use if you needed to jump your motorcycle over a canyon. When you fire off this ramp on your snurfer, having hit the lip of it with tremendous force, you fly into the air very high and far. Big-air boarders routinely find themselves 65 feet above the slope. They spin around and do tricks and flips. Weirdly, the tricks and flips often don\u2019t even seem like that big a deal, the boarders are up so high. Imagine yourself in one of those zero-gravity simulator planes. You would be flipping all around and making cool moves, but you wouldn\u2019t be proud of yourself, because your great-grandmother could do the same thing. Death is always near where big air is getting caught. For that matter, regular old small-air snowboarding can be plenty life-threatening. Granted, most of the deaths are avalanche-related. Some result from helicopter crashes, when riders are searching for untouched snow in the high mountain passes. One biggie that is more clearly attributable to human error: collisions \u2014 most often between a rider and a stationary object, like a tree or a finish-line pillar (the Swiss champion Daniel Loetscher died in the latter way).\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Do you agree that snowboarding should be an Olympic sport? Why or why not?\n\n\u2014 What winter sports are you most excited about watching \u2014 either during the Olympics, or in general, and why?\n\n\u2014 Which other sports would you add to the Winter Games, and why?\n\nFor related Times Olympic coverage see The Times Magazine\u2019s Olympics Issue and the 2018 Winter Games.", "title": "What Winter Olympic Sports Are You Most Excited About Watching?", "authors": ["Caroline Crosson Gilpin", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "HOW TO STOP TIME\n\nBy Matt Haig\n\n325 pp. Viking. $26.\n\nThe first thing we discover about Tom Hazard, the protagonist of Matt Haig\u2019s new novel, \u201cHow to Stop Time,\u201d is that he is very, very old. He is old, he tells us, \u201cin the way that a tree, or a quahog clam, or a Renaissance painting is old.\u201d Born in France in 1581, he is fast approaching his 440th birthday. Not that anyone would know it to look at him, since outwardly he appears to be an ordinary man in his 40s. This is because Tom has a condition, rare but not unique, known as anageria. People with anageria age much more slowly than ordinary people, at a rate of roughly one year for every 15 ordinary human years. Although Tom lives life at the same pace as everyone else, judging by his appearance, it would seem that \u201conly a decade passes between the death of Napoleon and the first man on the moon.\u201d Immune to almost all human diseases, and assuming he avoids a violent death, Tom can expect to live until he is around 950. With four centuries of life under his belt, he is only just approaching middle age. And like many middle-aged men, he appears to be suffering something of a midlife crisis.\n\nThis is not, of course, a new idea. Ever since Jonathan Swift\u2019s Gulliver traveled to the nation of Luggnagg, where the \u201cstruldbrugs\u201d age but never die, writers have used the notion of immortality to examine the possibilities and limits of a human life. In recent years Audrey Niffenegger\u2019s \u201cThe Time Traveler\u2019s Wife\u201d and Kate Atkinson\u2019s \u201cLife After Life\u201d have both played inventively with the idea of lives lived outside of ordinary time. Haig himself touched on the idea in his previous novel, \u201cThe Humans,\u201d which saw an eccentric English mathematician unlocking the secret of prime numbers and thereby the means to rid the world of illness and death. Fearful of the power this would give violent and primitive humans, an advanced alien super-race from the planet Vonnadoria hurriedly dispatched one of their kind to extinguish all traces of his theory. \u201cThe Humans\u201d was warmhearted, sharply observed and often laugh-out-loud funny, funny enough to forgive Haig\u2019s alien his regrettable fondness for fortune-cookie philosophy.\n\nImage\n\nIn \u201cHow to Stop Time,\u201d Haig has ditched the comedy for something more melancholic. Others of Tom\u2019s kind \u2014 known as albatrosses (or \u201calbas\u201d), after the bird thought in Victorian times to be exceptionally long-lived \u2014 consider their lives infinitely superior to ordinary humans (or \u201cmayflies\u201d) who live so briefly. Tom fiercely disagrees. To him his longevity is a curse, forcing him from an early age to live alone. His unchanging appearance arouses hostility and suspicion. Superstitious neighbors condemn his mother as a witch. Similar accusations dog his beloved wife, Rose, and daughter, Marion, until he must leave them for their own safety. In the 400 years since Rose\u2019s death he has roamed the world, unwilling to settle, unable to find happiness. The only thing that keeps him from taking his own life is the knowledge that Marion has inherited his condition and is out there somewhere, waiting for him to find her. When he is approached by the Albatross Society, a secret association designed to protect albas from the twin threats of superstition and science, he hopes its mastermind, the hedonistic Hendrich Pietersen, will be able to help him track her down.\n\nThe resulting novel is part love story and part thriller, though not quite enough of either. Almost 500 years is quite something to compress into a conventionally sized novel, and Haig takes us on a whistle-stop tour through the highlights of Tom\u2019s life, playing the lute in Shakespeare\u2019s Globe, voyaging with Captain Cook to the Pacific islands, drinking cocktails in Paris with Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald. In the rather less star-studded present he is teaching history in a modern London high school, and it is these sections of the novel that are the most convincing. Haig remains a keen-eyed observer of contemporary life \u2014 a plastic bag \u201cfloats far over our heads like a cartoon ghost\u201d \u2014 and his dialogue has snap and charm. In the past, however, he is on shakier ground; his characters seem to exist less in their historical surroundings than to have pushed their faces through the holes in painted carnival cutouts. Shakespeare is a particularly clumsy creation, a man who quotes himself in conversation.", "title": "What Would It Be Like to Be 400 Years Old?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Have you ever lived in, or visited, a town or city that felt just right to you? If so, what was it that appealed to you, and why?\n\nImagine your ideal town or city. What would it look like? What would housing, commerce, transportation and recreation be like? What amenities or special features would it include, and why?\n\nIn \u201cTech Envisions the Ultimate Start-Up: An Entire City,\u201d Emily Badger writes:\n\nSAN FRANCISCO \u2014 For all the optimism, innovation and wealth that are produced here, the Bay Area can also feel like a place that doesn\u2019t work quite right. The cost of housing has priced out teachers and line cooks. Income inequality is among the widest in the nation. The homeless crisis never seems to ebb. Traffic is a mess. On bad days, transit is, too. And local governments are locked in conflict. Clearly, the region has not been optimized. \u201cIt could be so much better,\u201d said Ben Huh, who moved to San Francisco in 2016 after running the Cheezburger blog empire in Seattle. \u201cThere\u2019s so much wealth. There\u2019s so much opportunity.\u201d In the maddening gap between how this place functions and how inventors and engineers here think it should, many have become enamored with the same idea: What if the people who build circuits and social networks could build cities, too? Wholly new places, designed from scratch and freed from broken policies. Mr. Huh leads a project begun by the start-up accelerator Y Combinator to explore the creation of new cities. Hundreds applied to work on what looked like \u201cthe ultimate full-stack start-up.\u201d Last October, Sidewalk Labs, an Alphabet company, announced it would team up with a government agency in Toronto to redevelop a stretch of the city \u201cfrom the internet up.\u201d For others in tech \u2014 intrigued by word of a proposed smart city in Arizona, a big Bitcoin land grab in Nevada, a special economic zone in Honduras \u2014 fantasizing about newly built cities has become a side gig. They dream of utopias with driverless cars, radical property-ownership models, 3-D-printed houses and skyscrapers assembled in days. While some urban planners roll their eyes, it is true that America\u2019s cities have always been built on someone\u2019s hubris, whether the characters who plotted Manhattan\u2019s street grid, or those who imagined the Golden Gate Bridge.\n\nStudents: Read the entire article, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 Do you agree with the article that some cities today don\u2019t \u201cwork quite right?\u201d If so, what doesn\u2019t work, and why? If not, why not?\n\n\u2014 Do you agree with the article that today\u2019s cities are \u201cthe equivalent of the flip phone,\u201d and are out of date? If so, how could they be redesigned and improved, and why?", "title": "What Would Your Ideal City Look Like?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "A week into my assignment I learned through the grapevine a terrible truth: Medics in Vietnam were expected to endure six hard months in the field. A battle-tested sergeant advised me: Take good care of us and we\u2019ll take care of you. Other medics confirmed that if I survived six months of gore I might be rotated to a field hospital at a big base \u2014 showers, three hot meals a day, passes to town, tiki bars at China Beach.\n\nUntil then, though, I would be in one of the hottest war zones, supporting troops on search-and-destroy missions, as well as supply convoys along the lethal north-south Colonial Route 1. Long before us, the French military had named it the \u201cStreet Without Joy.\u201d With reason.\n\nIn Chu Lai, a Marine air base on that road that served as our home, I joined three field medics: Wayne Freeman, Eddie Dickson and Simon Britts. We essentially lived inside a medical armored personnel carrier, roaming embattled central Vietnam behind mechanized infantry units, tending and evacuating their wounded and dead.\n\nThe first five weeks were easy, spent guarding the perimeters of hilltop firebases and base camps. It was safe, except for frequent artillery barrages. There were even opportunities to go into villages to offer citizens simple health care, an activity the brass thought might help win hearts and minds. Occasionally we went on long, platoon-size tank patrols in search of guerrilla units hiding in remote villages or secret camps within the jungles of the Annamite Cordillera foothills. We didn\u2019t find many, but it gave us a feel of the land, its odors, sounds and perils.\n\nThe rice paddies reeked of stagnant water, the jungles of humus and raw vegetation. Every now and then a sniper targeted us, or a forward infantry unit fell into a small-arms ambush; we\u2019d patch light wounds from bullets or booby traps. Even so, the jungle\u2019s stillness and the absence of heavy battle lulled us into thinking the war wasn\u2019t as bad as advertised.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut it was. As summer passed, the small guerrilla skirmishes were winding down, but well-trained regular combat veterans of the North Vietnamese Army were secretly infiltrating the central coastlands, preparing for the coming Tet offensive.\n\nBy autumn, heavy fighting was breaking out in Chu Lai and Tam Ky, two key coastal centers of the war. In the First Armored Division, now part of the 23rd Infantry Division, commonly known as the Americal Division, combat medics were called into action every day because the fighting was now constant and bloody, with the enemy firing heavy mortars, rocket grenades and powerful machine guns. When the foot soldiers left their vehicles to fight, we would wait just outside the battle in our personnel carrier until called to scramble in ourselves, under fire, treat the wounded where they\u2019d fallen, then get them the hell out of there.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOur job now was to tend multiple gunshot wounds, apply tourniquets to the stumps of legs amputated by mines, and bandage shrapnel-mutilated bodies. Mortars fell near our armored personnel carrier. Bullets zinged around us and ricocheted from helicopter fuselages as we loaded the wounded into them. Death became a daily reality, as we zipped our fallen comrades into body bags.\n\nOn two occasions, two of our medics were wounded by shrapnel as we drove close to the big firefights. By October, we had to park so deep in the combat zones that more medics would inevitably become casualties too.\n\nBefore the fighting got really hot, aspects of being a field medic had felt strangely magical. We were our own bosses. We slept in our vehicle on bloodstained stretchers among boxes of medicine and munitions. We listened to rock music on the way to small battles. No haircuts or polished boots. Shave or don\u2019t shave. Bathe in rivers. Just take meticulous care of the grunts.\n\nThey would come to us for a Darvon pain pill or foot rot powder, or simply to share a cigarette or a warm beer with the \u201cdocs.\u201d We gave lidocaine for itching groins, tetanus shots, and emulsions for head lice and crabs. We scolded them for not taking their anti-malaria pills. We reprimanded them for bad hygiene, too much pot smoking, or carelessness at a village brothel. We were their \u201cmale moms.\u201d\n\nThe camaraderie beguiled me, especially as a Hispanic man. Many of the soldiers were from the Deep South and couldn\u2019t understand why a guy from a Caribbean paradise would volunteer for the Army. They laughed at my accented English, but they warmed to the rum I carried in my duffel bag. They gave bro-hugs when I treated them. Sometimes they faked a malady. When we declared them fit for battle, they bore silent grudges \u2014 until the next firefight.\n\nRank mattered little. During and after combat, the officers, sergeants and privates consulted and consoled one another. Of course, with the intimacy came broken rules \u2014 as when an infantry sergeant ordered me into a tunnel hole to see if a guerrilla was lurking. I protested that I was a medic, but he insisted. Luckily, the lair was empty.\n\nAnother time, a green lieutenant saw us giving plasma to a wounded Vietcong suspect. He ordered me not to \u201cwaste\u201d medical supplies on the enemy. But at Fort Sam Houston I had been taught that in combat, a medic could override an officer in any lifesaving situation. I paid no heed to his order. The court-martial he threatened me with never materialized.\n\nWhen I enlisted, I was no peacenik. But what I experienced during those first five months washed away any ignorance about the degradations of war.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI cannot forget the many times we would arrive in a village with tanks, shows of force and Zippo lighters with which to torch humble peasants\u2019 homes. I can still see a sad old farmer, kneeling and crying in his trampled rice field, broken seedlings in his hands.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Vietnam \u201967 Newsletter This weekly newsletter includes eyewitness accounts, rare photos and historical insights about the Vietnam War. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nI remember a monsoon rain during which we had only two litters with which to carry the bodies of a half-dozen of our dead buddies to the nearest chopper landing zone. With time short, we resorted to dragging bodies unceremoniously through the thickening mud \u2014 a scene of horror that disturbs me even now. These had been my brothers in combat. What would their kin have felt, watching this?\n\nI never did get to enjoy the pleasures at the bases in Danang, Nha Trang, Cam Ranh Bay or even Saigon.\n\nAbout five months after arriving \u2014 just weeks from the anticipated end of regular combat danger for me \u2014 we were accompanying a sweep against North Vietnamese troops in a thin 43-mile-long strip of land we called Cigar Island, just north of Chu Lai. As fighting grew intense at a remote fishing village called Binh Thinh, a rocket grenade slammed into our waiting armored personnel carrier, splintering its side into shrapnel that tore apart my right leg. All four of us medics were wounded, leaving the entire troop without their \u201cdocs.\u201d Some 25 infantrymen and tankers died that day.\n\nSo that was how I would leave combat duty: in an evac helicopter, stoned out on morphine, bleeding half to death with a shattered leg wrapped in bloodied bandages. My fellow medic Simon Britts had applied them during the battle, even though he was wounded himself and we were still under fire. He was put in for a Silver Star for bravery, but never received it. The paperwork was lost.\n\nLater, as I lay on a gurney in a trauma surgery room, my pistol fell from my pocket to the floor. It shocked the surgeon and nurses, and caught a chaplain\u2019s attention. He came over and prayed with a hand on my head, and I assumed this was last rites. Then he said: \u201cYou\u2019ll be O.K., son. You\u2019re in good hands now.\u201d I could only hope he was referring to my surgeons, not the Almighty.\n\nOne operating room after another followed until I reached Walter Reed Medical Center, for a year of rehabilitation. I was there in 1968 when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated and riots broke out in Washington. Soldiers were told to stay on the hospital grounds, because Vietnam vets were not much appreciated by Americans who had turned against the war.\n\nThe war had taught me to despise all firearms. After basic training, the only time I ever pointed and fired one was on a trip back to Vietnam in 2004 to help make a documentary film about a veteran \u2014 me \u2014 returning to the war theater. At a shooting gallery for tourists, I fired an AK-47 into a dirt wall.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat journey awoke memories. The film crew rambled in a van from Hanoi south to the Mekong Delta, stopping where I had soldiered. The Vietnamese were friendly and forgiving. The bus driver, a former North Vietnamese artillery colonel, said: \u201cNo one won or lost the American war. We all simply did what was required of us at the time.\u201d\n\nAnd then we reached Binh Thinh. I began narrating the attack in which I was wounded. Suddenly, I began salivating and my mind shut down. I sat on the sand and cried. In a flashback, I conjured the dead and the wounded of that savage day.\n\nUnexpected flashbacks still haunt me. In a restaurant I can go into stress if I smell a rare steak oozing blood. In a movie theater, I can suddenly imagine the stench of gunpowder and cordite in the air.\n\nFifteen Army medics received the Medal of Honor during the Vietnam War, most posthumously. According to the website 1st Cav Medic, the Vietnam Veterans Memorial wall lists 2,096 Army medics and Navy corpsmen, our naval and Marine equivalent, who died or were missing in action. Thousands of others like myself were wounded, all in a war I now consider pointless.\n\nA war that remains with me.", "title": "What a Combat Medic Still Carries", "authors": ["Rafael Matos"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Late last year, Tom Nichols, a professor at the Naval War College and a NeverTrump conservative, proposed a little thought experiment for Republicans skeptical of Robert Mueller\u2019s investigation of the Trump campaign\u2019s Russia ties.\n\n\u201cLet\u2019s play Alternate Universe,\u201d he wrote on Twitter. \u201cIt\u2019s 2017, and President Hillary Clinton is facing charges that Chelsea met with Russians who offered oppo on Trump. Chelsea didn\u2019t call the FBI; and Clinton nat sec adviser Jake Sullivan lied to the FBI about talking to the Russians.\u201d\n\nNichols laid out the unfolding drama over a series of tweets. President Clinton fires the F.B.I. director after he declines her request to \u201clet it go\u201d on Sullivan. \u201cThen, at least three other Clinton campaign officials end up indicted. All of them are tied in some way to a hostile foreign power.\u201d Later, she threatens to \u201cyank FOX\u2019s license\u201d because she didn\u2019t like its critical coverage.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m sure \u2026 totally sure \u2026\u201d Nichols added with no little irony, \u201cthat stalwarts of the G.O.P. would say: Look, this is a nothingburger, you can\u2019t define \u2018collusion,\u2019 it\u2019s just \u2018the coffee boy,\u2019 and on and on.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | What if Clinton Had Done All This?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "The White House ousted a top aide, Rob Porter, after it was reported that he had physically and verbally abused two ex-wives. President Trump was \u201cvery saddened\u201d by the reports, a spokesman, Raj Shah, said at Thursday\u2019s news briefing. Mr. Shah added that the White House does \u201ctake violence against women and these types of allegations very seriously.\u201d\n\nThose are the sorts of sentiments you\u2019d want to hear from the president and his staff after such revelations. Of course, it\u2019d be easier to take them at face value if his chief of staff, John Kelly, hadn\u2019t reportedly known about the allegations against Mr. Porter since the fall, and if Mr. Trump\u2019s first wife hadn\u2019t accused him of rape and if more than a dozen women hadn\u2019t said he sexually molested, assaulted and harassed them. That\u2019s not to mention his own taped admission of grabbing women by the genitals.\n\nIt would be even easier to take seriously the official White House line about Mr. Porter if officials there had shown any appetite to fight violence against women. If they become interested in doing more than talk, here are some ideas:\n\nName a White House adviser on violence against women, a position created during the Obama administration that has gone unfilled for the past year. Likewise, the Trump administration has not appointed anyone to head the Department of Justice\u2019s Office of Violence Against Women, nor to be the State Department\u2019s ambassador at large for global women\u2019s issues.\n\nAdvocate full funding of the Violence Against Women Act, which is the principal tool for focusing federal attention on domestic abuse. The law, passed in 1994, has directed billions of dollars toward policing and prosecuting offenders as well as providing legal and other services to victims. Cases of domestic violence in the United States have dropped precipitously as a result. And yet, since Mr. Trump was elected, its proponents have lived in constant fear of funding cuts. Beyond declaring it a funding priority, the Justice Department should be directed to make enforcing the law a priority, too.", "title": "Opinion | What if Donald Trump Really Cared About Women\u2019s Safety?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "SPECIAL POST \u2014 One of the entries that solvers had the most trouble with last week was the acronym CAPTCHA.\n\nA CAPTCHA is a program used to verify that a human, rather than a computer, is entering data. It stands for \u201cCompletely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart,\u201d and they are commonly seen at the end of online forms to help thwart spam and automated extraction of data from websites. The term was coined in 2000 by Luis von Ahn, Manuel Blum, Nicholas J. Hopper, and John Langford of Carnegie Mellon University.\n\nText CAPTCHAs ask the user to enter text from a distorted image.", "title": "What the Heck Is That?: CAPTCHA", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "SPECIAL POST \u2014 There are many ways to fool a crossword puzzle solver, but solving difficulties really break down into two categories: Not understanding what a clue is asking of you, and not knowing a bit of general knowledge that might be required.\n\nWe talk about tricky clues and how to decipher them every day on Wordplay, but one thing that doesn\u2019t get covered enough is general knowledge, primarily because there is so much to know.\n\nIn \u201cWhat the Heck Is That?\u201d we break out a single entry from the past week of puzzles that many solvers had trouble with because the entry might have been unfamiliar to them.\n\nWe\u2019ll define the entry for you and show you examples of how you might see it clued, so you will be better equipped to solve it the next time it comes up. It\u2019s both O.K. and expected that you won\u2019t know everything, but some of these entries are going to come up in your puzzles again, so it\u2019s worth learning them.", "title": "What the Heck Is That?: NEMEAN", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "SPECIAL POST \u2014 There are many ways to fool a crossword puzzle solver, but solving difficulties really break down into two categories: Not understanding what a clue is asking of you, and not knowing a bit of general knowledge that might be required.\n\nWe talk about tricky clues and how to decipher them every day on Wordplay, but one thing that doesn\u2019t get covered enough is general knowledge, primarily because there is so much to know.\n\nWelcome to a new series called \u201cWhat the Heck is That?\u201d where we will break out a single entry from the past week of puzzles that many solvers had trouble with because the entry might have been unfamiliar to them.\n\nWe\u2019ll define the entry for you and show you examples of how you might see it clued, so you will be better equipped to solve it the next time it comes up. It\u2019s both O.K. and expected that you won\u2019t know everything, but some of these entries are going to come up in your puzzles again, so it\u2019s worth learning them.", "title": "What the Heck is That?: DE NOVO", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Even with the appointment of four new directors by the year\u2019s end, the Federal Reserve stopped short of ordering any to step down immediately, nor was anyone in senior management identified as acting improperly.\n\nThe central bank sent letters to the former chief executive John G. Stumpf and to the former chairman Stephen W. Sanger, criticizing their performance as \u201can example of ineffective oversight that is not consistent with the Federal Reserve\u2019s expectations\u201d for a bank of its size and scope.\n\nWells Fargo\u2019s attitude seems to be that the order is more of a legacy cost for past misconduct than a censure of its current operations. In a statement issued by the bank, its chief executive, Timothy J. Sloan, said: \u201cIt is important to note that the consent order is not related to any new matters, but to prior issues where we have already made significant progress.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nEven the limitations on growth don\u2019t seem to be too much of a stumbling block. Mr. Sloan said on a conference call with analysts that \u201cwe want to have this cap lifted as soon as possible, and we\u2019re going to work very hard to make sure that\u2019s the case.\u201d In other words, nothing for investors to fret too much about.\n\nUnlike banks, most corporations have little fear that a civil regulator might take actions that cost executives or directors their jobs. The Securities and Exchange Commission can seek to bar a person from serving as an officer or a director of a public company, but that requires proving the person engaged in fraud, not just mismanagement of the company.\n\nAn individual who has a controlling interest in a company that is convicted of violating federal health care fraud laws can be excluded from participating in the Medicare and Medicaid programs, effectively requiring that the person be removed from his or her position. But this provision has not been used against corporate executives who did not have any direct involvement in the criminal violations.\n\nWells Fargo was widely admired for how it navigated the financial crisis, coming out of it stronger than most of its competitors even after acquiring a failing bank, Wachovia, at the government\u2019s behest in October 2008. Now a corporate culture that emphasized cross-selling products over protecting customers has made it something of a pariah, subject \u2014 at least for the moment \u2014 to more exacting oversight by the regulators.\n\nIts competitors are unlikely to view what the Federal Reserve did as having much deterrent effect except perhaps in the short term. Other large banks will no doubt pat themselves on the back for not engaging in the types of customer abuses that put Wells Fargo in its current position. When you don\u2019t think you\u2019ve done anything wrong, and you believe it was just the other guy who got caught, then any penalty is unlikely to have much of an impact on your future actions.\n\nRather than viewing what happened to Wells Fargo as an instance of \u201cthere but for the grace of God go I,\u201d directors and executives at other banks will more likely see it as a case of an aggressive company that crossed the line too many times. For those looking at this as a harbinger of a federal crackdown on corporate misconduct, this is more likely to be a one-off situation, with little prospect of its happening again in the current deregulatory environment.", "title": "What the Wells Fargo Crackdown Signals to Corporate America", "authors": ["Peter J. Henning", "White Collar Watch"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "The White House knew about problems with the staff secretary Rob Porter\u2019s security clearance nearly a year before he was forced to resign, F.B.I. director Christopher Wray said this week. We know now that the hold up on his clearance was tied to allegations of domestic abuse \u2014 and the Trump White House seems to have known that by last November, too.\n\nThis contradicts Trump aides\u2019 reassurances that they were as shocked as anyone to read about Porter\u2019s alleged misogynist violence in The Daily Mail last week. (I fail to see how the notion that the executive branch gets its intelligence from The Daily Mail could possibly be reassuring to any sentient creature crawling this planet\u2019s sizzling crust, but many things are beyond me these days.)\n\nWray testified that the F.B.I. sent the White House a partial report about the \u201cproblems\u201d with Porter in March 2017, following that with a full background check in July, and a further update in November. The investigation was \u201cadministratively closed\u201d in January, several weeks before Donald Trump presumably \u2014 according to the White House\u2019s initial timeline \u2014 heard about the allegations against his buddy.\n\nTrue to form for the Trump White House, even doing nothing was an unachievably high bar. Not only was Porter allowed to remain in his position (and briefly defended by the administration after the allegations finally became public), at the time of his termination he was reportedly being considered for multiple promotions: speechwriting, an expanded policy portfolio, a crack at deputy chief of staff. CNN reported that chief of staff John Kelly, aware of the allegations for months, \u201ctold associates that Porter was one of the few competent professionals on his staff and wanted to ensure that he was being used to his full potential.\u201d One wonders if Kelly saw the photographs of Porter\u2019s ex-wife\u2019s face, the gold and the purple nimbus around her eye, the angry swell, the throb of it.", "title": "Opinion | What the White House Knew About Rob Porter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning. I used to feel guilty about how, some time at the top or middle of most weeks, I\u2019d have a loaf of fancy artisanal bread going stale on the counter, left over from a run to this cool bakery or that one on Saturday mornings. Maybe it happens to you, too, sometimes? How often can you make bread crumbs before you\u2019re taking them to work like extra zucchini in August?\n\nComes now a fantastic recipe for French onion panade (above) from Samin Nosrat, along with a terrific column in The Times all about making it, to remove all shame from your purchase and failure to use. Indeed, Samin writes, you may find yourself buying good bread with the express purpose of letting it go stale just so you can make this meal: a kind of French onion soup that\u2019s more onion and bread and cheese than soup, though there\u2019s an enormous amount of stock in it, to rehydrate the stale slices that form its base.\n\nHere\u2019s hoping you can make that dish this week. But not only that dish!\n\nCheck out Melissa Clark\u2019s new recipe for a chicken sheet-pan dinner with sweet potatoes, peppers and sage. Melissa doesn\u2019t mess around: thin slices of quick-pickled red onion provide a zip at the end, above the dense deliciousness. It\u2019s extra good because the grocery store I drive out to on the weekends just got another shipment of those giant, lumpy, beautiful mandarin oranges called dekopon, or shiranuhi, and they\u2019re sweet and juicy and seedless and $1.99 apiece. I can\u2019t get enough of them, and I bought some extra to peel for dessert tomorrow after Nigella Lawson\u2019s penne alla vodka, which seems like a superlative way to take the edge off a Monday night.\n\nTuesday, it has to be hot white rice with Meera Sodha\u2019s beautiful Sri Lankan-style dal topped with coconut kale (above). As Meera says, \u201cred lentils are the king of weekday cooking,\u201d and she\u2019s right. Or see how you can make Alison Roman\u2019s shortcut for chicken tikka masala, marinating the chicken thighs in spiced yogurt and then broiling them to get a touch of char.\n\nAre you starting to miss Sam? It\u2019s O.K., I get it. On Wednesday, you could plan to make his dead simple pan-roasted salmon with jalape\u00f1os. Note: The last time I made this, I carelessly threw in a few whole garlic cloves, still in their skins. It\u2019s not part of the recipe, but it worked out! They got kind of squishy and caramelized without burning, and it was delicious. Garlic or not, it\u2019ll go great with a side of tiny boiled potatoes, covered in melted butter and herbs.\n\nThursday is soup night. But here it is midwinter at the end of the week and everyone\u2019s tearing into their drums as if inked by Hanna-Barbera, their white rice stained beautiful with sauce, and suddenly we\u2019re smiling, water calm, all of us through the storm.\n\nOf course maybe you don\u2019t like turkey drumsticks. There are thousands of other recipes to consider making this week on NYT Cooking. Go browse around over there and see what you like. Save the recipes you like to your recipe box, and organize them however you like. Then cook them! And share them and rate them and leave notes on them, for yourself or others, to let people know about what changes you\u2019ve made in preparation or ingredients, for good or for ill.\n\nAnd if anything goes wrong along the way, if you run into trouble with a particular recipe or with the technology we use to power the site and apps, reach out for help. Know this: If you make chicken and sausage gumbo on Monday after the pizza, it\u2019ll cure up delicious for dinner the next night.\n\nAnd with the time you save Tuesday night not cooking gumbo? After dinner (or in the morning) you can make this awesome make-ahead recipe for coquilles St.-Jacques to serve Wednesday night, with red roses on the table beside the creamy, golden scallops fresh from the broiler. It\u2019s amazing, romantic and fiercely delicious: a recipe Ina Garten has been making since the start of her marriage to Jeffrey Garten in 1968.\n\nI\u2019d understand, of course, if you can\u2019t do that, can\u2019t plan out a week where you\u2019re always eating the food you made last night before cooking the food for tomorrow. So here are recipes to make when Valentine\u2019s Day is on a weeknight, if you\u2019ve got to move fast and in the moment.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. See you tomorrow.", "title": "What to Cook This Week", "authors": ["Sam Sifton", "What To Cook", "Melissa Clark", "Marian Burros", "Julia Moskin", "David Tanis"]} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning. I was talking to the international pizza consultant Anthony Falco the other day. Seriously, that is his job: international pizza consultant. He travels around the world in sweatpants and a ball cap, with some spare dishwasher shirts and sourdough starter in his bag, helps people open pizzerias, or helps them make already-open pizzerias better pizzerias. It\u2019s a cool gig.\n\nWe talked about that for a while on stage at The New York Times Travel Show last weekend, and while we were at it, he gave me a new tip for making pizza at home (above). I think it might up your crust game about 20 percent.\n\nJust add a second pizza stone, or steel, or set of quarry tiles to the rack above the one where you\u2019ve already got a pizza stone, or steel, or set of quarry tiles. Putting a roof above the deck on which you cook the pie, Falco said, helps create a kind of oven within your oven, with the surfaces both above and below the pizza holding and radiating heat. This helps cook the top of the pizza considerably.\n\nHave you been having problems getting those beautiful burnt leopard spots on the crust of your pies? Here is the start of a solution, and on the cheap: Quarry tile runs around $3 a square foot at the Home Depot.", "title": "What to Cook This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGood morning. I\u2019m still messing around with this recipe for risotto with sausage and parsley (above). Julien Shapiro, who runs the butcher and charcuterie shop at 8 Hands Farm in Cutchogue, N.Y., got on me the other day about how I call for saut\u00e9ing the onions before I toast the rice, and about how much stirring I do afterward, while adding the stock.\n\nJulien used to make risotto like that, he said, until the chef he was working for called him into the walk-in to tell him to stop. He paused then and looked at the ground and I realized he was telling me to stop, too. \u201cYou don\u2019t want any moisture in the pot when you start,\u201d he said. \u201cJust toast the rice in the oil until it looks like mother-of-pearl, then hit it with the onions, wine and stock. Bare simmer, covered, 10 minutes.\u201d Julien makes the best sausages in Suffolk County, and he displays a quiet authority when he talks. I did what I was told.\n\nAnd, man, that is a good way to cook risotto. You may need a little bit more hot stock at the end of the process, before you add butter and cheese to finish the dish. (Maybe a few handfuls of baby greens as well.) But you\u2019ll cut down on your time at the stove by a considerable amount, with no diminishing of flavor.\n\nSo maybe cook risotto this weekend. Me, I\u2019d also like to take on this recipe for a venison and trotter pie, which Tejal Rao coaxed out of Angie Mar at the Beatrice Inn in New York. I think it would be pretty lip-smacky for a midwinter feast, super unctuous, really strong.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat\u2019s for Sunday, though, I think: a formal meal to round out the week. Today is the Lunar New Year, and I\u2019d like to welcome it this evening with a steamed whole fish with ginger and sesame, maybe some pork and shrimp won tons and definitely noodles for miles.", "title": "What to Cook This Weekend", "authors": ["Sam Sifton", "David Tanis", "Dorie Greenspan", "Alison Roman"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nGood morning. I had this crazily delicious packet of fish a while back at the restaurant Houseman here in Manhattan \u2014 baked bluefish, wrapped in Swiss chard. I know. I didn\u2019t think it would be crazily delicious, either. But it was and I was amazed and eventually I interrogated the restaurant\u2019s chef, Ned Baldwin, about how he\u2019d made it.\n\n\u201cDulse butter\u201d was his answer \u2014 he cut a few tablespoons of ground dried sea lettuce into the fat and then patted onto the fish before he wrapped it and put it into the oven to roast. The dulse acts as a kind of flavor enhancer, a natural version of monosodium glutamate. I started to cook with it all the time.\n\nThat, anyway, is the subject of my \u201cEat\u201d column in The Times this week, which serves as introduction to my new recipe for seafood chowder (above). I think it might bring a lot of joy into your eating this weekend, whatever species you put into it above its base of root-cellar vegetables, clams and, of course, a lot of butter and dulse.\n\nSo make that tomorrow, why don\u2019t you? Then eat it for dinner that night or the next. (As with most chowders, its flavor improves after an overnight rest in the fridge.) And on whichever night that you\u2019re not slurping, make Melissa Clark\u2019s recipe for tarragon chicken thighs with sherry vinegar and onions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat recipe will shake out as a midweek slayer for you, I think, alongside potatoes, either mashed or roasted. But pausing on a weekend to make a recipe for the first time, working slowly and deliberately through the steps, will help when you have to knock it out fast on a weeknight evening because you\u2019re getting home late after picking the car up from the shop that gave it an inspection because you forgot that last year\u2019s expired at the end of last month and the precinct cops got wise to your parking on the left-hand side of the street where they could only see the 2017 sticker if they were on foot patrol and \u2026 maybe that\u2019s just me?", "title": "What to Cook This Weekend", "authors": ["Sam Sifton", "Julia Moskin"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "The old oven in my apartment in Brooklyn was tiny and hideous and stubbornly sloping to one side \u2014 this is Tejal Rao by the way, filling in for Sam. But it worked just fine until about six weeks ago. While I waited for my landlord to send a guy, I made do with an electric pressure cooker. I cooked all kinds of beans (so. many. beans.); I braised fennel hearts and simmered a big batch of Andrea Nguyen\u2019s fantastic pho broth.\n\nBut not being able to bake for six weeks has put me in such a mood to bake! Now, the oven\u2019s been replaced, and I\u2019ve got the most delicious to-do list for the weekend. Right at the top: Samin Nosrat\u2019s soufflazy (above), a glorious, golden, cheesy puff of beaten eggs, herbs and goat cheese that she adapted from her friend Amalia Mari\u00f1o.\n\nIt\u2019s all in the name, a souffl\u00e9 for the lazy: Beat egg yolks with cheese over a simmering water bath, then mix in warm, whipped egg whites and bake it for breakfast, lunch or dinner. That\u2019s pretty much it. (If you\u2019re feeling a bit drunk with confidence after the soufflazy, and you want to make a more classic, time-consuming souffl\u00e9, Melissa Clark has got you.) What else? Of course, I want to try those famous shortbread cookies, you know the ones, with the chocolate chips and the brown sugar and the flaky salt by Alison Roman. And I\u2019ve been thinking a lot about Laurie Colwin\u2019s gingerbread, because, excuse me, gingerbread isn\u2019t just a December thing and I can eat it whenever I want. I\u2019ll put it on the table with a bowl of cr\u00e8me fra\u00eeche on Sunday, for those friends who text when they\u2019re in the neighborhood and drop by.\n\nSpeaking of cakes. Before I joined the Times, I\u2019d never made the Marian Burros plum torte, and it felt like some kind of dark secret that I was carrying around. Last fall, I finally went for it, and now I make it all the time, even in the winter, when you can replace the fresh fruit with poached. My favorite version so far was filled with whole seckel pears cooked in saffron-cardamom syrup. I replaced half the flour with almond meal, took the sugar down by a third of a cup and didn\u2019t regret a thing.", "title": "What to Cook This Weekend", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "And there is, in our view, plenty else to cook this weekend besides those recipes! Or both.\n\nI\u2019d like a luncheon of fried eggplant sandwiches. Saturday or Sunday, you choose. Or maybe instead: quickly made, not-at-all-difficult, fun-to-cook-with-children pot-stickers, either with the soy-and-vinegar sauce we call for in the recipe, or drenched in a heated mixture of soy, peanut butter and a lot of chile-scallion oil. Craig Claiborne\u2019s recipe for beef stroganoff (above) is on the menu for dinner tonight. It is a delicious meal when served over buttered noodles with parsley and maybe especially so if you make like some of your fellow Cooking subscribers and add a smidgen of smoked paprika to the sour cream that coats the meat.\n\nFor dessert, pick up some ice cream, apples and butter and make this no-recipe recipe for dessert: saut\u00e9ed apple slices in a lot of butter. Don\u2019t go too far. Don\u2019t let them collapse. Just let them start to soften and get hot in the pan, then hit them with some cinnamon, maybe, or a flash of bourbon, and serve with a scoop of ice cream. That\u2019s living large, on a Wednesday night in America. Soundtrack: Broken Social Scene, \u201cHalfway Home.\u201d\n\nHeading in a very different direction indeed, you might try this Florence Fabricant recipe for baked fish with potatoes, peppers and olives, which she picked up, in classic Fabricant style, from the kitchen of the hotel La Mamounia in Marrakesh. I like that with white rice. But you may prefer couscous.\n\nTaking yet another tack, this time toward a meatless meal, you could cook Melissa Clark\u2019s recipe for a shredded tofu and shiitake stir-fry. I like that with white rice as well. You could absolutely make it with brown.", "title": "What to Cook Tonight", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Kyle Glanville should have been thrilled. All 70 of the outdoor seats at Go Get Em Tiger were taken, only three days after he and his partner opened the cafe in the Los Feliz neighborhood of Los Angeles.\n\nHe was not. \u201cEverybody was at a laptop wearing headphones,\u201d Mr. Glanville said. He strode inside, unplugged the device that provided free Wi-Fi and tossed it into a bin in his office.\n\nHe wanted a courtyard where people talked to one another, not a silent office for remote workers. And while anyone with a cellphone hot spot could connect without his help, he had made himself clear. On a recent weekday morning, almost a year and a half later, the courtyard was still full of people, but this time they were talking to one another. Only one was at his laptop.\n\nRemote workers have staked out coffee shops for years, but small-business owners say their ranks are rising. In 2016, 43 percent of American employees spent some time working remotely, according to a Gallup survey; the number who telecommute at least half the time has grown by 115 percent since 2005, said a report last year from FlexJobs and Global Workplace Analytics. Add in the self-employed, and the crowd gets even bigger. And while some still embrace the home-and-pajama model, a large contingent hits the corner cafe.", "title": "What to Do When Laptops and Silence Take Over Your Cafe?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "You can also hide under your desk if there is no alternative. It\u2019s not the best choice, but removing yourself from the line of sight and gunfire is better than nothing.\n\nPlaying dead is generally not a good idea, Dr. Blair said. Gunmen have been known to circle back and fire into wounded people or others on the ground, he said.\n\nBut in the 2012 Sandy Hook shooting, a teacher remained motionless after being shot in the leg and then escaped after the gunman had moved on. A student at Virginia Tech was shot while fleeing but kept going and survived.\n\n\u201cKeep operating if shot,\u201d Dr. Blair said. \u201cTry to get yourself out.\u201d\n\nWhat should I do after hiding?\n\nDon\u2019t stop to grab belongings, not even your cellphone. But if you do have one, once you are hidden, call 911, identify yourself and explain briefly what is happening and where. Then silence the phone or stop speaking but leave it on so the dispatcher can hear.\n\nTurn off lights. Do not talk with others in the room if the gunman is nearby.\n\n\u201cStay quiet as a mouse,\u201d Dr. Dietz said.\n\nSocial media use might give away your location or help the attacker know where the police are, Dr. Blair warned.\n\nStay low in your hiding place, because a gunman is likely to open fire at torso or head-level, Dr. Dietz said.\n\nIf a barricade or lock is not available, Dr. Blair suggests not lying on the floor, because that would prevent you from the last resort: a surprise attack on the gunman if he bursts into the room.", "title": "What to Do When There\u2019s an Active Shooter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDear Sugars,\n\nMy mom and her new fianc\u00e9 have been together three years. On paper, he\u2019s a great match for her. But he\u2019s revealed himself as jealous and controlling. I once told my mom about a restaurant I visited, for example. When she replied that her college boyfriend owned the restaurant, her fianc\u00e9 threw a temper tantrum.\n\nHe\u2019s also inexplicably jealous of my dad. He can\u2019t be in the same room as my dad, and I\u2019ve overheard him insulting my dad to my mom. When my parents drove my brother to college together, my mom lied so her fianc\u00e9 wouldn\u2019t get upset, even though she\u2019s made clear she\u2019ll never reconcile with my dad. This irrational jealousy makes family events extremely uncomfortable for me and my siblings. What\u2019s more, he often says disparaging things about his ex-wife, including rude comments about her drug addiction.\n\nMy siblings and I have all expressed our concerns to my mom many times. When we found out he was going to propose, I begged her to say no. She didn\u2019t. She says he makes her happy. I know I need to accept that, but I\u2019m struggling.\n\nI could not have asked for a better mother growing up. She\u2019s sacrificed so much for us. I feel terrible that I can\u2019t just be happy for her. But it\u2019s almost physically painful to be around them. How can I make peace with her choice and rebuild our strained relationship into a strong one? What can I do to accept this man who will soon be my stepfather?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Of the Moment The lifestyle newsletter from the Styles, Travel and Food sections, offering the latest trends to news you can use. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSad Soon-to-Be-Stepdaughter\n\nSteve Almond: The optimist in me hopes that your mom\u2019s fianc\u00e9 is expressing situational insecurity, and that once he\u2019s married to your mom (i.e. feels more secure) he\u2019ll be less of a jerk. But the realist in me suspects this problem is one of his character traits. Unfortunately, this kind of dynamic can become a vicious cycle. As this guy\u2019s behavior further alienates you and your siblings, he\u2019ll sense your rising disapproval and react by becoming increasingly possessive, further driving a wedge between you and your mother. That\u2019s the underlying risk here, the scenario you want to avoid: a kind of loyalty showdown. I\u2019d do what you can to ease the tension, especially as the wedding approaches. You don\u2019t have to pretend to like this man, or approve of his conduct. But it might help to remind yourself that this man makes your mother happy, by her own account. What\u2019s most important in all of this is that you establish a relationship with your mother that\u2019s independent of your feelings toward her partner. This begins by letting her know that you love and support her unconditionally.\n\nDear Sugars Listen to \u2018Dear Sugars\u2019 What makes a mother? The Sugars advise. Audio\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCheryl Strayed: My heart sinks every time I read your letter, Sad. Your situation is awful and, unfortunately, common. Everyone who loves someone who\u2019s in an unhealthy romantic relationship shares your conundrum. I\u2019ve been there myself a few times. That your mother reports her fianc\u00e9 makes her \u201chappy\u201d does not obliterate the fact that he behaves horribly, and perhaps abusively, toward her. You and your siblings have done the right thing in being honest with your mother about your observations and feelings about her fianc\u00e9. Your intervention in advance of her engagement didn\u2019t yield the results you\u2019d hoped for, but that doesn\u2019t mean it was a wasted effort. If your mother ever questions her relationship, she\u2019ll remember your words. That she can\u2019t see now what you see doesn\u2019t mean she won\u2019t.", "title": "What to Do When You Don\u2019t Like Your Stepfather-to-Be", "authors": ["Cheryl Strayed", "Steve Almond", "The Sweet Spot"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Make the best pizza\n\nIf cooking is your way to spend a day of leisure, you can\u2019t go wrong with our best recipe for pizza dough, which has more than 2,500 five-star ratings. Read more \u00bb\n\nBack up your photos\n\nYeah, yeah, you\u2019ll get to it sometime \u2014 it\u2019s the little fib we all tell ourselves to get out of doing the often tedious work of backing up our digital data. But don\u2019t keep putting it off! Here\u2019s a sad tale: Three years ago my computer stopped working one night and it hasn\u2019t turned on since. The photos stuck in limbo on that hard drive, if they\u2019re even salvageable, will cost me an estimated $800 to retrieve. Don\u2019t make my mistake, and go back up your photos. (And while you\u2019re at it, re-evaluate your storage practices in general.) How are you coming along? Did you pick a new goal, or double down on the one you made on Jan. 1? I\u2019ve been doing well with my sub-goals \u2014 1. Run three days per week, and 2. Cross-train at least one day per week \u2014 and I\u2019m making some strong progress. I have a long way to go, but I\u2019m feeling confident.\n\nIf you\u2019re still struggling to stay motivated, or you\u2019ve fallen short this month, brush it off and keep going. Any amount of progress is better than none.", "title": "What to Do With a Day Off", "authors": ["Tim Herrera"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 For Lent, many Christians give up indulgences like tobacco, alcohol or sweets, or transgressions like lying and swearing. And for Anglicans, don\u2019t forget synthetic fabrics, wet wipes, and those little boxes that hold dental floss.\n\nThe Church of England has asked people to add a new culprit to the list of ills they forsake for the six weeks of penance that begin on Ash Wednesday: plastics. Specifically, the church wants people to avoid the plastic consumer products and packaging that have become a major environmental problem, polluting oceans and rivers, fouling beaches, killing wildlife and clogging landfills.\n\n\u201cI think it might well be a first for us, to have an entire Lent program on an environmental issue, but it is very much an integral part of what the church is about,\u201d said Ruth Knight, the Church of England\u2019s environmental policy officer. In fact, environmental stewardship \u201cto safeguard the integrity of creation\u201d is one of the five \u201cmarks of mission\u201d the church lists in describing its purpose.\n\nThe church\u2019s \u201cLent Plastic Challenge\u201d arrives on a wave of anti-plastic sentiment and legislation in Britain and across Europe, as more people conclude that the first element of the motto \u201creduce, reuse, recycle\u201d should take precedence. In December, the European Union announced binding waste-reduction targets for member nations, with particular emphasis on plastics.", "title": "What to Give Up for Lent? Smoking? Cursing? How About Plastic?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "The long-anticipated \u201cBlack Panther\u201d film debuted in theaters on Feb. 17, and the response from critics and fans has been overwhelmingly positive. The movie earned $387 million in its opening weekend, which makes it the highest-grossing film of all time by a black director. If you want to dive deeper into the world of black comics, here are three books to start you off.\n\nImage\n\nBLACK COMICS\n\nPolitics of Race and Representation\n\nEdited by Sheena C. Howard\n\n288 pp. Bloomsbury Academic. (2013)\n\nHoward, who wrote \u201cEncyclopedia of Black Comics,\u201d presents a collection of analytical essays that explore the historical and vast contributions of black artists to the graphic book genre, including comic strips, political cartoons, manga and graphic novels. One essay, \u201cBrief History of the Black Comic Strip: Past and Present,\u201d chronicles the work of black creators starting in the 1920s, while other contributors contextualize the work of black creators, explaining how they tackled themes such as the intersection of gender and race and incorporated political and social commentary in their comics.\n\nImage\n\nBLACK PANTHER\n\nA Nation Under Our Feet (Book 1)\n\nBy Ta-Nehisi Coates, Illustrated by Brian Stelfreeze\n\n144 pp. Marvel. (2016)", "title": "What to Read After Watching \u2018Black Panther\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Eat\n\nHaervaerk\n\nIn addition to concrete floors, rough wood tables and a large meat locker that\u2019s fully visible from the dining room, this restaurant in culinary-centric Frederiksbjerg has a tasting menu that changes not just daily, but sometimes hourly. That\u2019s because the chef-owners source virtually all of their highly seasonal ingredients from farms within a 40-mile radius, and when a certain type of prized produce is gone, it\u2019s gone. Still, guests can always count on memorable, hearty dishes along the lines of haddock ceviche with blackcurrant vinegar and roast pigeon confit with kale and onions. The contents of the meat locker, meanwhile, are regularly transformed into venison tartar and pork kebabs served with a crispy Belgian waffle.\n\nFrederikshoj\n\nCompared to the New Nordic restaurants that have become Denmark\u2019s culinary signature, Frederikshoj, with its white tablecloths, quilted leather chairs and hushed dining room, feels comfortingly retro. Located a few miles outside downtown Aarhus, the restaurant provides views of the Marselisborg forest and tastes of the sea, with creative seafood dishes such as Norwegian lobster bisque and Jerusalem artichoke with fresh snow crab.\n\nAarhus Street Food\n\nLocated in a former bus garage in Aarhus\u2019s main business district, this 18-month-old food hall \u2014 inspired by Borough Market in London \u2014 is worth multiple trips. Many of the 30 or so stands specialize in ethnic and street food: Standouts include Tuk Tuk, popular for its curries, and Banh Mi Bandits, for Vietnamese sandwiches, while Mormors Kokken (\u201cGrandma\u2019s Kitchen\u201d) is the go-to for Danish comfort food like pastry tartlets filled with baked asparagus and chicken ragout.\n\nDomestic\n\nThis popular Latin Quarter newcomer, located in an airy, exposed-brick loftlike space, is a temple to all things fermented \u2014 try the cod with pickled cabbage or the pickled gooseberries drizzled with pine oil. To drink, there\u2019s mead, a sweet and spicy brew made with fermented honey, and oolong-flavored kombucha. Just don\u2019t mistake Domestic for a casual joint \u2014 it was awarded a Michelin star last spring.", "title": "What to See and Where to Eat in Denmark\u2019s Second-Largest City", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Peter Plagens, now 76, has devoted most of his life to making paintings and writing about art. He will probably be best remembered for his stylish, cleareyed art criticism, which these days appears regularly in The Wall Street Journal. But persistence pays, and Mr. Plagens is now making the best paintings of his career. Like his writing, they are witty and knowing. They are also hard won, the results of more than a decade spent trying out different combinations of three or four specific abstract styles. His latest amalgam \u2014 the simplest and most balanced \u2014 is an eye-teasing sandwich of contrasting formalist strategies.\n\nThe paintings seem to begin with an allover field of semiautomatic drawing: fast and furious squiggles, loops and grids, rendered in graphite and charcoal and annotated with watery color. Most of this activity is then blocked out by a big, squarish expanse of opaque color \u2014 juicy orange, lavender-gray or deep aqua. It\u2019s a failed monochrome with wildly irregular edges and broad bands of drawing left exposed. Plunked into the center of this field is an irregular polygon, built from six or seven shards of bright color. This passing reference to hard-edged geometric abstraction, which the artist calls a badge, also evokes the big resin paintings of Ron Davis, an avatar of the Los Angeles art scene in the 1960s, when Mr. Plagens began his career there. Finally, the borders are gone over with flat white, as if a referee were moving in and out of the action, covering drips and editing down the outlying borders of drawing to blurry skirmishes at the frayed edges of the monochrome.\n\nLike most painters, Mr. Plagens has borrowed more than he has invented, but he\u2019s never done it with such confidence. He is fully present in these smart, glamorous, high-spirited works. They take things we\u2019ve seen before and put them together in ways we haven\u2019t.", "title": "What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "\u2018Of Earth and Heaven\u2019\n\nThrough March 10. Sam Fogg Ltd. at Luhring Augustine, 531 West 24th Street, Manhattan; 212-206-9100, luhringaugustine.com.\n\nSam Fogg, the respected London dealer, has regularly staged exhibitions of medieval art in New York for around a decade, but never before in Chelsea. Unsurprisingly, this year\u2019s show begins with the thrill of simply walking into it, forsaking the neighborhood\u2019s contemporary-art babble for the otherworldly hush imposed by nearly 30 expressions of faith in painting, sculpture and whatnot from the Middle Ages. Here, the whatnot includes enamels, a silver and silver-gilt reliquary in the form of a bishop\u2019s hand; a large stained-glass window and the lavishly illustrated Carpentin Hours, by the artist known as the Master of the Dresden Prayer Book. The most secular item in this group is a two-tier cast-brass chandelier from the Southern Netherlands (1480-1520) that is remarkably like the single-tier one in Jan van Eyck\u2019s \u201cThe Arnolfini Portrait\u201d of 1434.\n\nThe era\u2019s religious faith is especially palpable in two carved softwood sculptures from the 14th century whose colors and gilding remain nearly intact: a pale, life-size Spanish crucifix that is both daunting and slightly comic and a polychrome wood Piet\u00e0 with anguished expressions and with gaping wounds whose red matches that of the Virgin\u2019s robes. The appealing emotionality of these works is countered by a marble of John the Baptist, also from the 14th century. Attributed to Robert de Lannoy of Paris, it is a study in idealization and dignified restraint \u2014 down to the orderly rivuletlike textures of the saint\u2019s camel-hair coat.\n\nAmong many other standouts, a triptych centering on an elaborately ensconced Virgin and Child (1490-1500) reflects the influence of van Eyck\u2019s infinite realism and his banishment of the Gothic gold that is so gloriously evident elsewhere in the show, especially in \u201cSaint Michael Vanquishing the Devil,\u201d an altarpiece panel made in Aragon around 1470.", "title": "What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Anna K. E.\n\nThrough Feb. 25. Simone Subal, 131 Bowery, Manhattan; 917-409-0612, simonesubal.com.\n\nAnna K. E. works from the body. Trained as a ballerina, she treats herself not chiefly as a metaphor to be mined for other metaphors but as a mechanical problem worth considering in its own right.\n\nWalking into her dazzling new show at Simone Subal is like walking right into her head \u2014 or it would be, if the inside of her head were all outside. Four groups of steel poles mounted with spherical light bulbs and tiny speakers shift and cross elegantly as you move around them. Six aluminum plates on the walls, engraved with fragments of not-quite-intelligible text, are filled in with marzipan. Eight photo prints of 3D-rendered hands, knees and feet modeled on Anna K .E.\u2019s own and decorated with colored pencil are partly enclosed in aluminum and glass jalousies. From the speakers comes her voice chanting, \u201cI have a new underpant, a violet underpant\u201d; intoning, \u201cWomen are so kind\u201d; or shrieking, \u201cYou could smell like a garlic, and I would love you even more!\u201d\n\nOf course, a woman chopping herself into parts like this is hardly without its political resonance, a point that\u2019s amplified by a deliciously blunt short video, playing around a corner created by two false walls, which pans Anna K. E.\u2019s reclining naked body to a pile of excrement balanced on her hip. But what\u2019s most striking to me is the picture this all proposes of consciousness: a rigid machine whose intricate design creates the illusion of motion.\n\nWILL HEINRICH", "title": "What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "A Luxe Introduction\n\nIn between shows, some industry insiders will surely be dashing to Greene Street in SoHo, where Louis Vuitton has temporarily set up shop. On Feb. 8, the pop-up will not only introduce the luxury label\u2019s spring 2018 women\u2019s Archlight sneakers (giving New Yorkers a chance to shop them first), but also carry a version that\u2019s exclusive to the shop: all-black clompers, as befits a notoriously color-shy New Yorker.\n\nLouis Vuitton Archlight canvas and leather sneakers, $1,090 at Louis Vuitton pop-up, 122 Greene Street, through March 10.", "title": "What to Talk About at New York Fashion Week", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "Our democracy is in serious danger.\n\nPresident Trump is either totally compromised by the Russians or is a towering fool, or both, but either way he has shown himself unwilling or unable to defend America against a Russian campaign to divide and undermine our democracy.\n\nThat is, either Trump\u2019s real estate empire has taken large amounts of money from shady oligarchs linked to the Kremlin \u2014 so much that they literally own him; or rumors are true that he engaged in sexual misbehavior while he was in Moscow running the Miss Universe contest, which Russian intelligence has on tape and he doesn\u2019t want released; or Trump actually believes Russian President Vladimir Putin when he says he is innocent of intervening in our elections \u2014 over the explicit findings of Trump\u2019s own C.I.A., N.S.A. and F.B.I. chiefs.\n\nIn sum, Trump is either hiding something so threatening to himself, or he\u2019s criminally incompetent to be commander in chief. It is impossible yet to say which explanation for his behavior is true, but it seems highly likely that one of these scenarios explains Trump\u2019s refusal to respond to Russia\u2019s direct attack on our system \u2014 a quiescence that is simply unprecedented for any U.S. president in history. Russia is not our friend. It has acted in a hostile manner. And Trump keeps ignoring it all.\n\nUp to now, Trump has been flouting the norms of the presidency. Now Trump\u2019s behavior amounts to a refusal to carry out his oath of office \u2014 to protect and defend the Constitution. Here\u2019s an imperfect but close analogy: It\u2019s as if George W. Bush had said after 9/11: \u201cNo big deal. I am going golfing over the weekend in Florida and blogging about how it\u2019s all the Democrats\u2019 fault \u2014 no need to hold a National Security Council meeting.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Whatever Trump Is Hiding Is Hurting All of Us Now", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "When Mr. Zuma became president of South Africa in 2009, he rallied behind him an alliance of people who felt themselves to be marginal and neglected, not just in relation to the world economic order or white South Africa but also in relation to the A.N.C. itself. The A.N.C. has been run by people drawn from the ranks of an urbane, cosmopolitan elite.\n\nMr. Zuma represented a dramatic change in this tradition. Although he spent years in exile and climbed the ranks of the A.N.C., his biography was unlike any of his predecessors\u2019. Nelson Mandela was born into royalty. Thabo Mbeki was the son of prominent intellectuals. Mr. Zuma\u2019s mother worked in the kitchen of a white family and was too poor to provide her son with a formal education. He grew up herding cattle in the hinterland.\n\nWhen he came to power in 2009, he did so with the support of organizations representing much of the urban working class \u2014 the country\u2019s largest trade union and the South African Communist Party.\n\nBut he soon dropped these organizations and turned for support to rural South Africa, in particular to traditional leaders and to the elites of far-flung provincial capitals. They carried with them into power an abiding sense of powerlessness, a feeling that the very institutions they now controlled were alien and belonged to others. In office, they believed that they had entered into their enemy\u2019s mansion. It seemed to be payback time.\n\nIn a speech delivered to a room of black businesspeople in December 2016, Mr. Zuma warned of the sophisticated ways in which the enemy confuses black people. One source of such confusion was the prevailing economic orthodoxy. Mr. Zuma suggested that the most fundamental of economic laws was merely nominal; remove the scales from our eyes and we see that so-called economic laws are a ruse invented by the powerful.\n\nHis genre of criminality is light-years from the sort that characterized the apartheid state. The corruption of apartheid\u2019s leaders stemmed from arrogance; they believed that they could control the world forever. Mr. Zuma\u2019s corruption stems from the grievances of a man who feels very small.\n\nThis sense of grievance was on display in the last words he uttered publicly as president. In a swipe at his successor, Mr. Ramaphosa, Mr. Zuma suggested that those in the party who had unseated him were \u201cserving the interests of the oppressors of yesteryear, who joyfully celebrate as we lynch one another.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | What\u2019s Distinctive About the Mess Jacob Zuma Has Made", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Updated: Feb. 15, 2018\n\nNote: Monday, Feb. 19 is a holiday for many school districts, so our next \u201cWhat\u2019s Going On in This Picture?\u201d will publish on Monday, Feb. 26.\n\n_________\n\nStudents\n\n1.
