How does reading the caption and learning its back story help you see the image differently?", "title": "What\u2019s Going On in This Picture? | Feb. 5, 2018", "authors": ["The Learning Network", "What S Going On In This Picture"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "The bill expands pilot programs meant to test the value of in-home care for some Medicare patients. And it expands the ability of private Medicare Advantage plans to offer so-called \u201ctelehealth,\u201d where doctors treat patients over the phone or internet. It would allow Medicare providers who are part of an accountable care association to offer patients cash bonuses as incentives for healthy behaviors.\n\nThe bill increases discounts that pharmaceutical companies must give seniors enrolled in the Medicare Part D drug plans, by making the so-called \u201cdoughnut hole\u201d smaller. This was a policy that was part of the Affordable Care Act, but the new legislation would speed up implementation by one year.\n\nFunding changes for public health programs.\n\nThe spending plan would cut $1.35 billion in funding to an Affordable Care Act program meant to improve public health and prevention funding for states and municipalities.\n\nAnother extension for the Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program.\n\nIt would extend funding for the Children\u2019s Health Insurance Program for an additional four years. Last month\u2019s spending bill had already extended the program for six years, so now CHIP will be funded for an entire decade. Another popular program that delivers health care to low income children and adults, the government-funded clinics known as Community Health Centers, will also get a two-year funding extension.\n\nContinued funding for abstinence education.\n\nThe bill would extend funding to abstinence-only sex education programs.\n\nA break for Berea College.\n\nThe spending bill restores a provision that was stripped out of last year\u2019s $1.5 trillion tax bill after the Senate parliamentarian objected to its inclusion.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe bill would exempt Berea College, a small private college in Kentucky that provides free tuition, from being subject to a new tax on large higher education endowments that was included in last year\u2019s tax law.\n\nThe bill adds language that makes the new excise tax on investment income applicable only to schools with \u201ctuition-paying\u201d students, shielding Berea College, which does not charge tuition. The school is in the home state of Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader.\n\nTax breaks for racetracks and horse owners continue.\n\nOwners of race horses and motor sports entertainment complexes would get an extension of special tax treatment. Horse owners are allowed to depreciate their horses over the course of three years. For racetracks, the depreciation is over the course of seven years. Those breaks would remain in place for 2017.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nExtension and expansion of energy tax credits.\n\nThe Senate bill features a multitude of tax breaks for renewable energy sources that had been neglected in a 2015 deal to bolster wind and solar power. These so-called \u201corphaned\u201d technologies include geothermal, small wind farms and fuel cells. Much like existing credits for wind and solar power, these incentives would phase out starting in 2020.\n\nThe bill also extends an existing production tax credit for nuclear power past 2020, which would benefit a pair of long-delayed reactors being built in Georgia that aren\u2019t expected to come online before 2021. Southern Company has said it may not be able to complete the reactors, the only two still under construction in the United States, without the credit.\n\nA separate measure would greatly expand a tax credit for companies that capture carbon dioxide from power plants or other polluting facilities and pump it underground. Oil firms such as Occidental Petroleum have been pumping captured CO2 into old wells in order to extract additional oil. Some environmental groups also lobbied for the measure, arguing that carbon capture technology, still in its infancy, could one day prove a crucial tool for tackling climate change.\n\nThe bill retroactively extends tax credits for biodiesel, advanced biofuels and fuel-cell vehicles through the end of 2017. Industry lobbyists had unsuccessfully fought to get many of these measures included in the tax overhaul bill passed by Congress in December. They could still face resistance in the House.\n\nA tax credit for mining safety.\n\nThe bill extends a tax credit for 20 percent of an employers\u2019 spending on mine rescue team training costs, up to $10,000. A separate provision allows the immediate deduction of a company\u2019s investment in mine safety equipment.\n\nA special rate for timber sales.\n\nThe bill continues a special tax rate of 23.8 percent for 2017 for gains from timber sales, a break from the top rate of 35 percent that would have otherwise applied.", "title": "What\u2019s Hidden in the Senate Spending Bill?", "authors": ["Margot Sanger-Katz", "Brad Plumer", "Erica L. Green", "Jim Tankersley"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "They have been in the public eye more than half their lives, and they take the attention in stride.\n\n\u201cI grew up lower-middle class in the middle of Pennsylvania,\u201d said Weir, who is from Coatesville and is now based in Philadelphia.\n\n\u201cMy parents always talked about the importance of being who you are and if you are different, celebrating that and being as special as you can be,\u201d Weir said, adding, \u201cSo when choosing the things I wear or the things I say, it really does come from the heart because that\u2019s all I know. I don\u2019t know how to create an image. I don\u2019t know how to be premeditated.\u201d\n\nThey bring to their presentation and their performance the same meticulousness and drive that fueled their success as athletes. Their workday starts before sunrise and usually doesn\u2019t end until after dark, which leaves them little time to drink in the glorious views from their adjoining rooms at the resort hotel, which overlooks the East Sea, Gyeongpo Lake and the Taebaek Mountains.\n\nWeir owns an impressive collection of brooches, and yet neither he nor Lipinski has traded a single Olympic pin. As Weir noted, who are they going to barter with, each other? \u201cWe\u2019re more likely to trade earrings,\u201d he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nAnd nine days into these Games, they hadn\u2019t made it to the mountains where many of the events are being held, although they came prepared, packing warm boots and clothing that is ski-lodge chic just in case.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe\u2019ve been to a lodge that looks like a ski area,\u201d Weir said.\n\nThey see a lot of each other, and that suits them fine. On Friday, they spent several minutes fingering through each other\u2019s wardrobe as they tried to settle on outfits for the men\u2019s long program. Lipinski started with Weir\u2019s shoes. She pointed to the diamond-encrusted pair he wore last year to her wedding to the sports producer Todd Kapostasy, in which he served as brides-man.\n\n\u201cJohnny had to stand out,\u201d Lipinski said, \u201cso these are customized shoes that I got for him.\u201d\n\nAt the end of an 18-hour workday, Weir returns to his room where, surrounded by the blazers he discovered while skating in Paris, the shoes he stumbled on in Japan, the leather pants he was thrilled to find in Italy and all his other beautiful couture comforts, he can put his wardrobe decisions to rest. Weir, whose every waking hour is spent obsessing over form and fashion, always wears the same thing to bed.\n\n\u201cI find myself feeling more sexy and comfortable if I\u2019m in the nude for sleeping,\u201d he said.", "title": "What\u2019s Inside Johnny Weir\u2019s Hotel Room at the Olympics", "authors": ["Karen Crouse"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Walter Skinner\u2019s history has been elusive, but your episode reflects something he said in the second season about how he had to shoot a 10-year-old North Vietnamese boy during the war. Now we\u2019re seeing this incident more fully.\n\nRight! I had to be reminded of that. [Laughs] You don\u2019t know that much about Skinner, so that was really exciting. In fact, when I had dinner with Mitch Pileggi, I wanted him to remind me what Skinner\u2019s deal was. Was he married or whatever? And Pileggi said, \u201cWell \u2026 I\u2019ve been wearing a wedding ring because I forgot to take it off.\u201d I was like: \u201cI\u2019m pretty sure you\u2019re not married. But if you want to wear your ring, I\u2019m O.K. with that.\u201d\n\nWhat sort of input did you have on the episode? What did you add to it, stylistically?\n\nOne thing was when Haley Joel Osment goes crazy and slaughters the villagers, I wanted to add a baby, add a baby crying. When Mulder is flipping through the photo album, I put some of my family photos in there. My mom just died last year, so it was very fresh, and I wanted to give her something. And when we were shooting Vietnam, I see this period beer that the props department has made called Orville. Orville is my dad\u2019s name, so I was like, \u201cWhat?\u201d Turns out, they had done it as a surprise for me.\n\nHaley Joel Osment gets to play essentially two characters, both of whom seem softer at first, then turn creepy.\n\nIt\u2019s tough to do that quickly, to make him be the scared kid and then creepy, because of the horror of what was happening in Vietnam. My one regret was, we wanted to shoot the scenes in order, to have his longer mane of hair and big beard for the present day, and then cut it off for the Vietnam flashbacks. But because the leaves were coming off the trees in Vancouver, we had to shoot Vietnam first.", "title": "What\u2019s More Elusive Than the Cigarette Smoking Man on \u2018The X-Files\u2019? A Female Director", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages \u2014 and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.\n\nPreviews and Openings\n\n\u2018THE AMATEURS\u2019 at the Vineyard Theater (previews start on Feb. 8; opens on Feb. 27). Jordan Harrison\u2019s new play is a comedy about a group of actors who wander medieval Europe performing cycle plays. It\u2019s also a serious-minded exploration about what art can and should do in times of plague. In the Vineyard\u2019s production, directed by Oliver Butler, Quincy Tyler Bernstine, Thomas Jay Ryan and Michael Cyril Creighton star as the players.\n\n212-353-0303, vineyardtheatre.org\n\n\u2018DRAW THE CIRCLE\u2019 at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater (in previews; opens on Feb. 2). Running in repertory with Dael Orlandersmith\u2019s \u201cUntil the Flood,\u201d Mashuq Mushtaq Deen\u2019s piece is an autobiographical solo show with a twist. Deen the character never appears. Instead we get the point of view of the parents, friends and girlfriend of a young Muslim transitioning from female to male. Chay Yew directs this exploration of gender and identity.\n\n212-627-2556, rattlestick.org\n\n\u2018HANGMEN\u2019 at the Linda Gross Theater (in previews; opens on Feb. 5). Will the new Martin McDonagh play slay? The playwright and filmmaker arrives at the Atlantic Theater with his latest play, a London hit, directed by Matthew Dunster. Set in 1963 and 1965, its mysteries and yarns straddle the end of capital punishment in England. Reviewing an earlier production, Ben Brantley wrote, \u201cI can think of few contemporary playwrights who infuse old-fashioned, precision-tooled dramaturgy with such fresh blood.\u201d\n\n866-811-4111, atlantictheater.org", "title": "What\u2019s New in NYC Theater", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nOur guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages \u2014 and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.\n\nPreviews and Openings\n\n\u2018ADMISSIONS\u2019 at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center Theater (previews start on Feb. 15; opens on March 12). A play of personal statements and professional compromise, Joshua Harmon\u2019s drama centers on the admissions director of a private school whose own son is applying to college. Daniel Aukin directs a cast including Jessica Hecht, Andrew Garman and Ben Edelman.\n\n212-239-6200, lct.org\n\n\u2018THE LOW ROAD\u2019 at the Public Theater (previews start on Feb. 13; opens on March 7). A freewheeling approach to free market theory, this 50-character picaresque from Bruce Norris (\u201cClybourne Park\u201d) is set in the late 18th century and inspired by the theories of Adam Smith. Good thing a drama about unrestrained markets and morally dubious economic modes won\u2019t resonate today. Michael Greif directs.\n\n212-967-7555, publictheater.org\n\n\u2018QUEENS\u2019 at LCT3 (previews start on Feb. 14; opens on March 5). Martyna Majok (\u201cCost of Living,\u201d \u201cIronbound\u201d) writes plays that explore constraint, responsibility and the difficult business of being human. In this new drama, directed by Danya Taymor, female immigrants old and young cram together in a basement apartment in the titular borough.\n\n212-239-6200, lct.org\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2018RETURNING TO REIMS\u2019 at St. Ann\u2019s Warehouse (in previews; opens on Feb. 11). Based on a memoir by the French sociologist Didier Eribon, this play stars Nina Hoss (\u201cHomeland\u201d) as an actress recording the commentary track for a documentary about a leftist community\u2019s rightward turn. Directed by Thomas Ostermeier, the piece becomes an increasingly personal meditation on family and politics.\n\n866-811-4111, stannswarehouse.org", "title": "What\u2019s New in NYC Theater", "authors": ["Alexis Soloski"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Nearly 1,200 readers shared why the loved \u201cThe Greatest Showman.\u201d You can read the responses here.\n\nWhy do people like \u201cThe Greatest Showman\u201d?\n\nWhen the movie starring Hugh Jackman was released in December, our critic Jason Zinoman said it was solidly meh. It\u2019s \u201ca montage sequence that occasionally turns into a movie musical,\u201d he wrote. And the box office numbers seemed to back him up, opening to an underwhelming $13.2 million \u2014 not great for an $84 million production.\n\nMusic writers were just as unimpressed. The soundtrack, by the \u201cLa La Land\u201d guys Justin Paul and Benj Pasek, is \u201cpopulist to a fault, every song a Voltron-esque evocation of various current pop and rock stars,\u201d Rob Harvilla wrote in The Ringer.", "title": "What\u2019s So Great About \u2018The Greatest Showman\u2019?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Rosy Assumptions on the Economy\u2019s Growth\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s plan could easily result in much larger federal deficits.\n\nThe administration made its calculations using assumptions about the nation\u2019s economic trajectory that are more optimistic than the consensus among private-sector forecasters, or the assumptions used by other parts of the government.\n\nThe forecasts in Monday\u2019s plan are also significantly more optimistic than the Trump administration itself used in its budget calculations last year.\n\nMost notably, the administration projected annualized economic growth of 3.1 percent over the next three years. The Federal Reserve in December projected annualized growth of 2.2 percent over that period. The Survey of Professional Forecasters estimated the annualized growth rate at about 2.4 percent.\n\nThere is a similar gap in the projections of long-term growth. If the less optimistic forecasts were correct, the government would collect significantly less revenue. By its own estimates, the result would be another $3 trillion in federal debt.\n\nThe administration attributed the difference to the expectation that the president\u2019s policies would significantly increase productivity growth.\n\nJason Furman, the former chairman of President Barack Obama\u2019s Council of Economic Advisers, calculated that productivity growth would have to reach the highest level in any decade since the immediate aftermath of the World War II. Productivity growth was 1.1 percent over the last decade; it would have to reach 2.5 percent.\n\n\u201cIt is hard to understand where this growth would be coming from,\u201d Mr. Furman tweeted.\n\n\u2014Jim Tankersley\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nA 5% Reduction for the Department of Education\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s 2019 budget proposal requests $63.2 billion in discretionary spending at the Education Department, a reduction of $3.6 billion, or 5 percent, from 2017 spending levels.\n\nThe proposal calls for a $1.5 billion \u201cschool choice\u201d program, which includes taxpayer-funded scholarships for private schools and a vast expansion of charter schools. However, the budget would eliminate or cut 39 programs including two staple programs in public schools that provide teacher training and after-school programs to low-income children.\n\nThe Department\u2019s budget also funds initiatives that Mr. Trump has given lip service to in the last year, calling for $43 million in \u201cSchool Climate Transformation\u201d grants to help fight the opioid epidemic in schools, and $200 million in new grants to improve science, technology, engineering and mathematics education.\n\n\u2014Erica A. Green\n\nA Hint at the Special Counsel\u2019s Timeline\n\nThe proposal indicates that the work of the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, could last another year and a half. It allocates $10 million to his office from October 2018 through the end of September 2019.\n\nBut that does not mean the Russia investigation itself will last that long. The office would also oversee a trial of Paul Manafort, the president\u2019s former campaign chairman, who has pleaded not guilty to charges he laundered millions of dollars through overseas shell companies. No trial date has been set, but the judge in the case has indicated it would not start before the fall.\n\nDocuments released last year by the special counsel\u2019s office, which is part of the Justice Department, provided a view into its expenses. Those documents showed that between the time the office was opened in May and the end of September it racked up $3.2 million in costs. The largest portion of that money \u2014 $1.7 million \u2014 went to personnel, compensation and benefits. The second highest cost was for the \u201cacquisition of equipment\u201d at $733,969.\n\nThe Justice Department\u2019s $28 billion proposed budget overall is relatively flat from last year, with notable increases in spending to combat violent crime and drug use as well as house more prisoners. The department wants to increase its immigration enforcement efforts and add 75 immigration judges and support staff. The department counts more than 117,000 employees.\n\nTo offset the spending increases, the Justice Department plans to close two of its six Bureau of Prisons regional administrative offices and two of its seven minimum security prisons.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014Katie Benner\n\nTargets Planned Parenthood\n\nThe president\u2019s budget singles out abortion providers and would prohibit Health and Human Services funding, including money used for family planning, from going to any clinic or health care facility that also offers abortion services.\n\nThough the language is broadly written, its intended target is Planned Parenthood, which relies on government funding to offer a variety of services to women other than abortion. The budget would help achieve the longstanding goal of social conservatives to cut off Planned Parenthood from federal assistance.\n\n\u2014Jeremy W. Peters\n\nBig Changes for Food Stamps\n\nThe White House is proposing a significant change for a low-income food program known as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program or SNAP. The White House proposes to cut funding for the program by about $213 billion \u2014 or 30 percent \u2014 over a decade. It also wants to change how SNAP recipients get their food, replacing a portion of the benefits that allow SNAP recipients to go to a grocery store to purchase food with a package of \u201cnutritious\u201d American-grown food delivered to SNAP households.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe White House says the proposal is \u201ca bold new approach\u201d to administering SNAP that combines traditional benefits with \u201c100-percent American grown foods provided directly to households.\u201d\n\nMore for Immigration Enforcement and a Border Wall\n\nThe Department of Homeland Security would receive $46 billion, a $3.4 billion increase over the enacted 2017 budget, all part of the administration\u2019s efforts to crack down on illegal immigration and build a wall on the border with Mexico. The request calls for $18 billion for border security, including $1.6 billion to build about 65 miles of the wall in South Texas. The request also calls for the department to hire 2,000 new Immigration and Customs Enforcement and 750 Border Patrol agents.\n\nWhile most of the budget increases focus on illegal immigration and border security, the administration also requested funding to hire 450 new agents for the chronically-short staffed Secret Service, $1 billion for the department\u2019s cybersecurity efforts and $71 million for new scanning technology for the Transportation Security Administration. The new budget request would provide $1.9 billion for the Federal Emergency Management Agency\u2019s grant program to state and local communities, $800 million less than the $2.7 billion funded in 2017.\n\n\u2014Ron Nixon\n\nDeep Cuts to the Environmental Protection Agency\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s second federal spending plan proposes steep cuts for the Environmental Protection Agency, despite Congress\u2019 rejection of a similar plan last year to dramatically shrink the agency\u2019s budget.\n\nThe fiscal 2019 budget blueprint would pare the E.P.A. by $2.8 billion or 34 percent from its current level, while eliminating virtually all climate change-related programs. It also would cut the agency\u2019s Office of Science and Technology nearly in half, to $489 million from its current $762 million.\n\nIn outlining the budget, the administration said the E.P.A. is refocusing on what it called \u201ccore activities\u201d and eliminating \u201clower priority programs.\u201d That list includes a program to promote partnerships with the private sector to tackle climate change; environmental education training; and an effort to protect marine estuaries.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe White House estimated cutting those programs and others will save taxpayers $600 million compared to 2017 levels.\n\n\u2014Lisa Friedman\n\nAnother Call to Repeal the Affordable Care Act\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s budget proposes once again to \u201crepeal and replace\u201d the Affordable Care Act and to eliminate the law\u2019s expansion of Medicaid. More than 30 states have expanded Medicaid under the law. Republican efforts to dismantle the law failed in Congress last year.\n\nAs a presidential candidate, Mr. Trump said there would be \u201cno cuts\u201d to Medicare or Medicaid if he won the election. But his 2019 budget request is full of proposals to squeeze savings out of the two programs, which together provide health insurance for more than 100 million Americans.\n\nProposed savings in Medicare total more than $490 billion over 10 years, or about 5 percent of Medicare spending expected under current law.\n\nThe budget would cut $69.5 billion over 10 years in projected Medicare payments to hospitals for \u201cuncompensated care.\u201d It would cut more than $95 billion over 10 years from nursing homes and home health agencies, and $22 billion from Medicare Advantage plans, which manage care for about one-third of Medicare beneficiaries.\n\nIn addition, the budget would cut $48 billion over 10 years in Medicare payments to teaching hospitals for graduate medical education,\n\nThe budget includes several proposals intended to reduce out-of-pocket drug costs for Medicare beneficiaries by requiring insurers and pharmacy benefit managers to share at least one-third of the discounts and price concessions they receive from drug manufacturers. The budget would also establish a limit on beneficiaries\u2019 out-of-pocket costs for prescription drugs covered by Medicare.\n\n\u2014Robert Pear\n\nParing Back a Dodd-Frank Watchdog\n\nThe Treasury Department plan calls for continuing to cut the budget of the Office of Financial Research, which was set up in the wake of the financial crisis to help federal agencies stay ahead of financial risks. The office, which provides analysis and research to the Financial Stability Oversight Council, has previously been targeted for both funding and personnel cuts. \u201cThe Budget reflects continued reductions in O.F.R. spending commensurate with the renewed fiscal discipline being applied across the Federal Government.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nChanging the Role of the A.T.F.\n\nThe budget would allocate $28 billion to the Justice Department \u2014 a 1.2 percent decrease from the department\u2019s 2017 budget. That budget funds agencies like the F.B.I., the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives and Drug Enforcement Administration. The budget proposal would take tobacco and alcohol enforcement authority away from the A.T.F. and move those authorities to the Treasury Department.\n\nThe D.E.A. would receive an addition $41 million to specifically combat the opioid crisis, and the agency would also take over the High-Intensity Drug Trafficking Areas program, which is currently run by the White House drug czar\u2019s office.\n\n\u2014Ali Watkins\n\nState Department Gets Less Funding\n\nAt the State Department and USAID, the president\u2019s budget proposes a base budget of $25.8 billion, a $9 billion decrease in funding from the 2017 enacted budget. This is a 26 percent decrease in funding, similar to the president\u2019s budgetary intentions last year.\n\nNotably, the president\u2019s new budget aims to shift $12 billion from Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) funding to the base budget. The OCO is traditionally used for United States presence in turbulent regions like Syria and Iraq.\n\nThe addendum provides an additional $1 billion to USAID\u2019s International Disaster Assistance account for use in humanitarian crises as well as an additional $400 million for the U.S. President\u2019s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR).\n\n\u2014Emily Baumgaertner", "title": "What\u2019s in the White House Budget Request?", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNas performs \u201cIllmatic\u201d with the National Symphony Orchestra. And a new cyberpunk series comes to Netflix.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nGREAT PERFORMANCES 9 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). There\u2019s not much in the way of symphonic instrumentation on Nas\u2019s era-shifting 1994 album \u201cIllmatic.\u201d Producers including DJ Premier and Pete Rock laid down subdued keyboard samples and crisp drums and let Nas fill in the rest with his dense wordplay and vivid storytelling about daily life in Queensbridge. But in this concert at the Kennedy Center, the M.C. is backed by the National Symphony Orchestra for a full performance of the album. The indelible, spiky piano riff on \u201cN.Y. State of Mind\u201d is played by an acoustic bass and padded by lurking brass; creeping vibraphone on \u201cOne Love\u201d gets a lift from flighty woodwinds. And the once even-keeled, resigned \u201cLife\u2019s a Bitch\u201d builds to a euphoric, mesmerizing climax.\n\nSTRIKE BACK 10 p.m. on Cinemax. This action series was a hit for Cinemax over four American seasons \u2014 it followed British and U.S. operatives on high-risk, first-person-shooter missions in gorgeous locales around the world. \u201cIt incorporates the look and spirit of video games and violent comic books into a television series as well as any show around,\u201d Mike Hale wrote in his Times review in 2015. That year\u2019s season was billed as the show\u2019s last, but the franchise is reloading with an entirely new cast that includes Daniel MacPherson and Roxanne McKee. The premise \u2014 an elite, international, gun-toting force chases terrorists to their hidey holes \u2014 remains the same.\n\n#METOO, NOW WHAT? 8:30 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). After leading to the downfall of Harvey Weinstein, Kevin Spacey and others and landing on the cover of Time\u2019s Person of the Year issue, the #MeToo movement has waded into more ambiguous waters, with debates raging over the behavior of public figures like Chuck Close or Aziz Ansari. This special, hosted by Zainab Salbi, founder of Women for Women International, explores the cultural moment through original reporting and extensive discussions, and ponders the next steps of fighting harassment and gender inequality.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nALTERED CARBON on Netflix. \u201cBlade Runner 2049,\u201d in theaters last year, and \u201cPhilip K. Dick\u2019s Electric Dreams,\u201d on Amazon, both unveiled hazy worlds in which rugged heroes struggled against menacing technological developments. Next up is \u201cAltered Carbon,\u201d based on a novel by Richard K. Morgan. A soldier named Takeshi Kovacs (Joel Kinnaman) wakes up hundreds of years after his death in a dystopian future, where human personalities can be stored digitally and downloaded into new bodies.\n\nPhoto\n\nON BODY AND SOUL (2017) on Netflix. This surreal Hungarian romance is nominated for best foreign film at the Oscars. Directed by Ildik\u00f3 Enyedi, it follows two slaughterhouse workers who realize they share the same dreams every night. Their hallucinations \u2014 in which they are transformed into deer in serene, wintry landscapes \u2014 are juxtaposed with the bloody viciousness of their workplace.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Friday: Nas and \u2018Strike Back\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "THE RITUAL on Netflix. The director David Bruckner has contributed to several well-reviewed and extremely frightening films over the past decade, including \u201cSouthbound\u201d and \u201cSiREN.\u201d He specializes in agile dialogue and thrilling set pieces, and in \u201cThe Ritual\u201d he steps out for his feature-length debut, building a story around a group of friends who head into the Swedish wilderness and find supernatural forces waiting for them. Like in any good backwoods horror film, there are dead deer, pagan symbols and an abandoned cabin.\n\nENTANGLEMENT on Amazon and iTunes. Few actors play the charming, neurotic sad sack as well as Thomas Middleditch, who has been perfecting those traits over four seasons of HBO\u2019s \u201cSilicon Valley.\u201d He gets another starring turn in this rom-com; his suicidal character, Ben, receives a spark and a reason to live from Hanna (Jess Weixler). But greater mysteries soon unfold. \u201cImpressively photographed and perkily paced, Jason Filiatrault\u2019s story never droops quite as much as its lead character, injecting a welcome poignancy that tempers the cuteness,\u201d Jeannette Catsoulis wrote in her Times review.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Friday: \u20182 Dope Queens\u2019 and \u2018Seeing Allred\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIt\u2019s a busy weekend for streaming services, as Netflix premieres a romantic comedy, while a new season of \u201cMozart in the Jungle\u201d arrives on Amazon Prime.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nIRREPLACEABLE YOU on Netflix. Gugu Mbatha-Raw and Michiel Huisman have each played a part in unforgettable recent television romances \u2014 Ms. Mbatha-Raw on \u201cSan Junipero,\u201d the Emmy-winning episode of \u201cBlack Mirror,\u201d and Mr. Huisman on \u201cGame of Thrones,\u201d in which he wooed the Mother of Dragons. They\u2019re matched up in this new Netflix film, which shares some similarities with \u201cThe Big Sick\u201d: Boy meets girl. Girl falls ill. When Ms. Mbatha-Raw\u2019s character, Abbie, learns she has cancer, she sets out to find a new partner for Mr. Huisman\u2019s Sam before she dies. The tragic story is offset by supporting roles featuring plenty of comedic talent, from Christopher Walken to Kate McKinnon to Brian Tyree Henry.\n\nPhoto\n\nEVERYTHING SUCKS! on Netflix. IDK guys, it feels like we\u2019re in a new golden age of teen TV! There\u2019s something for every squad, from blockbuster dramas (\u201cStranger Things,\u201d \u201c13 Reasons Why\u201d) to cult comedies (\u201cAmerican Vandal\u201d) to whatever \u201cThe End of the ____ing World\u201d is. Next up is \u201cEverything Sucks!\u201d which doesn\u2019t depict monsters or murder fantasies so much as the agony and euphoria of everyday high school life. It\u2019s set at a school in 1990s Oregon, where first kisses are planted, hearts are broken and slow afternoons are shared at the A.V. club. The soundtrack is fueled by the laconic rock of the era, from Weezer to Oasis.\n\nMOZART IN THE JUNGLE on Amazon Prime. This week, the New York Philharmonic announced its first season under the baton of a new conductor, Jaap van Zweden. Meanwhile, the orchestra\u2019s fictional corollary \u2014 the New York Symphony \u2014 is staying firmly in the hands of the sprightly Rodrigo De Souza (Gael Garc\u00eda Bernal) as the fourth season of \u201cMozart in the Jungle\u201d arrives on Friday. The show delights in taking its music around the world, and so this season will feature Rodrigo and Hailey (Lola Kirke) navigating her ambitions to be a conductor \u2014 as well as the pair\u2019s newish relationship \u2014 in Japan.\n\nPhoto\n\nHUMAN FLOW on Amazon Prime. Ai Weiwei shot this documentary in 23 countries over the course of just a year, traversing deserts, rivers and bustling port cities to capture the refugee and migrant crises afflicting nearly every corner of the globe. Some of the most affecting scenes take him into refugee camps with squalid living conditions; he shoots from the ground and in the air, with drone technology. Manohla Dargis called it a \u201cbracing, often strangely beautiful movie\u201d in her review in The New York Times.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nPYEONGCHANG 2018 OLYMPICS 8 p.m. on NBC. The Japanese figure skater Yuzuru Hanyu won gold four years ago. He hopes to fend off the American Nathan Chen and reclaim the title. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "A cyberpunk movie from Duncan Jones comes to Netflix. And HBO\u2019s \u201c2 Dope Queens\u201d wraps up with the fourth episode, featuring Uzo Aduba and Tituss Burgess.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nMUTE on Netflix. The filmmaker Duncan Jones spent much of his childhood in Berlin while his father, David Bowie, created his fabled Berlin trilogy. Mr. Jones revisits that city in this new film, which is set in 2052. Alexander Skarsgard, who took home plenty of awards for his terrifying turn in \u201cBig Little Lies,\u201d stars as a mute bartender. When his girlfriend goes missing, he plunges into the underbelly of the cyberpunk city to find her, turning to seedy characters played by Paul Rudd and Justin Theroux for answers.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Friday: \u2018Mute\u2019 and \u2018Ugly Delicious\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Three best friends steal more than they can manage in \u201cGood Girls.\u201d And \u201cRat Film\u201d exposes troubling parallels in Baltimore.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nGOOD GIRLS 10 p.m. on NBC. It\u2019s three suburban moms against the world in this new comedy-drama by Jenna Bans (\u201cDesperate Housewives,\u201d \u201cGrey\u2019s Anatomy\u201d). Four minutes into this pilot, Beth (Christina Hendricks), Ruby (Retta) and Annie (Mae Whitman) have robbed the grocery store where Annie works. The story then backtracks to explain what drove them into that messy situation \u2014 the men in their lives share most of the blame \u2014 and the women quickly find themselves up against a larger threat than they anticipated. \u201c\u2018Good Girls\u2019 certainly works as a caper,\u201d James Poniewozik wrote in The New York Times. \u201cThe problem is that it\u2019s also very much a drama, and the needs of the one mode often conflict with those of the other.\u201d\n\nTHE VOICE 8 p.m. on NBC. Adam Levine and Blake Shelton are back for more bickering in Season 14. Alicia Keys returns to the red swivel chairs after her Season 12 win, while Kelly Clarkson makes her debut as a coach.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: \u2018Good Girls\u2019 and \u2018Rat Film\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nNetworks celebrate Black History Month with \u201cMalcolm X\u201d and the series \u201cTwo Sides.\u201d \u201cTom of Finland\u201d arrives on Hulu.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nMALCOLM X (1992) 7 p.m. on SundanceTV; also on iTunes and Amazon. Drawing from \u201cThe Autobiography of Malcolm X\u201d (1965), a screenplay by Arnold Perl and James Baldwin, and copious research, Spike Lee traces the life of Malcolm Little (Denzel Washington), the street hustler turned black nationalist leader who became a tenacious force in the civil rights movement. When Warner Bros. capped the film\u2019s budget at $28 million, celebrities donated funds to help Mr. Lee carry out his vision. \u201cExquisitely acted, with a gorgeous, expressionistic Terence Blanchard score, this is one of Spike Lee\u2019s most enduring films,\u201d Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. \u201cRosewood,\u201d the historical drama about a 1923 massacre in Rosewood, Fla., follows at 11:30 p.m.\n\nATOMIC HOMEFRONT (2017) 8 p.m. on HBO; also on HBO streaming platforms. This documentary follows activists mothers in St. Louis as they pressure the Environmental Protection Agency and other government agencies to remove radioactive waste that was dumped in a nearby landfill decades earlier. Residents claim the waste has led to high rates of cancer, other diseases and birth defects. On Feb. 1, the E.P.A. announced a plan to partly remove the hazardous material.\n\nTWO SIDES 10 p.m. on TV One. Narrated by Viola Davis, this documentary series looks at four recent cases that catalyzed national uproar over police brutality against black people. This final episode questions the death of Sandra Bland, who was found hanging in a Texas jail cell in 2015, three days after being arrested during a traffic stop. A medical examiner ruled the death a suicide, yet Ms. Bland\u2019s friends and relatives dispute that.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nTOM OF FINLAND (2017) on iTunes, Amazon and Hulu. Before the world knew him as Tom of Finland, the artist and corporate advertising designer Touko Laaksonen lived in fear of persecution as a gay man in his homeland. His art \u2014 subversive, erotic drawings of hyper-muscular men \u2014 offered an escape. Twenty years after publishing his first piece, he would inspire other gay men, from Freddie Mercury of Queen to Glenn Hughes of the Village People. This biopic doesn\u2019t delve much into his impact on fashion and art but sheds light on his struggles before success.\n\nPhoto\n\nROMEO AND JULIET on Cennarium. The Brazilian troupe Grupo Galp\u00e3o puts a playful twist on this Shakespeare classic. (Romeo prances around on stilts, while Juliet performs on point.) Directed by Gabriel Villela, the 2012 production is streaming free through Wednesday.\n\nCHRISTOPHER AND HIS KIND (2011) on Britbox. Based on a 1976 memoir by the British-American author Christopher Isherwood, this BBC adaptation stars Matt Smith as a young Isherwood, who finds love in 1930s Berlin during the rise of Nazism.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: \u2018Malcolm X\u2019 and \u2018Tom of Finland\u2019", "authors": ["Sara Aridi"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Enjoy Presidents\u2019 Day with a host of documentaries. Stanley Nelson traces the history of historically black colleges, while \u201cThe Dog\u201d reveals the real-life man behind \u201cDog Day Afternoon.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nTELL THEM WE ARE RISING: THE STORY OF BLACK COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES (2017) 9 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). This new documentary by the Emmy and Peabody Award-winning director Stanley Nelson chronicles the development and impact of historically black colleges and universities, from their inception in the mid-19th century to their standing under the Trump administration. In an opinion article for The New York Times, Mr. Nelson wrote, \u201cThe story of H.B.C.U.s is the story of a community that refuses to be denied and of a powerhouse group of institutions that have shaped not only the lives of individual families but also the landscape of the country.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: \u2018Tell Them We Are Rising\u2019 and \u2018The Dog\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Amy Schumer plays a proudly promiscuous men\u2019s magazine writer in \u201cTrainwreck.\u201d And the rapper Snoop Dogg makes for an encouraging-but-tough \u201cCoach Snoop.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nTRAINWRECK (2015) 8 p.m. on FXM. The New York Times\u2019s Manohla Dargis named this Judd Apatow-directed, Amy Schumer-written comedy a Critic\u2019s Pick, calling it \u201csomething of a sexual bildungsroman cum romantic comedy jumping with pop-cultural references and edged with razored social cultural critique.\u201d The film stars Ms. Schumer as a proudly promiscuous men\u2019s magazine writer who falls for a surgeon (Bill Hader), much to her own surprise. Parts of the film are based on Ms. Schumer\u2019s own life, including her character\u2019s father (played by Colin Quinn), who, like Ms. Schumer\u2019s father, has multiple sclerosis. \u201cHaving it be such a personal story but still leaving room for comedy was not a challenge for me,\u201d Ms. Schumer told The Times in 2015.\n\nVANITY FAIR CONFIDENTIAL 9 p.m. on Investigation Discovery. This series gives retrospective looks to notable stories on crime and scandal from Vanity Fair; the first episode of its fourth season revisits a story about campus sexual assault.\n\nINDEPENDENT LENS: WINNIE 10 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). \u201cWinnie,\u201d Pascale Lamche\u2019s 2017 documentary about the South African activist Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, is part of PBS\u2019s \u201cIndependent Lens\u201d series. Ms. Madikizela-Mandela came to prominence as an activist in South Africa during the apartheid era and was married to the activist Nelson Mandela for years. But in 1991 she was convicted of kidnapping and being an accessory to the assault of four young men. This film examines her life and legacy.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Monday: \u2018Trainwreck\u2019 and \u2018Coach Snoop\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nStream Oscar-nominated titles before the Academy Awards air next Sunday, or explore the country\u2019s prison problem with \u201cNotes From the Field.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nTHE FLORIDA PROJECT (2017) on iTunes and Amazon. Inspired by news reports about families living in cheap motels after the Great Recession, this drama by Sean Baker follows a mother-daughter relationship over the course of a summer in Central Florida. Six-year-old Moonee (Brooklynn Prince) is as carefree as a child should be, capering about the Magic Castle motel with her partners in crime Scooty (Christopher Rivera) and Jancey (Valeria Cotto), while her rebellious mother, Halley (Bria Vinaite), can barely make ends meet. Willem Dafoe assumes the role of responsible guardian as the admirable motel manager, which earned him a nomination for best supporting actor. \u201cThis movie insists on meeting people on both sides of the screen where they are, on suspending judgment and extending compassion without abandoning its ethical grounding,\u201d A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times.\n\nLAST MEN IN ALEPPO (2017) on iTunes and Netflix. Hollywood celebrated the volunteers of Syria Civil Defense, also known as the White Helmets, last year by awarding Orlando von Einsiedel an Oscar for his 2015 short \u201cThe White Helmets.\u201d The search-and-rescue team is back in the Academy spotlight with this documentary by the Syrian director Feras Fayyad. He spent nearly two years following the emergency rescue workers as they raced to the scenes of airstrikes in search of survivors. \u201cIt kills something inside you,\u201d Mr. Fayyad told The Times. \u201cWe made a film about our nightmare.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE SQUARE (2017) on iTunes and Amazon. The protagonist of this Oscar nominee for best foreign language film is a sleek curator (Claes Bang) at a modern Stockholm museum who\u2019s preparing for a coming exhibition on morality and trust. He has faith in the artwork, titled \u201cThe Square,\u201d yet his behavior outside the museum contradicts the ideals \u201cThe Square\u201d champions. There\u2019s more to the feature\u2019s meandering plot, and it\u2019s worth watching for the surprise factor, wry dialogue and provocative scenes. The film practices \u201can aesthetics of shaming, laying bare the hypocrisy, the selfishness and the wishful thinking embedded in the deep structures of 21st-century metropolitan existence,\u201d A. O. Scott wrote in The Times.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nPhoto\n\nNOTES FROM THE FIELD (2018) 8 p.m. on HBO; also on HBO streaming services. The playwright and actress Anna Deavere Smith portrayed 18 real-life characters in her 2016 one-woman show, \u201cNotes From the Field.\u201d Each of the subjects has played a role in the fight for underprivileged American youth who fall victim to institutional racism and mass incarceration. This film adaptation weaves Ms. Smith\u2019s electrifying performance with sobering video footage and photographs.\n\nPYEONGCHANG 2018 OLYMPICS 7 p.m. on NBC. Watch the gold medal match for women\u2019s curling before the Winter Games wrap up tomorrow. Canada has long dominated the sport, but, for the first time in Olympic history, the women\u2019s team didn\u2019t even reach the semifinals.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: Oscar-Nominated Movies and \u2018Notes From the Field\u2019", "authors": ["Sara Aridi"]} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "Emma Stone plays the star athlete to Steve Carell\u2019s \u201cmale chauvinist pig\u201d in \u201cBattle of the Sexes.\u201d And Chris Evans is a de-facto father in \"Gifted.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nBATTLE OF THE SEXES (2017) on iTunes and Amazon. When this film came out last year, audiences unfamiliar with the actual 1973 exhibition tennis match in which Billie Jean King, a 29-year-old feminist tennis star, faced off against Bobby Riggs, a 55-year-old self-proclaimed \u201cmale chauvinist pig,\u201d might have had trouble believing the historical accuracy of details like Riggs\u2019s \u201cSugar Daddy\u201d-branded clothing and Ms. King\u2019s being lifted onto the court by a group of shirtless muscle men. Those details are, in fact, true; it was an over-the-top symbolic battle for gender equality, broadcast in prime time. The New York Times\u2019s Manohla Dargis found the film, which casts Emma Stone as Ms. King and Steve Carell as Riggs, a \u201cglib, enjoyable fictionalization\u201d of the lead-up to the match.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: \u2018Battle of the Sexes\u2019 and \u2018Gifted\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "Eric Clapton gets personal in \u201cLife in 12 Bars.\u201d And SundanceTV brings back \u201cRoots\u201d for Black History Month.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nERIC CLAPTON: LIFE IN 12 BARS (2017) 9 p.m. on Showtime. Upon hearing the blues for the first time as a young child grappling with a confusing home life, Eric Clapton was stunned. \u201cSomething about it got me,\u201d he says in this intimate portrait. \u201cSomething stirred me. Without me even being aware of it, it took all the pain away.\u201d Music\u2019s ability to heal is the recurring theme in this documentary. Directed by Lili Fini Zanuck, the film chronicles Mr. Clapton\u2019s rise as a rock \u2019n\u2019 roll trailblazer (he is the only musician to have been inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame three times), yet doesn\u2019t shy away from his demons. The 72-year-old guitarist opens up about his painful childhood, his battles with alcohol and drug addiction and the loss of his 4-year-old son.\n\nROOTS 12 p.m. on SundanceTV. As part of a celebration of Black History Month there\u2019s a marathon of this groundbreaking 1977 mini-series. Adapted from the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel by Alex Haley, \u201cRoots\u201d retraces the author\u2019s family history, beginning with his 18th-century ancestor\u2019s enslavement. It remains one of the most-viewed television series of all time, and a remake was broadcast on History, A&E and Lifetime last year. \u201cRoots\u201d was a \u201cprime-time national reckoning for more than 100 million viewers,\u201d James Poniewozik wrote in The New York Times. \u201cAs a television drama, it was excellent. But as a television broadcast, it was epochal.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: \u2018Eric Clapton: Life in 12 Bars\u2019 and \u2018Roots\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "A brief love affair turns into a day of wonder in \u201cMedicine for Melancholy.\u201d And the comic horror film \u201cTragedy Girls\u201d arrives on Hulu.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nMEDICINE FOR MELANCHOLY (2008) on iTunes, Amazon, and Mubi. As the Oscars draw closer, revisit last year\u2019s star winner with this debut feature by Barry Jenkins, the director of \u201cMoonlight.\u201d The low-budget indie begins the day after a one-night stand between Micah (Wyatt Cenac) and Jo\u2019 (Tracey Heggins), twentysomething San Franciscans who, at the outset, don\u2019t even know each other\u2019s names. Rather than go their separate ways, they explore the city \u2014 somewhat of a third main character in this romance \u2014 while discussing gentrification, race and class. In his review, A.O. Scott designated the film a critic\u2019s pick and wrote, \u201cThere are no simple answers or obvious conclusions to be gleaned from this movie, which, like its soundtrack, is both sad and vibrant, meandering and formally sure-footed.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Saturday: \u2018Medicine for Melancholy\u2019 and \u2018Tragedy Girls\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cThis Is Us\u201d gears up for an emotional episode after the Super Bowl, which features a halftime show from Justin Timberlake.\n\nWhat\u2019s On TV\n\nTHIS IS US 10:15 p.m., or after the Super Bowl, on NBC. This coveted time slot has produced some memorable television, from the pilot of \u201cThe Wonder Years\u201d to the most-watched episode of \u201cGrey\u2019s Anatomy\u201d to Prince\u2019s mesmerizing cameo on \u201cNew Girl.\u201d \u201cThis Is Us\u201d will try to outdo all of those on Sunday, when it reveals at long last how Jack Pearson died, on the day of the 1998 Super Bowl. (\u201cAll of your questions will be answered,\u201d a promo assures.) The previous episode ended as a Crockpot burst into flames in the family\u2019s kitchen; this new episode will show how Jack died while Rebecca, Kate and Randall survived. In the present, Randall hosts his own Super Bowl party to honor his father\u2019s legacy. It will probably get dusty in there.\n\nKITTEN BOWL Noon on Hallmark Channel. They\u2019re good cats.\n\nPUPPY BOWL 3 p.m. on Animal Planet. They\u2019re good dogs.\n\nPhoto\n\nSUPER BOWL LII NBC on 6 p.m. Oh yeah, the game! When the New England Patriots and the Philadelphia Eagles kick off, Tom Brady will become the oldest quarterback to play in a Super Bowl. A fiesty Eagles defensive line led by Brandon Graham will do its best to slow him. The halftime show features Justin Timberlake performing on a Super Bowl stage for the first time since the \u201cwardrobe malfunction\u201d with Janet Jackson in 2004. (\u201cThere\u2019s little doubt that his dance moves will be perfect and his small but supple voice will stay suave all the way through his 12 minutes. But as the world watches, he could do some small measure of karmic payback to Ms. Jackson,\u201d wrote Jon Pareles in an NYT critic\u2019s notebook.) He\u2019ll probably slip in a song or two from his new album, \u201cMan of the Woods,\u201d and return to enduring early 2000s hits like \u201cCry Me a River\u201d and \u201cWhat Goes Around \u2026 Comes Around.\u201d The Pennsylvania native Pink will sing the national anthem.\n\nPhoto\n\nCRASHING 10:30 p.m. on HBO. The second season of the comedian Pete Holmes\u2019s semi-autobiographical show has him coping with a divorce, sleeping on his friend\u2019s couches and working at Cold Stone Creamery. Bill Burr, Artie Lange and other comedians play versions of themselves to give Pete guidance or a place to stay; the show veers between thoughtful contemplation of morals and debaucherous one-night stands.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nABSENTIA on Amazon Prime. While on the hunt for a serial killer who slices off his victim\u2019s eyebrows, the F.B.I. agent Emily Byrne (Stana Katic) goes missing and is presumed dead. Six years later, she\u2019s found alive and scarred in a tank in the woods, with no recollection of her time in captivity. She returns to society to find that her husband has remarried and her son doesn\u2019t recognize her. Worst of all, another victim is found. The series traces her efforts to reassimilate, to remember what happened and to uncover if she\u2019s also a suspect in the investigation.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Sunday: Super Bowl, Puppy Bowl, Kitten Bowl", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cThe Shape of Water\u201d leads the way at the Baftas. And John Oliver returns to his desk on \u201cLast Week Tonight.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s On TV\n\n71ST BRITISH ACADEMY FILM AWARDS 8 p.m. on BBC America. It\u2019s perhaps unsurprising that two World War II-era British films are strong contenders at the Baftas this year: \u201cDarkest Hour,\u201d a Winston Churchill biopic, has nine nominations, while Christopher Nolan\u2019s \u201cDunkirk\u201d has eight. But leading the field is Guillermo del Toro\u2019s \u201cThe Shape of Water,\u201d with 12. Joanna Lumley will host the awards, taking over from Stephen Fry, who held the job for 12 years; stars are expected to wear black on the red carpet in support of the Time\u2019s Up initiative.\n\n60 MINUTES 7 p.m. on CBS. In this episode, Rex Tillerson, the secretary of state; discusses Syrian chemical attacks, his dealings with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, his hot-and-cold relationship with President Trump, and more.\n\n\n\nN.B.A. ALL-STAR GAME 8 p.m. on TNT. In recent years, the N.B.A.\u2019s all-star games have been far better in theory than execution, as superstars sluggishly jogged up and down the court, giving minimal effort on defense. The Commissioner Adam Silver designed a rule change this year to fire up the players by having rivals LeBron James and Stephen Curry pick their teams as if captains on the playground. And a couple pairs of former teammates whose relationships turned contentious will be reunited: Kevin Durant and Russell Westbrook (formerly of the Thunder), and James and Kyrie Irving (ex-runningmates on the Cavaliers).\n\nPhoto\n\nUNCENSORED 10 p.m. on TV One. It seems as if this is just the beginning for Tiffany Haddish, one of last year\u2019s breakout stars for her joyous, uproarious turn in \u201cGirl\u2019s Trip.\u201d She\u2019s become a late night circuit darling and the de facto face of Groupon, and is slated to co-star in a movie with Melissa McCarthy. She will be the first subject of this new docu-series, which explores the lives of personalities in culture: She discusses her ascent from foster care to hanging out backstage with Jay-Z and Beyonc\u00e9.\n\nLAST WEEK TONIGHT 11 p.m. on HBO. How can John Oliver keep up with the vicious news cycle in his weekly show, given that daily programs can barely stay on top of everything? By tweaking his focus. \u201cLots of times the main story we talk about is pretty irrelevant to the week, but pretty relevant, we would argue, to the concept of being alive,\u201d he said in a recent interview. He heads into his fifth season, fresh off a public spat in which he criticized Dustin Hoffman for his response to a sexual misconduct accusation. He will no doubt continue to be tenacious and unflinching toward big targets.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE JOEL McHALE SHOW WITH JOEL McHALE on Netflix. With a sheepish grin and biting wit, Joel McHale skewered pop culture on \u201cThe Soup\u201d for 12 seasons. As the show returns from a brief vacation \u2014 major spoilers ahead \u2014 Negan (Jeffrey Dean Morgan), the show\u2019s Big Bad, has firmly taken control in the \u201cAll Out War,\u201d and a showdown with Rick (Andrew Lincoln) looms in the distance. The biggest cliffhanger before the midseason break, however, didn\u2019t have to do with that confrontation, but rather with the plight of Rick\u2019s son, Carl (Chandler Riggs), who was bitten by a Walker and faces almost certain death. Some viewers weren\u2019t too happy about that: \u201cCarl\u2019s kinder tendencies have been a peg on which viewers could hang their hopes for a livable future, and the sting from having that possibility snatched away lingers,\u201d Charles Bramesco wrote in his recap in The New York Times.\n\n2018 PYEONGCHANG OLYMPICS 7 p.m. on NBC. It\u2019s closing time for the Winter Olympics, which featured the ascendance of new faces, like Adam Rippon, and lingering triumphs from familiar ones, like Shaun White. Simone Biles will carry the United States flag, and Ivanka Trump will be on hand to watch the ceremonies.\n\nFEAR FACTOR 7 p.m. on MTV. The terrifying and grotesque game show returns for its ninth season, with Ludacris serving as host. Justin Timberlake and Dua Lipa perform at the Brit Awards.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\n2018 WINTER OLYMPICS 8 p.m. on NBC. There\u2019s been plenty of drama outside the stadium walls leading up to the Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea, from a rule-bending North Korean ferry trip to a Norovirus outbreak. On Thursday, the focus will be on the Games themselves, as NBC broadcasts men\u2019s and pairs\u2019 figure skating and freestyle skiing. The 18-year-old figure skater Nathan Chen, who won the United States championships last month, hopes to land the gold. NBCSN will broadcast additional coverage, including curling and men\u2019s luge, also starting at 8.\n\nGREY\u2019S ANATOMY 8 p.m. on ABC. It\u2019s Shonda Night in America. On \u201cGrey\u2019s,\u201d April is in put in charge of a new surgical innovation contest. On SCANDAL at 9, Olivia Pope desperately tries to halt Mellie\u2019s plans to name Jake as her new chief of staff. And on HOW TO GET AWAY WITH MURDER, Annalise and her team continue to build her class-action lawsuit. (It remains to be seen whether Kobe Bryant will make an appearance this week.)\n\nHAPPY ENDING WITH NANDO VILA 10 p.m. on Fusion. The stock-market decline this week dented many bank accounts, but it came at an opportune time for Nando Vila. The first episode of his new political sketch comedy series is titled \u201cKilled by Capital\u201d; it uses a film noir lens to investigate capitalism and its effect on every facet of American life.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE GOOD, THE BAD AND THE UGLY (1967) on Amazon Prime and Hulu. Clint Eastwood\u2019s \u201cThe 15:17 to Paris\u201d comes to theaters on Friday. But before he ever got in the director\u2019s chair (or for that matter, talked to a chair), he left his mark on American cinema as the fearsome Man With No Name. Mr. Eastwood mugs and growls through Sergio Leone\u2019s spaghetti western, which arrived on Amazon Prime this month. It depicts a series of brutal skirmishes during the Civil War, as three gunslingers compete to unearth a stash of Confederate gold. Leone\u2019s filmmaking, depicting epic battles and an indelible three-way standoff, would forge a template for future action directors, while Ennio Morricone\u2019s brooding score remains unforgettable.\n\nPhoto\n\nWEINER (2016) on Hulu. When Anthony Weiner agreed to be the subject of a documentary in 2013, he envisioned it depicting his rise to becoming New York City\u2019s next mayor. Instead it captured his self-immolation. Its directors \u2014 Josh Kriegman, a former Weiner aide, and Elyse Steinberg \u2014 had front-row seats as revelations about Mr. Weiner\u2019s sexting habits derailed both his campaign and his marriage to Huma Abedin. The documentary spends much of its time on shocked faces behind closed doors, as campaign aides struggle to quell the media storm. In his Times review, Stephen Holden called the documentary \u201cinfuriating and depressing but rivetingly watchable.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Thursday: The Winter Olympics and the Brit Awards", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "The cast of \u201cRoseanne\u201d talks about its impending broadcast return. And Nathan Chen seeks redemption and a medal.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\n20/20: ROSEANNE: THE RETURN 10 p.m. on ABC. The reboot of \u201cRoseanne\u201d won\u2019t begin until next month, but it\u2019s already drawing tense headlines and protests because of Roseanne Barr\u2019s support for President Trump (in her character and in real life). \u201cI\u2019ve always had it be a true reflection of the society we live in,\u201d Ms. Barr said in January. \u201cHalf the country voted for him, half of them didn\u2019t.\u201d On this special, Ms. Barr and the rest of the cast (which includes John Goodman and the current Oscar nominee Laurie Metcalf) will sit down to address the direction of the new season, and talk about the legacy of its original nine.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Thursday: \u201820/20\u2019 With the \u2018Roseanne\u2019 Cast, and \u2018The Grey\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWith the Super Bowl three days away, a new documentary delves into Bill Belichick\u2019s relationship with his mentor, Bill Parcells. And the \u201cOcean\u2019s\u201d trilogy arrives on Netflix.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\n30 FOR 30: THE TWO BILLS 9 p.m. on ESPN. It\u2019s hard to imagine Bill Belichick coaching any team other than the New England Patriots, especially as he leads them to their eighth Super Bowl together on Sunday. But Mr. Belichick won two championships as defensive coordinator with the New York Giants under the tutelage of the head coach Bill Parcells. The two had a lasting partnership across three franchises, until Mr. Belichick betrayed his mentor to take the Patriots job in 2000. This documentary puts them back in the same room and pulls from an almost three-hour conversation, as the two fierce competitors reflect on their tumultuous decades-long relationship.\n\nPhoto\n\nA.P. BIO 9:30 p.m. on NBC. This new sitcom has intriguing firepower behind it, with Seth Meyers, Lorne Michaels and their former \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d colleague Mike O\u2019Brien as executive producers. Glenn Howerton (Dennis Reynolds on \u201cIt\u2019s Always Sunny in Philadelphia\u201d) plays to his strengths as an embittered, narcissistic former professor who washes out as an A.P. biology teacher in Ohio. (We really hope he won\u2019t be employing \u201cThe D.E.N.N.I.S. System\u201d as one of his teaching techniques.) And the perennial scene-stealer Patton Oswalt plays his principal. But early reviews have not been kind. (An hour earlier at 8:30, THE GOOD PLACE wraps up its second excellent season.)\n\nMYSTERIES AT THE MUSEUM 9 p.m. on the Travel Channel. Don Wildman hosts this series, which uses artifacts as a jumping-off point to investigate historical events. This episode focuses on the mob in America and visits Al Capone\u2019s jail cell in Philadelphia.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nOCEAN\u2019S TRILOGY on Netflix. Steven Soderbergh shot his forthcoming movie, \u201cUnsane,\u201d on an iPhone. His \u201cOcean\u2019s\u201d trilogy is decidedly higher-budget, with its casino set pieces, glimmering diamonds and, of course, names like Clooney, Pitt, Damon and Zeta-Jones. Each film builds toward one giant, improbable heist; the details aren\u2019t so important, but the actors, who also include Don Cheadle, Bernie Mac, Andy Garcia and Julia Roberts, make for good company along the way as they showboat, shimmy, roll dice and don prosthetics. All three films appear on Netflix on Thursday, with the first one (\u201cOcean\u2019s Eleven\u201d) receiving the strongest reviews.\n\nTHE HURT LOCKER (2008) on Hulu. Kathryn Bigelow\u2019s Iraq war film, which won six Oscars, including best picture, arrives on Hulu. It depicts American soldiers\u2019 brutal fight for survival in a war zone amid car bombs, clusters of shells and snipers. \u201cIf \u2018The Hurt Locker\u2019 is not the best action movie of the summer, I\u2019ll blow up my car,\u201d A. O. Scott wrote in his review in The New York Times. \u201cThe movie is a viscerally exciting, adrenaline-soaked tour de force of suspense and surprise.\u201d", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Thursday: \u201830 for 30\u2019 and \u2018A.P. Bio\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nStream a documentary about Muhammad Ali or a 1970s gang classic. And Oprah comes to Jimmy Kimmel Live!\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nI AM ALI (2014) on Netflix. You have a week to watch this Muhammad Ali documentary before it disappears from Netflix. It\u2019s built around private audiotapes Ali recorded for posterity, and focuses on his personal life, with interviews with his inner circle of family and friends, as well as George Foreman and Mike Tyson. \u201cThere\u2019s so much great vintage footage of Ali,\u201d Ben Kenigsberg wrote in his review in The New York Times. \u201cAnd he\u2019s so charismatic, it would be hard to watch the movie and not take something from it.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE WARRIORS (1979) on Amazon Prime. When this film was released, New York City still had the reputation of being a lawless landscape overrun by gang violence. The director, Walter Hill, takes a stylized approach to this material, with his street fighters in elaborate matching costumes, makeup and even roller skates. \u201cThe film is as handsome to watch as it is preposterous to listen to, full of gorgeous nocturnal city images that splash blaring neon colors against filthy, rain-slicked gray,\u201d Janet Maslin wrote in her review in The Times. A peaceful gang rally in the Bronx is upended when a leader is assassinated, and a gang called the Warriors is falsely accused of killing him. The movie follows the Warriors around the city as they\u2019re chased through streets and subway stations back to Coney Island.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\n2018 PYEONGCHANG OLYMPICS 8 p.m. on NBC. The American figure skater Mirai Nagasu will compete for gold in the free skate program, four years after she failed to make the team at Sochi and was presumed to have aged out of the competition. (\u201cI\u2019m not a fade-away kind of person,\u201d she told The Times in a recent interview.) Other events on Thursday include women\u2019s Alpine skiing and snowboarding, and short-track speedskating for men and women.\n\nPhoto\n\nNASHVILLE 9 p.m. on CMT. In the midseason finale, Daphne (Maisy Stella) auditions for a country music singing competition. Avery\u2019s band is invited to perform on late-night TV; he (Jonathan Jackson) and the rest of the band feel the consequences of choices by Will (Chris Carmack).\n\nJIMMY KIMMEL LIVE! 11:35 p.m. on ABC. Oprah Winfrey will appear on this late-night show ostensibly to talk about her appearance in the forthcoming film \u201cA Wrinkle in Time.\u201d But Mr. Kimmel may have other things on his mind. \u201cGiven the choice between Oprah and our current president, I\u2019m on the bus with Oprah traveling the country encouraging people to sign up and vote,\u201d he said last month. The other guest is Timoth\u00e9e Chalamet, who hopes to become the youngest best actor winner ever at the Oscars. And Andra Day and Common will perform after a rousing appearance at N.B.A. All-Star Weekend.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Thursday: \u2018Nashville\u2019 and Oprah on \u2018Jimmy Kimmel Live!\u2019", "authors": ["Andrew R. Chow"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Pixar\u2019s latest film arrives on Amazon. And \u201cThe Bachelor Winter Games\u201d begins on ABC.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nCOCO (2017) on iTunes and Amazon. Pixar\u2019s foray into death comes with this charming cartoon about Miguel (voiced by Anthony Gonzalez), a 12-year-old aspiring guitarist who wants nothing more than to be like Ernesto de la Cruz (Benjamin Bratt), a legendary Mexican musician. But Miguel\u2019s family \u2014 especially his shoe-throwing Abuelita \u2014 has a strict ban against music. When the departed are temporarily allowed into the land of the living during the Day of the Dead, Miguel finds himself between both metaphysical worlds, on a journey to uncover his musical potential and familial roots. The film \u201cplays a time-tested tune with captivating originality and flair, and with roving, playful pop-culture erudition,\u201d A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times.\n\nPAUL ROBESON: TRIBUTE TO AN ARTIST (1979) on FilmStruck. This Oscar-winning documentary short by Saul J. Turell celebrates the life of the singer, actor, activist and athlete Paul Robeson. In 1943, Robeson became the first black actor to play the role of Othello with a white supporting cast on Broadway. His most memorable work may be his rendition of \u201cOl\u2019 Man River\u201d in the film \u201cShow Boat.\u201d By later changing its lyrics, he transformed \u201ca half-ironic hymn to servility into an anthem of dignified resistance,\u201d Mr. Scott wrote in The Times.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Tuesday: \u2018Coco\u2019 and \u2018The Bachelor Winter Games\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nA Fred Armisen stand-up special debuts on Netflix. And \u201cThe Trade\u201d offers a diverse view of America\u2019s addiction crisis.\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nFRED ARMISEN: STANDUP FOR DRUMMERS (2018) on Netflix. Comedy and drumming have at least two things in common: they both revolve around timing and they\u2019re both activities done by Fred Armisen. Drums are a constant presence in the new Netflix special from this Portlandia co-creator and Saturday Night Live alum \u2014 both in the material and onstage. (There are multiple kits, which Mr. Armisen uses to do impressions of famous drummers, among other things.) He also provides commentary on life as a drummer, from feeling smug while walking through the airport with a snare drum to questioning how drummers treat cymbals when shopping (\u201cLike fine wine,\u201d he says). The set also features guest appearances from the drummers Tre Cool, Stella Mozgawa and Thomas Lang. Perhaps sensing that a set devoted exclusively to drum-centric humor would have limited marketability, Mr. Armisen also tackles such nondrum subjects as camping, American accents and feeling sorry for Burger King.\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE CHALLENGE (2017) on Amazon and Hulu. In this film, the director Yuri Ancarani documents the lives of a group of rich young Qatari falconers, whose routines involve transporting falcons in private jets, gathering to race SUVs over desert dunes and, in one case, offering up the passenger seat of a Lamborghini to an exotic pet. In his review for The New York Times, A.O. Scott wrote that Mr. Ancarani \u201cfilms their leisure pursuits with elegant gravity and understated \u2014 all but unstated \u2014 wit.\u201d\n\nWEINER (2016) on Amazon and Hulu. Elyse Steinberg and Josh Kriegman\u2019s documentary on the disgraced New York City mayoral candidate Anthony D. Weiner follows Mr. Weiner\u2019s pursuit of the 2013 Democratic nomination for mayor. The race was intended to be a comeback for Mr. Weiner, who had previously resigned from Congress in 2011 following a scandal over lewd online behavior. That story \u2014 as well as the trajectory of the 2013 race that also ends in scandal \u2014 will not be new to most viewers. But Ms. Steinberg and Mr. Kriegman\u2019s portrayal of it is, Stephen Holden wrote in his review for The Times, \u201cinfuriating and depressing but rivetingly watchable.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nTHE TRADE on Showtime streaming platforms. This ambitious documentary series offers a multifaceted look at America\u2019s opioid crisis by showcasing addicts, growers cartel members and members of law enforcement, who are all affected by it. Directed by Matthew Heineman (Cartel Land) and shot in the United States and Mexico, the series premiered last week, and the first episode is available to stream; the second episode will air on Showtime on Friday at 9 p.m.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nBEAT THE CLOCK 7:30 on Universal Kids. This kids\u2019 contest show is based on the format of the 1950s game show of the same name, and revolves around contestants competing to finish tasks in a limited amount of time. Kids and their family members work together on these challenges \u2014 like one requiring them to set a table while wearing boxing gloves.", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Tuesday: \u2018Fred Armisen: Standup for Drummers\u2019 and \u2018The Trade\u2019", "authors": ["Gabe Cohn"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThor: Ragnarok\u201d arrives on streaming services. And women lead a revolution in the newly restored fantasy film \u201cBorn in Flames.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nTHOR: RAGNAROK (2017) on iTunes, Amazon and FandangoNow. Marvel\u2019s latest in the Thor series finds the god of thunder (Chris Hemsworth) held captive on the planet Sakaar without his trusty hammer. Across the universe, his sister, Thela (Cate Blanchett), has descended on Asgard while the threat of Ragnarok \u2014 the end of Asgardian civilization \u2014 looms. But before he can save his home planet, Thor must win a gladiatorial battle against his old pal the Hulk (Mark Ruffalo). While \u201cthe Thor movies have been largely forgettable,\u201d Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, \u201c\u2018Ragnarok\u2019 tries hard to change that profile, and mostly succeeds by knocking its big, blond beauty consistently down to size.\u201d\n\nTHE FRANKENSTEIN CHRONICLES on Netflix. And Marlon Wayans returns to Netflix with a stand-up special.\n\nWhat\u2019s on TV\n\nUNSOLVED: THE MURDERS OF TUPAC AND THE NOTORIOUS B.I.G. 10 p.m. on USA. The rappers Tupac Shakur and Christopher Wallace, known as Biggie, were killed in drive-by shootings in 1996 (Tupac) and 1997 (Biggie). Their murder cases remain unsolved. This new true-crime series follows the dual investigations, led by Detective Greg Kading (Josh Duhamel) and Detective Russell Poole (Jimmi Simpson). In a conversation with Jon Caramanica of The New York Times, Salamishah Tillet, a writer and professor at the University of Pennsylvania, said she hoped programs like \u201cUnsolved\u201d would \u201cpressure the Los Angeles police to finally solve these murders, give the rappers\u2019 families some closure and get all of us who grew up with their deaths as our generational tragedy closer to the truth.\u201d\n\nWE\u2019LL MEET AGAIN 8 p.m. on PBS (check local listings). Ann Curry hosts this touching series that unites people who parted ways after historic events. In this series finale, two gay men seek the kind souls who helped them embrace their sexuality at the height of the gay rights movement.\n\nTHE PROFIT 10 p.m. on CNBC. In this season finale, the entrepreneur Marcus Lemonis takes a second stab at saving the Farrell\u2019s Ice Cream Parlour chain. He invested $750,000 in Season 4.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat\u2019s Streaming\n\nPhoto\n\nMARLON WAYANS: WOKE-ISH (2018) on Netflix. The comedian Marlon Wayans starred in the romantic comedy \u201cNaked,\u201d which arrived on Netflix last summer, and recently secured a second season of his family sitcom \u201cMarlon\u201d on NBC. This new no-holds-barred stand-up special unleashes his wilder side. Generous with his expletives, Mr. Wayans riffs on racism in America, shares his parenting methods and compares Donald Trump to Flavor Flav, the clock-wearing Public Enemy member and reality-TV personality.\n\nPhoto\n\nBREATHLESS (1960) on iTunes and FilmStruck. Jean-Luc Godard laid the groundwork for the French New Wave with this jazzy debut feature. After killing a police officer and stealing a car, a French hoodlum (Jean-Paul Belmondo) gets together with his American lover (Jean Seberg) before his cover is blown. Fans of this classic admire it not for its plot but for its groundbreaking style, cultural references and eccentric score. \u201cIt is certainly no clich\u00e9,\u201d Bosley Crowther wrote in The Times. \u201cIt is more a chunk of raw drama, graphically and artfully torn with appropriately ragged edges out of the tough underbelly of modern metropolitan life.\u201d\n\nPUNCH-DRUNK LOVE (2002) on iTunes, Amazon and Hulu. Adam Sandler stars as Barry, a socially awkward salesman whose mundane life (he sells wholesale bathroom supplies out of a warehouse) is transformed by his introduction to Lena (Emily Watson). Empowered by their love, Barry finds strength to overcome his seven sisters\u2019 relentless bullying and foil an extortion scheme plotted by a phone-sex entrepreneur (Philip Seymour Hoffman).", "title": "What\u2019s on TV Tuesday: \u2018Unsolved\u2019 and \u2018Marlon Wayans: Woke-ish\u2019", "authors": ["Sara Aridi"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Dua Lipa and Justin Timberlake perform at the Brit Awards.
