What happens when, say, an Eric Reid, a mainstay at safety for the 49ers for the last five seasons, becomes a free agent this winter? \u201cHow do we make sure this doesn\u2019t happen to anyone else?\u201d Okung, who also left the coalition, asked me, referring to Kaepernick\u2019s situation. \u201cReparations need to be made in some manner.\u201d Still, many players and owners I spoke to seemed to give Goodell the benefit of the doubt. \u201cI think he handled things as well as you could expect in this situation,\u201d Mara told me.\n\nBut while Goodell and the N.F.L. may have survived 2017, the commissioner and his league seem to be at the mercy of very uncertain and uncontrollable events in the future. The conflicts of 1982 that Goodell evoked might have been more dramatic and certainly \u201cdistracting\u201d \u2014 that year\u2019s regular season was shrunk to nine games on account of a players\u2019 strike. But they were also more easily resolved. The dilemmas of 2017 were more profound: There was no obvious common ground between Jerry Jones\u2019s vision of the football field as a \u201crespite\u201d and Kaepernick\u2019s vision of it as a platform. The players weren\u2019t kneeling to gain leverage or extract donations, or anything else Goodell or anyone in the league could give them. They were trying to make themselves heard. \u201cI talked to a lot of players who were saying, \u2018Man, I don\u2019t need to be quieter, I need to be louder,\u2019\u201d the Bengals\u2019 Eric Winston, the union president, told me. \u201cThat to me was the key takeaway from this season.\u201d And what happens if an owner like Jones decides to take matters into his own hands and \u201cfire\u201d players if their protests continue?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOur focus is on what we do,\u201d Goodell said, punting, when I asked him to speculate. \u201cAnd always trying to figure out the best way to get ahead of issues and focusing on what we can control.\u201d I pushed further: What happens if next season comes around and a handful of players are still kneeling and protesting? What if Trump tries to rekindle the issue, as you figure he\u2019d love to do, just in time for the 2018 midterm elections \u2014 or, for that matter, fires off a tweet calling on viewers to turn off the Super Bowl in the event that any players kneel, prompting the players to do exactly that?\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re dealing with hypotheticals,\u201d Goodell said. \u201cYou can come up with five scenarios of what could happen.\u201d\n\nFootball is always generating new scenarios. That\u2019s part of what makes it so great and so fascinating. But not all scenarios stay between the sidelines \u2014 or stay hypothetical.", "title": "Where Does the N.F.L. Go After a Season of Division?", "authors": ["Mark Leibovich"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Downtown, on the sidewalk outside the Oscar de la Renta show during New York Fashion Week, one photographer stands out among the many clamoring to get a picture of the model Theodora Quinlivan, known as Teddy, as she leaves the show. Wearing a bright pink Julian David coat, the street-style photographer Phil Oh is beloved by the many fashion editors and models who stop to greet him as they leave the show.\n\nMr. Oh has been working as the street-style photographer for Vogue.com\u2019s coverage of fashion weeks in New York, London, Paris and Milan for eight years. He was contacted by the magazine after the success of \u201cStreetpeeper,\u201d a street-style blog that he started in 2007. Four times a year, Mr. Oh spends a month standing outside fashion shows sometimes for eight hours a day \u2014 to capture guests as they arrive at or leave a show.\n\n\u201cFashion usually exists in a bubble,\u201d he explains. \u201cThese fashion shows are one of the few times when fashion and the real world intersect just for a little sidewalk on Sixth Avenue between the show venue and the model\u2019s car.\u201d\n\nGareth Smit is a South African documentary photographer and filmmaker based in New York.\n\nFollow @Gareth_smit and @nytimesphoto on Twitter. Gareth Smit is also on Instagram. You can also find Lens on Facebook and Instagram.", "title": "Where Fashion Photography Meets the Streets", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Many factors can cause traffic deaths to rise, and safety experts say the increases in recent years are partly a byproduct of recovery from the recession. \u201cPeople are driving more when the economy is growing,\u201d Mr. Retting said. Populations are rising in urban areas where most pedestrian fatalities occur, and cities are more congested.\n\nBut this year, the group also called attention to the numbers for states that legalized recreational marijuana between 2012 and 2016 \u2014 Alaska, Colorado, Maine, Massachusetts, Nevada, Oregon and Washington \u2014 as well as the District of Columbia, which did likewise.\n\nIn Alaska and Maine, pedestrian deaths are so few that any changes may not be statistically sufficient to identify a clear connection to the drug. Even in Colorado, a 12 percent jump in pedestrian deaths meant the total rose to 37 in the first half of last year, from 33 in 2016. Massachusetts was the only state in the group where such deaths decreased \u2014 by one.\n\n\u201cI\u2019d be cautious about drawing a direct link to any potential cause,\u201d said Jason Levine, executive director at the Center for Auto Safety, an advocacy group in Washington, D.C. \u201cBut it\u2019s certainly worth trying to figure out why those numbers are what they are.\u201d\n\nAmong the unanswered questions is whether and to what extent any link reflects marijuana use by drivers, pedestrians or both.", "title": "Where Pedestrian Deaths Are Up, Is Marijuana to Blame?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nJoshua Jodoin left New York for Alhambra, Calif., in 2013 to explore new career opportunities in the online gaming community. But recently, he had returned to the East Coast to see a doctor for his injured thumb, caused by his joystick grip.\n\nWhat was supposed to take a few days, however, turned into a few months. Mr. Jodoin, who goes by \u201cNerdJosh\u201d online and is a member of Team Spooky, the fighting game live-streaming group, had gotten lured back into his old scene at Next Level, a competitive arcade in Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn.\n\nPhoto\n\nA fan of games like Capcom vs. SNK 2, Mr. Jodoin said that Next Level is exciting because it attracts top talent and cultivates a community where up-and-comers can train to become future champions.\n\n\u201cThis environment has allowed so many people you wouldn\u2019t expect to come up from No. 2,\u201d Mr. Jodoin, 31, said, explaining how dark horse challengers have outcompeted top-ranked fighters in the humble Brooklyn space.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the evenings, competitive and amateur gamers alike, ranging in age from teens to 30-somethings, come to play, many armed with their own controllers and card decks. They sit at retro-style gaming cabinets or television screens, mashing buttons and flicking their wrists in bursts of 99 seconds or less. Every once in a while you\u2019ll hear a glitch-laden wail or adrenaline-fueled scream. For those who prefer trading card games like Magic: The Gathering or Yu-Gi-Oh!, whole evenings can be dedicated to sitting at white foldable tables, covered in kaleidoscopic card playmats.\n\nPhoto\n\nHenry Cen, 38, is a former manager of Chinatown Fair on Mott Street, which had been a bastion for New York\u2019s declining arcade scene until it closed in 2011. And it has significant resources at its disposal as part of the N.R.A.\u2019s far-reaching \u201cmembership support\u201d program. In recent years, that operation alone spent $35.5 million, according to its most recent publicly available tax filing.\n\nBut it is just the newest piece of a larger news media operation inside the N.R.A. that receives little attention compared with the group\u2019s political and lobbying activity. The organization produces at least seven print and online magazines that have a combined circulation of more than 11 million, according to the N.R.A. Its biggest social media channels on Facebook and Twitter count about 8.7 million followers. On YouTube, five N.R.A.-controlled channels have shared videos that have received nearly 102 million views.\n\nAndrew Arulanandam, a spokesman for the N.R.A., declined to discuss the media effort, the size of its online audience or its programming in the wake of the Parkland shooting. As a matter of policy, he said, the N.R.A. does not discuss proprietary matters.\n\nNRATV is a budding business for the organization, which has brokered sponsorship arrangements with gun makers like Kimber, Mossberg and Ruger to feature their firearms on its programs. Its series cover a range of topics and interests intended to appeal to gun owners of all kinds, like \u201cArmed and Fabulous,\u201d which profiles rifle-slinging women; \u201cFrontlines,\u201d a newsmagazine hosted by Oliver North; and \u201cUnder Wild Skies,\u201d which follows hunters in pursuit of big-game trophies.\n\nBut politics and provocation are NRATV\u2019s specialty. Speaks First and Loudest", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Between 2006 and 2016, there was a significant increase in the number of renters nationwide. According to an analysis of United States Census Bureau data by the rental listings site RentCafe, by 2016, roughly 23 million additional people were living in rentals \u2014 or nearly the same number of people that the country\u2019s overall population rose by in that decade (23.7 million).\n\nIn 2006, 20 of the country\u2019s 100 largest cities had more renters than homeowners. By 2016, that number had grown to 42. Of those cities, Newark had the largest share of renters (74 percent), followed by Jersey City, (70 percent), Miami (68 percent), New York (65 percent), and Boston (64 percent).\n\nWhich cities recently joined the list? Here are the 22 new renter-majority areas, ranked by the greatest proportional increases. Two by Ivor Prickett were from Mosul, while Adam Ferguson took one of a girl enlisted as a Boko Haram suicide bomber. He found the shooting suspect, Nikolas Cruz, 19, in a stairwell between the first and second floors in the freshman building.\n\nSitting on the stairs, Mr. Cruz was loading a semiautomatic AR-15 rifle, Chris said.\n\nMr. Cruz appeared \u201cshocked\u201d when he opened the door to the stairwell, Chris said. \u201cI don\u2019t think he expected me to see him at all,\u201d he said, as Mr. Cruz was loading the gun.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe told me, \u2018Better get out of here, things are about to get messy,\u2019\u201d Chris said.\n\nChris, who said he did not know Mr. Cruz, left the stairwell, heading outside, where he ran into Aaron Feis, an assistant football coach and security monitor, at a school gate. After Chris told Mr. Feis what he had seen, Mr. Feis drove him in a golf cart to a baseball field about 500 feet away. Levin, the councilman who represents the area. Mr. Levin said that he was trying to hammer out a compromise with the landlord, so far with no success.\n\n\u201cWhat has been done to these tenants is unconscionable,\u201d said Joseph Soldevere, a spokesman for the city\u2019s Department of Buildings. \u201cUnfortunately, what this case represents above all,\u201d said Mr. Soldevere, \u201cis that owners, particularly using the legal process, can draw things out even when the city brings out all the guns we have.\u201d\n\nAfter the inspector first came to 94 Franklin Avenue, the landlord, the Tiferes Yehuda Family Trust, filed plans to make improvements to the tenants\u2019 building. The proposal lacked several key changes, and the city rejected it. The landlord returned with new plans in 2016, but they too were incomplete, failing to account for emergency exits and missing floor plans. The city also rejected this proposal.\n\nAt that point, the Buildings Department issued a criminal court summons against the landlord. The case dragged on for a year, with both sides having to make more than half a dozen court appearances. Finally, last September, the trustees of the Tiferes Yehuda Family Trust, Esther and Joseph Schneebalg, pleaded guilty to failing to maintain a safe building for the tenants and to working without a permit.\n\nThe Schneebalgs were each fined $15,000, and the trust was fined an additional $20,000. This was on top of $14,000 in fines levied against the building over the previous months. The trust now has a new trustee, Meir Schwartz. As of late January, none of the $64,000 in fines had been paid, according to the Buildings Department.\n\nLast August, the city had finally approved a plan submitted by the landlord to repair and bring the entire site up to code. This would also make the synagogue legal. The squat, yellow structure, which takes up the space where the backyard had been, is accessible only by entering the front door of 94 Franklin Avenue. The synagogue is being built for some 100 congregants from the neighborhood, who had been searching for several years for a new home, said Meryl L. Wenig, the lawyer representing Mr. Schwartz, of the Tiferes Yehuda trust. Yet at the moment, the building, like Ms. Torres\u2019s apartment building, is not being used. A visit to the site on a recent Friday night, when observant Jews attend Sabbath services, found it padlocked.\n\nLast month, an inspector from the Buildings Department visited 94 Franklin to check on the renovations. He discovered that the contractor hired by the landlord was busy making improvements to the synagogue but had not completed any work on the apartments.", "title": "While the Landlord Renovates, Life in a Homeless Shelter", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Oliver spoke further about the coming season of \u201cLast Week Tonight\u201d and his exchange with Mr. Hoffman. These are edited excerpts from the conversation.\n\nAt this time last year, you spoke about not wanting \u201cLast Week Tonight\u201d to be overrun by coverage of President Trump. Do you think you succeeded?\n\nI was quite anxious that we protect the main body of our show from being cannibalized by him. So, I think we were able to do that. We tried to contain talking about whatever he had done that week \u2014 to the extent that we could \u2014 to the first section of the show, leaving the majority of the show for those long pieces that have nothing to do with him. Still, it\u2019s hard to ignore the president, right? Even though we did a piece on vaccines, he was in that, only because the president has expressed vaccine skepticism. It felt irresponsible not to mention the fact that there is someone in the Oval Office who\u2019s expressed skepticism for vaccines, which is dangerous.\n\nA year into this administration, do you feel a certain futility in your task, that all this satirical sunlight you\u2019re providing is not serving as any kind of disinfectant?\n\nWhen we take a position, we try to keep people on board who might disagree, so that at least they can watch our thought process. We don\u2019t want to be another haranguing voice, which turns people off. We did a long piece about the Confederacy, and I understand that people have different feelings about what those monuments mean. We didn\u2019t want to do the shorthand, which is \u201cblah, blah, blah, you\u2019re all wrong, they\u2019ve got to come down.\u201d We tried to explain who Jimmy Savile is, who was a genuine hero in Britain, who we had built statues of because he was so iconic. Then his memory became recontextualized when it turned out he had done terrible things and those statues had to come down. When you talk about that for a few minutes, you get people to at least buy into the idea that history can recontextualize people\u2019s actions. Then, hopefully, you\u2019ve approached it in a way that you\u2019re working from a basic point of agreement. Even if you don\u2019t agree with our conclusions at the end of it.", "title": "While \u2018Last Week Tonight\u2019 Was Away, John Oliver Was Busy", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIn 2013, John F. Kelly, a general at the time, defended a junior Marine officer who was accused of poor leadership after going on patrol in Afghanistan with team members who urinated on the bodies of three dead Taliban militants. Two years later, in 2015, he stood up for a Marine colonel facing a litany of charges, including sexual harassment.\n\nNow the White House chief of staff, Mr. Kelly has come to the defense of a subordinate, engulfing him in a Trump administration crisis that could lead to his own undoing.\n\nWhen accusations surfaced this week that Rob Porter, the White House staff secretary, had physically abused his two former wives, Mr. Kelly described the aide as \u201ca friend, a confidant and a trusted professional.\u201d He later said that he was \u201cshocked\u201d by the allegations \u2014 which spurred the release of a photograph of one of Mr. Porter\u2019s former wives with a black eye \u2014 and said, \u201cthere is no place for domestic violence in our society.\u201d\n\nMr. Porter resigned on Wednesday.\n\nMr. Kelly did not personally know the Marine he defended in the 2013 investigation that focused on the 2011 desecration of the Taliban bodies. In an interview on Friday, James V. Clement, who was the captain facing charges, said Mr. Kelly must have seen something in his case that spurred him to step up.\n\n\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cHe didn\u2019t care that I was accused of something. He cared about speaking about the facts he was aware of,\u201d said Mr. Clement, who later left the Marines.", "title": "White House Chief of Staff Is a Longtime Defender of the Accused", "authors": ["Thomas Gibbons-Neff"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Faced with unrelenting interference in its election systems, the United States has not forced Russia to pay enough of a price to persuade President Vladimir V. Putin to stop meddling, a senior American intelligence official said on Tuesday.\n\nAdm. Michael S. Rogers, the departing head of the National Security Agency and the military\u2019s Cyber Command, said that he was using the authorities he had to combat the Russian attacks. But under questioning during testimony before the Senate Armed Services Committee, he acknowledged that the White House had not asked his agencies \u2014 the main American spy and defense arms charged with conducting cyberoperations \u2014 to find ways to counter Moscow, or granted them new authorities to do so.\n\n\u201cPresident Putin has clearly come to the conclusion that there\u2019s little price to pay and that therefore \u2018I can continue this activity,\u2019\u201d said Admiral Rogers, who is set to retire in April. \u201cClearly what we have done hasn\u2019t been enough.\u201d\n\nAdmiral Rogers\u2019s testimony was the second time this month that a senior American intelligence official had said that Russia\u2019s efforts to meddle in American elections did not end in 2016, and that the Trump administration had taken no extraordinary steps to stop them. He and other intelligence leaders warned two weeks ago on Capitol Hill that Russia was using a digital strategy to worsen political and social divisions in the United States, and all the intelligence chiefs said they had not been expressly asked by the White House to find a way to punish Russia for its efforts.", "title": "White House Has Given No Orders to Counter Russian Meddling, N.S.A. Chief Says", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "According to Mr. Wray, the F.B.I. updated the White House three times in 2017 \u2014 in March, July and November \u2014 about Mr. Porter\u2019s background check as it progressed. Mr. Wray did not disclose the information that was given to the White House at those times, but according to two people briefed on the matter, the F.B.I. first provided the White House in July with a rundown of the spousal abuse allegations the bureau had uncovered against Mr. Porter.\n\nVideo\n\nIn November, the F.B.I. provided the White House with additional information about the allegations.\n\nMs. Sanders insisted Tuesday that senior West Wing officials had not learned about the allegations against Mr. Porter until they surfaced in The Daily Mail because the F.B.I. gave the information to the White House Personnel Security Office, which handles security clearances. The office is in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building next door to the White House and is overseen by Joe Hagin, the deputy chief of staff.\n\nMs. Sanders said that the security office \u2014 which she repeatedly noted was staffed by \u201ccareer officials,\u201d who would not have been appointed by Mr. Trump \u2014 had not yet made a final determination on whether Mr. Porter should receive his security clearance at the time of The Mail\u2019s article.\n\nStill, pressed on whether senior officials \u2014 including John F. Kelly, the chief of staff; Donald F. McGahn II, the White House counsel; and Mr. Hagin \u2014 could have been unaware as far back as last summer that such a significant issue had been raised about one of the president\u2019s closest aides, she conceded she could not be certain.\n\n\u201cNot that I\u2019m aware of,\u201d Ms. Sanders said. \u201cI can\u2019t say with 100 percent certainty.\u201d\n\nAccording to the two people briefed on the matter, the White House security office reviewed the allegations about Mr. Porter in July and saw that the F.B.I. had interviewed Mr. Porter\u2019s two former wives but not Mr. Porter himself. The office asked the F.B.I. to go back and do so, said the two people, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss the case.\n\nIn November, the F.B.I. provided another report to the security office, the two people said, adding that at that point, a final review began to determine whether to grant Mr. Porter a security clearance. As part of that review, three officials in the personnel office, including its head, were supposed to come to their own conclusions about whether to grant the clearance, the people said.\n\nBy the time The Mail published its article last week, only one of those officials had made a determination, the two people said, although it is not clear what the official had concluded.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn late November last year, a distraught girlfriend of Mr. Porter\u2019s contacted Mr. McGahn and told him Mr. Porter had been unfaithful to her by dating Hope Hicks, the White House communications director, and had anger problems, according to several people familiar with the discussion. Mr. McGahn, who knew Mr. Porter\u2019s girlfriend, at that point suggested to Mr. Porter he should consider leaving the White House, the people said. But Mr. McGahn did not follow up on the matter.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nOne former White House official, Anthony Scaramucci, who lasted 10 days last year as White House communications director before being removed by Mr. Kelly, weighed in on Tuesday on Mr. Wray\u2019s testimony. Mr. Scaramucci posted on Twitter that Mr. Kelly \u201calmost certainly knew about credible allegations of domestic abuse against Rob Porter at least 6 months ago - then recently forced others to lie about that timeline.\u201d\n\n\u201cInexcusable,\u201d Mr. Scaramucci added. \u201cKelly must resign.\u201d\n\nMs. Sanders said Mr. Trump maintained confidence in Mr. Kelly, who told The Wall Street Journal on Tuesday that he had no regrets about how Mr. Porter\u2019s case was handled, adding that \u201cit was all done right.\u201d\n\nMr. Porter, who as staff secretary handled all of the documents that made their way to the president, had in the weeks before the allegations been seeking an expanded portfolio in the West Wing, where experienced aides who can bring order to a chaotic operation are in short supply.\n\nMr. Trump\u2019s aides initially said they had no inkling of the accusations against Mr. Porter until the reports in The Mail, and said they acted swiftly to terminate him when they discovered them. In fact, the White House spent the first hours after learning of the accusations \u2014 including the publication of photographs of one of Mr. Porter\u2019s former wives with a black eye she said he had given her \u2014 defending Mr. Porter against the allegations and insisting that he was not being dismissed.\n\nEven after Mr. Kelly changed his stance, calling the allegations vile and orchestrating Mr. Porter\u2019s swift departure, the president has stuck up for Mr. Porter publicly, telling reporters that the situation had been \u201ctough\u201d and \u201csad\u201d for Mr. Porter. The president insisted that Mr. Porter had denied the accusations, and wished him a successful career. On Tuesday, asked by reporters at a White House event with sheriffs if he had a message for victims of abuse, Mr. Trump declined to answer.\n\nOn Capitol Hill, lawmakers in both parties criticized how the White House had handled the episode.\n\n\u201cA lot of us are concerned about what has come to light in terms of these background checks \u2014 how long they take, how long somebody can be in an interim status and still have access to classified material,\u201d said Senator Jeff Flake, Republican of Arizona. He said the scandal had exacerbated a generational divide that was already plaguing the party.\n\nSenator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York, said Mr. Trump, who dispatched Ms. Sanders yesterday to denounce domestic violence but has not addressed the matter himself, had missed an opportunity.\n\n\u201cI haven\u2019t heard the president say something directly about how bad domestic abuse is,\u201d he told reporters on Tuesday. \u201cYou know, to have a spokesperson get out and say something is not good enough.\u201d", "title": "White House Let Rob Porter Keep Job Even After Receiving Final F.B.I. Report", "authors": ["Julie Hirschfeld Davis", "Michael D. Shear"]} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "The assumptions in Monday\u2019s release are also significantly more optimistic than the Trump administration itself used in its budget calculations last year.\n\nMost notably, the administration projected annualized economic growth of 3.1 percent over the next three years. In December, the Federal Reserve projected annualized growth of 2.2 percent over that period. The Survey of Professional Forecasters estimated the annualized growth rate to be about 2.4 percent.\n\nThe centerpiece of Mr. Trump\u2019s budget is a plan to devote $200 billion over the next decade in new spending to improve the country\u2019s crumbling infrastructure, starting with $44.6 billion in 2019. The president says the plan will generate as much as $1.5 trillion to $1.7 trillion in new investments in building roads, bridges and other major projects over the next 10 years, in large part relying on states, cities and private companies to fund them. But the proposal faces steep challenges in Congress, where many lawmakers believe $200 billion is far too little to create a sustainable stream of federal infrastructure money for the future.\n\n\u201cWe will build, we will maintain, and the vast majority of Americans wants to see us take care of our infrastructure,\u201d Mr. Trump said Monday at the White House as he released an outline of the plan and discussed it with cabinet officials, governors and local leaders. \u201cWashington will no longer be a roadblock to progress; Washington will now be your partner.\u201d\n\nStill, the budget compensates for the new infusion of infrastructure spending in part by slashing existing transportation programs, which would be cut by $178 billion over a decade, according to a detailed budget breakdown the Trump administration sent Monday to Capitol Hill. Grants to Amtrak would be halved, from $1.2 trillion to $538 billion, while the Army Corps of Engineers, which manages vast amounts of public infrastructure projects, would see a more than 20 percent cut.\n\nLawmakers in both parties, who essentially went around Mr. Trump to strike their own budget compromise, made it clear they had no intention of embracing Mr. Trump\u2019s plan.\n\nRepresentative Kevin Cramer, Republican of North Dakota, denounced \u201cdrastic cuts\u201d to the federal crop insurance program, calling them \u201cill advised.\u201d Representative Ed Royce, Republican of California and the chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, said lawmakers in both parties would once again reject the president\u2019s \u201cdeep cuts\u201d to the State Department and foreign aid.", "title": "White House Proposes $4.4 Trillion Budget That Adds $7 Trillion to Deficits", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "There would be much to investigate. A few senior officials in the West Wing had access to details of the allegations of physical and emotional abuse made by Mr. Porter\u2019s ex-wives. A greater number of people had a sense that something was amiss, but chose to avert their gaze instead of asking questions.\n\nThe first hours after the issue was brought to light by an article in The Daily Mail were a confused blur, with officials like Mr. Kelly at first endorsing Mr. Porter\u2019s resignation, but then agreeing to issue statements in support of him. That disarray belied the belief of some in the White House that someone \u2014 Mr. Kelly \u2014 was finally in charge after six months of drama and infighting in 2017. In reality, these officials now concede, no one truly was.\n\n\u201cThey haven\u2019t figured out how the place operates, and apparently they don\u2019t want to learn,\u201d said John Dean, a White House counsel under President Richard M. Nixon. The Porter situation, he added, \u201cis a manifestation of what happens when you have chaos.\u201d\n\nMr. Kelly, a four-star Marine general, had been billed as uniquely qualified to bring order to Mr. Trump\u2019s world when he took his post in July. Now he faces a morale crisis in the West Wing, where aides describe a sense of betrayal by a chief of staff they no longer trust after his claims that he had not fully known about Mr. Porter\u2019s problems and had acted within minutes once he learned of them.\n\nBut above all, White House veterans say, President Trump is responsible for the haphazard nature with which his operation has functioned, in part because he knew and cared little for the rules and norms that govern the executive branch. Unprepared to fill the ranks of a new administration, Mr. Trump never tried to set a tone of discipline or ethical rigor in his West Wing.\n\n\u201cA White House reflects the president,\u201d said William M. Daley, a chief of staff under Mr. Obama. \u201cSo he moves on to the next scandal, crisis, attack, whatever, and no self-reflection. So why should anyone be surprised that that sort of becomes the M.O., even when there\u2019s a belief that there\u2019s institutional stuff one should consider.\u201d\n\nFor 13 months, Mr. Trump\u2019s aides have approached their mercurial and process-averse boss by putting their heads down and ignoring what they could not control, avoiding information that could rattle their daily balance.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut in the case of Mr. Porter, White House aides privately acknowledge, some advisers appear to have chosen to try to protect a colleague who was generally well liked and, more important, too competent to lose. Mr. Trump himself often expressed his regard for Mr. Porter by describing him as \u201cout of central casting.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nIn the hours after the allegations against Mr. Porter became public, some senior officials in fact hesitated to force him out, in part because they argued that if one top adviser could be felled by accusations, they could all potentially be vulnerable. Mr. Porter denied privately to his colleagues, as well as publicly, that he had ever physically abused his wives.\n\nWhat distinguished this crisis from the ones that preceded it was that it was not localized to one official, such as Stephen K. Bannon, the isolated chief strategist who left in August, or Reince Priebus, the often uninformed chief of staff who departed a month before that. Mr. Porter\u2019s case had spread to so many aspects of the White House that it ensnared a number of staff members.\n\nWhile multiple officials in the West Wing were aware that he had been unable to pass his background check, none appear to have made an effort to ascertain precisely why and take action on it. Several former White House counsels have said they would have made it their business to know if an official at Mr. Porter\u2019s level was facing allegations as serious as domestic abuse, but officials in the White House have privately maintained that Donald F. McGahn II, the White House counsel, never did.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cThey plainly abided a situation that was intolerable, and they shouldn\u2019t have done it,\u201d said Robert F. Bauer, a White House counsel under President Barack Obama.\n\nC. Boyden Gray, who served as White House counsel under President George Bush, said the problems might have been exacerbated by the existence of the special counsel investigation into Russian election meddling and potential Trump campaign ties to it.\n\nMr. McGahn and other senior officials may be reluctant to engage with the F.B.I. or the Justice Department on security clearances or any other matter, for fear of being drawn into the inquiry, he said. \u201cYou just didn\u2019t want to call the F.B.I. or call the D.O.J. on any subject, Russia or not,\u201d Mr. Gray said of officials in the West Wing. \u201cThat may have contributed to the breakdown here.\u201d\n\nWhat\u2019s more, Mr. Trump has been in open war with the F.B.I. for months, a fact that some West Wing aides believe contributed to the debacle.\n\nThe dismissal on Wednesday of George David Banks, who was the White House point person on climate change, was seen as a particularly galling move after 13 months in which nobody in the West Wing had seemed particularly concerned about enforcing a standard for past conduct.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Banks had been told that he would not be granted a full security clearance. In an interview, he said the reason was that he had smoked marijuana a handful of times between 2010 and 2013, conduct that he said he had self-reported to the F.B.I. nearly a year ago.\n\n\u201cIt was unbelievable,\u201d Mr. Banks said of the decision to deny him a clearance, which he learned about abruptly at the end of a workday, when an official from Mr. McGahn\u2019s office and a human resources aide asked for a meeting later that evening. After informing him of their decision and allowing Mr. Banks to resign, they asked him to gather his things and escorted him from the premises.\n\nInside the West Wing, officials said, Mr. Banks is seen as collateral damage in a belated effort by Mr. Kelly and other top officials to show they are cracking down on interim security clearances.\n\nYet former White House advisers from both parties have been mystified at the ineptitude of Mr. Trump\u2019s team in dealing with the fallout from Mr. Porter\u2019s situation.\n\nPart of the problem, they argue, is a culture at the White House that does not appear to prioritize getting at the truth.\n\n\u201cThe fundamentals of Crisis Management 101 were certainly not observed here, but more importantly, there does not seem to be a priority on marshaling and disclosing the facts, whatever they may be,\u201d said Jack Quinn, who served as White House counsel under Bill Clinton during the Monica Lewinsky affair. \u201cThey need to stop the bleeding, and I think that they\u2019ve got to understand that the bleeding is not going to stop until the full truth is told.\u201d", "title": "White House Seeks to Move On From Abuse Scandal. But What Did It Learn?", "authors": ["Maggie Haberman", "Julie Hirschfeld Davis"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 David Sorensen, a White House speechwriter, resigned on Friday after a news report detailed accusations from a former wife who said he had abused her during their marriage.\n\nHis resignation came two days after Rob Porter, the White House staff secretary, submitted his own resignation after his two former wives publicly accused him of being abusive to them when they were married.\n\nIn an interview in The Washington Post, Mr. Sorensen\u2019s former wife, Jessica Corbett, detailed a volatile two-and-a-half-year marriage in which Mr. Sorensen ran over her foot while driving a car and put out a lit cigarette on her hand. Their divorce became final last fall. Ms. Corbett said she described those episodes to the F.B.I. last fall as it was conducting a background check of Mr. Sorensen, according to The Post.\n\nMr. Sorensen denied Ms. Corbett\u2019s account, and insisted that she was the abuser. Responding to a Facebook message on Friday evening, Mr. Sorensen called his former wife \u201ccreative\u201d and later emailed a lengthy statement disputing her account. confrontations.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe added, \u201cAlthough I had hoped to never have to think about or discuss the woman who spent years physically attacking, "text": "He noted that Mr. Kushner had been working to broker peace in the Middle East. \u201cThe hardest deal to make of any kind is between the Israelis and the Palestinians,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re actually making great headway.\u201d\n\nMr. Kelly, who has tried to inject discipline and order into Mr. Trump\u2019s freewheeling West Wing, has bristled from the start at Mr. Kushner\u2019s amorphous and omnipresent role, and Mr. Kushner has been angered in turn at what he regards as challenges to his authority and access.\n\nThe strains have deepened in recent days, as Mr. Kushner and his wife, Ivanka Trump, have privately disparaged the chief of staff to Mr. Trump, faulting his handling of the scandal surrounding Mr. Porter, the staff secretary who resigned under pressure after spousal abuse allegations became public.\n\nMr. Kelly\u2019s memo further inflamed the situation, essentially suggesting that Mr. Kushner might lose the high-level clearance \u2014 including to view the presidential daily brief, a summary of intelligence and other sensitive information \u2014 that he has enjoyed for more than a year.\n\nAt his news conference, Mr. Trump blamed the federal government for the delay on the security clearance, saying there was a \u201cbroken system,\u201d and that it took too long for White House employees to have their backgrounds screened by investigators. He complained that it had taken \u201cmonths and months and months\u201d for some of his staff members to be given their security clearances, despite the fact that some of them do not have complicated financial backgrounds \u2014 a factor that sometimes delays background investigations.\n\nWhile the federal security clearance system has long been criticized as broken and has a backlog of hundreds of thousands of pending applications, senior White House officials almost always have their applications expedited so they can be cleared within weeks and perform their duties.\n\nIt is highly unusual for multiple senior officials to spend months serving with only interim clearances, a problem that Mr. Kelly privately began talking about fixing in September.\n\nMr. Kushner met with Robert S. Mueller III\u2019s investigators briefly last year to discuss his dealings with the former national security adviser, Michael T. Flynn. The interview led Mr. Kushner\u2019s lawyers to believe that he was considered a witness, not a target, in the special counsel investigation.", "title": "White House Told Kushner\u2019s Security Clearance Will Be Delayed", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "After General McMaster left the room, Mr. Mattis and Mr. Tillerson continued to speak, not realizing that other participants were still on the line. The officials familiar with the matter overheard them complaining about a series of meetings that the National Security Council had set up to consider options for North Korea \u2014 signs, Mr. Tillerson said, that it was becoming overly aggressive.\n\nFor now, the frustration at the White House appears to be limited to senior officials rather than Mr. Trump himself. But the president has shown impatience with his military leaders on other issues, notably the debate over whether to deploy additional American troops to Afghanistan.\n\nAs they examine the most effective way of giving credibility to Mr. Trump\u2019s threat of \u201cfire and fury,\u201d officials are considering the feasibility of a preventive strike that could include disabling a missile on the launchpad or destroying North Korea\u2019s entire nuclear infrastructure. American officials are also said to be considering covert means of disabling the nuclear and missile programs.\n\nWhile General McMaster also favors a diplomatic solution to the impasse, officials said, he emphasizes to colleagues that past efforts to negotiate with North Korea have forced the United States to make unacceptable concessions.\n\nThe Pentagon has a different view. Mr. Mattis and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., argue forcefully for using diplomacy. They have repeatedly warned, in meetings and on video conference calls, that there are few, if any, military options that would not provoke retaliation from North Korea, according to officials at the Defense Department.\n\nRepresentatives of Mr. Mattis and General Dunford denied that they have slow-walked options to the White House.\n\nThe Pentagon press secretary, Dana W. White, said that Mr. Mattis \u201cregularly provides the president with a deep arsenal of military options\u201d and that reports of a delay were \u201cfalse.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nGeneral Dunford\u2019s press secretary, Col. Patrick S. Ryder, said: \u201cWhile the details of his conversations with the secretary of defense and the president are privileged communication, I can assure you that General Dunford regularly provides his best military advice in a timely and responsive manner to both senior leaders, to include military options for a wide range of national security challenges. Suggestions to the contrary are inaccurate.\u201d\n\nDuring a visit in October to the Demilitarized Zone between the two Koreas, Mr. Mattis confronted the central contradiction in the Trump administration\u2019s bellicose language: Virtually any military option would put the sprawling city of Seoul, with its population of 10 million, in the cross hairs of North Korea\u2019s artillery guns.\n\nPhoto\n\nAt times, South Korea\u2019s defense minister, Song Young-moo, appeared to be giving Mr. Mattis a guided tour of how a strike against North Korea\u2019s nuclear facilities would quickly trigger extensive retaliation.\n\nEven the most limited strike, the so-called bloody nose option, risks what one Defense Department official called an unacceptably high number of casualties. Mr. Cha, writing in The Washington Post, said the premise of such a strike \u2014 that it would jolt Mr. Kim into recognizing that the United States was serious, and draw him back to the bargaining table \u2014 was flawed.\n\n\u201cIf we believe that Kim is undeterrable without such a strike, how can we also believe that a strike will deter him from responding in kind?\u201d Mr. Cha wrote. \u201cAnd if Kim is unpredictable, impulsive and bordering on irrational, how can we control the escalation ladder, which is premised on an adversary\u2019s rational understanding of signals and deterrence?\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFriends said Mr. Cha pressed that case in meetings at the Pentagon, the United States Pacific Command, the State Department and the National Security Council. He passed along articles critical of preventive military action by two colleagues: John J. Hamre, the president of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, and Michael J. Green, a senior fellow at the center who worked in the George W. Bush administration, as did Mr. Cha.\n\nMr. Green warned against a preventive strike in testimony on Tuesday before the Senate Armed Services Committee. He said there appeared to be little support for it, even among normally hawkish Republicans like Senators Tom Cotton of Arkansas, Joni Ernst of Iowa and Dan Sullivan of Alaska.\n\nEven the White House has struggled to send a consistent message. In the week after Mr. Trump issued his threat to rain \u201cfire and fury\u201d on North Korea, Stephen K. Bannon, then his chief strategist, told a progressive journalist, \u201cThere\u2019s no military solution. Forget it.\u201d\n\n\u201cUntil somebody solves the part of the equation that shows me that 10 million people in Seoul don\u2019t die in the first 30 minutes from conventional weapons,\u201d he said, \u201cI don\u2019t know what you\u2019re talking about.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Bannon\u2019s bluntness angered other White House officials and hastened his exit from the White House. But there is evidence that General McMaster shares those concerns. Asked by a reporter in August whether there was any military option that would not put Seoul in North Korea\u2019s cross hairs, he paused briefly, then said, \u201cNo.\u201d\n\nWith as many as 8,000 artillery pieces and rocket launchers positioned along its border with the South, North Korea could rain up to 300,000 rounds on the South in the first hour of a counterattack.\n\nWhile that arsenal is of limited range and could be destroyed in days, North Korea would still have time to cause widespread destruction. In a rare appearance last year on the CBS News program \u201cFace the Nation,\u201d Mr. Mattis warned that war with North Korea would be \u201ccatastrophic\u201d \u2014 \u201cprobably the worst kind of fighting in most people\u2019s lifetimes.\u201d\n\nThat does not mean the military has not begun preparing for that possibility. At multiple Army bases across the country this month, more than 1000 reserve officers are practicing how to set up so-called mobilization centers, which move reservists overseas in a hurry.\n\nBut as the military gears up, Mr. Tillerson continues to look for a diplomatic channel to North Korea. State Department officials say the United States has far from exhausted its nonmilitary options for pressuring Pyongyang. It could, for example, push to expel North Korea from the United Nations or interdict ships that it suspects are violating sanctions against the government.\n\nNeither Mr. Tillerson nor Mr. Mattis has broken with the White House on the issue of a preventive strike. That is because for now, they still view it as a useful tool in deterring North Korea, according to people briefed by the administration. More important, they continue to be confident that, despite their anxieties, cooler heads with eventually prevail.", "title": "White House Wants Pentagon to Offer More Options on North Korea", "authors": ["Mark Landler", "Helene Cooper"]} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "1. That Republican memo that\u2019s roiling Washington? It could become public as early as Friday.\n\nPresident Trump cleared the way for the release of the memo, which is said to criticize the F.B.I.\u2019s actions in obtaining a warrant to spy on Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign adviser Carter Page, above. That puts the ball in the House Intelligence Committee\u2019s court.\n\nThe uproar has everything to do with the special counsel\u2019s investigation into Russia\u2019s role in the presidential election. We discuss it on today\u2019s episode of \u201cThe Daily.\u201d", "title": "White House, Syria, Myanmar: Your Thursday Evening Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cOur Hackable Political Future,\u201d by Henry J. Farrell and Rick Perlstein (Op-Ed, Feb. 5):\n\nThe problem isn\u2019t really fakery, whether of documents or videos. The bigger problem is that the worst among us do not care in the least whether or not something is true.\n\nThey don\u2019t want fact-checking, and they don\u2019t want to hear that the source they follow is unreliable. They don\u2019t even pay attention to the source; they just click or tune in to what they want to hear. And that is not an easy problem to solve.\n\nHow do you convince people that they should care whether something is true?\n\nMARGRIT MCINTOSH, TUCSON", "title": "Opinion | Who Cares About Truth?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Wells pointed to the rise of lynching after the fall of slavery as not merely a legal matter to be rectified with new laws. Having fled her hometown to escape threats of her own lynching, Wells used the press to make her moral arguments. She described a nation in the grip of a dark remorse for freeing black Americans from slavery, and condemned white Americans for cruelties that violated their own commitment to the democratic project.\n\nThe horrors that Wells described were a factor in the Great Migration of blacks to the North, which fed the flourishing of black thought and cultural life that gave rise to the Harlem Renaissance. An indication that the Harlem Renaissance was always meant to be a period of radical black philosophy and social change was the name originally coined for the movement: The New Negro. Alain Locke, the Harvard-educated black intellectual who became known as the father of the Harlem Renaissance, envisioned a philosophical position that reinvigorated blacks\u2019 relationship to their culture and that would in turn solidify their status as equal co-participants in our democracy.\n\nA strong theme among some of the luminaries of the time focused on the will of blacks to assert their humanity against racism and to insist on their status as persons owed respect. Among those stars, the poet Langston Hughes was one of the brightest. His \u201cI Too\u201d is a quiet yet insistent poem depicting a black man employed by a white one and his struggle with invisibility. The protagonist resolves to sit at the table with the white folks the next day and show people how beautiful he is and that he, too, is America. The writer Zora Neale Hurston had an equally persistent but at times more playful take on the matter. In her essay \u201cHow It Feels to Be Colored Me,\u201d she wrote, \u201cSometimes, I feel discriminated against, but it does not make me angry. It merely astonishes me. How can any deny themselves the pleasure of my company! It\u2019s beyond me.\u201d\n\nThinkers like Hughes and Hurston were involved in the Harlem Renaissance project of presenting a vision of black cultural vitality and worth that would rework the image of black Americans that whites typically relied upon. That stream of thought runs directly into the heart of Black Lives Matter.\n\nAnother valuable and necessary development to come out of the Black Lives Matter movement is the de-emphasizing of black patriarchy and the equal acknowledgment of the suffering of black women and the black L.G.T.B.Q. community. Though sexuality was an avenue of inquiry during the Harlem Renaissance, it was perhaps the mid- to late-20th century poet and theorist Audre Lorde who did the most to make black women\u2019s sexuality a focal point of political and social philosophy.\n\nWhile today \u201cintersectionality\u201d is bandied about as the cutting edge of social research, it was Lorde who in her writing insisted on complicating our view of personal identity by claiming that each of us belongs to multiple identity communities, all of which contribute to our sense of self and our purposes.\n\nShe also showed the broad reach of white supremacy and its effects on black Americans as they located themselves in more nuanced ways in the tapestry of American culture. For her, the primary form taken by resistance to racism was the denial of blunt categories imposed on black Americans, which stifled the possibility of an individual\u2019s full flourishing. Lorde, then, called for a radical form of self-possession whose boundaries were not open to negotiation with a white society.\n\nWhen people think of Black Lives Matter, they often think of anger feeding forceful protests. Anger is a reasonable response to racial injustice. To be certain, groups like the Black Panthers and thinkers like Malcolm X advised black Americans to get angry and take the doctrine of armed self-defense seriously. Though anger and love are not mutually exclusive emotions, James Baldwin and Martin Luther King Jr. affirmed a view of civic love to pre-empt the need for violence.", "title": "Opinion | Who First Showed Us That Black Lives Matter?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "It is now tragically apparent that degrading the Islamic State has not created an opening for peace in Syria. Instead, the country\u2019s vicious president, Bashar al-Assad, and his enablers in Russia and Iran have exploited the battlefield successes against ISIS to unleash a new round of carnage on civilians, as the leaders of the United States and other world powers largely stand by, unwilling or unable to do anything to stop it. Shame on them all.\n\nThe Assad-led bombardment of eastern Ghouta, a Damascus suburb of about 400,000 people and one of the last rebel-held areas, is being called one of the most violent episodes of the seven-year war. Since Sunday at least 310 people, many of them children, have been killed. That\u2019s in addition to nearly 500,000 Syrians killed countrywide since 2011.\n\nGhouta has been under siege for years, although it\u2019s technically part of a negotiated de-escalation zone, leaving the district facing chronic shortages of food, medicine, medical personnel and other necessities.\n\nThis week\u2019s massive attack \u2014 which has involved rocket fire, shelling, airstrikes and helicopter-dropped barrel bombs that struck hospitals and other civilian infrastructure \u2014 intensified the misery. It seems intended to force rebels to surrender so the government can reclaim the territory. Most of the civilian casualties resulted from airstrikes on residential areas, the United Nations\u2019 human rights office said. There have been signs that a government ground assault may soon follow.", "title": "Opinion | Who Has Innocent Syrians\u2019 Blood on Their Hands?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "After graduating from the United States Naval Academy in 1978, he went on to become a naval flight officer and then earned a master\u2019s degree in Asian security at the Harvard Kennedy School of Government, another master\u2019s at the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown, and he attended Oxford.\n\nAs head of the Pacific Command, he oversees about 375,000 military and civilian personnel, conducting operations in a region that spans more than 100 million square miles, or more than half of the earth\u2019s surface.\n\nLast year, in two separate events, American warships under Admiral Harris\u2019s command were damaged and several sailors were killed in collisions. He also accepted full responsibility in April for a bewildering chain of events that mistakenly left the impression that the aircraft carrier Carl Vinson was rushing to confront an increasingly belligerent North Korea, when it was not.\n\nWhere does he stand on regional issues?\n\nChina\n\nAppointed to lead the Pacific Command President Obama, Admiral Harris has taken a hard line against Chinese military action, calling Beijing\u2019s policy to build bases in the South China Sea \u201cprovocative and expansionist.\u201d\n\nHe has described China\u2019s efforts to build artificial islands in contested waters \u201ca Great Wall of sand.\u201d Since his appointment, he has advocated actively patrolling the South China Sea in so-called freedom of navigation operations.\n\nNorth Korea\n\nAs much as Admiral Harris has warned of Chinese aggression, he has made clear that he believes the biggest threat to the region is North Korea.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Morning Briefing What you need to know to start your day in Australia, delivered to your inbox. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cOur most volatile and dangerous threat is North Korea, with its quest for nuclear weapons and the means to deliver them intercontinentally,\u201d he said during a 2014 Senate confirmation hearing.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cOur collective efforts amid the challenges,\u201d he said, \u201cunderscore the importance of America remaining a strong and engaged in the region.\u201d He continued, \u201cAmerican leadership does matter.\u201d\n\nDespite those warnings, Admiral Harris has made clear that the solution to the North Korean threat is not necessarily though the use of American force.\n\nIn a statement last year, he said it was crucial that the United States \u201cbring Kim Jong-un to his senses, not his knees.\u201d\n\nWhat would his appointment mean for Australia?\n\nIt has been more than a year since the United States had an ambassador in Australia, and Admiral Harris\u2019s nomination comes amid fears that President Trump was abandoning the countries\u2019 traditional alliance.\n\nAdmiral Harris\u2019 nomination \u201cis a demonstration that that\u2019s not actually happening,\u201d said Peter Jennings, executive director of the Australian Strategic Policy Institute.\n\nMr. Turnbull, the prime minister, welcomed news of the nomination on Twitter, saying on Twitter, \u201cLook forward to seeing you in Canberra, Harry.\u201d\n\nAdmiral Harris has frequently visited Australia and has said he believes the alliance between the two countries \u201canchors peace and stability in the region.\u201d\n\n\u201cAustralia,\u201d he added, \u201cplays a leading role in regional security, capacity-building efforts and addressing disaster response.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBut how Admiral Harris handles Australia\u2019s relationship with China is an open question. Australia increasingly finds itself economically dependent on China, its largest trade partner, even as some politicians have warned that the rising Asian power is trying to influence Australian politics.\n\n\u201cWhat he needs to be aware of is the sensitivity around looking like Australia is doing America\u2019s bidding,\u201d said Euan Graham, director of the international security program at the Lowy Institute.\n\nAlready, China has signaled concern about Admiral Harris\u2019s potential new position.\n\nThough Chinese officials have not commented on news of the nomination, the state news media reported on Friday that a \u201cU.S. hawk is made ambassador to Australia.\u201d", "title": "Who Is Harry Harris, Trump\u2019s Pick for Ambassador to Australia?", "authors": ["Jacqueline Williams"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "LONDON \u2014 The privatization of public services \u201cwas one of the central means of reversing the corrosive and corrupting effects of socialism,\u201d Margaret Thatcher wrote in her memoirs. \u201cJust as nationalisation was at the heart of the collectivist programme by which Labour governments sought to remodel British society, so privatisation is at the centre of any programme of reclaiming territory for freedom.\u201d\n\nThose sentiments fueled a sell-off that put nearly every state-owned service or property in Britain on the auction block in the final decade of the 20th century, eventually including the country\u2019s expansive public transportation infrastructure. Enshrined by parliamentary acts under Mrs. Thatcher and implemented by her two immediate successors, John Major, a Conservative, and Tony Blair of New Labour, the gospel of privatization was embraced by leaders around the world, notably including Mrs. Thatcher\u2019s closest overseas ally, President Ronald Reagan.\n\nIn the realm of transportation, that gospel was soon betrayed by its own chief disciples. Put simply, there were few private-sector buyers with the expertise and deep pockets necessary to maintain control of a transit system that serves approximately seven billion passengers per year. With minimal transparency, operational ownership of the network of train and bus lines that crisscross the 607-square-mile sprawl of Greater London, linking it to the far-flung corners of Britain, was peddled in bits and pieces by the British state or acquired in corporate takeovers.\n\nBut the new bosses were not private, business-savvy British firms. By 2000, the masters of British public transit \u2014 thanks to a scheme that was intended to replace state waste and sloth with soundly capitalist business principles \u2014 were foreign governments, most of them members of the European Union.", "title": "Opinion | Who Keeps Britain\u2019s Trains Running? Europe", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "SPECIAL POST \u2014 In this month\u2019s \u201cWho Made My Puzzle?\u201d we meet Laura Braunstein, a Dartmouth College librarian, whose debut New York Times Crossword \u2014 a collaboration with the veteran Erik Agard \u2014 appeared on Dec. 10, 2017.\n\nMeet Laura Braunstein\n\n1. Where do you currently reside?\n\nLebanon, N.H. (it\u2019s a small town near the Vermont state line)\n\n2. Where and when was your first puzzle published?\n\nMay 3, 2017, by American Values Club Crosswords.\n\n3. How did you get into puzzling? What is your first memory of solving?\n\nMy grandfather, who was an immigrant, used to solve crosswords to practice his English. He\u2019d tear a puzzle out of the paper and carry it around in his pocket with a little stub of pencil. He\u2019d ask me for help \u2014 to challenge me \u2014 when I was maybe 9 or 10 years old. Later, a family friend got me a subscription to Games Magazine in the 1980s. I can\u2019t remember ever not solving word puzzles, or not being fascinated by language.\n\n4. What made you decide to try your hand at making a crossword puzzle?\n\nI\u2019m a librarian at Dartmouth College. A few years ago, when he was a student here, Andrew Kingsley (a New York Times published constructor) used to work on his grids in the reference room. We used to chat about puzzles, and eventually I thought, this is something I could do! When I made my first few (not so great) puzzles, Andrew was very patient and encouraging (cue clich\u00e9d line from a martial arts movie: \u201cThe student is now the teacher!\u201d), and I learned much from his feedback. It also turned out that I shared some close mutual friends with a puzzle editor, Ben Tausig of the American Values Club, and eventually I got up the courage to ask him to mentor me. Since then I\u2019ve also had some opportunities to collaborate, which is a great way to learn (and enormous fun). I\u2019ve been very, very lucky to meet people in the overlapping constructor and solver communities who have been supportive and kind.\n\n5. Why do you do this to yourself?\n\nBecause I want to. There\u2019s a poem by Marge Piercy called \u201cFor the young who want to\u201d \u2014 its last lines are: \u201cWork is its own cure. You have to like it better than being loved.\u201d I think about that poem often. Making puzzles is hard work that is its own cure for this desire I have to make something my own. Sure, I like it when I make something that solvers enjoy. And I\u2019ve felt honored to be associated with all the smart and funny people who are my fellow constructors. But I\u2019d probably make puzzles even if they never got published.\n\n6. Do you use a computer software constructing program, and if so, which one? What do you like about it?\n\nI have a Mac, so I\u2019ve been using CrossFire. I started out with a $5 iPad app called Crossword Maker for Cruciverbalists. It\u2019s rudimentary but I\u2019d recommend it for aspiring constructors before making a larger investment. I\u2019ve integrated Matt Ginsberg\u2019s clue database into CrossFire, which is helpful because in many cases it suggests clues that I don\u2019t want to use again. I love cluing; it\u2019s a chance to get a little looser.\n\n7. How many hours a week, on average, do you spend on refining your tools, like your word list?\n\nI\u2019m pretty new at this business, so I don\u2019t yet have my own carefully curated word list \u2014 a friend kindly gifted me his, so I\u2019m standing on the shoulders of giants in that department. In general, though, it\u2019s hard to quantify. I probably spend a lot of unconscious time processing ideas. I have a Google Doc of notes and themes that is mostly rejects and dead ends. It\u2019s convenient because I can add to it using my phone.\n\n8. What entry or entries would you NEVER put in a puzzle, and why? Or, with what entry would you deliberately fail the \u201cbreakfast test,\u201d and why?\n\nIt\u2019s interesting to me that G-SPOT has appeared in The New York Times puzzle plenty of times, but PAP SMEAR hardly ever. I guarantee that there are many solvers who think about pap smears at breakfast and are not grossed out. Why should the human body offend anyone? And why should we further stigmatize illness or disability by pretending that they\u2019re not appropriate for language games? I\u2019m more offended by N.R.A., which appears constantly in grids, than by sexuality or women\u2019s health or so-called profanity. I think puzzles can also be a space to engage with social and political issues \u2014 recently I put SEXTS in a grid and clued it as an opportunity to open a conversation about consent, instead of as a throwaway joke.\n\n9. What is your favorite clue of all time and why?\n\n\u201cTurn-down for Watt?\u201d for the word NAE. This was from a Jonesin\u2019 puzzle by Matt Jones, brought to my attention by Erik Agard; getting it relies on one\u2019s knowledge of both contemporary electronic dance music and eighteenth-century Scottish inventors. I\u2019m also very pleased when constructors turn the clues into a kind of puzzle in their own right; there was one by Peter Gordon, probably my favorite New York Times puzzle of 2017, about Emily Dickinson. Every single clue was a double dactyl \u2014 just like her name. My favorite clue that I\u2019ve not yet had a chance to use in one of my own puzzles: \u201cI can believe it\u2019s not butter\u201d for OLEO.\n\n10. What are you doing these days?\n\nLast summer I was on the constructing team for Boswords, a crossword tournament in Boston. We\u2019re hoping to make it an annual event.\n\nThank you for spending time with us, Ms. Braunstein.\n\nYour thoughts?", "title": "Who Made My Puzzle?: Laura Braunstein", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "There is nothing in the Constitution that says we have to have congressional districts. Article 1, Section 2, says merely that \u201cthe House of Representatives shall be composed of members chosen every second year by the people of the several states.\u201d No particular method is prescribed.\n\nAnd indeed, in the early days of the republic, states did not uniformly use what we now call \u201csingle-member district\u201d voting. Most did. But a few states used what was then called \u201cgeneral ticket\u201d voting. Under this system, there were no districts. In those states in the first congressional elections, the Federalists and the Anti-Federalists put up slates, and the side with the winning slate took all or most of the seats.\n\nAs it happens, Pennsylvania was the state where the most experimenting was done. In that first Congress, it had no districts. Eight representatives were chosen under general-ticket voting, and the Federalists, the moneyed interests based in Philadelphia, dominated. By the time of the second Congress, the state switched to districts. Then it switched back. Then by the fourth Congress it had switched back again.\n\nAs new states were added, most went with districts, but not all did. By 1839, 17 states used districts, while nine did not (three of those nine had only one representative). Four slave states used general-ticket voting, which allowed them to vote with one voice on slavery questions.\n\nSoon enough, push came to shove, and the Whigs \u2014 who controlled both Congress and the White House after the 1840 elections, but who worried that general-ticket voting favored the rival Democratic Party \u2014 passed the Apportionment Act of 1842, which outlawed general-ticket voting. President John Tyler, who had been elected as a Whig, signed the bill \u2014 but added a statement expressing doubts about the bill\u2019s constitutionality. Four states, three of them Southern, defied the bill. In the 1850s, California and Minnesota joined the union and ignored the 1842 act.", "title": "Opinion | Who Needs Congressional Districts?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "THE REAL LIFE OF THE PARTHENON\n\nBy Patricia Vigderman\n\nIllustrated. 195 pp. Mad Creek Books/Ohio State University Press. Paper, $21.95.\n\n\u201cThey were created in a short time for all time. Each one of them, in its beauty, was even then and at once antique, but in the freshness of its vigor it is, even to the present day, recent and newly wrought.\u201d Thus Plutarch described the buildings on the Acropolis as a showcase of Periclean Athens. Although he was writing half a millennium after the Parthenon was built, he touched on the essence of its enduring appeal. Few complexes have cast a greater spell on later generations and even fewer boast such a strange afterlife, its component parts dismembered and divided between Athens and London, its heritage contested and the source of debates that seem to generate more heat than light.\n\nImage\n\nThe afterlife of ancient art and architecture is the subject of \u201cThe Real Life of the Parthenon\u201d by Patricia Vigderman, a professor of English at Kenyon College whose previous book was \u201cPossibility: Essays Against Despair.\u201d Part memoir, part travelogue and part musing on cultural patrimony, her new book is a voyage around the ancient world in which she examines the issues raised by the migration of art in the modern era. Her quest takes her from Athens and Pompeii to Manhattan and Malibu as she confronts the paradox of ownership and wrestles with conflicting evidence. Is the universality of art a pernicious concept, a form of \u201ccultural strip mining,\u201d or is it an acknowledgment of art as part of our common humanity? Should works of art be repatriated to their countries of origin and is that always the right decision? These are big questions, and our answers depend on whether we believe a work\u2019s original context is paramount.\n\nVigderman\u2019s approach is informed by Walter Benjamin\u2019s concept of an object\u2019s aura, a property embedded in time and history. Deprived of its original location, the object\u2019s aura is diminished; yet do major works like the Parthenon marbles belong only to one place, since so many of them have resided in the British Museum for two centuries? Have they not now acquired a different aura, given their impact on generations of artists, from Canova and Rodin to Henry Moore? Mary Beard, whose astute history of the Parthenon lies behind Vigderman\u2019s study, has described the marbles as \u201cvalued because of their deracination,\u201d which charges them with a \u201ccultural electricity.\u201d", "title": "Who Owns the Elgin Marbles?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "He grabs pussies. He kisses females without concern for the revulsion and horror they feel for him. Does he ever experience rejection? He does not. \u201cMost men would get discouraged,\u201d he says, referring to those he comes on to. \u201cFortunately for her, I am not most men.\u201d\n\nHe is Pep\u00e9 Le Pew. Does he remind us of anyone else?\n\nIn advance of Valentine\u2019s Day, and to better understand the inner workings of a man who appears to have no inner workings, I bypassed last week\u2019s State of the Union address and spent the evening watching all 17 Pep\u00e9 Le Pew cartoons, from his 1945 debut in \u201cOdor-able Kitty\u201d to 1962\u2019s \u201cLouvre Come Back to Me!\u201d And I can now share what I have learned \u2014 about love, the French, narcissistic personality disorder, men, women, the president of the United States and the smell of Limburger cheese.\n\nBut first, for younger readers: Pep\u00e9 Le Pew is a Warner Bros. cartoon character, part of the Looney Tunes stable during the golden age of American animation, alongside Bugs Bunny, the Road Runner, Daffy Duck and Porky Pig.\n\nHe was never a marquee star of the same magnitude of, say, Bugs Bunny or the Road Runner. He appeared in just 17 stand-alone cartoons, virtually all of them directed by Chuck Jones. Still, he made a fragrant impression: \u201cFor Scent-imental Reasons\u201d (1949) won the Academy Award for best animated short film.", "title": "Opinion | Who Said It: Pep\u00e9 Le Pew or Donald Trump?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\nLet\u2019s make this simple:\n\n1. Russia attacked the United States in 2016 by disrupting the presidential election.\n\n2. The origin of the attack is a matter of consensus among American intelligence agencies.\n\n3. The current president of the United States refuses to acknowledge the attack, refuses to respond to it and refuses to help protect the country against a likely follow-up attack.\n\n4. In the wake of the mass murder of 17 Americans in Florida, the president falsely claimed that the F.B.I. failed to prevent the massacre because it was too occupied with the Russia investigation. Here\u2019s a look at the performers.\n\nThe Children\u2019s Choir\n\nThe children\u2019s choir, known as the Rainbow Chorus, performed \u201cAegukga,\u201d the national anthem of South Korea. The choir is sponsored by the South Korean government, and it was created to educate the public about multiculturalism and to help integrate immigrants and multicultural families.\n\nThe choir performs at official events and competitions. Here are the singers performing in 2015.\n\n\u2018Imagine\u2019\n\nPhoto\n\nJohn Lennon\u2019s \u201cImagine\u201d was performed by Jeon In-kwon, Lee Eun-mi, Ha Hyun-woo and Ahn Ji-young, who are all considered stars in South Korea and who represented several generations of Korean pop music.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sports Newsletter Get our most ambitious projects, stories and analysis delivered to your inbox every week.
