Aligned side-by-side at the bottom of a mountain, the area resembles a Gypsy encampment, albeit one guarded by a high fence because of the irreplaceable equipment stored within. Inside the work spaces, it is wall-to-wall skis, and the floor is scattered with spent wax, drills, scrapers and dozens of travel ski bags.\n\nFor the Pyeongchang Olympics, Shiffrin scaled back her supply to 35 pairs of skis. By this point, at the end of the season, she has whittled it down through trial and error to her favorite pairs.\n\nStill, throughout these Games, Shiffrin has been in daily contact with Erlandsson to talk about her equipment. They deliberate over the choices and the modifications to be made before each training session and race. Last week, between the morning and afternoon runs of the Olympic giant slalom, Shiffrin visited with Erlandsson again.\n\nWhat did they discuss?\n\n\u201cAdjustments,\u201d Erlandsson, a man of few words, answered.\n\nIn her second run, Shiffrin came from behind to win the gold medal.", "title": "Why Mikaela Shiffrin Brought 35 Pairs of Skis to the Olympics", "authors": ["Bill Pennington"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019m very American,\u201d he told Nichol. \u201cI can\u2019t really relate to this character very much.\u201d\n\nYes, Nichol replied, but Chen could pay homage to his parents\u2019 immigration in 1988 from Tianjin, China, to Carbondale, Ill., and, four years later, their move to Salt Lake City. His parents did not defect, as did Li, but arrived on his father\u2019s student visa. They sought not political asylum but opportunity. Still, it was not an easy journey and they felt acute dislocation. His mother spoke no English when they came to the United States, and the couple knew no one.\n\nHetty Wang, Chen\u2019s mother, now works as a medical interpreter of Mandarin Chinese for hospitals. His father, Zhidong Chen, had obtained his medical degree in China and later got his doctorate in pharmaceuticals from the University of Utah. He owns a small biotech company.\n\n\u201cThey tend not to talk too much about their struggles, but it must have been so difficult, coming to a new country, not speaking the language, not having much money, not having any friends,\u201d said Nathan Chen, the youngest of five siblings. \u201cIt\u2019s amazing how they were able to fight through that.\u201d\n\nFinally, Nichol convinced Chen to perform to \u201cMao\u2019s Last Dancer\u201d with a line she read in The Globe and Mail\u2019s review of the movie. As Li\u2019s story unfolded, the review said, \u201cpolitics stepped aside to let art do what it does best \u2014 defy boundaries.\u201d\n\nIn a metaphorical sense, Chen would be confronting the perceived limits placed on all skaters who are magnificent jumpers.\n\n\u201cI felt he could defy boundaries of people saying, \u2018You can\u2019t possibly do all those quads and have artistic merit,\u2019\u201d Nichol said.\n\nLast May, and again in June, Chen visited Nichol in Richmond Hill, Ontario, outside of Toronto. She gave him a Power Point presentation, seeking to expand his understanding of art through dance, painting, sculpture, even gardening, while also trying to demystify the art of skating. They spoke of feeling music, not simply hearing it, of learning to interpret its nuances and of building on his ballet training to tell a story through movement.", "title": "Why Nathan Chen Shuns Sequins", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-24 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cYou are 100 percent in the moment, hyper-aware of everything and focused on just that job and nothing else,\u201d said Carlos Pedro Brice\u00f1o, 43, of DeLand, Fla., about his now almost full-time leisure pursuit, wingsuit proximity flying, which involves jumping off things like mountains and cellphone towers and gliding perilously close to the surrounding terrain before deploying a parachute. \u201cIt\u2019s addictive, that feeling of fear and the reward when you control the fear and land safe. And then you want to go up, like, right away and do it again.\u201d\n\nA market analysis by Delaware North, a company that manages concessions for sporting events, says participation in extreme sports (including grueling and sometimes fatal endurance competitions like the Tough Mudder and Spartan Race) has surpassed conventional sports.\n\nThe company forecasts that by 2020, extreme sports will challenge professional and collegiate sports as the most watched category of sports content. This is thanks in part to the multiple hours of heart-stopping video uploaded daily to the internet, documenting not only death-defying feats but also perpetuating a dangerous game of one-upmanship.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Opinion Today Newsletter Every weekday, get thought-provoking commentary from Op-Ed columnists, the Times editorial board and contributing writers from around the world. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIndeed, Mr. Brice\u00f1o, who used to be a cost controller at an oil company in his native Venezuela, was inspired to start parachuting and then proximity flying by watching YouTube videos of other people\u2019s jumps. He also starred with his friend, Alexander Polli, 31, in the film \u201cBase,\u201d about proximity flying (also known as BASE jumping). Mr. Polli died in 2016 after clipping a tree during a proximity flight; the movie was released last year. His death followed that of another well-known base jumper, Dean Potter, who crashed into a granite rock formation after leaping off a cliff in Yosemite National Park in 2015.\n\nPsychologists have tried to categorize people who take extreme physical risks, like sky divers and racecar drivers, as being prone to \u201csensation seeking,\u201d similar to people who abuse drugs and gamble compulsively. Researchers have variously attributed this to psychopathology, a genetic quirk or possibly a chemical imbalance (for instance, low levels of the feel-good neurotransmitter dopamine).\n\nBut none of these explanations is likely the whole story. And while the research is slim and lacking much scientific rigor, studies of extreme-sports enthusiasts suggest they have diverse biologies, personalities and backgrounds.\n\n\u201cThere is no single profile that predicts engagement in extreme sports,\u201d said Dr. Erik Monasterio, a psychiatrist and clinical lecturer at University of Otago in New Zealand, who is also an avid mountain climber. \u201cThere are all sorts of paths to it.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe and others who study extreme sports point to cultural, sociological and even technological factors as the most likely explanations for the recent surge in participation. \u201cEfforts to eliminate risk are an obsession in the Western world,\u201d Dr. Monasterio said. \u201cWe have to make playgrounds and public spaces perfectly safe and there\u2019s all this litigation around physical and mental injuries in relation to all kinds of activities. That sterile environment is frustrating and makes people crave stimulation and excitement.\u201d\n\nHigh-risk sports are also seen as a reaction against living life mediated through a mobile device rather than having real experiences. \u201cIt\u2019s an escape from a social media-obsessed society where so much seems fake and contrived and we\u2019re indoors so much that the idea of risk-taking in the outdoors is very appealing,\u201d said Dr. Starn, though he added that it\u2019s disturbing that people feel they must go to such extremes to find release.\n\nResearch by Welsh and French sports psychologists indicates individuals who have trouble identifying or expressing their feelings, which is essential to maintaining stable and supportive relationships, are drawn to high-risk sports because it presents them with a very recognizable and unambiguous emotion: fear.\n\n\u201cPeople feel good about themselves afterward because they have the sense that they have control over their emotions, like, \u2018I can conquer my fear,\u2019 \u201d said Tim Woodman, professor of performance psychology at Bangor University in Wales. \u201cBut then they have this urge to go to back again and again because their true, underlying fear hasn\u2019t been dealt with.\u201d\n\nAlthough this largely subconscious fear most often has to do with relationships and intimacy, there is also the compounding unease these days about the state of the world. Political unrest and dysfunction, discord between races and between sexes and the plight of the planet can also make people seek to \u201cexternalize their internal fears\u201d by engaging in extreme sports, said Christine Le Scanff, dean of the school of sports sciences and movement at the University of Paris-Sud in France.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s a way for people to burn away these worries about the world that occupy their minds,\u201d said Mr. Brice\u00f1o, who continues proximity flying despite having lost several friends, in addition to Mr. Polli, to the sport. \u201cIt gives you this rush and that rush makes you feel like you are alive and free and the happiness in that moment makes you think, \u2018Well, I don\u2019t mind if I don\u2019t have any more days of life because what I just did, it was so good, I could die right now.\u2019 \u201d", "title": "Why People Love to Jump Off Cliffs", "authors": ["Kate Murphy"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Recently someone (my boss, actually) mentioned to me that I wrote more articles about dogs than I did about cats and asked why.\n\nMy first thought, naturally, was that it had nothing to do with the fact that I have owned numerous dogs and no cats, but rather reflected the amount of research done by scientists on the animals.\n\nAfter all, I\u2019ll write about any interesting findings, and I like cats just fine, even if I am a dog person. Two of my adult children have cats, and I would hate for them to think I was paying them insufficient attention. (Hello Bailey! Hello Tawny! \u2014 Those are the cats, not the children.)\n\nBut I figured I should do some reporting, so I emailed Elinor Karlsson at the Broad Institute and the University of Massachusetts. She is a geneticist who owns three cats, but does much of her research on dogs \u2014 the perfect unbiased observer. Her research, by the way, is about dog genomes. She gets dog DNA from owners who send in their pets\u2019 saliva samples.", "title": "Why Scientists Love to Study Dogs (and Often Ignore Cats)", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "MONTREAL \u2014 When Justin Trudeau first met Donald Trump face-to-face last February, the contrast between the Canadian prime minister and the American president couldn\u2019t have been any sharper. Mr. Trudeau, worldly and dapper, can barely open his mouth without extolling Canada\u2019s cheery multiculturalism or its open-border globalism. Mr. Trump lurches from thinly concealed xenophobia to America-first protectionism by way of insults and tirades.\n\nYet Mr. Trudeau survived their meeting and has remained in Mr. Trump\u2019s good graces ever since. \u201cI like the prime minister very much,\u201d Mr. Trump told a gathering of his supporters last December. \u201cNice guy. Good guy.\u201d\n\nMr. Trudeau\u2019s smooth relationship with Mr. Trump hasn\u2019t only kept the North American Free Trade Agreement negotiations alive, if teetering. It is also one of the main reasons that, after just over two scandal- and gaffe-prone years as prime minister, Mr. Trudeau remains far and away the most popular political figure in this Trump-adverse country.\n\nCanada\u2019s obsession with Mr. Trump\u2019s whims and overindulgences goes beyond morbid curiosity.\n\nDespite differing views on the metric system and the occasional far-flung war, the United States and Canada have enjoyed more than 150 years of benign relations. Yet Mr. Trump\u2019s frequent threats to scuttle Nafta are seen here as an existential threat to Canada\u2019s economy, which sends over 75 percent of its exports to the United States.", "title": "Opinion | Why Trudeau Needs Trump", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nRe \u201cLawyers Tell Trump to Refuse Mueller Interview\u201d (front page, Feb. 6):\n\nSo, Donald Trump\u2019s attorneys do not want him to answer the special counsel\u2019s questions pertaining to the Russia investigation because they fear that: 1) he will not tell the truth and thus could be charged with lying to investigators or 2) he will tell the truth and thus incriminate himself for crimes he may have committed or 3) both of the above.\n\nWhat a very sad state of affairs for this country when the president cannot be relied upon, or not permitted, to tell the truth.\n\nRICHARD M. CLAYTON\n\nLEWISVILLE, N.C.\n\nTo the Editor:\n\nThe very idea of letting an unsupervised President Trump answer questions from Robert Mueller\u2019s attorneys must be making Mr. Trump\u2019s attorneys\u2019 hair stand on end and their teeth start chattering. The Trump approach of making things up as he goes along, his childish exaggerations and his outright lying could have disastrous effects on their job tenure, not to mention his.\n\nSHIRLEY STUART, BERKELEY, CALIF.", "title": "Opinion | Why Trump\u2019s Lawyers Advise, Don\u2019t Talk to Mueller", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "If \u201cyou\u2019re learning tennis, of course as the beginner, you have to think about, \u2018Where do I put my feet? How do I hold my racket?\u2019\u201d said Roy Baumeister, a social psychologist at Florida State University, whose research on this subject has helped shaped the theory. You start by focusing on the details: Stand right here. Hold this like this.\n\n\u201cSo if you don\u2019t know how to act in a job interview, then having a reminder to tell you, \u2018O.K., sit up, make eye contact\u2019 \u2014 all these things are likely to be helpful,\u201d Mr. Baumeister said. When you\u2019re new to something, it\u2019s often necessary to zero in on the minutiae of what to say and how to act.\n\n\u201cBut over time, it becomes more and more automatic, and you even lose awareness of what you\u2019re doing,\u201d Mr. Baumeister said.\n\n[Want more? Every Monday, get a weekly roundup of the best advice from The Times on living a better, smarter, more fulfilling life, straight to your inbox. Sign up for the Smarter Living newsletter here.]\n\nAn unfortunate thing about being human is that nerves have a way of narrowing your attention in on yourself, even if you entered a party without intending to mentally monitor your every word and movement.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Smarter Living Newsletter A weekly roundup of the best advice from The Times on living a better, smarter, more fulfilling life. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cWhen we are anxious, we turn our attention inward, to, \u2018Am I coming across O.K.?\u2019 Or, \u2018They just shifted in their seat, does that mean they\u2019re bored?\u2019 Or, \u2018Oh my gosh, what I just said sounds totally stupid, why did I say that?\u2019\u201d said Ellen Hendriksen, a clinical psychologist at Boston University\u2019s Center for Anxiety and Related Disorders. She\u2019s also the author of the upcoming book \u201cHow to Be Yourself,\u201d which is about social anxiety.\n\n\u201cWe focus our attention inward, to ourselves, to our bodies,\u201d she said.\n\nThe problem is that our brains can attend to only so much at once, said Sian Beilock, a cognitive scientist and the president of Barnard College. Think of that awkward elevator ride you shared with your company\u2019s C.E.O. and your mind blanked on the simplest things because you were trying so hard to think of something to say. (How do elevator buttons work again?)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cWe only have a limited ability to focus on things, which is why driving and talking on a cellphone is not a good idea, because it takes your focus away,\u201d said Ms. Beilock, whose research on explicit monitoring theory helped inspire her 2010 book on the subject, \u201cChoke.\u201d Trying to do something while worrying about how you\u2019re doing it is like doing two things at once, she said. One of those things is going to suffer.\n\nBut the question remains: Why can\u2019t we stop being so awkward? Hard as we try to \u201csolve\u201d that problem, it\u2019s kind of the wrong approach. Rather than ask, \u201cWhy am I so awkward?\u201d ask yourself, \u201cWhat am I focusing on?\u201d Much of the time, our awkwardness is self-induced because we\u2019re overthinking our behavior so much that it becomes our only focus. Dr. Hendriksen has a little experiment she sometimes asks her social anxiety patients to try.\n\n\u201cHave two separate conversations \u2014 and it could be with anybody. It could be with a guy at the gas station, or a co-worker or your barista. Whoever,\u201d she said. \u201cAnd in one of those conversations, focus on you, you, you. Focus on how you\u2019re coming across, what\u2019s happening in your body, monitor what you\u2019re saying.\n\n\u201cAnd then, in the second conversation, focus on them, them, them,\u201d she said.\n\nAfterward, ask yourself: Which conversation was more pleasant? And in which did you feel more at ease?\n\n\u201cInevitably, the second conversation is the one in which people feel most comfortable,\u201d she said.\n\nIt also helps to borrow another idea from the world of athletics: Keep your mind on the goal, not the process. To avoid the self-focus vortex in a job interview, for example, instead focus on the three things you\u2019d like to get across.\n\n\u201cYou can focus on that rather than how you\u2019re moving your mouth or how you\u2019re holding your hands,\u201d Ms. Beilock said.\n\nYou know what else helps? Lightening up.\n\n\u201cI think all the rules not only take up all our bandwidth, but I also think it sets this unattainable standard of, \u2018O.K., I have to stand in a power pose and make eye contact and speak slowly,\u2019\u201d Dr. Hendriksen said. \u201cAnd I think it creates this idea that if you don\u2019t do all these things perfectly, that you will fail.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s O.K. to lower your standards a tiny bit. You will spill wine on someone. Someone else will spill wine on you. You will live. But you\u2019d live a little happier through these moments if you could also get yourself to laugh at them.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story", "title": "Why Trying to Be Less Awkward Never Works", "authors": ["Melissa Dahl"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "My wife and I were just settling into bed one night when Alexa, the other woman in my life, decided to make herself heard.\n\nWithout being summoned, the Amazon Echo Dot at my bedside \u2014 one of the half-dozen devices that Alexa inhabits in our house \u2014 lit up its spectral blue ring, as if it had heard its triggering wake word, \u201cAlexa.\u201d But instead of offering help with some household chore, the voice assistant began to wail, like a child screaming in a horror-movie dream.\n\n\u201cHuh,\u201d I said to my wife when it was over. She said something less kind.\n\nBut here\u2019s what\u2019s really strange: By the next morning, we had forgotten all about it.\n\nIt is a measure of how thoroughly Amazon\u2019s voice assistant has wormed herself into our lives, and into much of the culture beyond, that I never considered unplugging her after the scream. Instead I chalked the incident up to a harmless bug \u2014 one of the many mysteries of living with an artificial intelligence life form that can be summoned at a breath. (An Amazon representative offered to investigate, but said the company had never heard of such a thing happening before and didn\u2019t think Alexa was even capable of making such a sound.)", "title": "Why We May Soon Be Living in Alexa\u2019s World", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "I was one of many who saw the clips and got excited. Joining Danny McBride as the son of Dundee were Australia\u2019s biggest stars, including Margot Robbie, Chris Hemsworth, Russell Crowe, and Hugh Jackman.\n\nThe trailer\u2019s premise \u2014 the foolish Americanized son of an Australian legend returns to the bush \u2014 also suggested a chance to poke fun at Americans and American assumptions about Australia. Bring it, I thought.\n\nBut what looked like a summer film was actually a setup for a Super Bowl ad. Tourism Australia duped us all, aiming directly at America\u2019s love for the Dundee story, with the goal of exploiting it.\n\nAnd it seems to be working.\n\nJohn O\u2019Sullivan, the managing director of Tourism Australia, told me yesterday that their site has seen record traffic since the Super Bowl, and that tourism operators are reporting double and triple the usual interest.\n\n\u201cWhat we\u2019re saying to North America is you\u2019re welcome in our country and we want you to visit,\" he said. \u201cThat character really does bring that to the fore in a way that no other character has really done before.\u201d\n\nPerhaps. It\u2019s true that Dundee is quite welcoming to the visiting American reporter played by Linda Kozlowski (Hogan ended up marrying her in real life) and there\u2019s clearly something deeper going on with Dundee and Aussie identity.\n\nHere\u2019s Vincent Canby, our former chief film critic, grappling with Hogan and his character in 1986:\n\nMore than anything else, he seems to represent the newly proud Australian, the man who doesn\u2019t apologize for not being born English, who relishes his own, very pronounced accent and vocabulary, and who celebrates skepticism and the old, frontier values, more or less simultaneously.\n\nDoes that sound right to you? (The original film review is a hoot as well.)\n\nRegardless, here\u2019s a related question: Is there a \u201cCrocodile Dundee\u201d for today? A character or story that embodies how Australia sees itself now?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIt\u2019s one thing to use Dundee to reintroduce Americans to Australia. Good on ya for that, especially if it means gaining a deeper understanding of the place through visiting.\n\nBut ad-driven nostalgia is a sticky wicket. In the actual movie, I saw quite a bit more than what many Americans and Australians might recall.\n\nHogan\u2019s performance, closely observed, is unlike what he did for Tourism Australia as a spokesman before the film \u2014 he\u2019s not just a breezy larrikin.\n\nHis Dundee in America is more complicated, revealing in his facial expressions a fair amount of anxiety and awkwardness as he wanders through New York.\n\nThe Australia that he embodied in the \u201980s was not yet a middle power, or middle-power plus as Australia is sometimes known today. It was a young country far away, lacking urgency, trying to figure out a fast-paced, competitive world and just how much it wanted to get involved with all that ambition.\n\nTo some degree that\u2019s still Australia. To some degree it\u2019s not.\n\nAustralia in 2018 is more confident, far richer, more diverse, more urbanized and less unified politically. It\u2019s a beach lifestyle brand, not a Foster\u2019s ad. But it\u2019s still not sure what role it wants to play globally.\n\nSo what would a new Dundee reveal?\n\nAssuming we can cast Chris or Liam Hemsworth \u2014 or perhaps the role belongs to Russell Crowe or Hugh Jackman, who are roughly the same age as Hogan was for Dundee \u2014 what would a tale of Australia and the world tell us about the country today?\n\nWhere would the film be set, whose stories would it capture, and what would make it resonate with today\u2019s Australians?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Tell them to sign up (or just sign them up as a friendly provocation), email us at nytaustralia@nytimes.com, and join us in our Facebook group for brainstorming.\n\nNow here\u2019s more from this week in The Times and in Australia, followed by a recommendation for another Aussie film that I\u2019ve come to love.\n\nPhoto\n\nUma Thurman, after promising to express her anger about Harvey Weinstein when she was good and ready, has found a way to get it all out: in an interview with Maureen Dowd.\n\n\u201cThe complicated feeling I have about Harvey is how bad I feel about all the women that were attacked after I was,\u201d she said, explaining an array of experiences with candor and frustration.\n\nOne reader commented: \u201cMs. Thurman embodies everything I\u2019ve ever wanted to be.\u201d\n\n______\n\nPhoto\n\nYou may think of augmented reality as simply Pokemon Go. But it can be a lot more than that, and as part of our effort to stay ahead of the journalism pack, we\u2019re introducing an augmented reality experiment for our Olympics coverage.\n\nIt\u2019s a way to study and see some of the world\u2019s greatest athletes, up close and personal.\n\nHere\u2019s how to get started on your phone or tablet.\n\n______\n\nPhoto\n\nThe world\u2019s stock markets are way, way down, but don\u2019t fret. Context matters.\n\nThe Dow fell by 1,175 points on Monday, which represents a 4.6 percent decline, but our economics columnist takes the long view: There were steeper percentage declines on several occasions during the global financial crisis and its aftermath, not to mention the 508-point drop in the Dow in 1987 that represented a 22.6 percent market crash.\n\nAnd one more thing: All of the world\u2019s big economies are now growing.\n\n______\n\nPhoto\n\nOur latest coverage of Australia and New Zealand ranges from food to flight, nudists to firestarters:\n\n\u2022 A Wrestling Team Fights to Prove It\u2019s Not an \u2018African Gang\u2019: Sudanese in Australia have come under unwelcome scrutiny after politicians said they were behind a crime wave in Melbourne. A few ornithologists have set out to find proof.
