Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe context\n\nThe change comes after an outside review of behavior within the stock-picking unit and reports of sexual harassment allegations.\n\nMore from the WSJ\u2019s Sarah Krouse and Kirsten Grind:\n\nStock picking has been under unprecedented pressure in recent years as investors have poured money into low-cost index-tracking funds. The star-manager system helped fuel careers of top fund managers at the family-run firm, but it also created a system in which portfolio managers wielded outsize power over analysts, more than a dozen current and former employees said.\n\nPhoto\n\nCorporate America examines its relationship with gun makers\n\nBlackstone asked outside fund managers to detail their ownership in companies that make or sell guns by Sunday evening, according to unnamed sources that spoke to the WSJ.\n\nBank of America said it was examining its relationship with the weapons industry, too.\n\nAnd Best Western, Delta Air Lines, MetLife, Symantec and United Airlines joined the ranks of companies cutting ties to the N.R.A. Here\u2019s the list of companies that have distanced themselves so far.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe response to the Florida school shooting has happened faster than after previous mass attacks, partly because the survivors are teenagers well versed in the power of social media, The NYT\u2019s Julie Creswell and Tiffany Hsu report.\n\nWhat does this mean for corporate social responsibility?\n\n\u2022 Mike Allen of Axios: \u201cBe it guns or global warming, a fascinating trend is unfolding in the Trump era: Corporations, under intense social pressure, are filling a void left by governmental gridlock or avoidance.\u201d\n\n\u2022 Brooke Masters of The FT: \u201cWading into America\u2019s fundamental divide on gun rights, even in the wake of a tragic school shooting, was probably not the way most chief executives expected to respond to the new enthusiasm for corporate social responsibility. There are big risks involved.\u201d\n\nMore on gun control\n\n\u2022 Lawmakers return to Washington today under pressure to break the decades-long inertia on the issue. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Thousands turned up for a gun show in Tampa, Fla. One seller of body armor said most of his sales had been to teachers, school administrators and \u201cparents who are scared to death.\u201d (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nA looming fight over changes in tax law\n\nThe rush by Republicans in Congress to overhaul U.S. tax law before the end of last year has complicated planning for individual taxpayers.\n\nAnd things could grow more uncertain as fights are expected over the changes, The NYT\u2019s Jim Tankersley reports.\n\nHere\u2019s Jeffrey C. LeSage, vice chairman for the Americas of KPMG\u2019s tax practice:\n\nThis is anything but tax simplification. I don\u2019t personally see us coming back to the rates that we\u2019ve had, historically, on the corporate side. On the individual side, who knows?\u201d\n\nThe Washington flyaround\n\n\u2022 President Trump\u2019s legal team is examining potential routes to provide testimony to the special counsel, including giving written answers to his questions, according to unnamed sources. (WSJ)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 The House Intelligence Committee has released a redacted Democratic memo rebutting claims by Republicans that top officials at the Justice Department and the F.B.I. abused their power in the Russia investigation. (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nPresident Xi Jinping looks to stay in power indefinitely\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party announced that it intended to abolish term limits on the presidency.\n\nThe move has injected new uncertainty into international politics, NYT\u2019s Jane Perlez and Javier Hern\u00e1ndez report.\n\nThe ruling Communist Party\u2019s decision to open a path to a third term for Mr. Xi heightened a sense of resentment in China among academics, lawyers, journalists and business executives. Many have watched warily as Mr. Xi has used his power to imprison scores of dissidents, stifle free speech and tighten oversight of the economy, the world\u2019s second largest.\n\nThe plan could also exacerbate a tense relationship between Beijing and Washington, which is preparing plans to impose tariffs on Chinese imports and to limit Chinese investments in the U.S.\n\nCritics\u2019 corner\n\n\u2022 Christopher Beddor of Breakingviews: \u201cOpaque as it is, international companies and investment firms had grown accustomed to the rules of the Chinese political game as it has been played for two decades. It is rapidly evolving into something new. They should not brush this aside as mere politics.\u201d\n\nThe China flyaround\n\n\u2022 Li Shufu, the Chinese businessman who owns the Geely group, acquired a $9 billion stake in Daimler, which makes Mercedes-Benz cars and trucks. Forging ties with Daimler could be tough for Geely, writes Jeffrey Goldfarb of Breakingviews. And the money would have been far better spent on organic growth, Bloomberg Gadfly\u2019s David Fickling argues.\n\n\u2022 Regulators in control of Anbang indicated that they intend to hold onto the Waldorf Astoria, unnamed sources told the WSJ. But they are listening to offers for other hotels in Anbang\u2019s portfolio.\n\n\u2022 The challenge for those regulators: They must avoid a fire sale and contagion that could hit healthier financial institutions.\n\n\u2022 China\u2019s crackdown on outbound deals and heavy debt loads is colliding with pushback from American authorities citing national security concerns. The road from China to the U.S. appears to be largely closed for now, writes Brooke Sutherland of Bloomberg Gadfly.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Tech leaders are envisioning a reinvention of the city. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Researchers and technology firms are looking at social media and smartphone use to see if the data reveal changes in physical and mental health. (NYT)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 Apple will start storing encryption keys for some iCloud customers in China, raising concerns with some privacy experts. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 In the push for self-driving cars, a variety of technology and automotive companies are pursuing efforts to create mapping systems, hoping to beat Google to the punch. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Facebook and Google are struggling to contain posts falsely claiming that some survivors of the Florida school shooting were paid actors. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Russian spies hacked computers at the 2018 Winter Olympics and tried to make it appear that the intrusion was by North Korea, according to unnamed U.S. officials. (Washington Post)\n\nPhoto\n\nPushback against \u2018Blockchain Bros\u2019\n\nWomen always question if they\u2019re qualified. But look at these clowns around us.\n\nThat\u2019s Arianna Simpson, one of the relatively few women who were early cryptocurrency investors.\n\nThe world of virtual currencies and blockchain has been dominated by men, but female investors and entrepreneurs are trying to change that.\n\nRevolving Door\n\n\u2022 McKinsey has elected Kevin Sneader, the firm\u2019s Asia-Pacific chairman, to lead the consultancy. (FT)\n\n\u2022 Marianne Lake, JPMorgan\u2019s chief financial officer, has emerged as a contender to succeed Jamie Dimon. (WSJ)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Speed Read\n\n\u2022 TCI Fund Management, run by the investor Christopher Hohn, and TPG-Axon Management have sued funds managed by the private-equity company IREO over a big Indian real estate bet that has failed to see much of the capital invested returned more than a decade later. (Barron\u2019s)\n\n\u2022 Deutsche Bank plans to sell a minority stake in its asset management business as part of an initial public offering next month. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 Saudi Arabia is making overtures to China and Russia for help in diversifying its oil-dependent economy. At stake is the Saudi Aramco public offering and the future of the kingdom\u2019s economic overhaul. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Qualcomm said it believed it had made progress in takeover talks with its suitor Broadcom regarding regulatory and other issues. Qualcomm also urged Broadcom to negotiate further over the price of the deal, after having called previous offers an undervaluation. (Reuters)\n\n\u2022 Investors are borrowing a record amount to buy stocks, which could lead to more volatile financial markets, analysts say. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Volkswagen\u2019s U.S. business has agreed to settle a lawsuit brought by more than 300 diesel vehicle owners over the carmaker\u2019s emissions scandal. (Reuters)\n\nKnow someone who would enjoy this newsletter? Tell them to sign up here.\n\nYou can find live updates throughout the day at nytimes.com/dealbook.\n\nWe\u2019d love your feedback. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Will Buffett\u2019s Bet on Apple Work Out?: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Wall Street watchers should ask:\n\nIs this good or bad volatility? In recent years, investment bank executives had differentiated between two types of volatility: One that leads to less trading because it frightens and confuses investors, and another that generates a higher level of trading because investors see changes in yields and prices they have to adapt to. Goldman is counting on the latter.\n\nIs Goldman well positioned to profit? The bank has a plan to revamp its bond trading operations that centers on broadening the types of investors it does business with. The bank was too dependent on hedge funds that liked to make big bets on bonds, currencies and commodities, so it has made efforts to bring in large asset managers and other financial institutions as clients. But do these new clients trade anywhere near as much as the hedge funds, and are the trades they do as profitable as the ones the hedge funds favor?\n\nGoldman\u2019s first-quarter earnings could offer clues.\n\nPhoto\n\nMaybe the meal-kit industry isn\u2019t dead yet.\n\nBlue Apron gained notoriety when its I.P.O. proved to be one of the biggest busts last year and spurred talk that the meal kit industry was a flash in the pan. But its latest results showed some tentative signs of life \u2014 and those of its biggest rival, HelloFresh of Germany, suggest that it isn\u2019t worth writing off the sector just yet.\n\nWhat Blue Apron reported\n\n\u2022 For the fourth quarter, the company reported a 13 percent year-on-year drop in revenue, to $187.7 million \u2014 less than analysts had expected.\n\n\u2022 It also reported a $39 million loss for the quarter, again a smaller loss than expected.\n\n\u2022 Both the cost of goods sold and marketing expenditures were down from the year-ago period.\n\n\u2022 The company\u2019s customer rolls dropped 15 percent year-on-year to 746,000, though the company said that was to be expected from the lower marketing spend.\n\n\u2022 The average orders per customer and revenue per customer each rose a tiny bit.\n\nBlue Apron\u2019s ability to hold the line on marketing expenses was probably the most promising sign, though that was in part because management was also focused on improving operations at the company\u2019s distribution center in Linden, N.J.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe HelloFresh perspective\n\nHelloFresh has had a better run in the stock markets since going public last year. The latest good news for the company: Its preliminary sales numbers for its just-closed fiscal quarter beat analyst expectations, while its customer base has grown.\n\nHere\u2019s what its C.E.O., Dominik Richter, told me last week about why the meal-kit business isn\u2019t doomed, necessarily:\n\n\u2022 His company has managed to make its marketing profitable, with every dollar spent turning into $3 in sales.\n\n\u2022 Though the company overall has run a loss \u2014 93 million euro, or $115 million, in the 2016 fiscal year \u2014 it has shown profitability in some of its markets. Mr. Richter contended that the company could become profitable this year. \u201cIt\u2019s not something that we need to strive for or put a lot of effort into,\u201d he said.\n\n\u2022 He added that he doesn\u2019t see supermarkets selling their own meal kits as true competitors, running counter to investor fears that the combined Amazon/Whole Foods portends doom for smaller competitors. \u201cWe have more in common with Chipotle or a fast-casual chain,\u201d he said.\n\nThe tale of the tape\n\nBlue Apron\u2019s shares are down 66 percent since their debut. HelloFresh\u2019s are up 23 percent since they started trading.\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nBlackstone names Jonathan Gray as president and C.O.O.\n\nThe head of Blackstone\u2019s real estate business has long been considered the likely successor to Hamilton \u201cTony\u201d James, the firm\u2019s president and chief operating officer.\n\nToday that became a reality.\n\nBlackstone announced that Mr. Gray will become the private-equity firm\u2019s president and C.O.O., taking over the day-to-day operations of the firm. Mr. James was named executive vice chairman. Both will report to Stephen A. Schwarzman, Blackstone\u2019s co-founder, chairman and chief executive.\n\nMr. Gray, 48, joined Blackstone straight out of college in 1992. He has led Blackstone\u2019s real estate group since its creation in 2005.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. James, 67, joined Blackstone in 2002 as vice chairman and C.O.O. He was named president in 2006.\n\n\u201cI have had a wonderful 15 years at Blackstone so far and still savor every minute of it. One of my most important responsibilities is succession, and I am blessed to have a spectacular leader and investor like Jon Gray to whom I can hand the reins,\u201d Mr. James said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe stock markets have done Jay Powell a solid\n\nThe Federal Reserve chairman took his position this year facing plenty of economic factors that could stoke inflation, including:\n\n\u2022 Resurgent global economies\n\n\u2022 Years of cheap and plentiful credit\n\n\u2022 Joblessness falling to multiyear lows, making it easier for workers to get a raise or a bonus, which could push up companies\u2019 costs\n\nThen the Fed\u2019s job got harder. Congress passed a large tax cut that will add a jolt of stimulus to an economy that no longer needs extra juice. The stock market loved it and kept zooming higher.\n\nBut turbulence hit. On Feb. 5, the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted over 1,100 points, or 4.6 percent.\n\nThat brought some much-needed caution\n\n\u2022 Junk bonds, for instance, have sold off. (Financial conditions, however, are still loose enough for Broadcom to raise $100 billion in the debt markets for its Qualcomm takeover bid.)\n\n\u2022 Investors in the stock market, down 7.6 percent from its high, now know the party can\u2019t go on uninterrupted.\n\n\u2022 People are having a real debate about inflation.\n\nIn other words, nose-diving stocks did Mr. Powell a favor: They threw some cold water on the animal spirits that Congress whipped up.\n\nThe notes of caution\n\nThe best scenario for the Fed is that the rate hikes forecast for this year are enough to also limit the stimulus from the tax overhaul.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMeanwhile, to finance the deficit, the Treasury Department now has to sell more billions of dollars of extra bonds. The huge new government demand for credit could push up interest rates in the markets. The Fed may be fine with that, given that it is expected to raise interest rates this year. But if interest rates in the bond market spike higher than investors expect, or the Fed is happy with, Mr. Powell would face his first big challenge as Fed chairman.\n\n\u2014 Peter Eavis\n\nAnd for the Fed\u2019s No. 2 spot..: The WSJ is reporting that the Trump administration is considering nominating Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester as vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve Board in Washington.\n\nIn brief prepared remarks at a ceremonial swearing-in on Tuesday, Mr. Powell said: \u201cWhile the challenges we face are always evolving, the Fed\u2019s approach will remain the same. Today, the global economy is recovering strongly for the first time in a decade. We are in the process of gradually normalizing both interest rate policy and our balance sheet with a view to extending the recovery and sustaining the pursuit of our objectives.\u201d\n\nIs the 30-year bull market in bonds over? Ray Dalio thinks so. The Bridgewater Associates mogul wrote on LinkedIn, \u201cWe don\u2019t know exactly how far we are from the top in the stock market and then the economy, though it is clear that we are past the top in the bond market.\u201d (Others disagree.)\n\nMore in markets: They jumped yesterday, but how will they react to the Bureau of Labor Statistics\u2019 inflation report tomorrow? And who is \u201c50 Cent,\u201d the trader who made $200 million from last week\u2019s volatility?\n\nTo find its new C.E.O., Chipotle turn to...\n\nIn its prime, Chipotle Mexican Grill positioned itself as the paragon of clean, casual, cool dining, a darling of Wall Street, a restaurant industry innovator.\n\nBasically, nothing like Taco Bell.\n\nHow the tables have turned. Chipotle has spent the past few years struggling to recover from a string of food safety crises, steady abandonment by its clientele and a plunging stock price. For help, the chain is turning to the quick-serve cousin many once thought was inferior.\n\nBrian Niccol, the chief executive of Taco Bell, will replace Chipotle\u2019s founder Steve Ells as chief executive on March 5. Mr. Niccol is tasked with replicating his success transforming Taco Bell from a fast food afterthought to a social media-savvy company with sleek new stores and a hugely popular Doritos Locos Tacos product.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShares of Chipotle are up 12 percent after hours.\n\n\u2014 Tiffany Hsu\n\nBroadcom just moved the goal posts in its hostile takeover bid for Qualcomm.\n\nBroadcom announced on Tuesday that it is seeking only a majority of the chip maker\u2019s board seats in next month\u2019s shareholder vote.\n\nBroadcom said that it was now pursuing the election of six nominees that it had put forward, rather than the full 11 it had originally named.\n\nMr. Tan essentially signaled that Broadcom would seek fewer board seats in an interview on CNBC on Monday.\n\n\u201cIf at least a majority of our slate does not get in on March 6, then I guess we will get the message that this deal is not going to happen,\u201d he said. We will walk.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The All-New DealBook Newsletter Our columnist Andrew Ross Sorkin and his Times colleagues help you make sense of major business and policy headlines \u2014 and the power-brokers who shape them. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBoth companies are expected to meet on Wednesday for the first time in months.\n\n\u2014 Michael de la Merced\n\nPhoto\n\nPeltz to leave Mondelez\u2019s board.\n\nAfter nearly four years on Mondelez International\u2019s board, the activist investor Nelson Peltz is stepping down on March 1 to focus on his other board commitments.\n\nThe decision comes two months after Mr. Peltz won a seat on Procter & Gamble\u2019s board in what was one of the largest, priciest and nastiest corporate proxy fights in history. He will join P.&G.\u2019s board on March 1.\n\nMondelez said that Debra Crew, the Reynolds American chief executive, and Peter May, Trian Fund president, will be named to the board the same day as Mr. Peltz steps down.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Peltz joined Mondelez\u2019s board in 2014 after he ended his push for a merger between Pepsi and Mondelez.\n\nPhoto\n\nA sexual discrimination suit roils Steve Cohen\u2019s new firm\n\nAs the billionaire prepares to get back in the hedge fund game with Point72 Asset Management, a lawsuit from a female executive, Lauren Bonner, has drawn back the curtain on what she describes as a toxic environment for women:\n\n\u2022 Just one of 125 portfolio managers is a woman.\n\n\u2022 Women were often excluded from meetings.\n\n\u2022 For several weeks last year, a white board in one executive\u2019s office had \u201cpussy\u201d written on it.\n\nMr. Cohen himself isn\u2019t accused of wrongdoing, and Point72 denied the allegations.\n\nThe bigger picture: Point72 is expected to open as a full-fledged hedge fund this year, after Mr. Cohen\u2019s ban from the securities industry expired in 2017. And Ms. Bonner\u2019s lawsuit is an unusually prominent sexual discrimination case in the world of hedge funds.\n\nThe misconduct flyaround\n\n\u2022 In his latest column, Andrew asks whether it helps Harvey Weinstein\u2019s victims for the New York attorney general to block the sale of the Weinstein Company? (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Betterworks Systems shows how hard it is for a Silicon Valley start-up to move on from a sexual harassment scandal. (Bloomberg)\n\n\u2022 The C.E.O. of the U.S. Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, Javier Palomarez, was ousted amid allegations of financial impropriety and sexual harassment. (NYT)\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat\u2019s for sale in the Trump infrastructure plan\n\nAmong the assets that could be sold to private financiers if the White House got its $1.5 trillion infrastructure investment program:\n\n\u2022 Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport and Dulles International Airport\n\n\u2022 The George Washington and Baltimore Washington parkways\n\n\u2022 The Washington Aqueduct\n\nThe thinking behind the plan\n\nThe administration believes private investors can do a better job of running highways, airports and railroads than the government, and states and local governments can do a better job of allocating money. But critics say its plan unfairly favors rural areas over liberal-leaning major cities. (Economists also say that it\u2019s a \u201cbizarre time\u201d for such a stimulus, Ben White of Politico writes.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAn interesting point about infrastructure investment\n\nDan Primack of Axios points out:\n\nPhoto\n\nThe average level of return sought by infrastructure investment funds was about 10.6 percent in 2016, down from 14 percent in 2004, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers and the Global Infrastructure Investor Association. They\u2019re generally considered a low-but-steady return asset class, which may be why they only raised about $200 billion from 2006 to 2016.\n\nThe big question: Can private investors fill in the $1.3 trillion required to fulfill the White House\u2019s vision?\n\nThe Washington flyaround\n\n\u2022 The White House\u2019s $4.4 trillion budget (which lawmakers will likely ignore) would add $7 trillion to the deficit over the next decade. The Trump administration\u2019s budget chief, Mick Mulvaney, conceded, \u201cDoes it balance? No, it doesn\u2019t.\u201d\n\n\u2022 The administration is suffering from a 34 percent turnover rate, the highest for a White House in decades. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The controversy over Rob Porter again raised the issue of national security clearances at the White House \u2014 and why Jared Kushner\u2019s still isn\u2019t permanent. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 \u201cReciprocal taxes\u201d on countries the White House considers unfair trade partners won\u2019t be simple to enact. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 On immigration, the Senate is taking an unusual approach: an open-ended debate to build a bill from scratch on the legislative floor. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Republicans are pressuring Bob Corker to consider staying on, for fear of losing his Senate seat. (Politico)\n\nPhoto\n\nHow Facebook came to a reckoning\n\nWhen Mark Zuckerberg said it was \u201cpretty crazy\u201d to think fake news on Facebook could tip an election, one executive feared that the company would head down the \u201cpariah path that Uber was on.\u201d Now, people say that he has faced a deeper realization about that ways that the platform can be abused.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHere\u2019s a recounting of what Mr. Zuckerberg told employees last Thanksgiving about the company\u2019s responsibility, from Nicholas Thompson and Fred Vogelstein of Wired:\n\nAccording to one attendee, the remarks came across as blunter and more personal than any they\u2019d ever heard from Zuckerberg. He seemed humble, even a little chastened. \u201cI don\u2019t think he sleeps well at night,\u201d the employee says. \u201cI think he has remorse for what has happened.\u201d\n\nMore Facebook news: It\u2019s losing younger users, eMarketer says. Its default privacy settings violate German law, a Berlin court says. And it\u2019s experimenting with a news section on its video platform to help users find reliable sources.\n\nThe tech flyaround\n\n\u2022 Scott Galloway of NYU\u2019s Stern School of Business says that it\u2019s time to break up Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google. (Esquire)\n\n\u2022 Amazon is laying off hundreds of employees in Seattle and internationally, unnamed sources say. (Seattle Times)\n\n\u2022 Russia has threatened to block YouTube and Instagram if they don\u2019t take down videos and photos relating to the oligarch Oleg Deripaska. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 A cyberattack disrupted internet access and telecasts during the Winter Olympics opening ceremony. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 The Trump White House has done little to counter China\u2019s rise in A.I. research. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Google is selling access to its powerful A.I. chips. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Top university computer science courses are rushing to add ethics courses. (NYT)\n\n\u2022 Who gets to experience 5G first? Pyeongchang\u2019s wild boars. (Bloomberg)\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat would make Broadcom walk away from Qualcomm\n\nBroadcom\u2019s C.E.O., Hock Tan, told CNBC what would stop him, as the companies prepare for a Valentine\u2019s Day meeting:\n\n\u2022 If Qualcomm\u2019s shareholders don\u2019t vote for a majority of the directors that Broadcom has nominated for its target\u2019s board. \u201cI guess we will get the message that this deal is not going to happen,\u201d he said.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 If Qualcomm raises its bid for NXP Semiconductors beyond $110 a share. \u201cWe have made it very clear, it\u2019s a clear transfer of value from Qualcomm shareholders to NXPI shareholders,\u201d he said.\n\nThe deals flyaround\n\n\u2022 Walgreens Boots Alliance has made a preliminary takeover bid for AmerisourceBergen, a drug distributor that it owns 26 percent of, unnamed sources say. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Disney may need to raise its $52.4 billion bid for Fox to stave off Comcast. (Breakingviews)\n\n\u2022 Fox has offered to insulate Sky News\u2019s editorial staff as a concession to British regulators considering its bid for the satellite broadcaster Sky. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Carl Icahn and Darwin Deason, two big investors in Xerox, urged their fellow shareholders not to \u201clet Fuji steal\u201d the company. (Reuters)\n\n\u2022 General Dynamics\u2019 $6.8 billion bid for CSRA highlights an era of increased military spending. (DealBook)\n\n\u2022 Here\u2019s the betting on who will buy Time Inc. titles from Meredith. (Vanity Fair)\n\nRevolving door\n\n\u2022 Equifax hired Jamil Farshchi as its chief information security officer, in the wake of its giant data breach last year. (WSJ)\n\n\u2022 Snap\u2019s head of sales, Jeff Lucas, is leaving as the company relies more on automated ad bidding. It\u2019s the latest in a string of executive departures. Please email thoughts and suggestions to bizday@nytimes.com.", "title": "Will Market Volatility Help Goldman Get Its Groove Back?: DealBook Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Then, on New Year\u2019s Day, Mr. Kim announced that he wanted to send North Korean athletes to Pyeongchang, though only two \u2014 a figure-skating duo \u2014 had qualified. It was a pinky-finger promise not to stage any provocations during the Winter Games. It was also a stunning act of theater.\n\nIn swift succession, just days before the opening of the Pyeongchang Games, the two Koreas agreed to march into the Olympic arena under a unified flag, to field a joint women\u2019s ice hockey team for the first time at an Olympics and to stage cultural performances. Mr. Kim had yet one more surprise: He sent not only North Korea\u2019s ceremonial head of state but also his trusted younger sister in what will be the first official visit by an immediate member of the Kim family to South Korea.\n\nThis may sound like a movie-ready Olympic story of peace and reconciliation, but I doubt it will be so simple.\n\nAs a young journalist, I was at Sydney\u2019s Olympic Stadium in 2000 when the two Koreas marched in together, for the first time at an Olympic Games, under the white-and-pale-blue \u201cunified Korea\u201d flag. The moment, met by cheers and a standing ovation, sent chills down my spine. It felt like we were on the cusp of a new era of peace.\n\nEighteen years later, the mood is different here in South Korea. Hope for peace has been replaced by distrust and skepticism. The South Koreans who remember Korea as one country and long for its reunification \u2014 my grandparents\u2019 generation \u2014 are gone. Younger people, accustomed to affluence, are less willing to shoulder the financial burden of reconciliation or reunification, a wariness reflected in the drop in President Moon Jae-in\u2019s popularity in recent days.\n\nIt\u2019s not just skeptical South Koreans whom Mr. Moon needs to placate. As the Games begin, South Korea must navigate hosting the North Korean athletes and officials without violating United Nations sanctions \u2014 and without alienating Washington, which is leading a global campaign to pressure, punish and isolate Pyongyang for its nuclear defiance.\n\n\u201cWe will not allow North Korean propaganda to hijack the message and imagery of the Olympic Games,\u201d Vice President Mike Pence said en route to Pyeongchang, vowing to highlight North Korean provocations and alleged human rights abuses and promising new sanctions.", "title": "Opinion | Will North Korea Win the Gold Medal for Deceit?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Gail: Blocking the kids out of my mind. Will not even mention Junior mixing business with \u2014 government \u2014 in India.\n\nLet\u2019s move on to Congress. House and Senate skulking back into action \u2014 or whatever you call what it is they do. Doesn\u2019t look as if there\u2019ll be any action on guns, does it?\n\nBret: Not while Republicans are in control. The president has spoken about raising the age limit for the purchase of assault rifles to 21, along with a ban on so-called bump stocks, which are devices that help increase the rate of fire. The N.R.A. seems broadly opposed to both, however, so that\u2019s a nonstarter. And I don\u2019t think Trump is going to expend much political capital on getting the G.O.P. to change its mind, either. Which is a tragedy, given the number of future mass shootings we can expect, considering how many past ones we\u2019ve endured.\n\nGail: Yeah, if it hurts gun business, it\u2019s toast. Like the N.R.A. folk, Trump lives in an alternate universe where being armed means always being capable of hitting somebody in a crisis situation. And of course the president himself would have run right into that school the second he heard gunfire, armed or not. Because that\u2019s just the kind of guy he is.\n\nI think we should start by challenging him to hit the side of a barn.\n\nBret: In an alternative universe, Trump might have been the president with the popular clout to oppose the rank-and-file G.O.P. on the positions worth opposing \u2014 like the ones the party has on guns and abortion rights \u2014 while not opposing it on the positions worth preserving, like its past friendliness toward free trade and immigration. But since he\u2019s incapable of broadening his base, he\u2019s going to become ever more dependent on its hardest and most extreme core.\n\nGail: Yeah, remember when we thought he might be someplace between Mitt Romney and Bernie Sanders? As opposed to where we find him now, which is someplace between a weekend replacement talking head on Fox and a professional wrestling villain.\n\nBut about guns \u2014 you may be more radical than I am, given that you want to repeal the Second Amendment, while I\u2019d be thrilled if we could just prohibit gun dealers from selling caches of weapons across state lines. I just can\u2019t summon the energy to talk about changing the Constitution. When was the last success \u2014 1992? And it was to ban Congress from getting a pay raise until after an election had passed. Which had originally been submitted for ratification in 1789. Wahoo.", "title": "Opinion | Will We Ever Stop With the Political Games?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Good morning. Happy Valentine\u2019s Day, if you celebrate that feast of courtly love. It\u2019s a nice evening for cooking someone special a rib-eye steak with potatoes (above) \u2014 or at any rate a nice evening for cooking something special for someone, even if it\u2019s just a mug of spicy hot chocolate (or a platter of Melissa Clark\u2019s brownie-style cookies with white chocolate, nuts and dried cherries!)\n\nNo? Be kind to people on this day, however you feel about the hearts and Cupids and flowers. Not everyone\u2019s a cynic. Not everyone\u2019s happy. But pretty much everyone likes sweet potato fries.\n\nI could see making shrimp scampi this evening, as a gesture of affection for those I feed. I could absolutely imagine serving a bowl of pappardelle with greens and ricotta. I might make Rishia Zimmern\u2019s amazing recipe for chicken with shallots, and put a Valentine card in front of each setting at the table. Apple crisp for dessert! With ice cream!\n\nOr, because it\u2019s Wednesday, and there\u2019s no way I\u2019m making ice cream on a Wednesday, I might freestyle dessert in keeping with our midweek tradition of cooking without a recipe: Valentine\u2019s sundaes of strawberry ice cream with hot fudge. The fudge is easy so long as you keep the ratios right: 1 cup each of cocoa powder, white sugar and heavy cream, whisked together over medium heat; 1 stick of unsalted butter, stirred in by pats until everything\u2019s velvet; a glug of vanilla and you\u2019re good to go. Drizzle that over the strawbo, and call this evening a win. It beats the jarred stuff from the bodega by a considerable margin. Store what you don\u2019t eat in the refrigerator, in a covered jar.", "title": "Will You Be My Valentine?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "BANGKOK \u2014 A senior cabinet minister and army general from Myanmar arrived in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Thursday to discuss a trouble-plagued scheme to repatriate Rohingya Muslims who fled military assaults and now are in camps in Bangladesh.\n\nIn less than half a year, around 700,000 Rohingya escaped attacks in their home state, Rakhine, and what the international community has called ethnic cleansing by Myanmar\u2019s security forces.\n\nThe Myanmar government insists it is committed to the repatriation of those Rohingya who can prove they recently left Rakhine. The Bangladeshi side says the same.\n\nBut few expect that the two days of meetings between Lt. Gen. Kyaw Swe, Myanmar\u2019s home minister, and Asaduzzaman Khan Kamal, his Bangladeshi counterpart, will elicit much action. Over months of sporadic talks, each side has blamed the other for failing to put in place a voluntary repatriation agreement signed in November.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nOn Monday, Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina of Bangladesh called on the international community to increase pressure on Myanmar to take back the Rohingya.", "title": "Will the Rohingya Ever Return Home?", "authors": ["Hannah Beech"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "So while filing an appeal to the Ninth Circuit, the administration\u2019s lawyers also went to the Supreme Court with a \u201cpetition for a writ of certiorari before judgment,\u201d a request to the justices to hear the case this spring without waiting. The Supreme Court\u2019s rules reserve this court-jumping procedure for cases of \u201cimperative public importance.\u201d Only a handful of cases has cleared that bar, including the Nixon tapes case, which effectively forced the president\u2019s resignation and the 1981 case that ratified the agreement that ended the Iran hostage crisis. Invoking those cases, Solicitor General Francisco insists to the court that \u201cthat standard has been met here,\u201d an assertion the plaintiffs vigorously dispute.\n\nSaying so doesn\u2019t make it so, and in fact the odds of a rebuff from the Supreme Court are so good as to raise the question of why the president\u2019s legal team doesn\u2019t devote its energy to the Ninth Circuit, which has agreed to hear the appeal on an expedited schedule. Beyond the president\u2019s grudge against the appeals court, I think the answer lies in a more subtle effort to demonize Judge Alsup and through him, the growing number of federal district judges who are pushing back against the administration across a range of issues. The petition sends a message that Judge Alsup \u2014 a highly respected veteran of 17 years on the bench \u2014 and by extension, the others, are so out of line that the country can\u2019t afford to wait for a normal appeal to run its course. And if the Supreme Court doesn\u2019t take the bait \u2014 well, that just shows that the justices are part of the problem.\n\nIt\u2019s no wonder that in the hall of mirrors that passes for the Trump administration\u2019s legal policy shop, this case, U.S. Department of Homeland Security v. Regents of the University of California, looms large. Judge Alsup and, most recently, Judge Garaufis in Brooklyn, have called the president\u2019s hand. Their analysis is a subtle one. Judge Alsup suggests, and Judge Garaufis says explicitly, that the president has the legal right to terminate the DACA program if he does so properly. What was improper about the order issued in September by the acting secretary of homeland security to wind DACA down in six months? Judge Alsup observed that the administration based its action not on a policy judgment, which might have rendered the termination unreviewable in court, but on a \u201cmistake of law.\u201d The judge noted that President Trump had repeatedly said and tweeted that he liked the Dreamers and wanted to help them. These statements left Attorney General Jeff Sessions and other die hard anti-immigrant presidential advisers with a problem. Disabled by the president himself from an all-out attack on DACA on policy grounds, they had to come up with another rationale for ending the program.\n\nWhat they came up with was something called \u201clitigation risk.\u201d It turned out that Texas and allied states, which had successfully gone to court to stop the Obama administration from expanding the DACA program to include more than four million parents of DACA-eligible children, had conveniently offered to sue to undo DACA itself. This lawsuit would succeed because the program was in fact illegal, Attorney General Sessions declared in a memo aimed at providing a seeming law-based, and therefore neutral, justification for ending the program.\n\nBut that \u201cpithy conclusion\u201d of illegality was not the attorney general\u2019s to reach, Judge Alsup said in his opinion, explaining that \u201cdetermining illegality is a quintessential role of the courts.\u201d He said the current DACA program and the earlier proposed expansion that the lower courts had invalidated were sufficiently distinct as to make improper a simple extrapolation from one to the other. The judge labeled the \u201clitigation risk\u201d explanation a \u201cpost hoc rationalization\u201d \u2014 an explanation made up after the fact to fit a desired outcome.", "title": "Opinion | Will the Supreme Court Become Trump\u2019s Enabler?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "The last thing the Middle East needs is another country with the potential to build nuclear weapons. Yet that could happen if the United States mishandles Saudi Arabia\u2019s plans to enter the nuclear power business and erect as many as 16 nuclear reactors for electricity generation over 25 years.\n\nThe Saudis aren\u2019t saying they want to become the second country, after Israel, to have a nuclear arsenal in the increasingly unstable region. They insist the reactors would be used only to generate energy for domestic purposes, so they can rely on their huge reserves of oil to generate income from overseas.\n\nStill, there are growing signs that the Saudis want the option of building nuclear weapons to hedge against their archrival, Iran, which had a robust nuclear program before accepting severe curbs under a 2015 deal with the United States and other major powers.\n\nObama administration efforts to negotiate an agreement on transferring civil nuclear technology \u2014 required before a country can buy American nuclear technology \u2014 faltered over the Saudis\u2019 refusal to make a legally binding commitment to forgo uranium enrichment and plutonium reprocessing, which could be used to produce fuel for nuclear weapons. The United Arab Emirates made a commitment like that in its 2009 agreement, setting the nonproliferation \u201cgold standard\u201d for civil nuclear cooperation deals.", "title": "Opinion | Will the U.S. Help the Saudis Get a Nuclear Weapon?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "James Anthony Tyler\u2019s \u201cArtney Jackson\u201d is the third play that will receive a world premiere in Williamstown this summer. Pooh is a famous yellow bear and favorite good-luck charm of Hanyu.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut before the Games, Hanyu, of Japan, learned that he couldn\u2019t carry his trademark bear with him at competitions. The Disney character is his personal mascot, and according to a fan blog, he finds comfort in Pooh\u2019s unchanging gaze.\n\n\u201cSome conflict with the sponsor, so I was not able to bring the yellow bear,\u201d said Hanyu after the men\u2019s short program. The International Olympic Committee has strict rules about the nonessential products athletes are allowed to carry with them to competitions.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow he leaves Pooh at the hotel. \u201cI put my head against the head of the yellow bear because it\u2019s a good-luck charm for me,\u201d Hanyu said.\n\nPhoto\n\nSoohorang, the white tiger, has been a constant presence at every Olympic venue and in the souvenir stores. We\u2019re excavating some of the more peculiar provisions included in the 600-plus-page bill.", "title": "Winter Games, Syria, Rob Porter: Your Thursday Evening Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Norwegians Take Top Two Spots in Men\u2019s Downhill\n\nAksel Lund Svindal gave Norway its first men\u2019s downhill gold on Thursday.\n\nUnder a bright sky and a warm sun, Svindal turned in a gutsy run on a winding but tame course that was almost perfectly suited to him. His teammate, Kjetil Jansrud, took the silver medal, finishing 0.12 of a second behind Svindal in a triumphant showing for the country that has won more medals than any other at the Winter Olympics but is better known for its prowess in Nordic sports.\n\nBeat Feuz of Switzerland finished 0.18 of a second behind Svindal and won bronze.\n\nAll three medal winners were lucky enough to be among the first 10 skiers on a day when the sun was heating up and slowing down the snow with each passing minute.\n\nSvindal, one of the elder statesmen of the Alpine circuit at 35, blasted out of the starting gate, poling and skating his way down the initial slope. Midway through his run he lost his balance, went upright in the middle of the jump and landed on the back of his skis 20 feet down the hill. Svindal somehow regained his stability though and ended up gaining speed on the relatively flat and winding third quarter of the course where so many other races were losing time.", "title": "Winter Olympics 2018 Medals: Aksel Svindal Wins Men\u2019s Downhill", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "A slight change in the program.\n\nWith the North Koreans deciding just a month before the start of the Winter Games to send a delegation, there was little time to adjust the opening ceremony. Five hours before the start of the show, Song Seung-whan, a South Korean actor and popular theatrical producer who served as director, said that he had only tinkered with one segment to reflect North Korea\u2019s presence. (He would not offer any spoiler alerts.)\n\nLooking relaxed in a black turtleneck sweater and jeans, Mr. Song said that his biggest concern in the run-up to the ceremony was the cold. \u201cWe had to develop many contingency plans just in case the weather went bad,\u201d he said. A few days ago, when temperatures plunged below zero degrees Fahrenheit, dancers were given spikes for their shoes to ensure that they could dance in icy conditions. Mr. Song said that engineers were also concerned that the hundreds of electronic devices being deployed for the ceremony might not work in the freezing temperatures, but \u201cwe tested them at the rehearsal, and they were fine.\u201d\n\nAs it turns out, the weather on Friday night was practically balmy, expected to fall only to about 28 degrees.\n\nMr. Song said he struggled to keep the show, which features 1,300 performers and another 700 volunteers in one scene, within a \u201cvery limited budget.\u201d He declined to say what that budget was, but noted with a laugh: \u201cIt was far less than Beijing.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThomas Bach, gold medalist, opened the Games.\n\nThomas Bach, president of the International Olympic Committee, made his appearance. She finished ninth.\n\nGermany Wins Bobsled\n\nFrancesco Friedrich of Germany, driver of the winning two-man sled, added the gold medal in the four-man bob. A second German sled and South Korea tied for the silver. Germany won gold in all three bobsled events at the Games. It was Germany\u2019s 14th gold medal at the Games, equaling a record set by Canada in Vancouver in 2010. Norway also won 14 golds at these Games.\n\nMass Start Wins to Japan and South Korea\n\nNana Takagi of Japan and Seung-Hoon Lee of South Korea won the mass start speedskating races. New at these Olympics, mass start races are the only long-track events in which skaters all race at once. \u201cAs the first mass start, I feel very happy to do this in front of my home crowd and I am honored to get so much praise with this medal,\u201d Lee said.\n\nCanadian Athlete and Manager Arrested\n\nTwo members of the Canada\u2019s Olympic delegation, an athlete and a manager, were arrested Friday in Pyeongchang, accused of stealing an idling car and driving drunk, a local police official and representative of Team Canada said Saturday.\n\nLee In-ho, superintendent of the Gangwon Province Police, declined to name the athlete or manager but said the driver had a blood alcohol level of .160. [The New York Times]\n\n\u2022 London\u2019s City Airport was shut down when a German bomb from World War II was found during construction work. The airport will be operating as usual today. [The New York Times]\n\nSmarter Living\n\nTips, both new and old, for a more fulfilling life.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Want a more perfect union? Act (within limits) like you\u2019re single.\n\n\u2022 Studies on giving up saturated fats often failed to consider what people ate in their place.\n\n\u2022 For Mardi Gras, you can\u2019t go wrong with a chicken and sausage gumbo.\n\nNoteworthy\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Newly unveiled official portraits of Barack and Michelle Obama caused a stir. They are strikingly different from their predecessors\u2019. (Portrait painting is generally making a comeback.)\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2022 For the first time since 1945, Ash Wednesday and Valentine\u2019s Day fall on the same day. Some Christians face a culinary dilemma.\n\n\u2022 Thousands of dogs have been checked into New York hotels ahead of the annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. Here\u2019s our full coverage of the canine high society.\n\n\u2022 A \u201ccognitive prosthetic\u201d in the brain promises to help people store some memory, scientists have found. But the road to perfecting recollections remains daunting.\n\n\u2022 And she\u2019s off! Our new 52 Places travel columnist \u2014 who beat out more than 13,000 other applicants for the job \u2014 has started her whirlwind world tour. She found plenty to celebrate in New Orleans.\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\nAs the end of a particularly bad flu season approaches in many parts of the world, you\u2019re probably accustomed to hearing \u201cachoo!\u201d\n\nBut cultures respond to sneezes differently, and there\u2019s little consensus on how some of those norms developed.\n\nWhile it\u2019s unnecessary in Japan and parts of China to comment, many countries use a version of \u201c(God) bless you.\u201d\n\nThe sneezer\u2019s welfare is the main concern. Germans say \u201cgesundheit\u201d (health), while Turks say \u201c\u00e7ok ya\u015fa\u201d (may you live long).\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSometimes the response is dictated by the number of sneezes. In parts of Latin America, the first sneeze is met with \u201chealth,\u201d the second with \u201cmoney\u201d and the third with \u201clove.\u201d The Dutch wish you \u201chealth\u201d for your first two sneezes before the third time turns into \u201cgood weather tomorrow.\u201d\n\nHealth-based wishes seem self-explanatory, but the origin of \u201cGod bless you\u201d is uncertain.\n\nThe most popular theory is that Pope Gregory I started it by blessing a person infected with the plague. But it\u2019s probably not true.\n\nAcademics believe saying \u201cbless you\u201d to a sneezer can be traced back even earlier \u2014 some say to 77 A.D., others to Greek mythology.\n\nAnna Schaverien contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nSign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning, or to receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights.\n\nBrowse our full range of Times newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 Best of late-night TV\n\nStephen Colbert used a schoolyard taunt to try to persuade President Trump to speak with the special counsel: \u201cChicken!\u201d\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cOne hundred years in the context of history is a drop in the ocean.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Julianne Hughes-Jennet, a lawyer, on the 100th anniversary of women getting the right to vote in Britain.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 The Times, in other words\n\nHere\u2019s an image of today\u2019s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nBack Story\n\nMaybe you thought it was just the title of a Tom Wolfe novel.\n\nOn this day in 1497, supporters of the firebrand Dominican friar Girolamo Savonarola burned \u201cindecent\u201d cosmetics, art and books in Florence, Italy. It became the best known of many such fires, and usually gets uppercase status: the Bonfire of the Vanities.\n\nPhoto\n\nSavonarola railed against corruption and advocated the destruction of secular art and culture. He denounced the nude paintings of the Italian Renaissance and attacked the powerful Medici family.\n\nHe briefly led Florence \u2014 one account called him its \u201cmoral dictator\u201d \u2014 when the Medicis were temporarily ousted in 1494. He drew support from those who felt culturally and economically alienated. And he spread his message through one-page screeds, becoming one of the first purveyors of printed political propaganda.\n\nBut a few months after his major bonfire, he was excommunicated by a foe, the Borgia pope Alexander VI. The next year, he was executed: hanged and burned before a mob in the Piazza della Signoria.\n\nThe monastery that served as his home and headquarters is now the Museum of San Marco in Florence.\n\nKaren Zraick contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Winter Olympics, SpaceX, Steve Wynn: Your Wednesday Briefing", "authors": ["Chris Stanford"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Valentine\u2019s Day is widely thought to mark a wine-fueled festival for courting couples in ancient Rome.\n\nBut in North Korea, it signifies a different kind of affection. On this day in 2012, Kim Jong-il, who led the country from 1994 until his death in 2011, was posthumously named a \u201cgeneralissimo.\u201d\n\nThe announcement came two days before what would have been Mr. Kim\u2019s 70th birthday, which is still celebrated in the country as \u201cThe Day of the Shining Star.\u201d\n\nThe only other North Korean generalissimo is Mr. Kim\u2019s father, Kim Il-sung, who began ruling in 1945 and received the title in 1992, two years before his death. The term is a clear cut above the \u201cmarshal\u201d title held by North Korea\u2019s third and current leader, Kim Jong-un.\n\nThe younger Mr. Kim may stay in power for decades, though, and he already has several titles: \u201cDear respected comrade,\u201d for one, as well as \u201csupreme commander\u201d of the Korean People\u2019s Army.\n\nMike Ives contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online.\n\nSign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning, or to receive an Evening Briefing on U.S. weeknights.\n\nBrowse our full range of Times newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Two imminent threats: a nasty outbreak of norovirus and hackers.\n\nDozens of Russian athletes lost an appeal against their ban from the Games over a state-sponsored doping scheme. And we have the back story to how North Korea\u2019s participation came about: months of quiet diplomacy in Switzerland and elsewhere.\n\nYou can find our full Olympic coverage here. And you can get direct messages from one of our editors in Pyeongchang. (He\u2019s taking questions and suggestions for our three dozen journalists there.)", "title": "Winter Olympics, Wall Street, Syria: Your Friday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Who was doing it and why they were doing it could take several months to figure out. Ryan Sherstobitoff, a senior analyst at McAfee, said the hacks had appeared to be well organized and backed by substantial resources, with \u201cthe hallmarks of a nation state.\u201d What that nation state planned to do with the stolen data and its foothold in victims\u2019 machines, Mr. Sherstobitoff said, was still anyone\u2019s guess.\n\nA spokesman for the International Olympic Committee declined to comment on how the organization was addressing the heightened threats.\n\nSecurity researchers often discuss risks with a level of informed paranoia. Some of their warnings are based on what is possible but has not actually occurred in the real world. On other occasions, their warnings are based on what has already happened, and where those incidents could lead.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut cyberattacks on international events have become common. The 2015 nuclear negotiations in Geneva and the 2009 climate talks in Copenhagen, for example, were plagued by hackers from various nation states. The Olympics are another alluring target \u2014 but with wall-to-wall television coverage.\n\n\u201cThe Olympics involve so many countries, and so many sports, many of which have their own infrastructure, that it has become a rich target environment for many adversaries,\u201d said John Hultquist, director of threat intelligence at the security firm FireEye.\n\nHe has been tracking the activities of Russian hackers and other groups as they lay the groundwork for attacks on Olympic organizations. In the past few months, Mr. Hultquist said, his team at FireEye has seen several examples of Russian groups tampering with the computers of Olympic-related organizations. The activity is \u201cobviously meant to drag Olympics-related organizations through the mud and discredit them,\u201d he said.\n\nThe Russian cyberespionage group known as Fancy Bear, which has been tied to the 2016 hack of the Democratic National Committee and has links to Russia\u2019s main military intelligence unit, has already started posting hacked emails intended to highlight discord among global sports officials and investigators who exposed systemic Russian doping.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLast month, the group posted emails and other documents online from the International Luge Federation, claiming they demonstrated violations of antidoping rules. And earlier in January, the group released hacked emails and documents from the International Olympic Committee, which it advertised as proof \u201cthe Europeans and the Anglo-Saxons are fighting for power and cash in the sports world.\u201d\n\nTrend Micro, the Tokyo-based security company, said its researchers had also witnessed Fancy Bear attacks on the International Ice Hockey Federation, the International Ski Federation, the International Biathlon Union, and the International Bobsleigh and Skeleton Federation in the final months of 2017. The attacks occurred while an International Olympic Committee disciplinary panel was preparing bans for dozens of Russian athletes caught doping in the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.\n\n\u201cThe Kremlin has its fingerprints on cyberattacks that were retribution for exposing the Russians\u2019 Sochi games doping scheme, which was a fraud on the purity of sport,\u201d said Doug DePeppe, a founder of Sports ISAO, a nonprofit cybersecurity organization in Colorado Springs. The group is trying to help sports associations, including Olympic organizations, combat threats.\n\n\u201cTheir goal is to say, \u2018No one is following the rules, and Russia shouldn\u2019t be singled out,\u2019\u201d Mr. DePeppe said.\n\nFireEye, McAfee and other security companies said that over the past few months they had seen attack groups from Russia, and others of unknown origin, dispatch hundreds of \u201cspearphishing\u201d emails, laced with malicious links and attachments, to target Olympic-related groups.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Interested in All Things Tech? The Bits newsletter will keep you updated on the latest from Silicon Valley and the technology industry. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThey also have seen the groups set up computer servers under the names of some of their targets and seemingly innocuous organizations like the South Korean Ministry of Forestry. They warn that those activities could be a prelude for a broader Russian campaign.\n\nIn 2016, Russian hackers targeted the World Anti-Doping Agency after it recommended that Russian athletes be banned from the 2016 Rio Games because of doping. The personal data of more than 40 athletes was leaked not long after.\n\nThe worst-case scenario would be attacks in which hackers tried to shut off lights in a stadium during an event, or perhaps even tampered with electronic timing results, warned Betsy Cooper, the executive director at the Center for Long-Term Cybersecurity at the University of California, Berkeley.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nTo protect the Olympics, South Korea has mobilized tens of thousands of security personnel, including cybersecurity analysts and 50,000 soldiers, in what has been described as one of the most militarized security forces in Olympic history.\n\nOver the past few weeks, the United States State Department has set up a temporary security monitoring operation on one floor of its embassy in Seoul. Analysts from the State Department, the intelligence community and the Department of Homeland Security are scheduled to arrive there this week.\n\nBut an official who was briefed on the State Department-led operation, and who was not allowed to discuss it publicly, worried that the operation was too focused on combating traditional threats like physical attacks on venues.\n\nThe State Department did not reply to a request for comment.\n\nElsewhere in Pyeongchang, an alliance of security personnel from South Korea, various Olympic sponsors, technology suppliers and cybersecurity sleuths from around the world are monitoring computer screens and potential threats at the unmarked Security Command Center.\n\nEach country participating in the Olympics also has its own security delegation on the ground, with those from the United States and Israel among the largest. Those delegations are busy conducting their own threat assessments and receiving daily threat briefings from South Korean law enforcement authorities.\n\nWhile cybersecurity experts believe the North Korean threat was lessened by the last-minute addition of a North Korean delegation to the Games, they have not ruled out that North Korea may be looking to embarrass its southern neighbor.\n\n\u201cOne thing is for certain: We can\u2019t simply rely on these actors to behave themselves in this context,\u201d Mr. Hultquist said. \u201cThey\u2019ve proven, again and again, over the past few years that they are not afraid to flout international norms and create chaos.\u201d", "title": "Winter Olympics\u2019 Security on Alert, but Hackers Have a Head Start", "authors": ["Nicole Perlroth"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Q. How do you print from a Google Chromebook?\n\nA. Wireless printers designated as \u201ccloud-ready\u201d are typically the most straightforward to use with a Chrome OS netbook. But if you have an older \u201cclassic\u201d Wi-Fi printer without the \u201cCloud-ready\u201d label, you should still be able to use it with your Chromebook, as long as you have Google\u2019s Chrome browser on a Windows or Mac computer to handle the setup chores. (Google\u2019s YouTube channel has videos that demonstrate how to set up both cloud-ready and \u201cclassic\u201d printers to work with a Chromebook.)\n\nIf you have a cloud-ready printer already working on your network, sign into your Chromebook and make sure it is connected to the same network as the printer. Click your account\u2019s profile photo and select Settings on the Chromebook. At the bottom of the Settings list, select Advanced, go to the Printing section and choose Printers. Click \u201cAdd Printer.\u201d Choose your network\u2019s printer and click Add. (If you do not see your printer, the Chromebook support site has instructions for adding it manually.)", "title": "Wireless (or Wired) Chromebook Printing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "MONDAY PUZZLE \u2014 Are you the shy, quiet type? Today\u2019s collaboration, by Mark Diehl and Andrea Carla Michaels, reveals that there may be another, more passionate side to you.\n\nWe often see Mr. Diehl\u2019s byline toward the end of the week, but he\u2019s hitting for the cycle with this one, technically speaking. After publishing mostly late-week puzzles, some midweek ones and this Tuesday puzzle (from the pre-Shortz era), he now has a puzzle for every day of the week.\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nThe old SAW (our revealer at 57D) in today\u2019s puzzle is \u201cSTILL WATERS RUN DEEP.\u201d According to Merriam-Webster, the meaning of the adage is that people who are quiet (\u201cSTILL\u201d) often have interesting qualities or passion below the surface.\n\nAre you having trouble finding the adage? Take a closer look at the first words of each theme entry:\n\nSTILL KICKING\n\nWATERS DOWN\n\nRUN ERRANDS\n\nDEEP THOUGHTS\n\nRUN ERRANDS is not the strongest of the set, in my opinion, but the others are lively. I also liked SMOLDERS next to AIR KISS, and GREW UP ON for the sentimentality of the phrase.", "title": "Wise Old Saying", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "There was never any doubt that \u201cBlack Panther\u201d would rock the North American box office. Kevin Feige, the prodigy who runs Marvel, and Alan F. Horn, Disney\u2019s movie chairman, have delivered one juggernaut after another. Robert A. Iger, Disney\u2019s chief executive, took a personal interest in \u201cBlack Panther,\u201d approving its $200 million production budget (at least 30 percent more than budgets for other Marvel nonsequels like \u201cDoctor Strange\u201d and \u201cAnt-Man\u201d) despite concern by some at Disney about sales of \u201cBlack Panther\u201d toys.\n\n\u201cThe concept of an African story, with actors of African descent at the forefront, combined with the scale of modern franchise filmmaking, is something that hasn\u2019t really been seen before,\u201d Mr. Coogler, the director, told The Hollywood Reporter. \u201cYou feel like you\u2019re getting the opportunity of seeing something fresh, being a part of something new, which I think all audiences want to experience regardless of whether they are of African descent or not.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\n[ALSO READ: Wakanda is a Fake Country, but the African Language in Black Panther is Real]\n\nBut no one quite knew how \u201cBlack Panther\u201d would perform overseas.\n\nBig-budget films that focus on black characters have long been held back by the Hollywood argument \u2014 a ridiculous one, in the eyes of many critics \u2014 that foreign audiences have little interest in films with largely black casts. It has been a self-fulfilling attitude; studios, ever fixated on what kinds of movies have succeeded in the past, never challenged the assumption with a big-budget fantasy because they were always too afraid to take the risk.\n\n\u201cBlack Panther\u201d arrived to very strong results in the United Kingdom, Belgium, Ukraine, South Korea, Mexico and Brazil, in many cases beating initial ticket sales for Marvel nonsequels based on lesser-known characters, including \u201cGuardians of the Galaxy\u201d in 2014.\n\n\u201cBlack Panther\u201d was softer in Germany, an important market, where the sadomasochistic \u201cFifty Shades Freed\u201d outsold it.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re extremely pleased with the reaction around the world, even more so because we face nothing competitively for a month,\u201d said Dave Hollis, Disney\u2019s president of distribution.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDisney will release \u201cBlack Panther\u201d in Russia, China and Japan in the weeks ahead. Success in China, the world\u2019s fastest-growing movie market, would be particularly sweet. If audiences there do not respond, however, it could have little to do with race. Hollywood imports are losing their luster in China as local studios become more skilled at making blockbuster-style movies. (Over the weekend in China, the locally produced \u201cMonster Hunt 2\u201d arrived to more than $130 million in ticket sales. Lionsgate gave it a 69-screen release in the United States, collecting $390,000.)\n\n[ALSO READ: Black Panther Cosplayers: \u2018We\u2019re Helping People See Us as Heroes\u2019]\n\nThe frenzy surrounding \u201cBlack Panther\u201d has been puzzling to some.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s an important chipping away at this Hollywood notion that somehow studios are taking a bigger risk if they cast nonwhite actors, but I don\u2019t see it as a profound change,\u201d said Todd Boyd, a cinema and media studies professor at the University of Southern California who focuses on popular culture and race. \u201cI ultimately see it as exploiting a profitable niche.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cTo me, there is real change afoot when diverse actors are cast in roles that are not inherently diverse,\u201d Mr. Boyd added.\n\nBut many people stood in line to praise Disney for pushing toward more diverse filmmaking. Richard Gelfond, chief executive of Imax, the large-format movie exhibitor, which played \u201cBlack Panther\u201d in more than 60 countries, championed Disney for delivering \u201ccontent that is compelling on its face but also bridges the gap between different cultures, and ultimately is a reflection of the shared values of moviegoers all over the world.\u201d\n\nPhil Contrino, director of media and research for the National Association of Theater Owners, noted the power of seeing \u201cBlack Panther\u201d in a communal setting on a big screen. \u201cHopefully someday we\u2019ll look back at the release of \u2018Black Panther\u2019 as the turning point when diversity and positive representation in blockbusters switched from being an anomaly to being normal,\u201d Mr. Contrino said.\n\nAnd Stacy L. Smith, an author of blistering studies about Hollywood\u2019s lack of diversity, wrote on Twitter in a message to Mr. Iger, who has made inclusion a priority across Disney: \u201cWe have been watching; lead & supporting roles have been changing as well as behind the camera. There is more to be done but this weekend is a giant leap forward.\u201d", "title": "With $218 Million Haul, \u2018Black Panther\u2019 Smashes Box Office Records", "authors": ["Brooks Barnes"]} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "COCHRANE, Chile \u2014 An eagle soared over the lone house atop an arid hill in the steppes of Patagonia Park.\n\nIn the valley below, not far from the town of Cochrane, President Michelle Bachelet announced the creation of a vast national park system in Chile stretching from Hornopir\u00e9n, 715 miles south of the capital, Santiago, to Cape Horn, the southern tip of South America, where Chile splinters into fjords and canals.\n\nThe park is the brainchild of Kristine McDivitt Tompkins and her husband, Douglas Tompkins, who founded the North Face and Esprit clothing companies, and starting in 1991, put $345 million \u2014 much of his fortune \u2014 buying large swaths of Patagonia.", "title": "With 10 Million Acres in Patagonia, a National Park System Is Born", "authors": ["Pascale Bonnefoy"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 A lavish four-hour Lunar New Year show televised to millions across China on Thursday night set off a flood of indignation with its caricatures featuring blackface and African men in animal suits.\n\nThe gala, televised by China\u2019s state broadcaster, featured a well-known Chinese actress as an African woman with exaggerated buttocks, a large chest and a face painted black. Carrying a platter of fruit on her head, she was accompanied by an African man dressed as a monkey.\n\nMany found the portrayals offensive.\n\nHannah Getachew, 30, a law student at Peking University who is from Ethiopia, said that while an apology from CCTV would be welcome, the damage had already been done.\n\n\u201cFor all of his faults, Bill Cosby hired a Harvard professor of psychiatry to consult on almost every episode of \u2018The Cosby Show\u2019 to ensure that there wasn\u2019t a single stereotype of people,\u201d Ms. Getachew said. \u201cChina should consider similar action. What we need now is a clear signal that this sort of event will never occur again.\u201d", "title": "With Blackface and Monkey Suit, Chinese Gala on Africa Causes Uproar", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "Much to the chagrin of educators and advocates, the program, created in 2012 by President Barack Obama, has become a bargaining chip for the White House. Mr. Trump has conditioned its codification in law on Democratic acceptance of tough demands, including an end to decades of family-based migration policies, a wall on the Mexican border and a crackdown on other immigrants in the country illegally.\n\n\u201cEvery day, educators are being told to forget about the fact that at any given moment the rug will be pulled out of your lives and you may lose your job,\u201d said Lily Eskelsen Garc\u00eda, the president of the N.E.A., the nation\u2019s largest labor union. \u201cTo see them treated in this despicable way, to see them treated as pawns, is just not fair.\u201d\n\nMr. Trump recently said he supported a path to citizenship for DACA recipients who \u201cdo a great job,\u201d a commitment he reiterated in his State of the Union address, which was attended by several DACA recipients \u2014 including Ivonne Orozco, who was recently named New Mexico\u2019s Teacher of the Year.\n\nMs. Reyes resents that she has to prove her worth, beyond her use of her newfound freedom to teach in America\u2019s classrooms.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s so much pressure to be a perfect immigrant,\u201d Ms. Reyes said. \u201cThey basically want us to save babies from burning buildings, have a 5.0 GPA and become doctors. But I\u2019m just teaching these tiny humans to be great Americans.\u201d\n\nMs. Reyes was brought to the United States from Monterrey, Mexico, by her mother at age 2. When she thinks of home, she thinks of the only one she can remember, in San Antonio \u2014 a big city with a small-town feel, where she and her grandmother would pick pecans from a tree in the front yard. Her childhood was \u201call-American,\u201d she said, recalling late afternoons at marching band practice, at the Y.M.C.A. or selling Girl Scout cookies.\n\nThe only thing that distinguished her life from those of her friends was that she spoke Spanish at home, and her mother was strict. When she was 14, she found out why.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHer friends wanted to take a shopping trip to South Padre Island, then Laredo, on the Texas border with Mexico, but her mother forbade her from going because if she came upon an immigration checkpoint, she would not have the paperwork to pass.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt changes the trajectory of your life,\u201d Ms. Reyes said.\n\nThe barriers of being undocumented became more apparent after that \u2014 especially in applying to college. But with teachers\u2019 help, she secured private scholarships for a graduate school program for special education teachers who wanted to teach the hearing-impaired.\n\nShe received her master\u2019s degree from the University of Texas at San Antonio, and now educates six hearing-impaired 3- and 4-year-olds.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s like a game of charades in my classroom everyday, but we have a lot of fun,\u201d Ms. Reyes said. \u201cWe\u2019re on a journey together.\u201d\n\nHugo Arreola, who received DACA protection in 2012, is grappling with guilt.\n\nMr. Arreola works at the Phoenix high school from which he graduated, with 200 DACA recipients, many of whom he persuaded to apply for the program.\n\n\u201cNow, it\u2019s basically putting their trust in the government to not abuse what started as an opportunity, to make deportation lists,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s a lot of anxiety and fear, and questions.\u201d\n\nVicente Rodriguez, an aspiring English teacher, is preparing for the worst. Timing has not been kind to his journey. He was the only one of his mother\u2019s five children born in Mexico, because a family emergency took her back home for a few months. His DACA permit will expire before he can complete his master\u2019s program in teaching.\n\nHe said if he is forced to leave, he will still try to teach.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m educated, so I can go anywhere in the world, but I wanted to be here,\u201d he said. \u201cI wanted to give back \u2014 to be that one good teacher a child remembers \u2014 in the country that gave me this opportunity.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAcross the country, teachers have grappled with the immigration debate\u2019s aftershocks. They deal with crying colleagues, students acting out after a family member is deported and trembling when classmates talk about the past night\u2019s news, and parents skipping teacher conferences and school events.\n\nMs. Garc\u00eda, the N.E.A. president, blamed Mr. Trump.\n\n\u201cIt started at the beginning of this administration, where for the first time in history children cried over who got elected president because of the toxic campaign around immigrants,\u201d she said. \u201cNow, there are crying teachers.\u201d\n\nEducators for Excellence, a teacher-led advocacy group, has helped lead grass-roots efforts to urge Congress to codify DACA, circulating petitions and writing a letter to the president outlining the effects his policies have had on their students.\n\nAnd teachers have turned their classrooms into safe havens for undocumented students and families.\n\n\u201cWe all know we can\u2019t focus on multiplication tables right now,\u201d said Jessica Cuellar, a member of the organization\u2019s DACA team and an assistant principal at a California charter school. \u201cWe\u2019re just listening to them and trying to make them feel safe.\u201d\n\nCarlos Rodriguez, an eighth-grade teacher in Chicago, has used his experience to teach his students lessons of survival.\n\nHe remembers coming to the United States at age 7 with his sister and a dozen other people, traveling through cities and towns, past wire fences and a huge river. He remembers the \u201cflying monster in the air\u201d that he later learned was a helicopter, and the dark place whose door would not open, which he later learned was a train.\n\n\u201cWe educators, we are in the trenches,\u201d Mr. Rodriguez said. \u201cWe see these young people on a daily basis. We see the potential that we can maximize to benefit a country that they call their country.
