The Kurdish-dominated Syrian Democratic Forces took control here about 18 months ago, in a campaign supported by American Special Operations forces and air power. While the Manbij Military Council, which is now in charge, is a majority Arab force, the new government is organized on Mr. Ocalan\u2019s revolutionary principles.\n\nWomen were immediately given the right to divorce, previously a right reserved to men; to inherit property on an equal basis with men; and to keep their children and their homes in a marital breakup. Gone were long-observed Shariah law provisions that gave a woman\u2019s testimony in court only half the weight of a man\u2019s.\n\nThose changes were not without pushback. The Kurdish majority area of Kobani in Syria, for instance, outlawed the practice of men taking more than one wife. But when officials tried to apply that restriction to Manbij, anger from tribal leaders led to the granting of an exception here.\n\nStill, the Women\u2019s House in Manbij right away began aggressively counseling wives whose husbands married a second time that they could divorce, and walk away with the children, the house and half of any property. The result has been some 200 divorces in the past year, mostly in cases of polygamy and underage marriage, said Widat Hayat an Arab woman and a sociologist who heads the research department at the Women\u2019s House. It is an unprecedented number.", "title": "Women Are Free, and Armed, in Kurdish-Controlled Northern Syria", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Three Muslim women have each reached a $60,000 settlement with New York City after they were forced to remove their hijabs to be photographed while in police custody, according to a city official and court documents obtained on Wednesday.\n\nDocuments outlining the settlements were filed in Brooklyn federal court on Monday and reported by the The New York Daily News on Tuesday. Asked about the report, Kimberly Joyce, a spokeswoman for the city\u2019s law department, said in an emailed statement, \u201cThe resolution of these matters were in the best interest of all parties involved.\u201d\n\nThe settlements involved separate cases claiming that the women\u2019s religious rights had been violated.\n\nIn 2012, a Brooklyn high school student detained on a harassment complaint was told to remove her head scarf to be photographed at a central booking center in the borough. She had asked that a female officer take her picture in private, but the request was rejected, according to a complaint filed in district court that year.", "title": "Women Forced to Remove Hijabs for Mug Shots Settle With New York City", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "PALO ALTO, Calif. \u2014 When a cryptocurrency start-up that promised to revolutionize the fruit and vegetable industry shut down last month, it left behind one word on its website: penis.\n\nWhen a virtual currency company called DateCoin recently tried to entice investors for its initial coin offering, it posted a Facebook ad that featured a reclining woman in a swimsuit with text over her body that read, \u201cTouch my I.C.O.\u201d\n\nAnd after the North American Bitcoin Conference in January, which highlighted 84 male speakers and three women, the official conference party was held at a Miami strip club.\n\nVirtual currencies and blockchain, the digital ledger that forms the basis of the cryptocurrencies, were intended to be democratizing and equalizing forces, buoyed by a utopian exuberance. But women who have been trying to participate in the gold rush are finding a lopsided gender divide. And some say the culture is getting worse, with the male-dominated culture buoyed by a new fleet of wealthy crypto speculators known as \u201cblockchain bros.\u201d", "title": "Women in Cryptocurrencies Push Back Against \u2018Blockchain Bros\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Ms. Nielsen plays a grasping buffoon who lusts after much younger men \u2014 a setup that ordinarily, in our entertainment, calls for outright degradation of the woman. Not here, though. Comic humiliation? Absolutely. But there\u2019s a crucial tonal difference: no meanness in it. Ms. Rebeck and the brilliant Linda Cho (who also did the costumes for \u201cSovereignty\u201d) are good to their star. Which turns out to be a lot more fun.\n\n\u2018Created Equal\u2019\n\nBrief digression: Last fall, at Shakespeare\u2019s Globe in London, I saw a subversive confection of a musical called \u201cRomantics Anonymous\u201d that just about wrecked me. Adapted, from the French film of the same name, by Emma Rice, the Globe\u2019s soon-to-depart artistic director, it\u2019s about a tradition-bucking heroine too timid to stand up for her own genius, whose colleagues bow and scrape before an inscrutable man-fool they\u2019ve been told is a savant.\n\nDuring the scene where the heroine, reflexively overlooked, watches a man be congratulated for her sublimely innovative achievement, I put my head in my hands. It is so easy to be invisible, or inaudible, simply by virtue of being female.\n\nAnd this is the thing: that so many women\u2019s stories, for so many years, have gotten overlooked, or drowned out or shouted down, while men\u2019s stories have been enshrined in tradition.\n\nIn the theater, telling and retelling the same tales is part of the culture. There are good reasons to revisit the canon, searching for fresh resonances each time. But there are bad reasons, too, like being so tuned in to male voices and experiences that others fail to register as valid or worthwhile.\n\nGender parity for playwrights, a goal that the Women\u2019s Voices festival is helping to push forward, would almost by default improve our understanding of the world, deepening our knowledge of what it is to be human.\n\nIn the gift shop at Ford\u2019s Theater, there\u2019s a T-shirt emblazoned with a famously democratic phrase. \u201cCreated equal,\u201d it says, a proud allusion to the Gettysburg Address and the Declaration of Independence before it. Equal treatment, though, is something the American experiment has always struggled with. So has the American theater.\n\nIn Washington, that most political of cities, the festival is trying to do something about that. Let\u2019s hope it keeps coming back, with sustained focus and tenacious commitment, until it isn\u2019t needed anymore.", "title": "Women\u2019s Voices Festival a Potent Reminder of Who Goes Unheard Onstage", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "Meanwhile, it turns out that Allen\u2019s private notes over the decades are \u201cfilled with misogynist and lecherous musings,\u201d showing \u201can insistent, vivid obsession with young women and girls,\u201d according to Richard Morgan, who sifted through Allen\u2019s 56-box archive and recounted his findings in The Washington Post.\n\nThere is always a risk that meticulous scrutiny of a long career leads to cherry-picking and finding whatever we\u2019re looking for, especially for somebody trying to be creative and funny. I reached out to Allen through his publicist but did not receive a response. He has consistently denied the allegations of abuse, and in October he warned against allowing \u201ca witch hunt atmosphere, a Salem atmosphere.\u201d\n\nIndeed, the certainty of the Dylan Farrow case is that there has been a gross injustice: Either an innocent man\u2019s career is being destroyed, or a victim has been unfairly doubted since she confided in her pediatrician about an assault when she was 7 years old.\n\nI asked Dylan if there was any chance that this was a false memory, that she had been brainwashed.\n\n\u201cNo,\u201d she said flatly. \u201cI think it\u2019s more logical almost that the people who accuse me of being brainwashed are brainwashed themselves by the celebrity, the glamour, the fantasy, the pull they have to Woody Allen, their hero on a pedestal.\u201d\n\nThe larger point, she said, is not her own suffering over the years, but the need to listen to victims.\n\nThat\u2019s where we have systematically failed \u2014 with gymnasts, with Harvey Weinstein\u2019s victims, with the Catholic Church and with innumerable girls and boys suffering anonymously at the hands of abusive coaches, relatives, family friends or bosses. One demographer\u2019s new estimate is that at least three-fourths of women worldwide have been sexually harassed.\n\nYes, false accusations happen, and we must struggle to balance rights of victims against those of the accused \u2014 but it should be obvious now that we haven\u2019t gotten that balance nearly right. Too often, we have deferred to the powerful and doubted the weak, creating impunity and injustice.\n\nThe problem is not only abusers but more broadly a society that often disbelieves or scorns those crying for help, like that young woman curled up on her bed crying during the Golden Globes. I\u2019ll leave her with the last word:\n\n\u201cWhat needs to change,\u201d she said, with a teary firmness that comes from 25 years of pain, \u201cis our response.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | Woody Allen Meets #MeToo", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Kardashians paint a false picture of millennials,\u201d said Joan Kuhl, founder and president of Why Millennials Matter, a New York research agency. \u201cI don\u2019t see this group with a lavish affluent lifestyle.\u201d\n\nMillennials, many of whom saw their parents struggle with jobs and mortgages during the recession, generally have less interest in buying the big house, flashy sports car and designer clothing that previous generations sought as status symbols of success. Nevertheless, they will pay for the right experiences and technology.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s where you go on vacation, what you do and what technology you have,\u201d said Allen Adamson, one of the founders and managing partners of Metaforce, a brand marketing and consulting firm, and one of the authors of \u201cShift Ahead: How The Best Companies Stay Relevant in a Fast Changing World.\u201d Those experiences need to be \u201cInstagram-worthy,\u201d too. The quirkier, flashier and more offbeat the experience, the better, he said.\n\nAnd businesses are catching on.\n\nIMAX, for instance, rolled out six virtual reality theaters in New York, Los Angeles, Shanghai, Manchester and Toronto over the last year as a pilot project to attract millennials. And it has plans to open four more.\n\nPhoto\n\nIMAX charges roughly $10 for a 10-minute VR experience, which is far cheaper than the $1,500 or more needed to buy an in-home VR technology system with a high-end PC and headset. A visitor steps into a pod, snaps on a VR headset and is virtually transported on a 360-degree journey that can include flying over volcanoes, diving into the world of criminals and hit men from the John Wick films, or stepping into the shoes of virtual game superheroes like Batman and Wonder Woman.\n\nAfterward, the players receive a video of their VR experience, which they can share with friends on social media. \u201cMillennials want really special experiences and ones that are hard to replicate,\u201d said Rich Gelfond, the chief executive of IMAX.\n\nWhen it comes to automobiles, many millennials don\u2019t care about high-end cars the way that previous generations did, but they do want the in-cabin technology and luxury features that often go with them, said Sam Russell, Buick\u2019s marketing director.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSo Buick started marketing the brand as \u201cattainable luxury\u201d to attract younger buyers, and it added features normally seen in cars like Mercedes-Benz, Lexus and BMW to many of its models in recent years, like 4G LTE Wi-Fi, Apple CarPlay and Ionizer air purifiers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs for the Moxy, its very existence is aimed at millennials.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re delivering a killer experience at a price point that\u2019s affordable,\u201d said Toni Stoeckl, global brand leader of Marriott\u2019s Distinctive Select Brands.\n\nTo keep rates down, Moxy\u2019s rooms are tiny, averaging only 183 square feet. But its lounges, bars and public spaces are large and encourage a social atmosphere, where guests can mingle and even play board games with friends and strangers. Guests check in electronically through their phones or through the hotel bar instead of at a front desk. There are special events, like midnight pajama parties, where guests are invited to the bar for a nightcap, as well as yoga classes, tarot card readings and \u201cConBody\u201d events, where ex-convicts lead prison-style boot-camp fitness classes.\n\nAt the Moxy Times Square, a neon-pink light marks the entryway and art graces the ceiling and walls. And its five rooftop dining and nightclub spaces, operated by the Tao Group, contain a rotating carousel bar and outdoor mini-golf course with a clear view of the Empire State Building.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s funky and quite quirky,\u201d said Karl Fegredo, 27, from London, who recently stayed at the hotel.\n\nEven Moxy\u2019s hotel openings are edgy and memorable. At the Moxy New Orleans party, snake charmers, tarot card readers and sword swallowers took part in its \u201cFreak Show\u201d theme. The Berlin Moxy \u201ccoming out\u201d party featured drag queens, dominatrixes and tattoo artists as part of an S.&M. theme.\n\n\u201cMoxy is about transforming yourself in a playful environment,\u201d Mr. Stoeckl said.\n\nMany brands hope that by capturing millennials now, they can turn them into lifelong customers.\n\n\u201cI think everybody understands they really need to home in on millennials,\u201d Mr. Gelfond said, \u201cif they want to create a successful long-term business.\u201d", "title": "Wooing Millennials With Exotic Experiences That Aren\u2019t Too Costly", "authors": ["Janet Morrissey"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Note: Our Fifth Annual 15-Second Vocabulary Video Challenge is now underway. Submit your entry by Feb. 23 at 7 a.m. Eastern time.\n\ncyclic \\ \u02c8s\u012b-klik also \u02c8si- \\ adjective\n\n1. marked by repeated cycles 2. recurring in cycles 3. conforming to the Carnot cycle 4. forming a whorl or having parts arranged in a whorl 5. of a compound having atoms arranged in a ring structure\n\n_________\n\nThe word cyclic has appeared in three articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on June 21 in the Opinion essay \u201cWhat Killed Half a Million Indians?\u201d by Pranay Sinha and Scott K. Heysell:\n\nIndia\u2019s underfunded health care system struggles to provide preventive care to Indians who need it most. Affluent Indians prefer and can afford private institutions. Poor Indians are more likely to avoid preventive care, be malnourished and endure poor living conditions. Unsurprisingly, they are also more likely to get sick. Illness saps their productivity and health care expenditure drains their savings, reinforcing a cyclic and generational poverty. Indeed, Indian children are among the most malnourished and stunted in the world. This physical and cognitive stunting decreases lifetime productivity and wages.\n\n_________\n\nThink you know \u201ccyclic\u201d? Quiz yourself:", "title": "Word + Quiz: cyclic", "authors": ["The Learning Network", "Word Of The Day"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "Note: Our Fifth Annual 15-Second Vocabulary Video Challenge is underway. Submit your entry by Feb. 23 at 7 a.m. Eastern time.\n\npejorative \\ pi-\u02c8j\u022fr-\u0259-tiv , -\u02c8j\u00e4r- \\ noun and adjective\n\nnoun: a word or phrase that expresses disapproval or contempt adjective: expressing disapproval or contempt\n\n_________\n\nThe word pejorative has appeared in 48 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 29 in \u201cTransportive Reading for Underground Transportation\u201d by Adam Sternbergh:", "title": "Word + Quiz: pejorative", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "ascetic \\ \u0259-\u02c8se-tik , a- \\ noun and adjective\n\nnoun: someone who practices self denial as a spiritual discipline adjective: practicing great self-denial adjective: pertaining to or characteristic of an ascetic or the practice of rigorous self-discipline\n\n_________\n\nThe word ascetic has appeared in 29 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 3 in \u201cSurf\u2019s Up in the Rockaways? Let\u2019s Meditate on That\u201d by Corey Kilgannon:\n\nRetreats are extended, disciplined experiences that range from a weekend to more than 10 days, and are offered year-round. Participants are expected to remain silent throughout \u2014 no cellphones permitted \u2014 and eat only during meals, which are provided by the center. ... The retreats are not completely ascetic. For one, the cooking is done by the Italian-born Ms. Maselli, who said she uses produce grown in the house\u2019s expansive yard, as well as products donated by organic companies that support the retreat house. One company donated 2,000 boxes of pasta, which goes nicely with the garden\u2019s bounty of tomatoes.\n\nThink you know \u201cascetic\u201d? Mr. Westdorp noted correctly that it is not a day traditionally known for exchanging gifts. \u201cThe \u2018presents/presence\u2019 you can give to people,\u201d he said, \u201cis extending loving kindness\u201d \u2014 preferably, he added, \u201cin the Buddhist Metta tradition without any clinging or expectation of reciprocation.\u201d\n\nLincoln may well have anticipated all those convictions \u2014 Buddhist, Hindu, Muslim, Jewish and Christian \u2014 when in 1863 he proclaimed the last Thursday in November to be \u201ca day of Thanksgiving and praise to our beneficent Father who dwelleth in the Heavens.\u201d It was formally changed in 1941 to the fourth Thursday in November.", "title": "Word + Quiz: beneficent", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "bullion \\ \u02c8bu\u0307l-y\u0259n , -\u02ccy\u00e4n \\ noun\n\n1. a mass of precious metal 2. gold or silver in bars or ingots\n\n_________\n\nThe word bullion has appeared in 11 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 23 in \u201cFinal Nights at the Trump SoHo Before Trump Checks Out\u201d by Sarah Maslin Nir:", "title": "Word + Quiz: bullion", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Note: Our Fifth Annual 15-Second Vocabulary Video Challenge is underway. But the sweater features a symbol known as the Tyr rune, which neo-Nazis want to claim as their own. ... In many countries a national ski team\u2019s woolen sweater design would not be a major issue, but Norwegians take their knitting seriously. With each Games, both the sweater and its knitting pattern are available for sale to the public. Now, the controversy has caused divisions over whether the ski team\u2019s sweater can be worn with pride. Margaretha Finseth, whose job as the design and brand manager at the House of Yarn, a wholesaler, is to select and sell well-known patterns for Norwegians to knit, decided against this particular sweater. A published author on Norwegian knitting, Ms. Finseth said she did not want to give knitting ideas to white supremacists. \u201cOur greatest fear was that in the next big demonstration everyone would appear\u201d in the ski team\u2019s sweater, she said.\n\n_________\n\nThink you know \u201cdemonstration\u201d? Submit your entry by Feb. 23 at 7 a.m. Eastern time.\n\npersonify \\ p\u0259r-\u02c8s\u00e4-n\u0259-\u02ccf\u012b \\ verb\n\n1. attribute human qualities to something 2. invest with or as with a body; give body to 3. represent, as of a character on stage\n\n_________\n\nThe word personify has appeared in 16 articles on nytimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 1 in the Magazine On Technology column \u201cNot the Bots We Were Looking For\u201d by John Herrman:\n\nBut despite the tech industry\u2019s efforts and hopes, the bots that have most effectively lodged themselves in the public\u2019s consciousness over the last year were not here to help \u2014 at least, not us. A different sort of bot \u2014 undercover but public-facing, highly political but comparatively primitive \u2014 was implicated in toxic and disorienting online conversations throughout the 2016 election cycle.... ... This type of bot bears little resemblance to the ones demonstrated on the stages of tech campus auditoriums. But each sort of bot is made, in its own way, to exploit untapped opportunity in large-scale automation. Where commercial bot-makers see an almost-too-good-to-be-true chance to simultaneously personify their brands and automate their businesses, political bot-makers see an opportunity to exploit anonymity with a humanlike touch at an inhuman scale. While tech companies stand proudly behind their bots, the people who create prolific and ideological social bots hide behind them. (Their provenance remains murky even today.)\n\n_________\n\nThink you know \u201cpersonify\u201d? Quiz yourself:\n\n_________", "title": "Word + Quiz: vat", "authors": ["The Learning Network", "Word Of The Day"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHURSDAY PUZZLE \u2014 The thing about Thursday crosswords is that they\u2019re unpredictable. I happen to like that about them, variety being the spice of life, but it means that we have to prepare ourselves to be challenged.\n\nA good Thursday theme will hold its secrets until the last possible minute, and the fill should both delight and make us rifle through the files in our brains for the occasional factoid we are pretty sure we know. Today\u2019s crossword by Erik Agard fits that bill to a T. Not only was it a fun solve, in my opinion, but I also liked the way he gave a new voice to a 1987 movie called \u201cHOLLYWOOD SHUFFLE.\u201d\n\nToday\u2019s Theme\n\nThe movie, produced, directed and starring Robert Townsend, satirized the dearth of film roles for African-Americans, and how they were misrepresented in Hollywood movies in demeaning roles. I didn\u2019t get the revealer until the end, but that is part of the charm of a Thursday puzzle, and it gave the reminder about how black people have fared in Hollywood an extra wallop.\n\nHow did we get here? I realized that we were dealing with anagrams at 19A, when I filled in TAYE DIGGS using the crossings and my brain said \u201cHuh? How is the actor TAYE DIGGS related to a clue like \u2018Steady gig\u2019?\u201d And then, as they say, it hit me. TAYE DIGGS is an anagram of \u201cSteady gig.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn other words, if you shuffle the clue, you get the name of a Hollywood actor. HOLLYWOOD SHUFFLE (57A and 61A). There are three more shuffled Hollywood stars in the puzzle, so go find them.", "title": "Word That Becomes Its Own Synonym", "authors": ["Deb Amlen"]} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "BOTTROP, Germany \u2014 Guido Reil is a coal miner, like his father and grandfather before him. He joined a trade union at 18 and the center-left Social Democratic Party at 20. Fast-talking and loud, he has been an elected union representative for over a decade.\n\nBut two years ago, after the arrival of hundreds of thousands of refugees in Germany, Mr. Reil switched to the far-right Alternative for Germany party, or AfD. Competing in state legislative elections last May, the party won 20 percent of the vote in his home district with his name on its list \u2014 and the Social Democrats slipped 16 percentage points from a previous election.\n\n\u201cThose are my former comrades,\u201d Mr. Reil said, chuckling. \u201cThey came with me.\u201d\n\nHow is a far-right party drawing voters from labor, a traditional bastion of the left? The question is not academic, but goes directly to the heart of the emerging threat the AfD presents to Germany\u2019s political establishment, including Chancellor Angela Merkel.\n\nThe AfD shocked Germany in the fall when it became the first far-right party to enter Parliament since World War II. But that breakthrough not only shattered a significant postwar taboo. It has also enormously complicated the task of forming a new governing coalition, leaving Germany and all of Europe in months of limbo.", "title": "Workers of Germany, Unite: The New Siren Call of the Far Right", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "Night-shift work is linked to an increased risk for Type 2 diabetes, a new study has found.\n\nBritish and American researchers used a large health database to compare diabetes prevalence in 47,286 night-shift workers with that of 224,928 day workers.\n\nThe database included information on age, sex, race, family history of diabetes, alcohol use, sleep duration, body mass index and other health and behavioral characteristics, as well as diagnoses of diabetes.\n\nAfter controlling for many other factors associated with diabetes, they found that the more often people worked nights, the more likely they were to have diabetes. Compared with day workers, people who occasionally worked night shifts were 15 percent more likely to have diabetes; those who rotated shifts with some night work were 18 percent more likely; and those who worked irregular shifts with frequent night shifts were 44 percent more likely to have Type 2 diabetes. The study is in Diabetes Care.\n\nThe lead author, C\u00e9line Vetter, an assistant professor at the University of Colorado, said that night-shift work can cause misalignment of circadian rhythms, reduced energy expenditure, and partial sleep restriction, which can all contribute to the risk.", "title": "Working Nights May Raise Diabetes Risk", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Rauch said that while he would start working on plans for the Perelman Center now, he would remain with the Shakespeare festival through the summer of 2019, when he will move to New York.\n\nHis hiring was the latest indication that the project \u2014 which has appeared to be in doubt several times since the idea was included in the architect Daniel Libeskind\u2019s master plan for the site in 2003 \u2014 was moving forward. For years it was on the back burner: Potential tenants including the old New York City Opera, the Signature Theater Company and the Joyce Theater came and went, and the architect Frank Gehry created a design for it that was then shelved. Rival arts spaces were proposed, including the Shed, at the Hudson Yards on the West Side, and a new park on Pier 55 near 14th Street with three outdoor performance areas underwritten by the billionaire Barry Diller.\n\nBut Mr. Perelman\u2019s $75 million donation in 2016 got the project back on track.\n\nOfficials with the center said that they had raised $295 million, or 82 percent of its expected $363 million construction price tag. And on Thursday the Port Authority\u2019s board of commissioners ratified an agreement to enter into a 99-year lease with the Perelman Center. Once the lease is signed, the center is to pay the Port Authority $48 million from funding it will receive from the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation to cover the cost of the below-ground construction underway so that the theater, which is being designed by the architecture firm REX, can be built.\n\nMr. Rauch is the latest in a series of artistic figures involved in the project: David Lan, who led the Young Vic theater in London, was initially its temporary artistic director before he left a couple of years ago. Mr. Rauch said that they had spoken about the job several times.\n\nWhile he did not tip his hand too much about what he envisioned for the site, he did say that he hoped to create thematic programming \u2014 inviting, say, a dance company from another part of the world to create a piece there while commissioning a new play by a playwright with roots in the same area and inviting immigrants from around the city to see it. \u201cI think our job as an arts organization,\u201d he said, \u201cis to bring hope by bringing people together.\u201d", "title": "World Trade Center Arts Space Gets a Lease, and a Leader", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "ROME \u2014 Pope Francis and his diplomats have been quietly pouring energy into negotiations with the Chinese government that could help end a decades-long dispute over control of the Catholic Church in the country.\n\nBut as signs of a possible breakthrough have emerged \u2014 how bishops get ordained has long been a sticking point \u2014 some Catholics are worried. They fear that the Vatican, in its eagerness for a deal, could betray clerics and parishioners who have illicitly practiced their faith for decades and risked arrest and persecution by worshiping in the so-called underground church. They are also alarmed that a deal could end the independence for which the underground church has long stood.\n\nThe dissension escalated on Friday as the retired archbishop of Hong Kong, Cardinal Joseph Zen, intensified his criticism of the talks, saying that a reconciliation could result in 12 million Chinese Catholics being effectively put in a Communist-controlled \u201ccage.\u201d He has accused church bureaucrats of \u201cselling out\u201d Chinese Catholics, and warned, \u201cA church enslaved by the government is no real Catholic Church.\u201d\n\nCardinal Zen did not attack the pope directly, but called Cardinal Pietro Parolin, the pope\u2019s second-in-command, \u201ca man of little faith.\u201d Another prelate has mocked one of the pope\u2019s close collaborators as living \u201cin Wonderland\u201d for his depiction of China as a country uniquely in sync with the church\u2019s values.", "title": "Worries Rise as Pope and China Edge Closer to Deal on Bishops", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDo you use social media? If so, would you ever consider disconnecting from a particular platform you use now, or leaving all your social media feeds entirely? What do you think you would gain or lose?\n\nIn the Opinion essay \u201cI Quit Twitter and It Feels Great,\u201d Lindy West writes about quitting Twitter more than a year ago:\n\nTo be clear, it\u2019s not brave to quit Twitter, or righteous (I\u2019m still on Facebook, which is just a differently shaped moral stockyard), or noteworthy. Quitting Twitter is just a thing that you can do. I mention it only because there was a time when I didn\u2019t think it was a thing that I could do, and then I did it, and now my life is better. I\u2019m frequently approached by colleagues, usually women, who ask me about quitting Twitter with hushed titillation, as if I\u2019ve escaped a cult or broken a particularly seductive taboo. Well, here\u2019s what my new life is like: I don\u2019t wake up with a pit in my stomach every day, dreading what horrors accrued in my phone overnight. I don\u2019t get dragged into protracted, bad-faith arguments with teenage boys about whether poor people deserve medical care, or whether putting nice guys in the friend zone is a hate crime. I don\u2019t spend hours every week blocking and reporting trolls and screen-grabbing abuse in case it someday escalates into a credible threat. I no longer feel like my brain is trapped in a centrifuge filled with swastikas and Alex Jones\u2019s spittle. Time is finite, and now I have more of it. At the same time, I know this conversation is more complicated than that. I\u2019ve lost a large platform to self-promote and make professional connections, which isn\u2019t something many writers can afford to give up (less established writers and marginalized writers most of all \u2014 in a horrid irony, the same writers disproportionately abused on Twitter). I get my news on a slight delay. I seethe at the perception that I ceded any ground to trolls trying to push me out. I will probably never persuade RuPaul to be my friend. Also, I loved Twitter. Twitter is funny and smart and validating and cathartic. It feels, when you are embroiled in it, like the place where everything is happening. (Scoff if you like, but the president of the United States makes major policy announcements there. This is the world now.)\n\nStudents: Read the entire essay, then tell us:\n\n\u2014 What are your thoughts on the experiences Ms. West says she\u2019s had while using Twitter and after she stopped using her account?\n\n\u2014 Is Twitter a form of social media that you use regularly? What other platforms do you use? Are there any you\u2019d consider quitting? Why?\n\n\u2014 Would you ever consider giving up all social media for a short time?\n\n\u2014 What about permanently giving it up?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u2014 Ms. West mentions that because she\u2019s a writer, there is an expectation that she engage with the \u201cdiscourse\u201d taking place on social media as well as use social media to network. Do you think your career will require you to maintain a social media presence? How do you feel about that?\n\n\u2014 She also says she has more time as a result of giving up Twitter. What are your thoughts about that?", "title": "Would You Quit Social Media?", "authors": ["Shannon Doyne", "Student Opinion"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "I\u2019m looking for a lady who\u2019s loyal to the end, a real bite-or-die \u2014 I mean, ride-or-die bae. Oh, and I love a lady with a nice neck. Hope you don\u2019t mind if I leave a mark!\n\nYou must have a valid passport, because I love to fly off to exotic locations at the bat of an eye.\n\nSo what do you say: Do you want a stake in my heart?\n\nWhy you should swipe right: You love to travel, too.\n\nWhy you should swipe left: I\u2019m available only at night. I\u2019m just not a morning person.\n\nKing Kong in \u2018King Kong.\u2019 Age: 85.\n\nPhoto\n\nLoves: Climbing.\n\nHates: Planes \u2014 so annoying when they buzz over you.\n\nFavorite song: \u201cI Would Die 4 U.\u201d (Rest in peace, Prince.)\n\nI\u2019m a big, strong beast, and I would put you in the palm of my hand to protect you if I could. I may look terrifying, but I\u2019m really a gentle giant.\n\nI\u2019m originally from Skull Island, but I identify as a New Yorker. There is something about the city\u2019s skyline that makes me go bananas. But in a good way. I\u2019d love to take you to the top of one of Manhattan\u2019s tallest towers. You won\u2019t believe the view.\n\nWhy you should swipe right: I have kind eyes.\n\nWhy you should swipe left: You\u2019re afraid of heights.\n\nThe Monster in \u2018Young Frankenstein.\u2019 Age: Depends on the Body Part.\n\nPhoto\n\nI\u2019m a tall guy, so I\u2019d prefer to date a woman who\u2019s six feet or taller (sorry, shorties!). If you\u2019re into wearing high heels, even better. Maybe we can see eye-to-eye.\n\n\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI\u2019m good with children, unless they startle me. Other fears include fire. Fire bad!\n\nIf you like a cultured, sophisticated man about town, I might be the guy you\u2019re looking for. Just ask me and I\u2019ll perform my foot-stomping version of \u201cPuttin\u2019 on the Ritz.\u201d\n\nI\u2019m not what you\u2019d call a clothes horse, but I\u2019m as comfortable in a tuxedo as I am in casual wear.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nMy friends would describe me as having an electrifying personality.\n\nWhy you should swipe right: One of my exes said I helped her find the sweet mystery of life.\n\nWhy you should swipe left: Baldists need not apply.\n\nThe Beast in \u2018Beauty and the Beast.\u2019 Age: 20.\n\nPhoto\n\nI live in a huge castle, and I\u2019m really into interior decorating and antiques. It\u2019s filled with vintage teacups, armoires, clocks and candelabras. All the better for a romantic dinner at home. I must confess, though, that my table manners could use a little work.\n\nI love to read, and I hope you do, too. I\u2019ve got a library full of books, and I\u2019m happy to share.\n\nMy posse calls me an old-fashioned romantic. In fact, I\u2019ve got a special rose waiting for the woman who can win my heart.\n\nCall me out of step with the times, but I\u2019m a skilled ballroom dancer. I would love to waltz with someone special.\n\nA word of warning: If you\u2019re not into guys with lots of body hair, I\u2019m probably not the one for you. However, I\u2019m happy to cover up my furry physique with formal attire.\n\nSo would you like to be my guest for dinner?\n\nWhy you should swipe right: If we hit it off, you\u2019re welcome to stay at my pad indefinitely.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhy you should swipe left: I\u2019m not looking for a hookup.\n\nAmphibian Man in \u2018The Shape of Water.\u2019 Age: Unknown.\n\nPhoto\n\nI absolutely love the water. Take me to the ocean, a river or a canal \u2014 anywhere that\u2019s wet, and I\u2019ll thrive. I also love to take long, salty baths. You\u2019re more than welcome to join.\n\nI\u2019m lean and green, with the posture of a matador.\n\nMy culinary tastes are simple: Cook me a big batch of hard-boiled eggs, and I\u2019m good for breakfast, lunch and dinner.\n\nOld-time jazz records get my webbed toes tapping (a Benny Goodman is hard to find, am I right?), and I enjoy swing dancing.\n\nClassic Hollywood films are my favorite. You\u2019ll often find me alone in a movie palace, getting lost in a classic black-and-white gem.\n\nI\u2019m not a big talker, and it\u2019s O.K. if you aren\u2019t, either. Sometimes it\u2019s nice just to sit quietly and enjoy each other\u2019s company, don\u2019t you think?\n\nWhy you should swipe right: It\u2019s almost spring \u2014 let\u2019s go swimming.\n\nWhy you should swipe left: I\u2019m not into whips and chains.", "title": "Would You Swipe Right on Amphibian Man From \u2018The Shape of Water\u2019?", "authors": ["Bruce Fretts"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTHE KISS\n\nIntimacies From Writers\n\nEdited by Brian Turner\n\n243 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $25.95.\n\nWhatever happened to kissing as a source of literary inspiration? You hardly read about it anymore (except in news accounts of it being nonconsensual). As editor of The New York Times\u2019s Modern Love column, I sift through some 8,000 personal essays about relationships every year. Almost none are about kissing. People will always kiss, I suppose, but these days it\u2019s an act that doesn\u2019t seem to generate much conversational traction.\n\nExcept, that is, in \u201cThe Kiss: Intimacies From Writers,\u201d edited by Brian Turner, himself an essayist, as well as a poet and memoirist. In this anthology of essays and stories, lip-locking takes center stage \u2014 featuring such smoochy, no-nonsense titles as \u201cKiss,\u201d \u201cKiss, Kiss\u201d and \u201cKiss, Kiss, Kiss.\u201d Befitting the brevity of the average mouth-on-mouth contact, most entries last only two or three pages. A few go on too long, making you want to twist free, while others tantalize with such grace that they linger sweetly in your mind for days.\n\nI was curious to discover what all of these meditations \u2014 prompted by the editor\u2019s call for \u201cthoughts on a specific kiss\u201d \u2014 would unearth. Would they focus on new love, where passion dominates? (I realized, diving in, that I probably kiss the top of my dog\u2019s snout more than any other surface, if only because he lets me.) I hoped it would explore vulnerability. A kiss, after all, is typically the first physical gesture in which we make plain our desire and open ourselves to rejection.\n\nSoon enough, the book went straight there. In \u201cThe Evolution of a Kiss,\u201d Nickole Brown describes this action as \u201ca break in the dam separating two beings that agree, Yes, please touch me there. An insane gesture, at least on paper, to open up our most necessary and vulnerable aperture and surrender it to another, to give over that place with which we eat and speak and breathe.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nYes, when you spell it out kissing can sound crazy and even repellent (and especially frightful for germophobes). Unlike sex, which ensures survival of the species, kissing doesn\u2019t seem to serve any obvious purpose. And as Tom Sleigh points out in his short essay \u201cJudas Kiss,\u201d \u201ckissing is far from universal: In fact, less than half of the world\u2019s cultures kiss for romantic purposes, and almost no animals.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nThe book doesn\u2019t really explore why humans kiss, or why some of us do while others don\u2019t. But we do hear plenty about it being an urge, a compulsive act of affection, of love, of hello and goodbye. The most moving entries involve no romance at all, but rather familial bonds, and loss, and how with a kiss we seek to demonstrate the depths of devotion or grief when words fail.", "title": "Writers Pay Lip Service to a Universal Gesture of Love", "authors": ["Daniel Jones", "Brian Turner"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Steve Wynn, who recently stepped down amid sexual harassment allegations as the head of the casino empire that bears his name, will not receive a severance package, according to the company.\n\nIn a securities filing on Friday, Wynn Resorts said its billionaire founder was not entitled to the separation terms laid out in his employment contract. The filing did not specify how much Mr. Wynn would have received had he left under different circumstances.\n\nHis employment contract included a $330 million severance stipulation, according to a shareholder lawsuit filed this month. In 2016, he made more than $28 million in total compensation from Wynn Resorts.\n\nAccording to the filing, Mr. Wynn signed an agreement that included a clause barring him from competing against Wynn Resorts for two years and requiring him to provide \u201creasonable cooperation and assistance\u201d to the company in any investigation related to his tenure.", "title": "Wynn Resorts Will Not Pay Steve Wynn Severance", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "President Xi Jinping of China has played his boldest political card yet, maneuvering to extend his rule indefinitely so that he can maintain control of the country\u2019s complex system long enough to achieve the dream of great-power status, asserting economic and political influence across the globe.\n\nSince China began to open to the West in the late 1970s, the United States and its allies have tried to integrate it into the political and economic system they built after World War II, hoping that economic progress would lead eventually to political liberalization.\n\nMr. Xi\u2019s move proves that policy has failed and that China will set its own path, challenging the liberal order based on the rule of law, human rights, open debate, free-market economics and a preference for elected leaders who leave office peacefully after a fixed period. Despite increasing concerns about China\u2019s evolution, the West has yet to come to grips with this threat.\n\nSince taking office in 2013, Mr. Xi has amassed power assiduously, taking control of not just the government but also of the Chinese Communist Party, the military and the press. He has imposed his views on the educational system and culture, hardening an already authoritarian system that ruthlessly controls social media and wields law enforcement to crush dissent. The obsession with control hints at a deeply insecure state, not a global power.", "title": "Opinion | Xi Jinping Dreams of World Power for Himself and China", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "BEIJING \u2014 Having cast aside presidential term limits, China is bracing for relations with the United States to enter a dangerous period under the continuing leadership of President Xi Jinping, intending to stand firm against President Trump and against policies it sees as attempts to contain its rise, according to Chinese analysts.\n\nEven before the announcement on Sunday that he could rule for the foreseeable future, Mr. Xi had ordered the Chinese military to counter the Pentagon with its own modernization in air, sea, space and cyber weapons, the analysts said, partly in response to Mr. Trump\u2019s plans to revitalize American nuclear forces.\n\nRather than beginning a final term next month as a lame duck, Mr. Xi will govern with new authority to pursue his agenda of making China a global power even if it risks putting Beijing in conflict with Washington and triggering a new Cold War after 40 years of mutual engagement, the analysts said.\n\n\u201cIn the Asia-Pacific, the dominant role of the United States in a political and military sense will have to be readjusted,\u201d said Cui Liru, former president of the China Institutes of Contemporary International Relations, a think tank under the Ministry of State Security that often reflects official thinking. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t mean U.S. interests must be sacrificed. But if the U.S. insists on a dominant role forever, that\u2019s a problem.\u201d", "title": "Xi Jinping Extends Power, and China Braces for a New Cold War", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "China has a new official political doctrine.\n\nIt\u2019s called Xi Jinping Thought, and it is everywhere. Schools, newspapers, television, the internet, billboards and banners all trumpet the ideas of Mr. Xi, the country\u2019s president and Communist Party leader.\n\nOfficially known as \u201cXi Jinping Thought on Socialism with Chinese Characteristics for a New Era,\u201d the ideology will soon be given an even more prominent platform: the preamble of China\u2019s Constitution.\n\nBoiled down, the doctrine is a blueprint for consolidating and strengthening power at three levels: the nation, the party and Mr. Xi himself.\n\nThe doctine, like Mr. Xi, is not going anywhere soon. The Party on Sunday abolished the presidential term limit, meaning Mr. Xi could remain in power indefinitely. Here\u2019s your guide to understanding the ideas likely to guide China through the next decade, or possibly longer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Nation: Make China Great Again\n\nPhoto\n\nSince Mr. Xi became chairman of the Communist Party in 2012, he has vowed a \u201cgreat rejuvenation\u201d to restore China to its ancient prominence and glory.", "title": "Xi Jinping Thought Explained: A New Ideology for a New Era", "authors": ["Chris Buckley"]} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 President Trump stunned many Americans by embracing elements of gun control: expanded background checks, keeping guns from the mentally ill and restricting sales to some young adults.\n\nAcross the country, protests against the gun lobby in the wake of the Florida chool massacre has been coalescing into a powerful movement.\n\nIn one of the strongest stances taken by corporate America, a huge sporting goods chain is ending sales of assault-style rifles and barring gun sales to those under 21, regardless of local laws. (Even some of our journalists piled in.)\n\nBack Story\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cWas it really that bad?\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s what Arthur Bicknell asked years after his play, a mystery-farce called \u201cMoose Murders,\u201d opened and closed on the same night this month in 1983 \u2014 setting a punishing new standard for Broadway flops.\n\n\u201cThe simple answer,\u201d he conceded to The Times, \u201cis yes.\u201d\n\nReviews at the time were brutal. Brendan Gill of The New Yorker said it \u201cwould insult the intelligence of an audience consisting entirely of amoebas.\u201d Dennis Cunningham of CBS advised, \u201cIf your name is Arthur Bicknell, change it.\u201d (In one account, a woman leaving the theater shouted to a policeman, \u201cArrest this play!\u201d)\n\nHere\u2019s the Times review by Frank Rich, who years later would call it \u201cthe worst play I\u2019ve ever seen on a Broadway stage.\u201d\n\nIn the years since its ill-fated Feb. 22 debut, \u201cMoose Murders\u201d has gained notoriety, if not respect. In 2011, Mr. Bicknell published \u201cMoose Murdered: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love My Broadway Bomb.\u201d)\n\nIn fact, there have been \u201crevivals\u201d of \u201cMoose Murders\u201d around the world \u2014 and at least one comical twist. In 2007, the Repertory Philippines misidentified the author of the play in its posters and playbills around Manila. Instead of Mr. Bicknell, it credited The Times\u2019s critic, Mr. Rich.\n\nCharles McDermid contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekday mornings and updated online. As our reporter writes, autocrats\u2019 power is growing from Russia to Turkey to Southeast Asia.\n\nWorse, critics say, the U.S. lacks the moral authority \u2014 or even the inclination under President Trump \u2014 to oppose the world\u2019s slide toward hard-line control. (\u201cI think Trump is probably jealous,\u201d one analyst said.)\n\nChina\u2019s censors, meanwhile, worked to erase online discontent about President Xi Jinping\u2019s move amid speculation that it might betray weakness in the Communist Party.", "title": "Xi Jinping, Syria, North Korea: Your Tuesday Briefing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 Sheriff Scott Israel defended his \u201camazing leadership\u201d as questions mounted over his department\u2019s response. There were reports on Sunday of a suspected chlorine attack.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 After the deadly school shooting in Florida, a number of companies announced plans to cut ties with the National Rifle Association, ending discount programs for the group\u2019s members.\n\n\u2022 The authorities in Atlanta announced a $10,000 reward for information about a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention employee who disappeared two weeks ago.\n\n\u2022 Warren Buffett said in his annual letter to Berkshire Hathaway shareholders that it had recorded more than $29 billion in gains from the tax overhaul in December.\n\n\u2022 \u201cBlack Panther\u201d may soon join the $1 billion club. The Marvel superhero movie has earned more than $700 million in global ticket sales in 12 days.\n\nNoteworthy\n\n\u2022 Fortified, but still in peril\n\nIn the years after Hurricane Katrina, more than 350 miles \u2014 and $20 billion \u2014 of levees, flood walls, gates and pumps were built to encircle New Orleans. Experts say it\u2019s not enough.\n\nThe article is part of a special report about the ecological crisis facing Louisiana\u2019s coast, the product of a partnership between The Times and NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune of New Orleans.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nFor more coverage of climate change, sign up for our newsletter, Climate Fwd:.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u2022 Hoping to head off would-be migrants\n\nFrance has set up an outpost in Niger to screen those seeking asylum.\n\nBut very few are actually approved, which sends a message to others thinking of migrating: Stay home.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story The Evening Briefing by Email Get a nightly rundown of the day\u2019s top stories, delivered to your inbox every Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2022 Quotation of the day\n\n\u201cXi Jinping is susceptible to making big mistakes because there are now almost no checks or balances. Essentially, he has become emperor for life.\u201d\n\n\u2014 Willy Lam, the author of a 2015 biography of Mr. Xi, on China\u2019s moves to abolish presidential term limits.\n\n\u2022 The Times, in other words\n\nHere\u2019s an image of today\u2019s front page, and links to our Opinion content and crossword puzzles.\n\nBack Story\n\n\u201cWas it really that bad?\u201d\n\nThat\u2019s what Arthur Bicknell asked years after his play, a mystery farce called \u201cMoose Murders,\u201d opened and closed on the same night this month in 1983 \u2014 setting a punishing new standard for Broadway flops.\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe simple answer,\u201d he conceded to The Times, \u201cis yes.\u201d\n\nReviews were brutal. Brendan Gill of The New Yorker said it \u201cwould insult the intelligence of an audience consisting entirely of amoebas.\u201d Dennis Cunningham of CBS advised, \u201cIf your name is Arthur Bicknell, change it.\u201d (In one account, a woman leaving the theater shouted to a police officer, \u201cArrest this play!\u201d)\n\nHere\u2019s the Times review by Frank Rich, who years later would call it \u201cthe worst play I\u2019ve ever seen on a Broadway stage.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the years since its ill-fated debut, \u201cMoose Murders\u201d has gained notoriety, if not respect. In 2011, Mr. Bicknell published \u201cMoose Murdered: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love My Broadway Bomb.\u201d)\n\nIn fact, there have been revivals of \u201cMoose Murders\u201d around the world \u2014 and at least one comical twist. In 2007, the Repertory Philippines misidentified the author of the play in posters around Manila. Instead of Mr. Bicknell, it credited The Times\u2019s critic, Mr. Rich.\n\nCharles McDermid contributed reporting.\n\n_____\n\nYour Morning Briefing is published weekdays and updated all morning. Check out our full range of free newsletters here.\n\nWhat would you like to see here? Contact us at briefing@nytimes.com.", "title": "Xi Jinping, Winter Olympics, Weinstein Company: Your Monday Briefing", "authors": ["Chris Stanford"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Patrick Chappatte is an editorial cartoonist for The New York Times. View more of his work, visit his website or follow him on Twitter.\n\nFollow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter, and sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter.", "title": "Opinion | Xi Jinping\u2019s Power Grab", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "The Harder Kind of Dictatorship\n\nIf Mr. Xi stays in office for life, as many now expect, that will only formalize a process he has undertaken for years: stripping power away from China\u2019s institutions and accumulating it for himself.\n\nIt helps to mentally divide dictatorships into two categories: institutional and personalist. The first operates through committees, bureaucracies and something like consensus. The second runs through a single charismatic leader.\n\nChina, once an almost Socratic ideal of the first model, is increasingly a hybrid of both. Mr. Xi has made himself \u201cthe dominant actor in financial regulation and environmental policy\u201d as well as economic policy, according to a paper by Barry Naughton, a China scholar at the University of California, San Diego.\n\nPhoto\n\nMr. Xi has also led sweeping anti-corruption campaigns that have disproportionately purged members of rival political factions, strengthening himself but undermining China\u2019s consensus-driven approach.\n\nThis version of authoritarianism is harder to maintain, according to research by Erica Frantz, a scholar of authoritarianism at Michigan State University. \u201cIn general, personalization is not a good development,\u201d Ms. Frantz said.\n\nThe downsides are often subtle. Domestic politics tend to be more volatile, governing more erratic and foreign policy more aggressive, studies find. But the clearest risk comes with succession.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a question I like to ask Russia specialists: \u2018If Putin has a heart attack tomorrow, what happens?\u2019\u201d said Milan Svolik, a Yale University political scientist. \u201cNobody knows.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIn China, up until now, the answer to that had been very clear,\u201d he said. A dead leader would have left behind a set of widely agreed rules for what was to be done and there would be a political consensus on how to do it.\n\n\u201cThis change seems to disrupt that,\u201d Mr. Svolik said. Mr. Xi, by defying the norms of succession, has shown that any rule could be broken. \u201cThe key norm, once that\u2019s out, it seems like everything\u2019s an option,\u201d Mr. Svolik said.\n\nFactional purges risk shifting political norms from consensus to zero-sum, and sometimes life-or-death, infighting.\n\nAnd Mr. Xi is undermining the institutionalism that made China\u2019s authoritarianism unusually resilient. Collective leadership and orderly succession, both put in place after Mao Zedong\u2019s disastrous tenure, have allowed for relatively effective and stable governing.\n\nStrongman on the Rise\n\nKen Opalo, a Georgetown University political scientist, wrote after China\u2019s announcement that orderly transitions were \u201cperhaps the most important indicator of political development.\u201d Lifelong presidencies, he said, \u201cfreeze specific groups of elites out of power. And remove incentives for those in power to be accountable and innovate.\u201d\n\nWhat Makes Authoritarian Legitimacy\n\nIn 2005, Bruce Gilley, a political scientist, wrestled with one of the most important questions for any government \u2014 is it viewed by its citizens as legitimate? \u2014 into a numerical score, determined by sophisticated measurements of how those citizens behave.\n\nChina, his study found, enjoyed higher legitimacy than many democracies and every other non-democracy besides Azerbaijan. He credited economic growth, nationalist sentiment and collective leadership.\n\nBut when Mr. Gilley revisited his metrics in 2012, he found that China\u2019s score had plummeted.\n\nHis data showed the leading edge of a force long thought to doom China\u2019s system. Known as \u201cmodernization theory,\u201d it says that once citizens reach a certain level of wealth, they will demand things like public accountability, free expression and a role in government. Authoritarian states, unable to meet these demands, either transition to democracy or collapse amid unrest.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThis challenge, overcome by no other modern authoritarian regime except those wealthy enough to buy off their citizens, requires new sources of legitimacy. Economic growth is slowing. Nationalism, though once effective at rallying support, is increasingly difficult to control and prone to backfiring. Citizen demands are growing.\n\nSo China is instead promoting \u201cideology and collective social values\u201d that equate the government with Chinese culture, according to research by the China scholar Heike Holbig and Mr. Gilley. Patriotic songs and school textbooks have proliferated. So have mentions of \u201cXi Jinping Thought,\u201d now an official ideology.\n\nMr. Xi\u2019s personalization of power seems to borrow from both old-style strongmen and the new-style populists rising among the world\u2019s democracies.\n\nBut, in this way, it is a high-risk and partial solution to China\u2019s needs. A cult of personality can do for a few years or perhaps decades, but not more.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Interpreter Newsletter Understand the world with sharp insight and commentary on the major news stories of the week. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u2018Accountability Without Democracy\u2019\n\nChina is experimenting with a form of authoritarianism that, if successful, could close the seemingly unbridgeable gap between what its citizens demand and what it can deliver.\n\nAuthoritarian governments are, by definition, unaccountable. But some towns and small cities in China are opening limited, controlled channels of public participation. For example, a program called \u201cMayor\u2019s Mailboxes\u201d allows citizens to voice demands or complaints, and rewards officials who comply.\n\nThe program, one study found, significantly improved the quality of governing and citizens\u2019 happiness with the state. No one would call these towns democratic. But it felt enough like democracy to satisfy some.\n\nThis sort of innovation began with local communities that expressed their will through limited but persistent dissent and protest. Lily L. Tsai, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology scholar, termed it \u201caccountability without democracy.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nNow, some officials are adapting this once-resisted trend into deliberate practice. Their goal is not to bring about liberalization but to resist it \u2014 to \u201csiphon off popular discontent without destabilizing the system as a whole,\u201d the China scholars Vivienne Shue and Patricia M. Thornton write in a new book on governing in China.\n\nMost Chinese, Beijing seems to hope, will accept authoritarian rule if it delivers at least some of the benefits promised by democracy: moderately good government, somewhat responsive officials and free speech within sharp bounds. Citizens who demand more face censorship and oppression that can be among the harshest in the world.\n\nThat new sort of system could do more than overcome China\u2019s conflict with the forces of history. It could provide a model of authoritarianism to thrive globally, showing, Ms. Shue and Ms. Thornton write, \u201chow non-democracies may not only survive but succeed over time.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Xi\u2019s power grab, by undermining institutions and promoting all-or-nothing factionalism, risks making that sort of innovation riskier and more difficult.\n\nWhen leaders consolidate power for themselves, Ms. Frantz said, \u201cover time their ability to get a good read on the country\u2019s political climate diminishes.\u201d\n\nSuch complications are why Thomas Pepinsky, a Cornell University political scientist, wrote on Twitter, \u201cI\u2019m no China expert, but centralizing power in the hands of one leader sounds like the most typical thing that a decaying authoritarian state would do.\u201d", "title": "Xi Sets China on a Collision Course With History", "authors": ["Max Fisher", "The Interpreter"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "There were three excavation locations at the museum, and we saved the biggest and best for last. The vast, final dig site held hundreds of soldiers, lined up in a majestic and slightly eerie show of force: infantrymen, archers, even a few horses. I was surprised when Jia Jia told us that while Qin Shihuang created around 8,000 life-size soldiers to protect him in the afterlife, only 2,000 or so have been unearthed and reassembled since local farmers made the discovery in 1974 (and only a portion of those are on public display at any given time). Many, many decades of painstaking work remain. Admission to the site, should you choose to go on your own, is 150 yuan, or 120 during the winter off-season.\n\nI was able to do most of my exploration of Xian solo, though, thanks to the compactness of the city center. I recommend making a quick stop at the Bell and Drum Towers, which closely resemble each other and are both located in the heart of the city. Tickets to each will cost 35 yuan, or you can buy a combo ticket for 50 yuan. The pagoda-like structures, with their distinctive upward-tilting eaves, are quite regal and majestic, and beautifully illuminated during the evening. They were constructed within years of each other during the 14th century by the Hongwu Emperor of the Ming dynasty \u2014 the Bell Tower rang to mark the beginning the day; the Drum Tower , its end.\n\nAnother duo of complementary sights is the Giant Wild Goose and Small Wild Goose Pagodas, both south of the city walls. The larger of the two is one of Xian\u2019s most famous structures, a sandy-colored Tang dynasty pavilion constructed in 652 A.D. to house sutras and icons brought from India by the Buddhist monk Xuanzang. The seven-story pagoda occupies the spacious and peaceful grounds of Dacien Si (Mercy Temple), which costs 50 yuan to access.\n\nMeandering around the temple grounds on a chilly day, I saw men and women lighting incense and worshiping at Sakyamuni, the main hall of the monastery. From there I entered the pagoda (this requires a separate 20-yuan ticket) and climbed the nearly 250 wooden stairs leading to the top. Created to protect the 657 volumes of Buddhist scriptures Xuanzang brought back, the pagoda yields another benefit: the views from the top are excellent, if slightly hindered by smog.\n\n(Air quality is a problem throughout China, and asthmatics and those with delicate respiratory systems should take particular notice. The government is t esting measures to stem the problem in different cities, including Xian, which is experimenting with building-sized air purification towers.)\n\nTo the northwest is the Small Wild Goose Pagoda (built in 707, it\u2019s slightly younger), and while the pagoda itself is currently being restored, the area is worth visiting for a couple of reasons. The Studio of Chinese Calligraphy and Painting, in addition to traditional artwork, has a small museum dedicated to Mao Zedong that I found to be more honest and critical than I expected. It cites the \u201clost generation of the Cultural Revolution\u201d and the era\u2019s \u201cdisastrous blow on traditional Chinese culture.\u201d A friendly employee at the shop directed me to the spacious, modern Xian Museum (free admission), which has diverse array of installations: contemporary paintings from the Taklamakan Desert region, relics from the Tang and Sui Dynasties, and, in the basement, an exhibition detailing the history of Xian.\n\nDon\u2019t forget that the city\u2019s ancient walls are an attraction in and of themselves. Accessible in different locations around the city, I found it easiest to enter by the main southern gate (Yongning), the most elaborate and ornate of the entrances. Tickets are 50 yuan, but I was able to score a half-off discount by showing my high-speed rail ticket from Chengdu. The ambitious can rent a bicycle on the parapets \u2014 45 yuan for three hours \u2014 and bike the approximately 8.5 miles around the entire wall. (Given the subfreezing temperatures and poor air quality, I decided to just walk the walls for a while. I wasn\u2019t disappointed \u2014 the views were good, and provided a nice vantage point of much of the surrounding area.)", "title": "Xian Offers Terracotta Warriors, Stunning Food and Plenty of Bargains", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "NEW HAVEN \u2014 In 1987, David Code \u2014 then a member of Yale\u2019s Whiffenpoofs, the country\u2019s oldest collegiate a cappella group \u2014 staked out an unpopular position: It was time for the group to admit women. The Whiffenpoofs possessed unparalleled resources, he reasoned, and he knew of female singers who wanted and deserved a spot in their ranks. The debate grew \u201cugly and personal,\u201d Mr. Code said, before the rest of his Whiffenpoofs class reached a unanimous conclusion: They would remain all male.\n\nThree decades later, that finally changed, when on Monday the Whiffenpoofs tapped Sofia Campoamor, a junior, as the first female member of the group since its founding in 1909. \u201cThis isn\u2019t something that I ever expected, and I\u2019m so excited,\u201d Ms. Campoamor said.\n\nThe break with tradition immediately rippled across Yale\u2019s campus and alumni community.\n\n\u201cI cried when I heard,\u201d Mr. Code said. \u201cI am thrilled. I am delighted. And most of all, I want to meet this girl. I want to hear her voice.\n\n\u201cThis is something I\u2019ve dreamed about for years. The Whiffenpoofs should have gone coed in 1968, when Yale went coed. Finally, 50 years later, meritocracy is here \u2014 and it\u2019s long overdue,\u201d he added, referring to the school\u2019s 1968 decision to admit women the following September.", "title": "Yale\u2019s Famed Whiffenpoofs Singing Group Admits First Woman", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nTAMPA, Fla. \u2014 Faced with the possibility of starting two rookies in their infield, the Yankees brought in some insurance on Tuesday, acquiring utility infielder Brandon Drury from the Arizona Diamondbacks in a three-team trade.\n\nThe Yankees sent two minor leaguers \u2014 second baseman Nick Solak and right-handed pitcher Taylor Widener \u2014 to the Tampa Bay Rays, who shipped outfielder Steven Souza Jr. to the Diamondbacks. The Rays will also get left-handed pitcher Anthony Banda and two players to be named later from the Diamondbacks.\n\nDrury, 25, appealed to the Yankees on several fronts: He has displayed decent pop \u2014 with 31 home runs and a .767 on-base-plus-slugging percentage in a little over two seasons with the Diamondbacks \u2014 and he came cheaply.\n\nBecause he is not yet eligible for arbitration, Drury will make close to the major-league minimum, giving the Yankees more flexibility to spend on pitching later this spring \u2014 or later this season \u2014 without endangering their goal of staying below the $197 million luxury tax threshold. The Yankees are currently about $20 million below the threshold.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Yankees began spring training on Monday intent on giving the rookies Gleyber Torres and Miguel Andujar opportunities to win the starting jobs at second and third base, respectively. But they are also hedging their bets: They signed the veterans Danny Espinosa and Jace Peterson to minor-league contracts last month, largely as cover at second base for Torres.\n\nDrury, who has played all four infield positions along with left and right field in his nascent career, is likely to see more time at third base. He played second base much of last season in large part because the Diamondbacks had an All-Star third baseman in Jake Lamb.", "title": "Yankees Acquire Brandon Drury as Infield Insurance", "authors": ["Billy Witz"]} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Stanton, Judge, Sanchez, Greg Bird and Didi Gregorius are in their 20s. So are most of the better pitchers. Gleyber Torres is 21 and might start at second base. Miguel Andujar, who turns 23 next month, might start at third. This team could be good for a long time.\n\n\u201cWe were so close last year,\u201d said reliever Dellin Betances, who has dropped to 264 pounds, from 280, after emphasizing nutrition \u2014 and better mechanics \u2014 this winter. \u201cWe were one game away from the World Series. We know what it feels like. We kind of have that sour taste in our mouth. We want to win, so if we don\u2019t win, I think it\u2019s not a great year for us. That\u2019s probably the first season I\u2019ve come in with those expectations.\u201d\n\nAfter four years without a playoff victory, the Yankees raced all the way to Game 7 of the American League Championship Series in Houston last October. They succumbed, at last, to a flurry of curveballs from the Astros\u2019 Lance McCullers Jr., whose father pitched for the Yankees in 1989 and 1990 \u2014 a time when chaos reigned. The Yankees used three managers in those two seasons, but Boone is just the third manager in the last 23.\n\nBrian Cashman has been the general manager for 20 years now, leveraging that stability into a disciplined franchise turnaround. The Hall of Famer Goose Gossage may not like him \u2014 the opinionated Gossage, who was not invited to be a guest instructor this spring, belittled Cashman in a series of interviews this week \u2014 but Cashman has adapted to the modern game, turning a roster once larded with dead money into something much more nimble.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThe Yankees have found no takers for their one bad contract \u2014 Jacoby Ellsbury\u2019s, which has three years and $68 million remaining. Boone must sort through the outfielders\u2019 roles, decide if Torres and Andujar are ready for the majors, and find depth beyond his top five starters. Any smart baseball person could make those calls, but as a first-time manager, Boone has subtler challenges.\n\n\u201cWhen you walk into our clubhouse, hopefully I\u2019m a part of what I believe is a winning culture \u2014 but also a culture where guys are at ease, where guys are allowed to be themselves, where when you walk into our room, it\u2019s not a stressful place,\u201d Boone said. \u201cIt\u2019s a place where guys are at work and enjoy coming there to do their job.\u201d\n\nBoone mentioned his first day as a Yankee, after a trade from Cincinnati in 2003, when he met Joe Torre in the manager\u2019s office in Oakland. Torre had a presence, Boone said, a \u201csoothing nature\u201d and tone that made him comfortable with a new team. Torre\u2019s successor, Joe Girardi, was more intense and uptight.\n\nEven so, Girardi was an excellent manager \u2014 driven, prepared, caring \u2014 and he shepherded a young clubhouse into a new era. Cashman could have easily brought Girardi back, but he wanted someone perhaps better suited for the most vital task of today\u2019s manager: communicating the vision of the front office to the players.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn that way, it helps that Boone has never managed; he can grow into the job in lock step with his boss. The Yankees want Boone to be another pillar of the stability that now defines them \u2014 along with home runs and high hopes, which have always been part of the scene.\n\nStanton led the majors in homers last season with 59 for the Miami Marlins. Judge led the A.L. with 52. Stanton has the majors\u2019 richest guaranteed contract, at $325 million. Judge has a wood-paneled cheering section in right field in the Bronx.\n\nMany will love these Yankees, many will loathe them, but all will expect them to win. That is just how Boone wants it.\n\n\u201cIt beats the alternative, right?\u201d he said. \u201cI mean, it really does.\u201d", "title": "Yankees\u2019 Era Under Aaron Boone Begins, With a Steinbrenner Beaming", "authors": ["Tyler Kepner", "On Baseball"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Asked how he viewed the case of Mr. Levine, and whether he felt the company needed healing, Mr. N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin was circumspect. \u201cFor me, I see my own curve with the institution, and I\u2019m focused on this, solely,\u201d he said, adding that the more he got to know the workings of the opera house and its company, the more eager he was to begin.\n\n\u201cI know what I want to do, and I just needed to have the time to start doing it,\u201d he added.\n\nPeter Gelb, the Met\u2019s general manager, predicted in an interview that Mr. N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin\u2019s arrival would cheer the entire company.\n\n\u201cThe Met, obviously, has suffered from what happened with Jim,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd I would say the healing process began the day Yannick set foot in the building conducting rehearsals of \u2018Parsifal,\u2019 because the orchestra and the chorus clearly gravitate to him.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nSome musicians said that they were ecstatic about the move. Jessica Phillips, a clarinetist and the chairwoman of the Met\u2019s orchestra committee, said in an email, \u201cAs fellow musicians excited by Yannick\u2019s vision for the future, it is our hope that the Met\u2019s inspired investment in his brilliance underscores its commitment to the musical artists and artistry that are the lifeblood of the Met Opera.\u201d\n\nThe company\u2019s investigation of Mr. Levine, who was suspended after The New York Times reported the accusations of four men who said that he had sexually abused them when they were teenagers or his students, continues. Mr. Levine has denied the accusations.\n\nNext season will feature a number of notable conducting debuts. Mr. Dudamel, the music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, will conduct Verdi\u2019s \u201cOtello.\u201d Robert Spano, of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, will conduct \u201cMarnie\u201d; James Gaffigan, \u201cLa Boh\u00e8me\u201d; and Cornelius Meister, \u201cDon Giovanni.\u201d\n\nA number of Met favorites will make star turns. Mr. Kaufmann, who has canceled his last three planned appearances at the Met, is set to return in a revival of Puccini\u2019s \u201cLa Fanciulla del West.\u201d Mr. Gelb said that since Mr. Kaufmann had made it clear that he does not wish to leave his home in Germany for long stretches of time, Mr. Gelb had offered to \u201ctailor-make\u201d repertoire for him to sing when he is free.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn addition to the title role of \u201cAdriana Lecouvreur,\u201d Ms. Netrebko will sing Verdi\u2019s Aida. Sonya Yoncheva will star in Tchaikovsky\u2019s \u201cIolanta\u201d and reprise her Desdemona in \u201cOtello,\u201d with Stuart Skelton in the title role.
