The baritone Quinn Kelsey will get two plum Verdi assignments: Giorgio Germont in \u201cLa Traviata\u201d and Aida\u2019s father, Amonasro.\n\nMr. N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin said that he had been happy to rearrange his schedule and cancel a number of appearances in Europe to make the directorship and added performances possible. But he will be busy, he acknowledged in New York on Tuesday at the end of the interview \u2014 which he joined after traveling from Philadelphia, where he had announced in the morning that he would be leading the Philadelphia Orchestra on a tour of Israel.\n\nWhen the interview was over, he got up, saying that he needed some time to rest before his next engagement: the nearly six-hour \u201cParsifal.\u201d\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a tiny show that\u2019s coming up tonight,\u201d he said with a smile.", "title": "Yannick N\u00e9zet-S\u00e9guin Will Lead the Met Opera, Two Years Early", "authors": ["Michael Cooper"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "AT 15 MINUTES 44 SECONDS\n\nLaugh-Out-Loud Piano\n\nUntil last week I had never heard Britten\u2019s Piano Concerto, which Leif Ove Andsnes performed with the New York Philharmonic. The piece is striking for how integrated the solo part is with the orchestral accompaniment. (Often the concerto could pass for a symphony, much like the Saint-Sa\u00ebns \u201cOrgan\u201d Symphony, which followed the intermission.) But it is also surprisingly funny. I sat next to one of our critics, and we both chuckled throughout. You can hear the humor in this recording with Mr. Andsnes and the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra, especially in the second movement, a beguiling and ironic waltz. As played by the orchestra, the theme is way over the top. For a brief moment, it repeats as a solo piano passage, which Mr. Andsnes delivered with a clever balance of satire and enigmatic nuance that revealed something darker beneath all the exuberance. JOSHUA BARONE", "title": "Yannick, Sooner: The 8 Best Classical Music Moments of the Week on YouTube", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWASHINGTON \u2014 Janet L. Yellen, who completed her term as Federal Reserve chairwoman on Friday, plans to start a new job on Monday morning as a fellow in economic studies at the Brookings Institution.\n\nMs. Yellen will follow a well-worn path from the Fed\u2019s marble headquarters on Constitution Avenue to the nearby Brookings building on Massachusetts Avenue. The roster of Brookings fellows includes her immediate predecessor as Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, and no fewer than three of her predecessors as Fed\u2019s vice chairman: Donald Kohn, Alice Rivlin and Alan Blinder.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m delighted to be joining the Brookings Institution,\u201d Ms. Yellen said in a statement released by the Brookings. \u201cI look forward to continuing to study the economy, especially issues related to the labor market, and contributing to public policy debates on a range of economic issues.\u201d\n\nFor Brookings, Ms. Yellen\u2019s arrival fortifies its recent focus on monetary policy, a subject that has commanded significantly greater public interest and scholarly debate since the 2008 financial crisis.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI congratulate Janet on her outstanding public service and look forward to being her colleague at the Brookings Institution,\u201d Mr. Bernanke tweeted.", "title": "Yellen, Departing Fed, Will Join Brookings", "authors": ["Binyamin Appelbaum"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI felt there was an unfair narrative in the U.S. associated with being Muslim and being an immigrant and being Yemeni-American,\u201d she said. \u201cI wanted to try to challenge that.\u201d\n\nHer young subjects, she said, were also trying to figure out what it meant to be New Yorkers and Americans, \u201ccontinuing to ask themselves what to keep of their past, and what to bring into the future. I\u2019m interested in that awkward stage in between, where new identities are being tested out.\u201d", "title": "Yemenis in New York, in the Shadow of a Travel Ban", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "There, Brian Procell, who runs a vintage boutique specializing in 1990s paraphernalia, suggested designers were rebelling against the fashion week grind. \u201cIt makes more sense not to follow these schedules,\u201d he said. \u201cAzzedine Ala\u00efa was the first outlier for how people act now. Kanye is just going to do his thing when he\u2019s ready.\u201d\n\nSome parties were bolstered by ties to pop culture. Lupita Nyong\u2019o, who stars in the movie, walked the red carpet; Heron Preston D.J.ed; and fashion designers unveiled their looks.\n\nRuth Gruca, the global fashion director of Made, said it felt like a slow week, party-wise. \u201cFebruary fashion week is a little irrelevant,\u201d she said, as she was leaving to check out the Barrag\u00e1n event nearby. \u201cNew York is kind of in fluctuation. A lot of brands are showing in Paris because that\u2019s where the commerce happens.\u201d", "title": "Yes, It Was a Quieter Fashion Week. But the Party Must Go On.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nIn \u201cPolitics Shouldn\u2019t Be Like Open Mic Night\u201d (Op-Ed, Jan. 26), Jonathan Rauch and Raymond J. La Raja expressed concerns about the \u201camateurization of politics.\u201d They are wrong.\n\nCompetition is good. More candidates running equals more voter contact equals more engaged voters. When turnout is good, Democrats fare better.\n\nWhile amateurs shouldn\u2019t be president, they should absolutely run for the other half-million state and local positions in our country. How else can people develop political experience? Every public servant has to start somewhere.\n\nThe traditional political gatekeepers failed us by supporting candidates who looked like them (read: rich old white men).", "title": "Opinion | Yes, Run for Office", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-13 00:00:00", "text": "Ron McMahan was the valedictorian of his high school class of 35 and the only one of them to go to college. He was from a small town in Colorado. His dad and granddad were Navy enlisted men \u2014 it was what you did. He got an R.O.T.C. scholarship to the University of Colorado and became the first college graduate and military officer in his family. He was married with a child by the time he went to Vietnam in 1969 with a top-secret cryptography clearance.\n\nRon\u2019s wife, Jane, was his lifeline and his connection to the antiwar and youth movements exploding in the United States. She knew, more even than he could express, that Ron had strong moral misgivings about the war. He wrote her about holding a dying Vietnamese boy in his arms and how much it upset him. She sent Ron tapes with his son\u2019s first words along with thoughts and advice. She told him he might be a conscientious objector, or C.O. When his ship returned to San Diego in the summer of 1970, Jane met him at the dock wearing granny glasses and a madras dress and carrying the local underground newspaper announcing a meeting of the Concerned Officers Movement. \u201cYou have to go,\u201d she said. He did. By the end of the year, he prevailed in a precedent-setting case, McMahan v. Laird, and was honorably discharged as a C.O.\n\nPaul Rogers went to Notre Dame. He was the son of a disabled World War II veteran and the Army nurse who saved his life. He had good grades, was captain of his high school football team, won an R.O.T.C. scholarship and did what was expected. But then in 1970 Kent State and Jackson State happened. The Notre Dame students voted to close the school down: Students had been killed; the war raged; Vietnam became the curriculum for the entire student body. Paul joined 50 graduating R.O.T.C. cadets in signing a petition pledging that upon becoming commissioned officers they would do everything they could to end the war. When assigned to the crew of the aircraft carrier Constellation, he carried out that pledge.\n\nJohn Kent was a two-time all-American wrestler from the Naval Academy. He wanted to be an astronaut and became a jet pilot. But events kept pulling him in another direction. There was that blind date at Annapolis who argued with him all night about the Vietnam War. He thought it was a just war, but he came out on the short end of every argument. And there was that Marine major, an A-4 pilot, bragging to John\u2019s training class of eager pilots about the old Vietnamese man on a bicycle he had incinerated with a heat-seeking missile \u2014 just for fun!\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Subscribe to the Vietnam \u201967 Newsletter This weekly newsletter includes eyewitness accounts, rare photos and historical insights about the Vietnam War. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nIn the summer of 1967, as a midshipman, John was serving on a ship in the Gulf of Tonkin. He didn\u2019t learn much about the war, but he learned something else when his ship docked at the Subic Bay Naval Base. This was the largest American Navy installation in the Pacific, adjacent to the Philippine town of Olongapo. It was one of the most celebrated R&R destinations for military personnel in Vietnam, a so called fantasyland for adults. What he found instead was a nightmare of degradation, all in service to and fostered by the American military. You could throw coins into the sewage-filled river and see kids and desperate Filipino adults dive into the fetid water. And that was only the beginning. No thank you.\n\nOn his way to Miramar, Calif., for F-8 training en route to Vietnam for the second time, John went home on leave. It was November 1969 and one of the biggest antiwar demonstrations was gathering in Washington, D.C., near where he lived. His siblings were going, and he and his dad decided to follow. The power of hundreds of thousands of antiwar voices was immense, and the songs brought both of them to tears. Pete Seeger led the huge crowd in singing, over and over, John Lennon\u2019s line, \u201cAll we are saying, is give peace a chance.\u201d Between choruses Seeger would sing phrases like, \u201cAre you listening, Nixon?\u201d \u201cAre you listening, Pentagon?\u201d\n\nJohn was listening, and before they left the Mall he turned to his dad and said, \u201cI don\u2019t think I can go back to Vietnam.\u201d He didn\u2019t, and within a few months, along with other naval officers, he founded the San Diego chapter of the Concerned Officers Movement.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJim Skelly grew up in an Irish working-class family within a strict Catholic tradition, which he rebelled against, leaving him with a hatred of arbitrary authority. He got into the University of Minnesota on an R.O.T.C. scholarship. By the time he graduated in 1967, he was already ambivalent about the growing war. He volunteered to work on an oil tanker with the Atlantic Fleet, even though he was increasingly disturbed by what he was reading and hearing about the war. Shortly after learning of Robert Kennedy\u2019s murder in June 1968, he wrote a letter saying he was opposed to the war and asking for a better way to serve his country. He never sent it.\n\nIn January 1970 Jim received orders to become part of the Military Assistance Command Vietnam in Saigon. He knew that if he went to Vietnam he might well come back a human wreck, drunk and dead at 40. Not sure what to do, he went to his predeployment training in San Diego and began searching. He found some literature from the Movement for a Democratic Military, an antiwar group, in a local head shop.\n\nWhen he showed up at the M.D.M. office, he met a San Diego police officer named John Paul Murray, then disguised as Jay King, an antiwar activist. They talked for a while and then \u201cJay King,\u201d playing his antiwar role, said, \u201cYou sound like a conscientious objector.\u201d Jim said, \u201cOh, O.K.,\u201d and within a few months had filed his application for C.O. and found the other men in the Concerned Officers Movement. He was the first of several of us to file a federal lawsuit against Secretary of Defense Melvin Laird seeking to be released from active duty as conscientious objectors.\n\nThe day John Huyler graduated from Princeton University in June 1967 and became an officer in the Navy, he knew that the Vietnam War was wrong and that he would refuse orders to go there. He had majored in philosophy, thought a lot about values and personal integrity, war and peace, and became a Quaker. His senior thesis was on civil disobedience: Thoreau, Gandhi and King. He had concluded that the war was wrong but thought that he could outwit the system. He thought the war would be over in the 18 months required to become a naval aviator. When it was not, he decided to become a flight instructor, avoiding the war for another 18 months. After those three years the war still was not over. When John received his final orders to a noncombatant squadron based in San Diego, he thought he had finally made it through.\n\nIn San Diego, John became active with the Concerned Officers Movement, where he met other officers who had declared themselves conscientious objectors, refused orders to Vietnam and stood trial when the Navy denied their claims. He watched a film called \u201cFaces,\u201d a 10-minute, silent, black-and-white documentary showing the faces of Vietnamese children during bombing raids, which turned his stomach. His thoughts had moved into his gut and he realized that if he was connected in any way to the terror in even one of those faces, he could no longer look himself in the mirror. The next Monday he told his commanding officer that he refused to fly because he was a conscientious objector. He was granted an honorable discharge on that basis.\n\nFrom all our different directions we came together in San Diego. We organized against the war and to stop the Constellation from returning to Vietnam. As officers and pilots, we could take advantage of tactics not normally available to other antiwar groups, such as John Huyler\u2019s flying the banner reading \u201cConstellation Stay Home for Peace\u201d frequently over San Diego, and making antiwar stickers appear everywhere onboard the Constellation, including in the captain\u2019s personal bathroom (which Paul Rogers to this day claims he had nothing to do with). We influenced public opinion through numerous public statements. We joined with thousands of others in San Diego and many, many more throughout the United States and around the world in resisting the war. We know we made a difference.\n\nWe went on with our lives. We became a college professor of peace studies, an environmental mediator, an accountant for Native American tribes, a union organizer, a successful entrepreneur and a revolutionary communist. We are all proud that we had the courage to stand up against injustice and an unjust war. Today, we continue to be a group of close friends with a powerful common experience who are still active and committed to peace and social justice.", "title": "Yes, There Were Antiwar Officers", "authors": ["John Huyler", "John Kent", "Will Kirkland", "Ron Mcmahan", "Paul Rogers", "James Skelly"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "On Twitter, he found his way, as most people in financial planning do sooner rather than later, to Michael Kitces. Mr. Kitces, who is 40 years old, is an industry octopus with 29 letters of credentials after his name who speaks at conferences, works as a partner at a financial planning firm, writes and researches in quantity, and starts companies here and there. Together, Mr. Moore and Mr. Kitces cooked up XY (as in Generations) to provide a community and infrastructure \u2014 including technology tools, investment resources and compliance assistance \u2014 for other advisers who wanted to work in this way.\n\nTo get this far, they\u2019ve sought out financial planners who could be content with a mere low-six-figure income. If 80 clients pay $150 a month, XY advisers can earn gross revenues of $144,000, though XY charges member financial planners $409 per month.\n\nMany traditional brokerage firms would fire people generating that amount of money. \u201cIt\u2019s literally failure, two or three times the median household income,\u201d Mr. Kitces said. \u201cOur income expectations in this industry are completely out of whack, and that was a big part of the opportunity for us.\u201d\n\nPerhaps the most compelling part of the XY offering is what the founders make the advisers do or promise to customers. Those potential clients are often seeking to check off a number of questions or concerns before they sign up with someone.\n\nYou must be a fiduciary, which means you have to pledge to act in your clients\u2019 best interest at all times. Revenue can come only from client fees, not commissions. You have to be a certified financial planner to be listed in the network\u2019s consumer directory and must have no major marks on your disciplinary record. One big fine can mean eviction.\n\nThere is that requirement to offer a recurring billing option, which can include an upfront charge for getting a new client set up, with no investment minimum. Also, advisers have to be willing to work virtually if clients want to, which allows people with particular niches to find their clients wherever they may live. One member employs Christian principles in his practice, while another specializes in helping women who work in technology companies that have not yet gone public.\n\nPhoto\n\nPeople find their way to the profession and the network in a variety of ways. Anna Sergunina\u2019s family immigrated from Moldova, and her father worked as a truck driver while her mother cut people\u2019s hair and did their nails. They wanted her to be a doctor, but she said financial planning gave her the same chance to make a difference in people\u2019s lives, especially her peers.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI always thought I\u2019d have to work with older people,\u201d said Ms. Sergunina, 34, who is based in Burlingame, Calif.\n\nThe median age of XY advisers is 38, and it\u2019s a refrain that many of them sound, having come from other planning firms or related industries where the easiest way to make a living is to chase older clients with the most money.\n\nXY encourages its members to find a niche among their peers instead. Jason Howell, 43, who works in Vienna, Va., considered politicians (he once ran for Congress), children of immigrants (his parents were born outside the United States) and others. He eventually found success helping many couples where one person is a business owner and the other works a 9-to-5 job.\n\nOthers seek niches in ways of thinking about the world. Inga Chira, 35, who has a doctorate in finance and is an assistant professor at California State University, Northridge, maintains a part-time practice with a focus on money and happiness.\n\nIt is reasonable to wonder if the practitioners are dabblers, as with any fledgling professional network filled with people in the first halves of their careers. Some won\u2019t make it in the industry, while others may go upmarket. And while no one has made a claim on XY\u2019s errors and omissions insurance yet, at least a bit of scandal tends to eventually find its way into most corners of the financial planning world.\n\nStill in a very short time, XY has grown to be more than twice the size of similar networks. Its closest cousin is probably the Garrett Planning Network. Its founder, Sheryl Garrett, is one of the great unsung heroes of American financial services, because she helped persuade many financial planners to charge by the hour.\n\nFinding so many new clients for hourly work does require a lot of effort, which doesn\u2019t appeal to everyone. \u201cThe majority of the financial services industry has always been chasing after customers with the ability to provide advisers with the most income for the least amount of labor,\u201d she said.\n\nMr. Kitces and Mr. Moore, who was once a member of the Garrett Network, profess no animus for Ms. Garrett and her member planners. Some, like Ms. Sergunina, belong to both.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI wish there were 5,000 Garrett planners serving a whole bunch of markets that don\u2019t get served,\u201d said Mr. Kitces, who recently had Ms. Garrett as a guest on his podcast.\n\nThere are other options, too. Vanguard\u2019s Personal Advisor Services offers holistic financial planning for a 0.30 percent annual fee, based on a percentage of your assets. And the so-called roboadvisers, which once only ran your investments with their trading and rebalancing software, have added other services. Betterment recently introduced a charitable giving feature, while Wealthfront can now help you plan your housing purchase.\n\nBut if you want to meet a real live human, face to face, you no longer have to be rich to do so. Sure, you are probably smart enough to do it all yourself. But will you make the time? Will you keep emotions at bay that might cause you to make ill-advised investment moves?\n\nIf not, there has probably never been a better time to go shopping for a financial planner.", "title": "Yes, You Can Find a Financial Planner Even if You\u2019re Not Rich", "authors": ["Ron Lieber", "Your Money"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "ST. PETERSBURG, Russia \u2014 Long before he was indicted by the United States in a case involving the troll factory that spearheaded Russian efforts to meddle in the 2016 United States elections, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin emerged from prison just as the Soviet Union was collapsing and opened a hot-dog stand.\n\nSoon, he has said, the rubles were piling up faster than his mother could count them in the kitchen of their modest apartment, and he was set on his improbable career. He earned the slightly mocking nickname of \u201cPutin\u2019s cook.\u201d\n\nDespite his humble, troubled youth, Mr. Prigozhin became one of Russia\u2019s richest men, joining a charmed circle whose members often share one particular attribute: their proximity to President Vladimir V. Putin. The small club of loyalists who gain Mr. Putin\u2019s trust often feast, as Mr. Prigozhin has, on enormous state contracts. In return, they are expected to provide other, darker services to the Kremlin as needed.\n\nOn Friday, Mr. Prigozhin was one of 13 Russians indicted by a federal grand jury for interfering in the American election.", "title": "Yevgeny Prigozhin, Russian Oligarch Indicted by U.S., Is Known as \u2018Putin\u2019s Cook\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. \u2014 When Yoenis Cespedes, the Mets\u2019 musclebound star outfielder, begins his off-season workouts or spring training, his lower back typically stiffens. It has been a byproduct of being too tightly wound and lacking in flexibility.\n\n\u201cThis year, I haven\u2019t felt that,\u201d said Cespedes, 32, of the usual back tightness.\n\nAfter another year of leg injuries in 2017, Cespedes, much like the Mets as a whole did this winter with their medical and training departments, made drastic changes.\n\nWhile he still trained with Mike Barwis, who oversees the organization\u2019s strength and conditioning program from Florida, Cespedes applied three simple changes: he ran more; he lifted less; and he became more flexible, in part, with weekly yoga sessions.\n\n\u201cInjuries are unpredictable,\u201d he said on Monday, the first day of full squad workouts in Mets camp. \u201cYou don\u2019t know when they\u2019ll happen. But what I did was better prepare myself to try and prevent them.\u201d", "title": "Yoenis Cespedes\u2019s New Workout: More Running and More Yoga", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "In a small victory for prosecutors, a federal judge overseeing a sprawling New York corruption case will allow the government\u2019s key witness to wear a suit in court \u2014 rather than jail attire \u2014 after his arrest last week for a likely violation of his bail conditions.\n\nBut whether the sartorial choices of the witness, Todd R. Howe, will be enough to distract jurors from the inconvenient fact of his incarceration remains to be seen, as defense lawyers are sure to seize upon his arrest as confirmation of their arguments that Mr. Howe is unreliable, untrustworthy and out to save his own skin.\n\nMr. Howe is a disgraced former lobbyist who pleaded guilty to eight felonies and is cooperating with government in the case against Joseph Percoco, once one of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo\u2019s top aides, and three other defendants.\n\nMr. Howe was arrested in Manhattan on Thursday night, after a cross-examination in court that afternoon revealed that he had attempted to defraud a credit card company after his cooperation agreement was finalized in 2016. Mr. Howe had his bail revoked and was taken into custody at his hotel room and transported to the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Lower Manhattan.", "title": "You Can Put a Suit on a Problematic Witness, but Will Jurors Believe Him?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Q. Last year I opened a Facebook account, and as I entered my information I soon decided I didn\u2019t want to continue. I deleted the app on my phone and tablet. Occasionally, I receive a \u201cWelcome back to Facebook\u201d message and realize I\u2019ve not cut the cord. Is there way to sever this connection for good? Completely?\n\nA. Removing the Facebook app from your mobile devices does not delete the user account connected with it. To fully sever your ties with the social network, you need to visit the site\u2019s Account Deletion page and log back in; you can do this from a web browser if you do not want to download the mobile app again. Use the box on the page to officially request that Facebook delete your account.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story How Do You Use Tech? Advice and tips on the technology changing how you live. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nFacebook\u2019s settings page also offers an account deactivation option, which removes your profile page from view but is not permanent. Accounts are reactivated when you log back in. If you deactivated your account and then started up a laptop that was set to automatically log into Facebook, your account may have revived itself.\n\nFrom your account settings page, you can see on which devices you are logged into Facebook and then log out if necessary. Logging in, then logging out of any forgotten devices and permanently deleting the account should cut your Facebook ties. (More active Facebook users can download an archive of the posts made while using the service by clicking the \u201cDownload a copy of your Facebook data\u201d link on the account settings page.)\n\nPhoto\n\nIf you deactivated the account and are sure no other devices were set to automatically log into Facebook, receiving \u201cWelcome back\u201d messages may mean Facebook is trying to re-engage you or that someone else is trying to get into your account. You can report the problem at facebook.com/hacked. Change the password of the mail account you used for Facebook and \u2014 to be safe \u2014 reset your Facebook password before deleting the account.\n\nFake messages purporting to be from Facebook have been flying around the internet for years, so it is also possible you received a phishing attempt urging you to supply your account information to a fraudulent site. Late last year, Facebook announced that its users could see a list of official messages by clicking the link at the bottom of the Security and Login tab on the Settings page. If you see that Facebook has not sent you any legitimate messages, report the one you received to phish@facebook.com.", "title": "You Dumped Facebook. So Why Does It Keep Sending You Emails?", "authors": ["J. D. Biersdorfer", "Tech Tip"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "I am a legal aid attorney. A lot of my cases involve child abuse \u2014 it breaks my heart to see these children. A particularly horrible case came my way yesterday. During my commute, I put on \u201cThe Greatest Showman\u201d soundtrack. And I felt better. I contemplated going to see the movie again (I have seen in 6.3 times \u2014 once I was taking my kids to another movie and kept sneaking into \u201cGreatest Showman\u201d). There is an indelible magical component of \u201cGreatest Showman\u201d that makes you feel like hope is out there, that good people are out there, and that we can have joy and happiness \u2014even when we make mistakes. J. WATERS\n\nI\u2019m a 44-year-old male high school English teacher, and I have seen \u201cThe Greatest Showman\u201d eight times with my wife. First, it\u2019s about a circus \u2014 and circuses have always offered the masses a much-needed break from reality. There is also a happy ending for everyone. Yes, it\u2019s hokey, but you leave the theater with a light heart and a smile on your face. CHRIS BRYANT\n\nEveryone Can Enjoy the Music\n\nAre you kidding me? The songs are golden. I cannot get enough of the soundtrack. And the movie was touching. The moment on the rooftop with his daughters was beautiful. I think many parents can relate to that feeling of wanting to give your kids a world of opportunities that were maybe unavailable to you in some way. HALEY KASPRZYK\n\nThe music is uplifting and joyful in a way that I haven\u2019t heard in such a long time. The choreography, costuming and sets were beautiful to me. And, most important, the story of a man losing his way and coming home was something I needed in these difficult times. ASHLEY C. NICHOLS\n\nEverything. The songs, the lessons ... the fact that my children loved it. I hate paying for the movies and we\u2019ve seen it twice. We sing \u201cThis Is Me\u201d as a family when someone is feeling down. It\u2019s an amazing message and movie. STEPHANIE BASTEK\n\nThis weekend will be my third time seeing the film. Is the film an accurate biopic about Barnum? No. Was Barnum as great a humanitarian as Hugh Jackman is in the film? Most likely not. But we\u2019re judging him by today\u2019s times instead of the times in which he lived. Instead, they gave us memorable songs to express what the characters were feeling and actors who can say much with little or no dialogue. ANGELA WEAVER", "title": "You Explain What\u2019s Truly Great About \u2018The Greatest Showman\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nIf you think about being thirsty at all, it seems like a fairly simple thought process: Find water. Drink it. Move on. But in fact there is something rather profound going on as you take that long, refreshing drink after a run or a hot day in the garden.\n\nAs you become dehydrated, there is less water in your blood, and neurons in your brain send out the word that it\u2019s time to look for water.\n\nThen, once you take a drink, you feel almost instantly satisfied. But if that is obvious, it is also mysterious. You aren\u2019t pouring water directly into your bloodstream, after all. It will take at least 10 or 15 minutes, maybe longer, for the water in your stomach to make its way into the blood. And yet somehow, the brain knows.\n\nSometimes that process isn\u2019t as straightforward as it should be: People with a syndrome called polydipsia feel excessive thirst and drink enormous quantities of water. That can be dangerous, because if the blood is diluted too much, a person can die \u2014 a victim of water intoxication.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAs neuroscientists ponder how and why we thirst, a group of researchers at the California Institute of Technology has shed light on one small corner of the problem. Interested in how the brain keeps track of what the body is drinking, they have identified a set of neurons that receive messages as thirsty mice gulp down water. Passed around in the brain\u2019s thirst centers, these messages seem to be behind the sensation of swift satisfaction that comes after a drink, and also suggest that it\u2019s not just what is drunk, but how it is slurped down, that affects the brain. If the circuits work the same way in people, it may be key to understanding the neuroscience of what happens as we feel thirsty.", "title": "You Get Thirsty and Drink. How Does Your Brain Signal You\u2019ve Had Enough?", "authors": ["Veronique Greenwood"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Pension Funds\n\nA number of state pension funds own shares in the gun makers. For example, pension funds for public employees in Florida, Texas, Wisconsin and Ohio all have stakes of less than 1 percent in American Outdoor Brands, formerly known as Smith & Wesson, which is the manufacturer of the AR-15-style semiautomatic rifle that has been used in a number of recent mass shootings.\n\nTIAA, which oversees retirement investments for educators and teachers, has small stakes in American Outdoor Brands and two other publicly traded gun companies. The pension fund for teachers in New York State also has very small positions in the gun companies Sturm Ruger and Vista Outdoor.\n\nThe investments represent slivers of the pension funds\u2019 overall assets, but they nonetheless are generating debate. New Jersey lawmakers last week moved to cut off investments in gunmakers by the state pension plan.\n\nIndex Funds\n\nExchange-traded index funds, which are designed to track the performance of various market indexes, are all the rage these days. They hold the shares of every company in whatever index they\u2019re tracking. These indexes include the Russell 2000 index for small companies and the Standard & Poor\u2019s Aerospace & Defense Select Industry index.\n\nThat means these investment firms own the stocks, not because they see investment value in them, but because they are part of a broad stock index.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nTwo of the world\u2019s biggest asset managers, the index giants BlackRock and Vanguard, are now among the top shareholders of three publicly traded gun companies: Sturm Ruger, American Outdoor Brands and Vista Outdoor.\n\nBlackRock has an 11 percent stake in American Outdoor Brands, while Vanguard\u2019s stake is 8 percent. For Sturm Ruger, BlackRock owns 17 percent while Vanguard has 9.5 percent.\n\nBlackRock said it would be contacting officials at the three publicly traded firearms companies, asking them about how they were responding to the shootings.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nVanguard has taken a more cautious stance. With 20 million clients, the firm said it was unrealistic to cater to such a wide variety of views on pressing social topics. \u201cWe believe mutual funds are not optimal agents of social change,\u201d a spokesman said.\n\nVanguard does offer clients a way to screen funds for stocks that they do not want to invest in.\n\nStock Pickers\n\nWhile index funds are prominent shareholders of these gun companies, some large mutual funds \u2014 in which portfolio managers individually pick stocks \u2014 are also substantial owners.\n\nOne of the world\u2019s biggest fund companies, Capital Group, which oversees $1.6 trillion in assets, has an 8 percent stake in Sturm Ruger.\n\nA spokesman for Capital said on Monday that the investment firm \u201cwas engaging with gun manufacturers to understand their plans to ensure the safe use of these products.\u201d\n\nAnd the mutual fund giant Fidelity is the top shareholder of Vista Outdoor, with 15 percent of the company. The stake is held largely through Fidelity\u2019s actively managed funds.", "title": "You Might Be Giving Gun Companies Money, Even if You Don\u2019t Own a Gun", "authors": ["Landon Thomas Jr.", "Stephen Grocer"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Driving Two Hours to Date a Stranger\n\nEmma Thom, Sweet Briar College, Class of 2018\n\nI fell in love with the small classroom environment of Sweet Briar College and the picturesque scenery of its surroundings in the middle of nowhere, Virginia. But as a heterosexual female at an all-women\u2019s college, my dating life was nonexistent until I was introduced to Tinder and Bumble. Initially I hated the concept of dating apps. The upside to them was blind dates (yikes) and the downside was the opportunity to get rejected in three seconds or less by a potential match.\n\nBut as I began to create my dating profiles, choosing the most attractive pictures of me and my golden retriever, I started to have some fun. I hadn\u2019t yet warmed up to the idea of driving an hour or two to grab a drink with a stranger, but the conversations were light and the attention was wonderful. After hundreds of swipes left and right \u2014 and plenty of opening lines that received no response \u2014 I finally matched with a guy I was eager to meet.\n\nHe was a Virginia Tech student who seemed intelligent, witty and happened to be 6-foot-4 \u2014 tall enough for my highest heels. Conveniently, my best friend is also a student at Tech, so when I told her about this new guy, she immediately responded with \u201cCome to Blacksburg! You can meet up with him, and if he sucks, stay with me.\u201d So I drove two hours to meet a guy I\u2019d only been messaging for a week and a half. I\u2019d never heard the sound of his voice, or seen the way he walked or chewed his food. What would he think about my smile or the awkward snorting sound I make when I laugh too hard?\n\nI pulled into the parking lot of the Thai restaurant hoping that I didn\u2019t have pit stains and flaking mascara. When I saw him waiting for me, I almost did a double take \u2014 not because he didn\u2019t look like the guy in the pictures, but because he looked better. He was tall, blond, with green eyes and a smile wider and more welcoming than I\u2019d imagined. We had dinner and drinks, and several months later, we\u2019re still doing the same. Dating apps aren\u2019t for everyone, but they gave me the opportunity to meet someone I wasn\u2019t sure existed.\n\nI Found My First Date on an App\n\nCaleb Keyes, Otterbein University, Class of 2018\n\nIn high school I had always wanted to date but struggled to believe anyone would want to date me. When I got to college those fears were compounded by a feeling of trepidation that if I tried to date someone and we broke up, it would be hard to see them around campus. A friend encouraged me to download Coffee Meets Bagel, which was described as a dating app for people who are easily overwhelmed.\n\nI got a date and she suggested we get ice cream, even though it was snowing outside. It was old-school romantic in a way I hadn\u2019t expected. She looked beautiful with snowflakes falling on her hair and her cheeks red from the cold.", "title": "Opinion | You Up? College in the Age of Tinder", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nDeMarre Carroll, 31, is a forward for the Brooklyn Nets. Raised in Birmingham, Ala., and currently living in Brooklyn and Atlanta, Mr. Carroll is known for his bright shirts and colorful ensembles off the court. \u201cGrowing up, my mother always used to put us in loud sweatsuits and everything matched down to the shoes,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s still with me. I have to match from head to toe.\u201d Here are some favorites from his closet.\n\n1. SHIRT\n\nI\u2019m more a fitted button-down type of guy. I like those by Dolce & Gabbana because they fit me. I\u2019m 6-foot-8, and the new trend now is a snug fit that\u2019s a little short \u2014 it\u2019s European cut \u2014 so I can buy off the rack. As for colors and patterns, most people would say that I\u2019m a vibrant guy with loud colors and things that catch the eye. That\u2019s always been my style.\n\n2. JEANS\n\nWith my jeans, I\u2019m actually more subtle. One of the best brands that fit me is JBrand. I usually wear dark blue and black, definitely slim fit. I don\u2019t go crazy. My shoes and my shirt really do most of the justice for me.\n\nPhoto\n\n3. COAT\n\nI have two fur coats from this Canadian brand called Hiso. They reached out because of my Instagram account. It\u2019s always because of Instagram now. If you don\u2019t have a certain look, people won\u2019t approach you. The coats: One is black with gray and white, and the other one is in dark brown. I have zero clue what kind of fur it is, but it gives me one of those \u201cI\u2019m in the room\u201d kind of looks. I love that.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nI\u2019m always dressed like I\u2019m going to see my worst enemy, even if I\u2019m just going to the arena for practice. When I step out of the house, I would want to run into the guy who hated me my whole lifetime and it would be, \u201cLook at me now.\u201d", "title": "You Won\u2019t Find DeMarre Carroll of the Brooklyn Nets in Sweats", "authors": ["Bee Shapiro"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI hope he would have been interviewed by the F.B.I. or referred to the local police assuming he was identified,\u201d said Eugene Casey, a veteran former F.B.I. agent. \u201cI would have done my best to identify the individual who made the threat, but he could have posted it to YouTube from a public computer in a library or somewhere else.\u201d\n\nThe case highlights the difference between how the United States government handles terrorism and other kinds of attacks. Over the past decade and a half, the F.B.I. and other agencies have established broad power to pre-emptively investigate people in matters of international terrorism \u2014 raising expectations that the government should be able to prevent attacks.\n\n\u201cIf they had gotten a tip that someone was going to shoot up the embassy in Cairo, they would have been all over it. But they don\u2019t know what to do with it when it\u2019s domestic,\u201d said Chris Fialko, a prominent North Carolina defense lawyer who has handled numerous F.B.I. investigations. \u201cWe are not Big Brother yet. They have to get search warrants. In America, the Bill of Rights still applies.\u201d\n\nThe F.B.I. is gathering information about Mr. Cruz\u2019s social media posts, along with his movements and conversations, Mr. Lasky said. YouTube did not respond to a request for further information.\n\nMr. Bennight said he did not fault the F.B.I. for failing to stop the shooting.\n\n\u201cWe live in a country where you can\u2019t just lock people away for saying something,\u201d he said. \u201cYou can\u2019t just stuff somebody in a black hole because they said something that makes you uncomfortable. I believe the F.B.I. took it seriously. I hope that they followed up.\u201d\n\nIf the bureau missed an opportunity to prevent the shooting, it could find itself in the cross hairs of Congress, which has criticized the F.B.I. for failing to stop the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing and the 2009 mass shooting at Fort Hood in Texas. In the Texas attack, the shooter was known to the F.B.I., as was one of the brothers who carried out the Boston bombing.", "title": "YouTube Comment Seen as Early Warning in Shooting Left Little for F.B.I. to Investigate", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "AT&T, one of the nation\u2019s biggest marketers, has yet to return to YouTube nearly a year after pulling its advertising from the platform because of concerns that it could appear alongside offensive material.\n\nThe company was among a wave of major marketers who paused their spending on YouTube last March after it was found that ads were appearing on videos promoting hate speech or terrorism and other disturbing content. The Google-owned video service has since introduced a series of changes aimed at limiting the types of videos that can run ads, and most brands have resumed marketing on the platform.\n\nBut that has not been enough for AT&T, which wants YouTube to get \u201cas close to zero tolerance for this issue as possible,\u201d Fiona Carter, the company\u2019s chief brand officer, said in a recent interview.\n\n\u201cIt became apparent to us as we worked through this that too much of the content our advertising could appear against was not brand safe \u2014 it was objectionable by any measure,\u201d Ms. Carter said. \u201cYou really have an epiphany when you see some of that content.\u201d", "title": "YouTube Revamped Its Ad System. AT&T Still Hasn\u2019t Returned.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "In the lawsuit filed Friday, the lawyers say there are at least 40 plaintiffs across New York State who have been detained indefinitely and who could be part of a class action. Most of those are not accused gang members, the suit said.\n\nThe United States Department of Health and Human Services, which oversees the resettlement of unaccompanied minors who have entered the country illegally, said it could not comment on pending litigation.\n\nThe suit claims that the government is violating the William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008, which requires that unaccompanied minors be released from detention promptly and placed in the least restrictive setting appropriate.\n\nA policy enacted in June, however, requires the director of the Office of Refugee Resettlement to approve every juvenile\u2019s release. The N.Y.C.L.U. lawyers said the director, Scott Lloyd, is delaying the process without explanation.\n\nThis policy, the suit claimed, violates the children\u2019s fundamental right to be reunited with their families while fighting their immigration cases.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Race/Related Newsletter Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with a diverse group of New York Times journalists. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cFrom everything we can tell,\u201d Christopher Dunn, a lawyer for the N.Y.C.L.U. said, \u201cthey have a view that anyone who had a gang taint at one point is always a gang member and they are just not going to release those kids.\u201d\n\nStarting in September 2016, Suffolk County on Long Island saw 17 MS-13-related murders in 15 months. That prompted a swift, coordinated local and federal response from law enforcement agencies. In August, the resettlement agency created its Community Safety Initiative, which says that no gang member can be released to a sponsor without a judge\u2019s order.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe last killings that authorities have linked to MS-13 came on April 11, when four young Latino men were found hacked to death with machetes in the woods behind a Central Islip soccer field. Two of the victims had been students at Bellport High School, where teachers had noted an uptick in the presence of MS-13.\n\nThat was where the plaintiff in the lawsuit was a freshman last year. Identified as L.V.M. because he is a minor, he was suspended from Bellport High School less than two weeks after the killings after being accused of flashing gang signs in the hallway with another student, according to the complaint.\n\nThree months later, L.V.M. was arrested by immigration agents conducting a sweep they called \u201cOperation Matador,\u201d which has arrested 205 young adults for MS-13 connections on Long Island.\n\n\u201cHe is not a gang member, he doesn\u2019t support MS-13, he fled gang violence in his home country,\u201d his lawyer, Paige Austin, said. L.V.M. said he was raising both middle fingers to respond to another student, the lawsuit said.\n\nAfter his arrest, agents brought L.V.M. to Shenandoah Valley Juvenile Center in Virginia, a secure facility. Nearly six weeks later, he was transferred to a lower level of supervision at Children\u2019s Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.\n\nAt L.V.M.\u2019s Dec. 18 hearing, the government presented additional evidence outlining his gang involvement. According to his lawyers, the government said a video existed of him flashing gang signs (which they have been unable to see), he wore clothing that distinguished him as a gang member, he had been identified by the Suffolk County Police Department as belonging to the gang, and he had gang tattoos.\n\nHis mother, Esmeralda Mejia de Galindo, said she was surprised to hear all of these allegations \u2014 especially that last detail. \u201cMy son doesn\u2019t have a tattoo,\u201d she said in an interview through an interpreter on Monday. \u201cI\u2019m the mom, I would know.\u201d\n\nMs. Meija, 36, fled El Salvador with L.V.M. and his younger brother in May 2016 because they were targeted by gang members, according to the lawsuit. They were arrested at the border and later applied for asylum; their applications are pending. After his arrest by I.C.E., L.V.M.\u2019s status was changed by immigration authorities to that of an unaccompanied minor.\n\nLast week, the Department of Homeland Security published a news release declaring that unaccompanied minors and families are exploiting \u201clegal loopholes\u201d that only \u201cinvite more illegal immigration,\u201d and that the abuses must end now.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Dunn said L.V.M. and other juveniles have rights. \u201cThey are not loopholes, they are federal guarantees to protect children like him,\u201d Mr. Dunn said.", "title": "Young Immigrants Are Being Held Illegally, Lawsuit Claims", "authors": ["Liz Robbins"]} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "To the Editor:\n\nI am a resident of Parkland, Fla., where 17 people were tragically killed last week. Another resident in my Morningside Heights co-op dislikes my dog, and, by association, dislikes me. Whenever she sees me in a common area, she curses at me and threatens to kill my dog. I informed the co-op board and building management, which then circulated a notice about pet owner etiquette. It addressed how owners should handle dogs, not how neighbors should behave. When I filed a complaint with the police, I was told that the building should handle the problem. Who, if anyone, can end threats from a neighbor?\n\nA. Your neighbor should not be cursing at you or threatening the life of your dog. However, she might have reasons for her behavior, even if it seems irrational to you. \u201cUnderneath the surface there might be reason for the anger,\u201d said Brad Heckman, the chief executive of the New York Peace Institute, an organization that provides free mediation service for New Yorkers.\n\nWhere you see a sweet, lovable pet, your neighbor may see one that barks, growls or appears aggressive. For you and your neighbor to continue to live in the same building peacefully, this dynamic needs to change. Your neighbor needs to alter her behavior, but you and your dog may need to make some adjustments, too.", "title": "Your Neighbor Dislikes Your Dog. And Now That\u2019s Your Problem.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "So why these wines? Because value is not strictly a synonym for inexpensive. It means you are getting inordinate quality for the price, which I hope will be the case with these bottles. They are:\n\nCh\u00e2teau Aney Haut-M\u00e9doc 2013 (Kermit Lynch Wine Merchant, Berkeley, Calif.) $25\n\nCh\u00e2teau Moulin de Tricot Haut-M\u00e9doc 2013 (Rosenthal Wine Merchant, New York) $28\n\nCh\u00e2teau le Puy Emilien Francs C\u00f4te de Bordeaux 2013 (Rosenthal Wine Merchant) $42\n\nThese wines are produced in relatively small quantities, as is so often the case with good-value Bordeaux. If you cannot find them, you could select any recent Bordeaux in this price range. Other names to look for include Peybonhomme les Tours, Auney, Moulin Pey-Labrie, Lanessan, Jean Faux, La Peyre, Milon and Peyredon, just to name a few.\n\nI should say that the 2013 vintage is not considered among the best, though I generally think that we pay too much attention to vintages. Yes, vintage conditions affect the character of the wine, and occasionally the price, though not much for wines as relatively inexpensive as these. But it\u2019s always more interesting to see what a good producer does with a mediocre vintage than it is to prioritize the vintage.\n\nThat said, if you see wines from these producers in other recent vintages, by all means snap them up.\n\nThese wines are best with simple meals. Lamb and beef are classic matches; chicken and duck are fine as well. For the week of Feb. 18, seven events in New York and elsewhere not to be missed:\n\nTheater: Ed Harris in \u2018Good for Otto\u2019\n\nFeb. 20-April 1; thenewgroup.org.\n\nThe last time that the New Group staged a play by David Rabe, a few seasons back, it was a revival of his Tony-winning classic, \u201cSticks and Bones,\u201d a surreal drama about an American family whose son returns from the Vietnam War, his mind crowded with troubling thoughts. Mr. Rabe\u2019s latest venture with the New Group \u2014 the darkly comic \u201cGood for Otto,\u201d a play from 2015 now receiving its New York premiere \u2014 also forges deep into interior worlds, though this time they belong to the patients and a couple of therapists at a New England mental health center.\n\nDirected by Scott Elliott, the production starts previews on Tuesday, Feb. 20, at the Pershing Square Signature Center, where the large Off Broadway cast includes Ed Harris and Amy Madigan as the therapists; F. Murray Abraham as a septuagenarian too depressed to get out of bed; Rhea Perlman as a foster mother to a child with an accelerating mental illness; Maulik Pancholy as a lonely man in tenuous touch with reality; and Mark Linn-Baker as a mercurial na\u00eff much devoted to Otto, the title character \u2014 a hamster, by the way, and the least tortured soul of the lot. LAURA COLLINS-HUGHES\n\nDance: Ronald K. Brown at the Joyce\n\nFeb. 6-11, joyce.org.\n\nGiven how short dance careers can be, sticking with the same company for 20 years is reason for celebration. For their return to the Joyce Theater, Ronald K. Brown and his Brooklyn-based troupe, Evidence, pay tribute to Arcell Cabuag, who joined the company in 1997 and serves as its associate artistic director. Mr. Cabuag was a student at the Ailey School when, peeking into a rehearsal, he first encountered Mr. Brown\u2019s inviting blend of African, hip-hop and modern dance styles. He was hooked.\n\nAt the Joyce the two will perform a new duet, \u201cDen of Dreams,\u201d on a program also featuring Mr. Brown\u2019s \u201cCome Ye\u201d (2002), inspired by Nina Simone, and an excerpt from his 1995 \u201cLessons\u201d set to a speech by Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Honoring another close relationship will be the company premiere of \u201cDancing Spirit,\u201d created in 2009 for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater as a homage to its artistic director at the time \u2014 and a mentor to Mr. Brown \u2014 Judith Jamison. SIOBHAN BURKE\n\nPhoto\n\nClassical: Nico Muhly Reimagining Philip Glass\n\nFeb. 8; carnegiehall.org.\n\nOne of the most exciting events of Philip Glass\u2019s current residency at Carnegie Hall \u2014 which includes the composer\u2019s own ensemble playing his landmark \u201cMusic with Changing Parts\u201d on Feb. 16 \u2014 will not feature Mr. Glass in performance at all. Instead, on Feb. 8, the prolific composer Nico Muhly, fresh off the debut of his new opera \u201cMarnie\u201d in London (coming to the Metropolitan Opera next season), will oversee and perform his own reimagined versions of some of Mr. Glass\u2019s more obscure works.\n\nAn obsessive admirer of Mr. Glass since high school and the composer\u2019s studio assistant in college, Mr. Muhly has crafted his own artistic voice that imbues Mr. Glass\u2019s minimalist abstraction with a rhapsodic self-expression. Mr. Muhly will be joined by a world-class clique of collaborators including composer and vocalist Caroline Shaw, violist Nadia Sirota and, perhaps most intriguingly, the great Laurie Anderson. WILLIAM ROBIN\n\nPhoto\n\nTV: The Cuter Bowls\n\nFeb. 4; animalplanet.com; hallmarkchannel.com.\n\nFor sports enthusiasts it\u2019s a week to beat, book ended by Super Bowl LII on Sunday, Feb. 4, and the opening of the Winter Games in Pyeongchang on Friday, Feb. 9.\n\nBut for those who prefer their athletes younger and cuddlier than Tom Brady \u2014 and yearn to give a rescued pet a forever-home \u2014 the action doesn\u2019t get any better than \u201cPuppy Bowl XIV,\u201d Sunday on Animal Planet. Ninety baby bruisers from across the country, including hurricane-devastated areas in Florida, Texas and Puerto Rico, will compete for either Team Ruff or Team Fluff in a new bone-shaped stadium outfitted with nose-level cameras to capture chew-toy interceptions, terrier tackles and the occasional slobbery kiss.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMore of a cat lover? Tune in to \u201cKitten Bowl V,\u201d Sunday on Hallmark, where a roster of displaced fur balls will paw and pounce their way into the end zone. And like their puppy rivals, they\u2019re all up for adoption. KATHRYN SHATTUCK\n\nFilm: \u2018Permission\u2019\n\n\u201cHow can you be certain he is the one, if he is the only one?\u201d That\u2019s the tagline of \u201cPermission,\u201d Brian Crano\u2019s Brooklyn-based rom-com, opening Friday, Feb. 9, and starring Rebecca Hall and Dan Stevens as Anna and Will, longtime sweethearts who have never been with anyone else.\n\nCut to Anna\u2019s 30th-birthday dinner, for which Will has tucked away an engagement ring, and the drunken suggestion by Reece (Morgan Spector) \u2014 his best friend and the partner of Anna\u2019s brother, Hale (David Joseph Craig) \u2014 that the couple sleep with other people before they inevitably tie the knot. After which that ring doesn\u2019t resurface.\n\nMr. Crano could have done without the crashing glasses and burning car to punctuate the fraught nature of Anna and Will\u2019s sexual unfurling with new partners (Fran\u00e7ois Arnaud and Gina Gershon). We get it. But the questions plaguing modern relationships \u2014 of love and fidelity for Anna and Will, of potential parenthood for Reece and Hale \u2014 make for an often-charming exploration in the hands of the magnetic Ms. Hall and Mr. Spector, who, like Mr. Crano and Mr. Craig, are married in real life. KATHRYN SHATTUCK", "title": "Your Week in Culture: Kendrick Lamar\u2019s \u2018Black Panther,\u2019 Paul Klee, Lesley Manville", "authors": ["The New York Times"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "New TV shows, museum openings, film releases and concerts \u2014 it\u2019s a lot to keep track of. Let us help you. For the week of Feb. 11, seven events in New York and elsewhere not to be missed:\n\nPop: Romeo Santos at the Garden\n\nFeb. 15-17; msg.com.\n\nAny discussion of the most influential New York musicians of the 21st century ought to include Romeo Santos, the Bronx-born bachata superstar who has done more than any other individual to bring that Dominican sound to a mass U.S. audience. In addition to his record as a reliable Latin hitmaker, he is also one of the city\u2019s top live draws. Four years ago, Mr. Santos memorably sold out two nights at Yankee Stadium; two years ago, he reunited his former band, Aventura, for a whopping 20 shows at United Palace Theater, in Washington Heights.\n\nHis three-night stand at Madison Square Garden, Feb. 15-17, may seem less like a milestone \u2014 he\u2019s already headlined there many times \u2014 but it still puts him in an elite class of performers. How many can book more than two consecutive nights at New York\u2019s most iconic venue and have it feel like business as usual? SIMON VOZICK-LEVINSON", "title": "Your Week in Culture: Romeo Santos, Alan Ball, Fran\u00e7ois Ozon\u2019s Valentine Thriller", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.\n\nI have been contemplating quitting my job for the past six months or so. I\u2019m finally certain about the decision, but I can\u2019t seem to find the right time to tell my boss. It didn\u2019t seem right just after the holiday break. Then I came down with the flu and missed several days, putting additional stress on my team. Plus the company is in the middle of kicking off several big new projects, and my role would be integral. Our company is small, and I have a close relationship with everyone, my boss included. I don\u2019t think anyone suspects that I am even thinking about leaving. I have had a couple of amazing years here and expected to stay longer. But I\u2019m burned out by long hours for not enough money and don\u2019t find creative satisfaction in the work any more. It\u2019s starting to affect my personal and professional relationships. I don\u2019t want to blindside my boss, but I fear postponing this conversation, as that may just overcomplicate things. I would love some advice. ANONYMOUS\n\nThe problem here is pretty clear: You like your colleagues, but you really don\u2019t like your job. You\u2019re right that postponing the conversation will not make it any easier. Eventually, in fact, it\u2019s just going to make you bitter: You\u2019re suffering for the sake of others who are blissfully ignorant of your unhappiness.\n\nIf you have something else specific lined up, let that dictate the timing. If you don\u2019t, then decide on the timetable that\u2019s best for you and stick to that as closely as possible. Be selfish about this. If a job is having a negative impact on your personal life and you can get out of it, you need to do so promptly.\n\nWhen you announce your decision, tie it to a concrete final date. You can choose to be flexible if requested, but anchor the discussion to a specific time frame; don\u2019t start out with something vague or squishy.", "title": "You\u2019re Ready to Quit, but When Should You Actually Do It?", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-17 00:00:00", "text": "Moreover, there\u2019s some experimental evidence that our biased approach to getting news actually makes us dumb. For example, one experiment asked 1,000 people to look at a simple data set and draw conclusions about a skin cream\u2019s effectiveness. Not surprisingly, Democrats and Republicans were about equally good at calculating the math and determining how well it worked.\n\nBut when the experiment offered the very same data set and said it referred to the effectiveness of a gun control measure, Democrats and Republicans alike went to pieces. In one version, the numbers showed that a gun control measure worked \u2014 and Republicans kept flubbing the math. In another version, the gun control measure was ineffective, and this time the Democrats couldn\u2019t manage the calculations.\n\nThe evidence on these biases is complex, studies sometimes haven\u2019t replicated well, and I don\u2019t want to exhibit confirmation bias in my warnings of confirmation bias. Researchers also caution that it\u2019s too glib to say we are all locked in our echo chambers, for most Americans still are regularly challenged by dissonant information.\n\nBut what does seem clear is that rigid ideological beliefs impair our cognitive functions. For many years, Philip Tetlock of the University of Pennsylvania has been running experiments measuring the ability of thousands of people to make sound predictions.\n\nThe best forecasters, Tetlock finds, are not experts or even intelligence officials with classified information, not liberals and not conservatives, but rather those instinctively empirical, nonideological and willing to change their minds quite nimbly. The poorest marks go to those who are strongly loyal to a worldview.\n\nI wondered whether to write this column, for there are so many urgent \u2014 and progressive! \u2014 causes on the table that I want to thunder about: Dreamers, guns in American life, White House dismissiveness toward domestic violence, and so on. But the \u201cDaily Me\u201d problem also undermines the capacity of liberals to win these arguments. When we stay within our own tribe, talking mostly to each other, it\u2019s difficult to woo other tribes to achieve our aims.\n\nThe ideological blinders may worsen because of our tendency to seek out like-minded people. A 2014 Pew survey found that half of consistent conservatives and 35 percent of consistent liberals say \u201cit\u2019s important to me to live in a place where most people share my political views.\u201d\n\nIt should be possible both to believe deeply in the rightness of one\u2019s own cause and to hear out the other side. Civility is not a sign of weakness, but of civilization.", "title": "Opinion | You\u2019re Wrong! I\u2019m Right!", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "So this week, let\u2019s all just evaluate whether we even care about our resolutions, then think about what we really want to do. (And if you got it right the first time, kudos!) Once we\u2019ve landed on the perfect goal, keep in mind you want to be SMART about it:\n\nSpecific: Set concrete, clearly defined goals with specific points of success.\n\nMeasurable: Whatever the goal is, find ways to measure progress.\n\nAchievable: Aim high, but within reason. Your goal should be a stretch, but something you could actually achieve.\n\nRelevant: Find a goal that matters enough to you that you\u2019ll be motivated to stick with it.\n\nTime-bound: Set a reasonable timeline for your goal, and focus on the small wins along the way.\n\nOnce you\u2019ve set your goal, email it to me at tim@nytimes.com with the subject line \u201c2018 resolutions,\u201d and fill in your answers to following questions. I\u2019ll start:\n\nYour name: I\u2019m Tim Herrera, your Smarter Living editor.\n\nYour resolution and why you chose it: My main resolution this year is more of a goal: I want to run the Brooklyn Half-Marathon in 90 minutes or less. It\u2019s a stretch goal, but one within reach.\n\nTwo specific sub-goals within your resolution: 1. My training starts in earnest today, and I\u2019m committed to running at least three days a week all month. 2. I will cross-train at least one day per week.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Sign Up for the Smarter Living Newsletter A weekly roundup of the best advice from The Times on living a better, smarter, more fulfilling life. It\u2019s harder to protect yourself when the sick person is living inside your house. But certain measures may help.\n\nWhat We\u2019re Reading\n\nThis week I\u2019ve invited one of my favorite writers, James Clear, to share some recent stories he loved. Let\u2019s Get Back on Track.", "authors": ["Tim Herrera"]} {"date": "2018-02-10 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWith spring training opening in Florida and Arizona next week, the camp of unsigned free agents has lost its ace. Yu Darvish, perhaps the most prominent pitcher left on the frigid open market, has agreed to a six-year, $126 million deal to join the Chicago Cubs.\n\nThe agreement, first reported by Ken Rosenthal of The Athletic, was confirmed by a baseball official who was granted anonymity because Darvish must pass a physical for the deal to be official. It is the richest contract given to any free agent this off-season, both in years and dollars, surpassing outfielder Lorenzo Cain\u2019s five-year, $80 million deal with the Milwaukee Brewers.\n\nDarvish, 31, is a four-time All-Star who beat the Cubs in the National League Championship Series last fall as a member of the Los Angeles Dodgers. He is 56-42 with a 3.42 earned run average in five seasons, mostly with the Texas Rangers, and his 11.04 strikeouts per nine innings lead all active pitchers with at least 100 starts.\n\nIncluding the postseason, Darvish won six of his first 11 starts after the Dodgers acquired him from Texas in a trade last July 31. But he was the goat of the World Series, allowing nine runs and collecting only 10 outs while losing Games 3 and 7 to the Houston Astros.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDarvish was relieved in Game 7 by Brandon Morrow, who worked in every game of the World Series and is now the Cubs\u2019 closer. The Cubs signed Morrow to a two-year, $21 million deal in December to replace Wade Davis, who went on to sign with the Colorado Rockies.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nBesides Darvish and Morrow, the Cubs have also signed Tyler Chatwood, the former Colorado right-hander who thrived outside of Coors Field last season, to a three-year, $38 million contract in early December. Darvish and Chatwood join Jon Lester, Jose Quintana and Kyle Hendricks in a rotation that should be imposing.", "title": "Yu Darvish and Cubs Said to Agree to $126 Million Deal", "authors": ["Tyler Kepner"]} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cI\u2019ve skated after him before and skated well,\u201d Chen said of Hanyu. \u201cObviously that didn\u2019t happen here, but I don\u2019t think that was really too much of a role.\u201d\n\nWith five quadruple jumps scheduled in his long program, Chen could move up a number of places Saturday, but the medal podium appears far out of reach without meltdowns from the leaders.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe has been out of sorts for both routines at these Games.\n\nA week ago, in his short program in the team competition, Chen fell on a triple axel and completed only two revolutions on a planned four-revolution jump. He said he was thinking too much instead of just skating. Still wearing his costume, he immediately went downstairs to the training rink and rehearsed his jumps.\n\nBut things only got worse in the singles competition.\n\nAsked how he would plan for Saturday\u2019s skate, Chen seemed at a loss.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve never been in this position before, so I don\u2019t know exactly what to do,\u201d he said.\n\nHanyu had not competed since late October.\n\nHe sustained ligament damage in his right ankle on Nov. 9 while rehearsing a quad lutz before a competition in Japan. It is the most difficult of the four-revolution jumps being performed.\n\nHe missed about two months of training on the ice; in the meantime, he rehearsed his jumps on the floor at his training center in Toronto.\n\nHe has only been practicing his triple axels for about three weeks and his quad jumps for two weeks. But his coach, Brian Orser, a two-time Olympic silver medalist for Canada in the 1980s, cautioned reporters not to underestimate Hanyu\u2019s talent and resolve. Hanyu has said that he does not want to simply be a champion skater, he wants to be a great skater.\n\n\u201cI know many people have been waiting for me to skate, and I want to the show them the performance that makes them feel it was worth the wait,\u201d Hanyu said at a news conference the other day. He added: \u201cThis is my dream stage, and I want to give my dream performance.\u201d", "title": "Yuzuru Hanyu Commands the Stage. Nathan Chen Falls Off It.", "authors": ["Jer\u00e9 Longman"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "In the end, the injury \u201ccould be the best thing that ever happened\u201d for Hanyu, said Jackie Wong, a prominent blogger from New York who is a former skater and skating judge and who is covering the Olympics. \u201cHe wasn\u2019t going for unnecessary difficulty.\u201d\n\nHanyu disregarded any talk about being the greatest ever in his sport, saying, \u201cI\u2019m not the best skater.\u201d But others were not so reluctant.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cIf you want him to be, you wouldn\u2019t be wrong,\u201d said Kurt Browning of Canada, a four-time world champion in the late 1980s and early 1990s. \u201cWhy not. He\u2019s everything. He\u2019s the skater, he\u2019s the jumper, but quintessentially, he\u2019s the performer. He seems to have the superpower to take all the pressure, all the expectations and all the lights and all the cameras, and somehow he\u2019s able to use it as a competitor.\u201d\n\nHere\u2019s how the free skate played out:\n\nGermany\u2019s Paul Fentz Does Game of Thrones Cosplay\n\nPaul Fentz of Germany had a heavily themed Game of Thrones routine. He skated to the dramatic music from the television show\u2019s soundtrack, and was dressed in a shirt designed to look like armor. He wore one gold glove, perhaps reminding some viewers of Jaime Lannister, who has a metal hand. But the judges did not seem to agree that Winter is coming, and put him in third place of the three skaters who have gone.\n\nJapan\u2019s Keiji Tanaka Leads Early; Nathan Chen Up Next\n\nWith the six lesser lights of the 24 competitors having skated, Keiji Tanaka of Japan is the early leader, helped by a quad Salchow at the top of his program. The second group of six will include Nathan Chen of the United States, who disappointed badly in his short program, but has a daring five-quad program to try to make up ground.\n\nPhoto\n\nTwo Quads Gives Bychenko the Lead\n\nAlexei Bychenko of Israel, the first skater of the second group, gave a strong performance that moved him into the lead. Bychenko, skating to music from the opera Pagliacci, hit both his quads and fell to his knees with joy at the end of the performance.\n\nPhoto\n\nNathan Chen Gets Aggressive, Goes for Six Quads\n\nNathan Chen, who bombed his short program and stood in only 17th place, hoped to make up ground with a daring five quad performance. But he did not land five quads. He threw in one more and landed six.\n\nChen, 18, performed a quad Lutz, flip combination, flip, toe loop combination, toe loop and Salchow. The quad toe loop-triple toe loop combo scored a huge 17.63 points by itself. Chen also did well on the more subjective judging elements, getting over 9 for performance. He takes a big lead over the other early skaters, by a full 40 points.\n\nIt was a redemptive and audaciously ambitious performance. Chen became the first Olympian to land five quadruple jumps cleanly in a routine and actually attempted six, but put his hands to the ice on the quad flip. His score of 297.35 could put him in medal contention if the leaders struggle later.\n\nBrendan Kerry Invokes Pink Floyd\n\nBrendan Kerry of Australia has had some of the more intriguing musical choices of the event. In the short program he skated to an eerie cover of \u201cEverybody Wants to Rule the World.\u201d For the free skate he chose a Pink Floyd medley, including \u201cShine on You Crazy Diamond\u201d and \u201cMoney.\u201d But his performance wasn\u2019t quite up to snuff and he bailed out of his quads. That concluded the second group of six skaters. Twelve to go. Chen still leads by 40 points.\n\nPhoto\n\nKeegan Messing Puts on a Show\n\nThe Olympics are at their heart, a sports competition, but no one has had more fun here than Keegan Messing of Canada, who entertained the crowd with a Charlie Chaplin routine on Saturday after skating to Singin\u2019 in the Rain on Friday.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHe is unapologetic about being a showman as much as a competitor. \u201cI just feel like I can bring the crowd in; it makes my skating so much more fun for me,\u201d he said. Messing also hit two quads and moved into third place.\n\nNathan Chen Made a \u201cGame-Time Decision\u201d to Try 6 Quads\n\nLeader Nathan Chen spoke after his amazing program:\n\n\u201cHaving such a rough short program allowed me to just forget about expectations and just allow myself to really enjoy myself,\u201d Chen said. \u201cI think six quads was almost a game-time decision, I knew at that point that I had literally nothing to lose.\n\n\u201cAs much as I tried to deny it, I felt the pressure a lot before the short program, especially thinking about scores and placement and all that. And that was completely out of my control. That just tightened me up and made me really cautious on the ice.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nVincent Zhou Nearly Matches Nathan Chen\n\nVincent Zhou, 17, exceeded expectations in his short program, placing 12th. And he rolled out an ambitious five-quad free skate. And like his countryman Nathan Chen, he delivered.\n\nIn skating\u2019s complicated scoring system, Zhou was credited with four quadruple jumps, three of them landed cleanly. He put his hand to the ice on a quad flip. And his attempt to become the first Olympic skater to land two quad Lutzes \u2014 the most difficult of the four-revolution jumps being performed \u2014 came up short. His second Lutz was judged to have been under-rotated. Still, his score for the long program was a lifetime best of 192.16 points.\n\nHis technical score was only 7 off Chen\u2019s and he moved into second place overall, 21 points down. Zhou is definitely one to watch for 2022.\n\nPhoto\n\nAdam Rippon Skates a Clean Program, but No Quads\n\nAdam Rippon, the man with the killer abs, was the final American to skate. A program without quads would make it difficult to finish high, but he wheeled out all his showmanship, including birdlike motions while skating to Coldplay\u2019s \u201cArrival of the Birds.\u201d And he landed all those triples.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nRippon skated with his accustomed elegance, but the jumping prowess of Nathan Chen and Vincent Zhou illustrated the gulf between his artistry and the bold athleticism needed to score highly under today\u2019s scoring system.\n\nWith six more to skate, the American men can finish no lower than 7th, 8th and 10th. This is the fourth time in the last five Olympics that all three men have made the top 10. The last time was 2010, when Evan Lysacek won the gold medal, Johnny Weir finished sixth and Jeremy Abbott took ninth.\n\nDmitri Aliev Struggles\n\nDmitri Aliev, the 18-year-old Russian, was the first of the final six to skate and probably the least likely winner, with only two quads in his program.
