Lawrence called a \u201creturn pilgrimage\u201d toward liberty and away from an intolerant imposition of religious dogma in the Muslim world, we must relaunch this vital journey together with the reformers, or we will be fighting jihadists forever.", "title": "Opinion | \u2018Enablers\u2019 in Afghanistan", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Below are a few of my favorites pitches \u2014 both serious and playful \u2014 followed by our weekly roundup and a recommendation for a photo festival we\u2019re working with that\u2019s eager for quality entries.\n\nShare the word. Share your Australia Diary anecdotes. And, of course, share (and sign-up for) this newsletter.\n\nFeedback? Find us at nytaustralia@nytimes.com and in our NYT Australia Facebook group.\n\n___\n\nTassie Time\n\nEnough with that desolate, overheated Outback stuff. Australian mainlanders and foreign outlanders alike need to know there is a place down here that, despite being wild and dangerous, has four seasons, charmingly spread across 12 months. The new Dundee should be a feature-length version of \u201cRosehaven.\u201d The Luke McGregor character doesn\u2019t carry a knife but he can still charm the leg off an iron pot. Even the NYT called \u201cRosehaven\u201d charming \u2014 not a word usually applied to anything Oz. And if you feel the need to put a Hemsworth in it, Chris would be an excellent ghost of Errol Flynn, roaming the streets of his Tasmanian childhood.\n\n\u2014 Sheila Allison\n\nAn Aussie Battler\n\nWind the clock forward. He or she can be a small business person, who does an enjoyable and authentic job, up against a multinational corporation. A David and Goliath story, or as Australians would think of it; a little battler does good story. Something heartwarming. Characters you can relate to and really get to like, but not quite sophisticated. Street smart, but honest street smart. Hard working, believes he or she can mix it up with the big players. Has a lot of front, but not brash. Maybe the character is a bit like a Federation house \u2013 all grand frontage that leads to a lean-to at the back. Doesn\u2019t want to rule the world, but wants a fair share. Of course, our politicians can get involved, but based upon their antics over the last couple of years they would be uncouth. I\u2019d even give a cameo to the locked filing cabinet. I\u2019d call it the Cabinet\u2019s cabinet after Major Major of Catch 22. Would the battler win? Of course. Not in the courts, but with daring do. For the cast, it is hard to go past Hugh Jackman and Russell Crowe.\n\n\u2014 Mark Thomas\n\n\u2018Croc Dundee,\u2019 Feminists First\n\nIt should be a girl. Margot Robbie has inherited her dad\u2019s bar in Alice Springs. She operates with a no-nonsense style, making it a draw for tourists and locals alike. One night she has to remove an unruly customer, which a patron videos and posts to the Internet. She becomes a viral sensation, and soon a crew from the New York Times comes calling. When they get to the bar, she is the real thing, and they want her to come to the States to appear in a reality TV show, \u201cCroc Dundee, the Woman\u201d She reluctantly gives it a try, and is a \u201cfish out of water\u201d in Brooklyn, where she can\u2019t understand the appeal of $5 cups of coffee and over-priced meals. After she encounters a bigot berating an Aboriginal (somehow one of them made it to NYC), she gives him a thrashing which is recorded by a \u201cman on the street\u201d with an iPhone, but this time she grabs it from the man and smashes it, saying \u201cone viral video in a lifetime is enough.\u201d She packs it up and heads back to Alice Springs, where her portrait is painted for inclusion in the museum at Canberra, and she meets up with an male mate from grade school. (second grade). Their children\u2019s romance is rekindled and they operate the bar which is now a tourist mecca, featuring the \u201cNew York Strip Steak, cooked Brooklyn style. They have a YouTube channel and post videos of famous people who drop by.\n\n\u2014 Kirby Franklin Warnock\n\n______\n\nPhoto\n\nThe autonomous \u201cselfie drone\u201d that will follow you and film you is finally here.\n\nAs someone who both loves technology but hates seeing and hearing drones hovering over some of Australia\u2019s most beautiful coastal walks, I\u2019m not sure how to feel about this.\n\nNeither is our tech columnist, Farhad Manjoo.\n\n______\n\nPhoto\n\nAre you watching the Olympics? (Travel)\n\n______\n\n...And We Recommend", "title": "\u2018Enough With That Desolate, Overheated Outback stuff.\u2019", "authors": ["Damien Cave"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "BEIRUT, Lebanon \u2014 At least 80 people were killed on Tuesday in Syrian government air and artillery strikes on besieged suburbs of the capital, Damascus, one of the last rebel-held strongholds. It was the bloodiest day so far in a weekslong escalation that prompted United Nations officials to issue an unusual call for an immediate cease-fire.\n\nThe toll, compiled by rescue workers and rising into the night, came as at least six more people were killed in another rebel-held area, in the northern province of Idlib. There, in the past week alone, the government\u2019s Russian-backed air war has damaged several hospitals and clinics and killed dozens of people, including many civilians.\n\nUnited Nations humanitarian officials declared the situation \u201cextreme\u201d even for the nearly seven-year war, and called on Tuesday for an immediate cease-fire for at least a month to allow aid deliveries.", "title": "\u2018Extreme\u2019 Suffering in Syria as Government Steps Up Bombing", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 In one of the more awkward box office pairings in memory, the rough-sex sequel \u201cFifty Shades Freed\u201d was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, while the cuddly-cute \u201cPeter Rabbit\u201d did well with children in second place.\n\n\u201cFifty Shades Freed\u201d (Universal Pictures), which did not delight critics nearly as much as it did pun-enthralled headline writers, arrived to ticket sales of roughly $38.8 million. Based on the third and final book in the \u201cFifty Shades\u201d series by E.L. James, \u201cFifty Shades Freed\u201d cost an estimated $55 million to make, not including marketing. It was directed by James Foley (\u201cGlengarry Glen Ross\u201d) and co-stars Dakota Johnson and Jamie Dornan.\n\nThe \u201cFifty Shades\u201d cultural fever ended a long time ago: Most readers discovered that a little of Ms. James\u2019s writing goes a long way. But ticket sales for the final movie adaptation \u2014 marketed by Universal with a baldfaced tagline, \u201cDon\u2019t miss the climax\u201d \u2014 were solid, declining only 16 percent from initial results for its series predecessor, \u201cFifty Shades Darker,\u201d a year ago.", "title": "\u2018Fifty Shades Freed\u2019 Ends Sex Trilogy With Solid Ticket Sales", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "Let the heavy breathing begin. The soundtrack album to \u201cFifty Shades Freed,\u201d the finale of the soft-core BDSM romance trilogy based on the novels by E.L. James, arrives with its goal clearly designated: getting a song on the radio with enough of a sultry frisson to sell tickets for the movie. Yet the album\u2019s upbeat love songs released in advance \u2014 \u201cCapital Letters\u201d by Hailee Steinfeld with BloodPop and \u201cFor You (Fifty Shades Freed)\u201d by Liam Payne and Rita Ora \u2014 haven\u2019t gained much chart traction; perhaps they\u2019re too wholesome. The album has slightly spookier material.\n\nSome soundtrack albums are grab-bags of moods; some are reserved and ambient. But the \u201cFifty Shades\u201d pop franchise \u2014 which on two previous albums has yielded Top 10 hits for the Weeknd (\u201cEarned It\u201d), the duo of Zayn and Taylor Swift (\u201cI Don\u2019t Wanna Live Forever\u201d), and Ellie Goulding (\u201cLove Me Like You Do,\u201d which reappears, barely altered, on \u201cFifty Shades Freed\u201d) \u2014 stays persistently on message. Each song spells out the trilogy\u2019s themes: desire, passion (with just a tinge of taboo), obsession, true love and, certainly not least, luxury shopping. \u201cI know you\u2019re afraid of what you want but I\u2019m curious,\u201d Sabrina Claudio sings in \u201cCross Your Mind\u201d over a reggaeton beat, in English and Spanish versions. (Don\u2019t forget the international market.) She adds, \u201cI\u2019m addicted to anything that\u2019s not good for me.\u201d\n\nImage Songs from previous \u201cFifty Shades\u201d soundtracks have cracked the Top 10.\n\nIt\u2019s not that big a stretch for current pop, which \u2014 soundtrack or no soundtrack \u2014 often fixates on the very same topics. Still, \u201cFifty Shades Freed\u201d comes across as very tightly targeted. If it wasn\u2019t a soundtrack collection, it could be a concept album about a risky infatuation with a posh happy ending.\n\nJulia Michaels fulfills the \u201cFifty Shades\u201d assignment with \u201cHeaven,\u201d a ballad with a hollow, plinking arrangement under her just-finished-crying voice, delivering lyrics that dovetail love and religion \u2014 \u201cFalling for him was like falling from grace\u201d \u2014 on the way to the twist in the chorus: \u201cThey say all good boys go to heaven/But bad boys bring heaven to you.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Fifty Shades Freed\u2019 Soundtrack Strains to Please", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-20 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLONDON \u2014 A facsimile of Mary Shelley\u2019s manuscript of \u201cFrankenstein,\u201d written when she was just 18, will be published in March by SP Books here to mark the bicentennial of the novel\u2019s publication in 1818.\n\nThe draft version, written in two large notebooks, is full of annotations by both Mary Shelley and her future husband, Percy Shelley, showing his corrections to her spelling (\u201cenigmatic o you pretty Pecksie!\u201d he wrote next to her \u201cigmmatic\u201d) and suggested changes to vocabulary.\n\nSP Books suggests on its website that Mary Shelley\u2019s own revisions show that she slowly made her monster more human, changing a description of a \u201ccreature\u201d to a \u201cbeing,\u201d replacing \u201cfangs\u201d with \u201cfingers,\u201d and making his hair (at Percy Shelley\u2019s recommendation) a \u201clustrous black.\u201d\n\nIn an interview with The Guardian newspaper, Jessica Nelson, a founder of SP Books, said that what was \u201cmoving about this manuscript is that you can see the literary work mixed with something tender and emotional.\u201d (The similar handwriting of Mary and Percy Shelley gave rise to the 2007 book \u201cThe Man Who Wrote Frankenstein,\u201d which claimed that Percy Shelley wrote the novel. The writer Germaine Greer riposted that the novel was too bad to have been written by the poet.)\n\n\u201cFrankenstein\u201d had its origins in a lighthearted ghost-story competition suggested by Lord Byron, whose Lake Geneva villa the Shelleys were visiting in the summer of 1816. Initially unable to come up with an idea, Mary Shelley then had a \u201cwaking dream\u201d in which she imagined a corpse reanimated by \u201cgalvanism,\u201d or electricity. \u201cHow I, then a young girl, came to think of, and to dilate upon, so very hideous an idea?\u201d Mary Shelley wrote in her preface to the novel. Lucky she did; it\u2019s been an inspiration to writers, directors, filmmakers and choreographers ever since.", "title": "\u2018Frankenstein\u2019 Manuscript Comes to Life in New Publication", "authors": ["Roslyn Sulcas"]} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nThey faithfully adapted and paved new ground for the \u201cGame of Thrones\u201d universe. Why not give it a whirl with \u201cStar Wars?\u201d\n\nDavid Benioff and D. B. Weiss, executive producers of \u201cGame of Thrones,\u201d will write and produce a series of new \u201cStar Wars\u201d movies, the Walt Disney Company said on Tuesday. There were no details about the number of movies or when they would be released. But Disney did say that the Benioff and Weiss films would be separate from the Luke Skywalker universe of movies and the trilogy that Rian Johnson, the writer and director of \u201cStar Wars: The Last Jedi,\u201d is working on.\n\nThe deal amounts to a coup for each party. Disney gets two extremely in-demand producers who have proved they can satisfy \u201cThrones\u201d book loyalists along with drawing in millions of general viewers that made \u201cGame of Thrones\u201d the most popular show in HBO\u2019s history.\n\nAnd for Mr. Benioff and Mr. Weiss, the \u201cStar Wars\u201d assignment could prove to be more welcoming than their planned HBO project announced last summer. The news that the two star producers would work on \u201cConfederate,\u201d a fictionalized drama that imagines the South won the Civil War and slavery remains intact in today\u2019s America, was met with an immediate backlash.\n\nHBO has said it would proceed with the drama if Mr. Benioff and Mr. Weiss wanted to, and that they \u201cshould be given time to develop the series rather than face prejudgment.\u201d Many TV executives in Hollywood are skeptical that it will get made, and it\u2019s possible \u201cStar Wars\u201d could give the \u201cThrones\u201d producers an excuse to put it off.\n\nThe last \u201cGame of Thrones\u201d season will be broadcast in 2019. HBO is currently developing several \u201cGame of Thrones\u201d prequels, and though Mr. Benioff and Mr. Weiss will get executive producer credits on any shows the cable network makes, they will not be actively involved.\n\nMr. Benioff and Mr. Weiss said in a statement, \u201cIn the summer of 1977 we traveled to a galaxy far, far away, and we\u2019ve been dreaming of it ever since. We are honored by the opportunity, a little terrified by the responsibility, and so excited to get started as soon as the final season of \u2018Game of Thrones\u2019 is complete.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Game of Thrones\u2019 Executives to Take on Disney \u2018Star Wars\u2019 Films", "authors": ["John Koblin"]} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSATURDAY PUZZLE \u2014 I was struck by two aspects of this Saturday puzzle by John Guzzetta, one very specific, one broad. First, for some reason, a pair of long crossing entries stuck out to me \u2014 PAROLE HEARING and BAILED OUT. That inspired the silly readout under the headline today, and just struck me as extra clever. It couldn\u2019t be my own conscience, which is as innocent as a spring lamb, and certainly couldn\u2019t be because the long, extremely slow-moving arm of the law has been on my blameless mind these days. Nevertheless, I appreciated it.\n\nThe other, less particular attribute today was the nice mix of clues from different vernacular eras. Today\u2019s puzzle had a couple of very recent terms that I was challenged by, and another couple of long entries that were anachronisms to me, equally hard to figure. Most of the good Times puzzles use modern slang, terms from antiquity, and everything in between; the best do it so skillfully that solvers of all linguistic interests can find a clue or two for their genre of choice, as well as pick up some terms. That\u2019s one of the things that keeps this sport alive!\n\nTricky Clues\n\n1A: So, there\u2019s a movie called the FIFTH ESTATE, from 2013, that\u2019s about WikiLeaks, basically, although the inference is that the term refers to everything informational and digital. That was the only reference I could come up with for this clue without help (from the fifth estate, I guess one could say). But a quick Google search finds a Canadian investigative journalism show like \u201c60 Minutes,\u201d sort of, by the same name; it dates from 1975. Then a little more perspective: The term was used in England in 1932 to refer to radio. As long as we in newspapering can just stay fourth it\u2019s O.K. It\u2019s not like we\u2019re going to get on the medal podium.\n\n17A: For \u201cDirt spreader,\u201d I thought literally, and tried to figure out what farming or construction implement could fit in here. Instead this cleverly refers to the kind of dirt we dish out, gossip or whisper about, the specialty of a RUMORMONGER.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThere\u2019s been a lot of research into the evolution of gossip, since it seems to be as omnipresent and influential in dogs as it is in human culture. Dogs convey important information to one another by leaking, or marking interesting smells and trails to potential food sources \u2014 garbage cans and flattened pigeons, for example. (Even when I don\u2019t let my urban dogs anywhere near such delicacies they always rebel by leaving a little hint for anyone else who comes by.)", "title": "\u2018Go, Me!\u2019", "authors": ["Caitlin Lovinger"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Dear Diary:\n\nWhen I am walking in Manhattan, I will occasionally compliment a dog owner on the pet that he or she is walking. Without fail, this seems to please the owner and elicit a smile and a thank you.\n\nWhile walking south along Central Park West on a recent day, I noticed a sleek, handsome Great Dane coming my way. It was on a leash. I didn\u2019t make eye contact with the owner.\n\n\u201cGorgeous,\u201d I said as we passed each other.\n\n\u201cYes,\u201d said the owner, without slowing down at all, \u201cI work out a lot.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Gorgeous\u2019", "authors": ["Jackie Schwimmer", "Metropolitan Diary"]} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "How did you go from vampire romance in rural Louisiana to a trouble-laden multiracial family in the Pacific Northwest?\n\nPhoto\n\nI\u2019d done a couple of pilots for HBO that didn\u2019t go. I also have a bunch of movies that I\u2019ve written over the years that nobody seems to want because they aren\u2019t about superheroes or exploding machinery. I\u2019m a person who likes to work. I knew that HBO was looking for a family drama. So I sat down to write one. But I didn\u2019t want it to be just another family drama about a family dealing with what families deal with. Certainly a multiethnic family made it more interesting for me as a writer. It also just seemed like it would give us more interesting stories than sibling rivalry or somebody gets a mammogram. You know, your usual family TV show tropes. [Laughs] The sort of mystical-mysterious element just sort of happened.\n\nWere your story lines affected by the political moment?\n\nI was working with the writers when Donald Trump was elected president, and we started to see the show as a kind of prism through which we could look at all these different characters\u2019 multiethnic, multigenerational viewpoints living in Trump\u2019s America. How do you deal with that? How do you make sense of that?\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhy Portland?\n\nPortland has this reputation for being so incredibly progressive \u2014 and it is. However, it also has a pretty sketchy history in terms of racism. For a place that\u2019s very progressive, it\u2019s still predominantly Caucasian. So there\u2019s an interesting dichotomy there, because it\u2019s a very progressive town and one of the greatest places to live. At the same time, it isn\u2019t really what it aspires to be.\n\nPhoto\n\nWhat research did you do for the characters?\n\nI knew that I wasn\u2019t going to be able to write a lot of the characters in this show from a place of personal experience. So when we \u2014 myself and my producing partner, Peter Macdissi \u2014 were putting the writers\u2019 room together, we made sure that we had a couple of African-Americans, a guy of Asian descent, a Lebanese Muslim guy and a Palestinian gay guy. We have people who are adoptive parents. Growing up in my white privilege, I have no reason to know these things. So it\u2019s not so much research on my part, it\u2019s having these great writers that I work with who bring their own experiences to the table.\n\nLike Greg, you recently turned 60. Were you as unhappy about the milestone as he appears to be?\n\nWell it\u2019s hard to age, to get older, to realize \u201cWow, my body isn\u2019t working like it used to.\u201d It\u2019s hard to go, \u201cHow many years do I have left?\u201d I\u2019m not sure I have any empirical data to back this up, but I think it\u2019s harder for men than women. I think women are more in touch with their emotions, with the cycle of living. Whereas men are conditioned to believe that we\u2019re invincible and will remain that way forever \u2014 and we\u2019re stupid enough to believe that. [Laughs] I feel like I\u2019ve had about five midlife crises. I think the first one was when I was about 35. As someone who struggled with depression and anxiety [my] whole life, I feel like you got to pull yourself out of there, you got to find a way. I wanted Greg to start off at the bottom. I wanted to see him work his way out of that.\n\nYou also feature a Muslim family where the parents are comfortable with their child being transgender. Is there a story behind this?\n\nPhoto\n\nPeter said, \u201cIf this is going to be a show about America, we need a Muslim family to be a part of this tapestry.\u201d People are so terrified of, don\u2019t understand, project all kinds of weird stuff onto Muslim characters \u2014 especially the way they\u2019ve been depicted in the mainstream media. They\u2019re never complex or nuanced. I did some research and, of course, there are trans Muslim kids. We\u2019re so conditioned to think of Muslim families as so conservative that there\u2019s no room for any kind of out-of-the-box expression for one\u2019s identity \u2014 and that\u2019s just not the case.\n\nYour favorite childhood movie \u2014 \u201cMy Six Loves\u201d \u2014 is about a family of adopted children. Are you paying tribute?\n\nIt\u2019s not my favorite movie. It\u2019s the first movie I ever went to see. Debbie Reynolds plays an actress who ends up adopting six adorable hillbilly children. And she realizes: \u201cOh, I don\u2019t want to be an actress. I want to be a mother. That\u2019s what\u2019s really fulfilling.\u201d [Laughs] One of the running gags is that one of the kids is mesmerized by flushing the toilet, and he keeps doing it. I just remember that was the first time I sat in a big darkened theater, looked up on a screen and saw this story unfold. I haven\u2019t seen it since I was 5 or 6. I\u2019m sure it would be a big letdown from what exists in my memory.\n\nIn 2000, you won an Oscar for writing \u201cAmerican Beauty.\u201d I read that you dressed it in a pink fur coat. Because?\n\n[Laughs] My identity, a lot of it, is based in feeling like the outsider. So when I won an Oscar, it was terrifying. When I brought it home, I put it on a shelf, and it looked so pretentious. So I bought a pink fur Barbie coat and put it on [the Oscar] and somehow it made it O.K. for me to have it in my house. But then I got over that and took it off. Now I have a shelf in my office where all the statuaries are. None of them are dressed.\n\n", "title": "\u2018Here and Now,\u2019 a New Supernatural Drama From the Creator of \u2018True Blood\u2019", "authors": ["Margy Rochlin"]} {"date": "2018-02-18 00:00:00", "text": "Ashley is the screen on which society\u2019s racism is projected. Kristen, who talks openly about slut-shaming and menstruation in class, is becoming the show\u2019s avatar for feminism. She\u2019s had the bad luck of contracting chlamydia from her very first sexual encounter, and when Ashley takes her to Planned Parenthood, Kristen beats up an anti-abortion protester who calls her a \u201cdumb whore.\u201d Both sisters get arrested, but while the cops goof around with Kristen, who finds the whole experience exhilarating, a female officer humiliates Ashley, forcing her to remove her wig, questioning her about her expensive purse and cracking that the tampon she finds inside it explains Ashley\u2019s bad mood.\n\nThe upshot? Ashley embraces her natural hair. Sure, why not?\n\nApart from my certainty that even the nastiest female cop wouldn\u2019t have made that tampon joke, what\u2019s irritating about this story line is that it\u2019s just as didactic as Greg\u2019s lecture. It doesn\u2019t give us any insight into who Ashley and Kristen are as individuals. From the clunkiness of its plot points to the laundry list of racial and gender issues it neatly checks off, the episode reduces one character to the archetypal oppressed black woman and the other to the archetypal entitled white girl.\n\nAudrey\u2019s story line, which casts her as a true believer in the power of empathy, is just as frustrating. We discover what her Empathy Initiative actually does, sort of, when the principal of Kristen\u2019s high school seeks her advice on what to do about a \u201cNorthern European Heritage Society\u201d that some students have recently organized. Many students are, understandably, angry about what they see as a school-sanctioned neo-Nazi organization. So, Audrey brings the factions together and, thanks to the magic of \u201cI feel\u201d statements, quickly gets the white kids to back down. Well, that was easy.\n\nThen there\u2019s poor Duc, who\u2019s stuck with this episode\u2019s worst subplot. In a painfully expository exchange (\u201cFairfax Press loves the latest draft of your book, not to mention your Twitter and Instagram followings\u201d), we learn that he\u2019s visiting Vancouver to meet with a potential publisher. Fairfax, which also happens to have published Greg\u2019s groundbreaking book, offers him a deal, with the caveat that he has to ask his father to write the foreword. This scene apparently exists to reinforce what was already apparent from the premiere: Duc is living in Greg\u2019s shadow. Got it.\n\nMore ridiculous is the sequence in which Duc, who\u2019s supposed to be celibate, beds a series of women in quick succession. These erotic-thriller shots are interspersed with flashbacks to his childhood in Vietnam, where a young Duc is forced to watch a prostitute, presumably his mother, sleep with clients. (At first, because there\u2019s no dialogue and the editing is so ambiguous, I thought the whole sequence was an abstinence-induced hallucination.) By the end of the Vancouver trip, this compulsively healthy \u201cmotivational architect\u201d is swimming in empty beer bottles, junk food wrappers and shame. I guess this means he\u2019s a secret sex addict?", "title": "\u2018Here and Now\u2019 Season 1, Episode 2: Empathy and Fear", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Whether it\u2019s chemical, environmental or both, Greg\u2019s affliction appears to be a potent cocktail of depression about the state of the world and anxiety about its future. He says as much at the ethics conference, scoffing at a colleague\u2019s insistence that the most logical response to global turmoil is optimism. \u201cNo wonder Dante populated the first circle of hell with philosophers,\u201d he says. \u201cAnxiety is a completely appropriate response to today\u2019s reality.\u201d\n\nThe word \u201canxiety\u201d reverberates through this episode, the same way empathy and fear kept popping up last week. Ramon confesses to Farid that he hasn\u2019t stopped smoking weed because it soothes his nerves. He and Henry don\u2019t have much else to do in this hour, besides serving as foils for Ramon\u2019s high-achieving older siblings \u2014 who are, by all appearances, driven primarily by their various anxieties.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAt the Bayer-Boatwright dinner party, Duc, who is quickly becoming a caricature of a Type A jerk, attacks Henry for working as a barista. Henry politely suggests that following some ambitious life plan doesn\u2019t always work out the way you intend. A new character, Carmen (played by Fernanda Andrade), an \u201cintuitive\u201d who seems destined to play a role in both Duc\u2019s and Ramon\u2019s lives (she balks at Duc\u2019s use of the word \u201cpsychic\u201d), heartily agrees. It turns out that Ramon\u2019s game, which he says is about \u201chow we perceive impossibility,\u201d whatever that means, isn\u2019t exactly goal oriented, either.\n\nBy now, it\u2019s obvious that the \u201cHere and Now\u201d creator, Alan Ball, reserves much of his empathy (that word again!) for characters like Ramon, Henry and Ashley\u2019s husband, Malcolm (Joe Williamson), who aren\u2019t always laboring toward some inane accomplishment. In a purely expositional side story, Duc scolds Malcolm for squandering his opportunity to win a bike race, and Malcolm replies that he\u2019d rather be happy than victorious. I appreciate that obnoxiously competitive people exist in the world, but three episodes in, I wish the show would give us a reason to care about Duc.\n\nInstead, it is painting Farid as a sort of secular saint. In a scene in which he bares his scarred back, the psychiatrist repeats worries he\u2019s already expressed about Navid\u2019s religious commitment and fluid gender expression: \u201cI just want to keep you safe, that\u2019s all,\u201d he tells his son. \u201cWe already have targets on our backs.\u201d As Farid explains to a clerk at Cannabliss, he suffers from \u201creligious anxiety\u201d and can only bear to attend a Muslim wedding after sharing a joint with (why not?) a homeless woman. The tension between Farid and his American-born family is rich with potential. But it is surrounded by so much narrative clutter that the show barely has time to dig into it.\n\nMeanwhile, Ashley is stuck with this week\u2019s \u201chuh?\u201d subplot. Just as Kristen is informing Ashley\u2019s model buddy that he gave her chlamydia (and that she still wouldn\u2019t mind hooking up with him again), his girlfriend appears. When Ashley hears what happened, she lures him into her studio for a photo shoot, where she dresses him in a doughnut-print onesie, threatens to report him to the police and forces him to confess on camera that he is \u201cguilty of statutory rape.\u201d Later, she emails Kristen the video. Subject line: \u201cVENGEANCE.\u201d\n\nI guess this is supposed to be a righteous, girl-power moment, but it just made me pity the model. Yes, he cheated on his girlfriend (assuming they\u2019re monogamous) and unknowingly passed chlamydia to a minor. Yes, the age of consent in Oregon is 18. But Kristen is 17, in a country where most states allow teens to consent at 16 or 17, and she was wearing a horse mask when they met and never took it off, before or during sex. Is humiliating this happy-go-lucky idiot and calling him a rapist \u2014 in that way implying that Kristen is a rape victim \u2014 really a sane response? I got the feeling that these scenes were supposed to demonstrate her loyalty to her sister, but Ashley comes out of them looking slightly unhinged.\n\nIt\u2019s story lines like these that crowd out the show\u2019s more promising aspects, from Farid\u2019s family drama to Ramon\u2019s video game to Greg\u2019s hunger to feel connected with the world again. Last week, I complained that \u201cHere and Now\u201d was spelling out what each character represents to the exclusion of exploring who they all are. That continuing issue aside, Ball is introducing too many subplots and invoking too many huge concepts (empathy, fear, anxiety, religious devotion, optimism, nihilism, relativism, hedonism, sexism, racism) to give any element the attention it deserves. At this point, an episode that delves deep into just a few characters or lingers at one event would be a relief. The only way to fix this show is to slow it down.", "title": "\u2018Here and Now\u2019 Season 1, Episode 3: High Anxiety", "authors": ["Judy Berman", "Here"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "Season 1, Episode 1: \u2018Eleven Eleven\u2019\n\n\u201cHere and Now\u201d is going to be a weird show. That much is implied in the first moments of the series premiere, as a barrage of apparently unrelated images flashes across the screen, followed by a shot of a woman and a little boy playing on the beach. The camera quivers. The sound skips like an old record. The woman gasps, removes her sunglasses, calls out the name \u201cRamon\u201d and scratches four long, deep gashes into her own face with her fingernails. She says something in a language that isn\u2019t English. It\u2019s as though we\u2019ve entered some new \u201cTwin Peaks\u201d lodge.\n\nBut, phew, it\u2019s nothing more than a dream. Or, at least, it seems that way when Ramon Bayer-Boatwright (Daniel Zovatto), a college student who designs video games, awakens in his Portland, Ore., apartment. That same morning, he summons the courage to take his flirting to the next level with Henry Bergen (Andy Bean), a bearded barista who might be Ramon\u2019s soul mate and who is surprisingly eager to accompany him to his father\u2019s 60th birthday party that evening.\n\nIt\u2019s a good day. The only thing that seems off about it is that Ramon keeps seeing the number \u201c11:11.\u201d First it\u2019s a clock in the coffee shop. Then it\u2019s the dashboard of his elliptical, at the gym, which freezes 11 minutes and 11 seconds into his workout. After a few of these scenes, it occurred to me that the four gashes from his dream also resembled four ones. Ramon tells Henry about a website that claims that people who are \u201ccontacted\u201d by the number 11:11 have \u201csome positive mission to accomplish.\u201d They laugh it off in bed, joking that their hookup is that mission.\n\nStill, the extent to which this show is going to be weird doesn\u2019t become clear until the final ten minutes of the episode. At the party, as his depressive philosophy professor father, Greg Boatwright (Tim Robbins), delivers an uncomfortably pessimistic speech, Ramon has a vision. There are four candles on top of a bookshelf, and their flames seem to stretch into, yes, four long, straight, blazing lines. No one else sees it.", "title": "\u2018Here and Now\u2019 Series Premiere: This Great Experiment", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "So Tim Robbins and Donald Trump walk into a bar.\n\nNot together.\n\nThey just happened to be in the same Greenwich Village club one night in the mid-1990s. But given the fact that fame is an irresistible magnet for Mr. Trump, the two men naturally ended up in a picture.\n\n\u201cI was throwing a private party for a friend, and he tried to crash it and I wouldn\u2019t let him,\u201d Mr. Robbins recalls. But Mr. Trump is not that easily put off, even when his quarry has disdain for him.\n\n\u201cWe were in a little roped-off section of the club that I had rented out and I was leaving to go to the bathroom and all of the sudden, there he is. And before I know it, I turn around and there\u2019s photo flashes, and it was weird. He wanted a photo with me because I was famous. He used to do that a lot, by the way. He wanted to be photographed with famous people all the time.\u201d\n\nIt is strange that this onetime cardboard-cutout celebrity popping up at Gotham parties has turned into a psychic dentist drill, boring into Americans\u2019 deepest, most painful schisms on race, gender and inequality.", "title": "\u2018Hollywood Is Changing,\u2019 Says Its Veteran Activist, Tim Robbins", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "[ Here\u2019s What You Need to Know for Season 7 ]\n\nWhich brings us to Season 7, which opens in the aftermath of Peter Quinn\u2019s heroic death. (Apologies for the spoiler if you haven\u2019t watched Season 6, or been aware of the #NotOurHomeland fan campaign expressing outrage over his treatment.)\n\nWith Quinn gone, where will the show go to find the crazy? (\u201cCrazy\u201d here referring to a dramatic quantity, not to any person or character\u2019s actual mental condition.) Will Carrie\u2019s mania re-emerge as a primary driver of the plot?\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nShowtime made only the season premiere available for review, so we can only guess. But the early indications are that the show is going to try to have it both ways \u2014 to keep Carrie medicated, while putting her in a situation so dire that her behavior still unnerves those around her. (There will, however, be changes in how she obtains her drugs, and which ones she takes, according to this interview with Ms. Danes.)\n\nThis echoes her current conflicted situation. Having prevented the assassination of the winning presidential candidate Elizabeth Keane (Elizabeth Marvel) by right-wing radicals in Season 6, only to be blindsided when Keane trampled on civil rights by ordering mass arrests (including that of Saul), Carrie is now secretly working to expose Keane\u2019s lies.\n\nFans will be happy that this involves the resurfacing of Carrie\u2019s spycraft, and it\u2019s a pleasure in the season premiere to watch her pulling her gear out of hiding, or duck into a hotel room and put on a disguise \u2014 it\u2019s like she\u2019s getting back into her own skin.\n\nOn the downside, it also means that she\u2019s back to willfully endangering the people in her life, a trait that could be seen as a complexity of character but has always registered as an unpleasant distraction. Once again it\u2019s up to Carrie\u2019s sister, Maggie (Amy Hargreaves, in one of television\u2019s more thankless roles), to angrily lecture her. \u201cThere\u2019s a vast government conspiracy and you\u2019re the only one who can bring it to light, I know,\u201d Maggie says.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m on my meds,\u201d Carrie wails in response to her sister\u2019s accusations. She\u2019s doing what she\u2019s doing \u2014 including putting her young niece at risk as part of her investigations \u2014 because the country is in free-fall, she says. And there\u2019s a poignancy to her plea that accords with the current mood of much of that country, an inchoate sense that events you can\u2019t control call for some sort of radical action.\n\nThe implicit promise of \u201cHomeland,\u201d of course, is that over the course of 12 weeks Carrie will indeed bring the vast government conspiracy to light, and restore justice and order to boot. It remains to be seen how crazy a task it will be.", "title": "\u2018Homeland\u2019 Season 7: Once Again, It\u2019s All Up to Carrie", "authors": ["Mike Hale"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "The bureau, which was already under considerable political pressure because of its investigation into Mr. Trump, faced calls for even more scrutiny following the massacre.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Scott said that Christopher A. Wray, the director of the F.B.I., should step down and that the bureau\u2019s failure to act on the tip about Mr. Cruz was \u201cunacceptable.\u201d \u201cSeventeen innocent people are dead and acknowledging a mistake isn\u2019t going to cut it,\u201d Mr. Scott said in a statement.\n\nIn an unusually sharp public rebuke of his own agents, Attorney General Jeff Sessions said Friday that the missed warnings had \u201ctragic consequences\u201d and that \u201cthe F.B.I. in conjunction with our state and local partners must act flawlessly to prevent all attacks. This is imperative, and we must do better.\u201d\n\nRobert F. Lasky, the special agent in charge of the F.B.I. field office in Miami, said the agency advised the victims\u2019 parents about the misstep in a conference call on Friday.\n\n\u201cWe will be looking into where and how the protocol broke down,\u201d he said. Read more here.\n\n\u2018How does this happen?\u2019 a parent asks as victims\u2019 funerals begin.\n\nAt the first funeral, Alyssa Miriam Alhadeff, 14, was remembered for her joy and kindness, traits that had attracted a wide circle of friends. Hundreds of mourners filled the Star of David Funeral Chapel in North Lauderdale, Fla., spilling outside.\n\nAmong the youngest victims, Alyssa, an honor student and a player for the Parkland soccer club, was buried in the Garden of Aaron at Star of David Memorial Gardens.\n\nHer mother, Lori Alhadeff, urged Alyssa\u2019s friends to stay in touch, but also let their future success be her daughter\u2019s legacy. \u201cLive, breathe for Alyssa,\u201d she said.\n\nAt a synagogue just a mile from where she had been gunned down, Meadow Pollack, 18, lay in a plain wooden coffin, closed in accordance with Jewish tradition.\n\nBefore her were hundreds of mourners, seated in row upon row and crowding every wall and corner: her cousins, her classmates, the governor and so many others. She is survived by many family members, including her brothers and her grandmother Evelyn.\n\nPhoto\n\nHer father stood in a black suit before the crowd.\n\n\u201cHow does this happen to my beautiful, smart, loving daughter?\u201d Mr. Pollack said. \u201cShe is everything. If we could learn one thing from this tragedy, it\u2019s that our everythings are not safe when we send them to school.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe room heaved with sobbing teenagers, and mourners wheeled out Ms. Pollack\u2019s coffin, to be buried in a nearby cemetery.\n\n\u2018It\u2019s sad something like that could happen,\u2019 the president said in Florida.\n\nThe Trumps arrived Friday evening at a hospital in Pompano Beach that took in eight of the shooting victims, accompanied by John F. Kelly, the White House chief of staff, and Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida.\n\nThe president and Mrs. Trump visited the Broward Health North Hospital \u201cto pay their respects and thank the medical professionals for their life-saving assistance,\u201d according to a statement related by a White House spokeswoman on Friday evening.\n\nWhen asked if he met with victims, Mr. Trump said: \u201cYes, I did. I did indeed.\u201d\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s sad something like that could happen,\u201d he said.\n\nMr. Trump did not respond when he was asked if gun laws needed to be changed. He then walked into another room.\n\nLater, speaking during a meeting with law enforcement officials at the Broward County sheriff\u2019s office, the president thanked first responders for what he called an \u201cincredible job,\u201d according to a White House press pool report.\n\nMr. Trump said he had met with the parents of some of the victims, and also spoke with a female victim at the hospital who he said had been shot four times and was saved because emergency workers got her to the hospital quickly.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSchools across the nation are on edge after Wednesday\u2019s shooting.\n\nThe authorities were still investigating reports of shots fired on Friday morning at Highline College, about half an hour\u2019s drive south of Seattle, said Capt. Kyle Ohashi, a spokesman for the Puget Sound Regional Fire Authority. No physical evidence of a weapons discharge \u2014 including shell casings or damage to any structure \u2014 had been found, he said. The school said in a statement on Facebook that the situation was cleared about three hours after a lockdown began. Several other agencies, including the federal Bureau of Alcohol Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, had also responded.\n\nThe Gilchrist County School District in Florida shuttered its schools after receiving an email threat, and the Nutley Public School System in New Jersey also said it would be closed because of a security threat. A high school in Colorado Springs canceled a pep rally.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nSchools also wrestled with how to proceed with lockdown drills, which have become as routine as fire drills as students prepare for the possibility of a shooting. Some schools opt to make the drills feel partially authentic \u2014 an approach several schools backed off from this week out of fear they would stir already heightened anxieties.\n\nAt Dysart High School in El Mirage, Ariz., the principal took extra steps to make sure students knew its previously scheduled drill on Thursday was, in fact, just a drill. The reminder was included in the morning announcements, and she reiterated it on the public address system several times throughout the day, said Zachery Fountain, a district spokesman.\n\nEureka High School in Eureka, Calif., postponed its drill that had been scheduled for Thursday, partly because officials were concerned about the mental state of students, said Fred Van Vleck, the district superintendent. Typically, the school doesn\u2019t announce that the lockdown is a drill, telling students only that there could be a drill within a one-week window, he said. Read more about the school closings.\n\nAs a boy, her grandfather survived a mass shooting by hiding in a closet. Now she was doing the same.\n\nDuring the horror at Stoneman Douglas High on Wednesday, Carly Novell, a 17-year-old senior who is an editor for the school\u2019s quarterly magazine, hid in a closet and thought about an awful family tragedy from before she was born. Her mother had told her about how her grandfather had survived a mass shooting in 1949 in Camden, N.J. His family had not made it.\n\n\u201cMy grandfather was 12, and his grandma and his mom and dad were killed while he hid in a closet,\u201d Ms. Novell said. \u201cThey heard gunshots on the street, so my great-grandma told my grandpa to hide in the closet, so he was safe. But he didn\u2019t have a family after that.\u201d\n\nInterviewed on Thursday, she said: \u201cI was thinking of him while I was in the closet. I was wondering what he felt like while he was there. My mom has told me he was in shock after it, too \u2014 that he didn\u2019t remember how he got to the police station, or anything like that. I didn\u2019t forget anything, but I was in shock and I didn\u2019t understand what was going on.\u201d\n\nMr. Cruz made his first court appearance on Thursday.\n\nIn an orange jumpsuit and shackled around his hands, feet and waist, Mr. Cruz was asked if he understood the circumstances of his appearance in court. \u201cYes, ma\u2019am,\u201d he whispered.\n\nVideo\n\n\u201cHe\u2019s sad. He\u2019s mournful,\u201d his public defender, Melisa McNeill, said afterward. \u201cHe is fully aware of what is going on, and he\u2019s just a broken human being.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Weekes, the chief assistant public defender, said lawyers were still trying to piece together the details of Mr. Cruz\u2019s life. He has a \u201csignificant\u201d history of mental illness, according to Mr. Weekes, and may be autistic or have a learning disability. But Mr. Weekes was not ready to say whether he would pursue a mental health defense.\n\nHoward Finkelstein, the chief public defender in Broward County, said the case would present a difficult question: Should society execute mentally ill people?\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s no question of whether he will be convicted of capital murder 17 times,\u201d he said. \u201cWhen we let one of our children fall off grid, when they are screaming for help in every way, do we have the right to kill them when we could have stopped it?\u201d", "title": "\u2018How Did This Happen?\u2019: Grief and Fury After Florida Shooting", "authors": ["Julie Turkewitz", "Patricia Mazzei", "Audra D. S. Burch"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "Describing those clashes, Mr. Adel said: \u201cPro-government forces are trying to storm the front.\u201d\n\nSana, Syria\u2019s state news agency, said that \u201cterrorist groups targeted five missiles at the designated passage for the exit of civilians to prevent them from leaving and continue to use them as human shields.\u201d\n\nGhouta has been devastated by years of warfare, including a 2013 poison gas attack that killed hundreds of people, sickened thousands, and was blamed by Western authorities on the Assad regime. The eastern part of Ghouta is the last major rebel-held area near Damascus, and the Islamist groups that control it \u2014 labeled terrorists by the Syrian and Russian governments \u2014 have fired shells at government-held areas in and around the capital, though not nearly on the same scale as the incoming bombardment.\n\nUnited Nations officials confirmed that there had been shelling in eastern Ghouta on Tuesday morning, and said there were also reports of shelling toward Damascus during the preceding night, before the cease-fire was to begin. Aid convoys cannot enter, they said, until conditions become safer.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nRobert Mardini, the Middle East regional director at the International Committee of the Red Cross, said the most pressing need in eastern Ghouta was for medicine and medical care, but that the five-hour daily window promised by Russia was inadequate.\n\n\u201cIt is impossible to bring a humanitarian convoy in five hours,\u201d he said. \u201cWe have a long experience of bringing aid across front lines in Syria, and we know that it may take up to one day to simply pass checkpoints, despite the previous agreement of all parties. Then you need to offload the goods.\u201d\n\nIn other formerly rebel-held areas, like Aleppo, Homs and Daraya, the government has bombed heavily and often indiscriminately, and choked off supplies, before allowing some evacuation and sending in troops. The government denies targeting civilians, insisting that the rebels inflict most of the suffering, which Western observers and aid groups dispute.\n\nDmitri S. Peskov, a spokesman for the Kremlin, said that whether the pauses will continue depends on the rebels and \u201cwhether they continue to open fire and whether provocations continue and so on.\u201d\n\nCivilians say that if they leave besieged areas, they risk permanent displacement from their homes, or arrest, conscription or even death at the hands of the government. At the same time, rebel groups have at times prevented them from leaving.\n\nMr. Adel, in Douma, said that he and his acquaintances did not trust the government, and had no plans to leave. He asked, \u201cWhat will guarantee our lives outside?\u201d", "title": "\u2018Humanitarian Pause\u2019 in Syria: More Fighting, More Death", "authors": ["Nada Homsi", "Richard P\u00e9rez-Pe\u00f1a"]} {"date": "2018-02-21 00:00:00", "text": "By Ella Sangster\n\nI believe in magic. Not because I\u2019ve seen it, but because I\u2019ve felt it.\n\nNestled in the rocks between many beaches on the East Coast of New South Wales lie mermaid pools, fairly narrow but deep rock pools on the ocean\u2019s edge filled with seaweed and coral and fish.\n\nThey\u2019re not particularly unique features of an Australian beach, but these ones in particular are special.\n\nThese ones are mine.", "title": "\u2018I Believe in Magic\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-06 00:00:00", "text": "But still lingering are questions about numerous taxpayer-funded city business trips Ms. Barry took with Mr. Forrest, raising the possibility of bruising weeks ahead for the mayor. The Tennessean newspaper, citing public records, reported that the pair took some trips in the company of other city officials, but that nine trips, including one to Athens, Greece, were taken by Ms. Barry and Mr. Forrest alone.\n\nThe Tennessee Bureau of Investigation, at the request of Nashville District Attorney General Glenn R. Funk, is looking into whether Ms. Barry or Mr. Forrest broke any laws by misusing public funds. The City Council, generally supportive of the mayor\u2019s agenda, voted on Tuesday to create a special committee to investigate the trips.\n\nMs. Barry has said that she did nothing wrong. A lawyer for Mr. Forrest declined to comment Tuesday.\n\nThis week, The Tennessean also reported that Ms. Barry had recommended Mr. Forrest\u2019s adult daughter, Macy Amos, for an entry-level job that Ms. Amos later landed in the city law department.\n\nSean Braisted, the mayor\u2019s spokesman, acknowledged that Ms. Barry recommended Ms. Amos to the city law director sometime after she took office. But Mr. Braisted insisted that the recommendation, and Ms. Amos\u2019s first day of work, all predated the affair, which he said started sometime in the spring of 2016.\n\n\u201cMs. Amos was recommended by many people inside and outside of Metro Government,\u201d Mr. Braisted said in a prepared statement. \u201cShe began the interview process with the Department of Law in December of 2014. She was offered a position in 2015 by Metro Law Director Jon Cooper and began her job in 2016.\u201d\n\nThe scandal has dealt an unexpected jolt to a political narrative here of a mayor well-matched with her city\u2019s burgeoning self-conception as a sophisticated but down-home place, where honky-tonks, high-rises and, increasingly, a pronounced streak of social liberalism all coexist.\n\nAs a City Council member, Ms. Barry had been an outspoken champion of abortion rights and same-sex marriage. In a September 2015 runoff election, she defeated David Fox, a former hedge-fund manager. Mr. Fox tacked to Ms. Barry\u2019s right, but his strategy seemed to show that the culture-war dog did not hunt in the new Nashville. Voters shrugged off his campaign\u2019s assertion, in radio advertisements, that Ms. Barry and her husband, Bruce Barry, an American Civil Liberties Union member, had opposed prayer before high school football games.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn interviews this week, a number of liberals and conservatives said they did not wish to judge Ms. Barry\u2019s decisions in her private life. But many of them said the questions about the money and the trips concerned them.\n\n\u201cWith two consenting adults, I understand that those things happen,\u201d said James R. Dickson III, 51, an insurance broker and Republican who was having a drink at Sperry\u2019s Restaurant, a clubby, old-school haunt in the well-heeled Belle Meade area. \u201cMy issue is the financial piece of it.\u201d\n\nThe sentiment was echoed almost exactly by Khadija Ali, 21, a socially liberal college student who was hanging out Monday at Bongo Java, a popular coffee shop in Ms. Barry\u2019s bourgeois-bohemian neighborhood of Belmont/Hillsboro Village.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box.
