Chi Chi, eliminated last week, wrote on the mirror: \u201cRemember to keep it fair.\u201d\n\nWith only six queens left and the skill gaps narrowing, the choice over whom to eliminate becomes less clear, and far more subjective. This unnerved BenDeLaCreme, who\u2019s from the Pacific Northwest and doesn\u2019t like to hurt people\u2019s feelings. \u201cHow do you quantify it when everyone\u2019s performing at a high level?\u201d she asked. Is it worse to be in the top one week and the bottom the next, she wondered, or merely safe each week?\n\nKennedy, tiring of BenDeLaCreme\u2019s agonizing, said in a confessional, \u201cIf you don\u2019t want to win, stop playing to win.\u201d\n\nShangela swung by to hug a relieved Trixie and drop off an invoice for not eliminating her last week. \u201cI will never forget it,\u201d Trixie said.", "title": "\u2018RuPaul\u2019s Drag Race All Stars\u2019: Season 3, Episode 5: Soup\u2019s On!", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Get attached to any New York institution and you will eventually see it replaced by something more contemporary, whether it\u2019s the 7-Eleven that takes over the space of your favorite corner bodega or a new set of \u201cSaturday Night Live\u201d cast members who get handed the reins of its long-running parody of \u201cFox & Friends.\u201d\n\nOn this week\u2019s episode, hosted by Natalie Portman and featuring the musical guest Dua Lipa, it fell to the \u201cS.N.L.\u201d performers Alex Moffat, Heidi Gardner and Beck Bennett to play chipper, clueless incarnations of the Fox News morning hosts Steve Doocy, Ainsley Earhardt and Brian Kilmeade. If this moment briefly made some longtime \u201cS.N.L.\u201d viewers wistful for the days when Taran Killam, Vanessa Bayer (as Gretchen Carlson) and Bobby Moynihan handled these duties, at least the rest of the show offered cameos from other \u201cS.N.L.\u201d alums to help us deal with the transition.\n\nThe \u201cFox & Friends\u201d parody that opened the show started with Gardner saying hello to viewers, \u201cwhether you\u2019re fixing your breakfast or getting dressed for work or laying in the Lincoln Bedroom, tweeting with an Egg McMuffin on your chest.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Saturday Night Live\u2019: Trump Calls In to \u2018Fox & Friends\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "As a guide to the various ways of thinking about abortion, \u201cScarlet A\u201d is readable and respectful \u2014 and therefore, in its own quiet way, revolutionary. Katha Pollitt\u2019s excellent \u201cPro: Reclaiming Abortion Rights\u201d (2014) was also addressed to those Americans in the \u201cmuddled middle\u201d of the debate, though Pollitt explicitly set out to persuade them that abortion, by allowing women a measure of control over childbearing and therefore their lives, was an unequivocal moral good. Watson\u2019s goal with \u201cScarlet A\u201d \u2014 to get Americans to just start talking with one another \u2014 is less polemical but no less difficult, at least in this distrustful day and age.\n\nImage Katie Watson Credit John White\n\nTo that end, she begins with a personal anecdote, recounting a trip to Rome when she came across a \u201cfoundling wheel\u201d at a hospital. Installed around the year 1200 at the behest of Pope Innocent III, the rotating compartment allowed parents to place their baby in the care of strangers, at a time when unwanted children were commonly drowned in the Tiber River. \u201cSpinning that 800-year-old wheel reminded me what an old question Roe v. Wade revolved around: \u2018I\u2019m pregnant, but I don\u2019t want to have a baby. What can I do?\u2019\u201d\n\n\u201cScarlet A\u201d is an unusual hybrid of a book: part memoir, part legal exegesis, part philosophical tract, part conversational guide. Watson delves into the underlying assumptions behind different positions, taking seriously arguments other than her own. She addresses the ethics of abortion \u2014 something those who support access to abortion are often loath to do, because of what she calls the \u201cRussian Doll problem\u201d: \u201cthe anti-woman, anti-sex, political pot-stirring motivations\u201d that often come hidden in the guise of morality.\n\nAbout an issue so fraught, she knows she can take very little for granted. She acknowledges the trouble with vocabulary and terms (\u201cpro-choice\u201d and \u201cpro-life\u201d are the least of them) that come with arguments baked in. She explains how Supreme Court decisions helped create certain \u201cmasterplots\u201d that circumscribe our cultural assumptions. She breaks down the various secular approaches to abortion ethics \u2014 whether they treat the issue as a matter of biology, autonomy or public health. She explores the connection between the decline in clinic blockades and the rise in restrictive abortion laws.\n\nAs comfortable as Watson is when navigating around treacherous shoals, readers seeking the bland flag of neutrality should look elsewhere. \u201cI don\u2019t claim neutrality,\u201d she writes, \u201cI claim plurality.\u201d The same warning goes for those who insist that the claims of embryos and fetuses necessarily trump those of women. If anything, Watson argues, the \u201cnever-ending\u201d abortion debate confirms \u201cthat the moral status of embryos and fetuses cannot be proven to the degree necessary\u201d to justify government intervention on their behalf. We can talk about embryos and fetuses to no end, circling one another\u2019s uncertainty, but that still \u201cfails to address the moral status of women, about which we are certain: 100 percent people.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Scarlet A\u2019 Wants Less Shouting About Abortion and More Talking", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "Another little girl trotted up to Ms. Sorden to share her own exciting find. \u201cWhen sloths are dead, they still hang in trees upside down!\u201d\n\nThat little girl was Ms. Sorden\u2019s daughter, Madison. Ms. Sorden has another daughter, Mia, who is in fourth grade at Concourse Village. Her third, Maison, the only boy, is 2 now, but she hopes he will join his sisters when he\u2019s older.\n\nMs. Sorden, who is quick to crack a joke or give a hug, founded Concourse Village in 2013, taking over what had been P.S. 385, which was being phased out. Last year, the school had its first graduating fifth graders and added a Gifted and Talented classroom in the third grade. Gifted classrooms are often a magnet for high-scoring children who might not otherwise attend a particular school, but Ms. Sorden said that last year, all but three of the students in the gifted class were already Concourse Village students.\n\nWhen designing the school, Ms. Sorden said she thought about what she would have wanted as a student. She grew up in a similar community in Washington Heights, born to a Dominican mother and an African-American father from Georgia. Her father died when she was a senior in high school, she said, but her mother remains a constant presence. In fact, she stays with Ms. Sorden and her family in Washington Heights during the week and takes care of Maison. Ms. Sorden and her husband can use an extra set of grown-up hands: she is generally at school from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m., and is augmenting her master\u2019s from Columbia University\u2019s Teachers College with a doctorate in education from St. John\u2019s University. On weekends, her mother goes home to Marble Hill. Sometimes.\n\nMs. Sorden inherited two grades\u2019 worth of the students from P.S. 385 but none of the teachers and hired her own new teaching staff.", "title": "\u2018Smart Is Something You Get\u2019: How a Bronx School Succeeds", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\n\u201cI\u2019m gonna be a pilot \u2014 best in the galaxy,\u201d the young Han Solo says in the new trailer \u201cSolo: A Star Wars Story.\u201d\n\nBut will \u201cSolo\u201d be the best \u201cStar Wars\u201d movie yet? That remains to be seen, as the film has remained under tight cover amid reports of on-set troubles. In June, the veteran director Ron Howard was brought in to replace Phil Lord and Chris Miller (\u201cThe Lego Movie\u201d), who exited, citing the ever-popular \u201ccreative differences.\u201d\n\n\u201cSolo\u201d reunites Mr. Howard with Woody Harrelson, who co-starred in the filmmaker\u2019s flop 1999 comedy \u201cEdTV\u201d and plays Han Solo\u2019s criminal quasi-mentor here. The trailer \u2014 which was broadcast Monday on ABC during \u201cGood Morning America\u201d in a bit of Disney synergy \u2014 provides glimpses of Mr. Harrelson as well as new cast members like Emilia Clarke (\u201cGame of Thrones\u201d), Thandie Newton (\u201cWestworld\u201d) and Donald Glover (\u201cAtlanta\u201d), who looks like a younger version of Lando Calrissian, previously portrayed by Billy Dee Williams.\n\nAlden Ehrenreich (\u201cRules Don\u2019t Apply\u201d) takes over the Harrison Ford role in this prequel and there is one very familiar, furry face: Chewbacca, who lets out an approving grunt. \u201cSolo: A Star Wars Story\u201d will touch down in theaters on May 25.", "title": "\u2018Solo\u2019 Trailer Stars Alden Ehrenreich and Chewbacca", "authors": ["Bruce Fretts"]} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "But this week\u2019s plot twist was the latest in a string of questionable decisions by seemingly competent characters. According to Cornwell, 20 percent of Federation territory is now occupied. But Starfleet just got its prized ship back and its cloak-breaking technology is now being disseminated to all the ships. The spore drive can put the Discovery anywhere it needs to be instantaneously. In effect, Starfleet has an advantage now that should help them get back some of that territory.\n\nPhoto\n\nSo why is the situation so dire that Evil Georgiou is in charge now? Imagine her giving orders to Saru, who is supposed to be a slave in her eyes? (And, there is a chance this whole thing is a red herring for some other plot twist. A good chance, in fact, judging from Sarek\u2019s farewell to Burnham.) And everyone in the Terran Empire lives in a universe of deceit and violence. What incentive does Georgiou have to keep to any plan for her freedom? She can just escape the ship on her own!\n\nBut that\u2019s just it: Everything is a red herring for something else in this show. Story threads and characters flip at a moment\u2019s notice, so there really is no point in getting invested in anything.\n\nWhat worked\n\nAsh and Saru\n\nShazad Latif and Doug Jones do excellent work as Tyler and Saru in their scene together. Saru shows reluctant compassion for Tyler, whatever is left of him, and Tyler\u2019s vulnerability is well-conveyed by Mr. Latif.\n\nWhat didn\u2019t work\n\nAsh and Burnham\n\nTyler and Burnham have a very emotional talk where they hash out their differences before saying goodbye. Burnham\u2019s beef: Tyler was forced into being a secret Klingon spy without fully realizing it and didn\u2019t come to her for comfort. Tyler\u2019s: After attempting to kill her as a secret Klingon spy, he thinks she is just trying to look for a way out because she\u2019s never been in love before. You know, normal couple stuff.\n\nThis felt forced, in part because we haven\u2019t seen enough of them together to get to know them as a couple. And also, he tried to kill her. Granted, it was a Klingon essence inside of his body, but still.\n\nThis reminded me of when Picard is captured and assimilated by the Borg in a \u201cThe Next Generation\u201d episode. The Borg, a single-minded robot entity, then turned him into Locutus, who went on to lead the drones in the killing of thousands of Starfleet personnel. The Enterprise crew eventually rescued and accepted him back as captain, and we, the viewers, loved it. That\u2019s because we knew the characters well. We saw their relationships develop and grow. We saw squabbles, humorous moments, rescues and everything in between. We just don\u2019t see that very often on \u201cDiscovery.\u201d\n\nDid you catch that?\n\nAside from a glancing response to Captain Archer, this episode had a similar plot thread to one in \u201cNext Generation\u201d: \u201cYesterday\u2019s Enterprise,\u201d where the Enterprise C travels 22 years into the future by accident, causing a brutal war with the Klingons. The Federation is losing in this timeline too. It remains one of the best episodes of any \u201cStar Trek\u201d series.\n\nFinale questions?\n\nNext week is the season finale of the \u201cDiscovery\u201d maiden voyage. Even though the show has flaws, it is ambitious and unpredictable. It also has no investment in its characters. So it wouldn\u2019t surprise me if I end up writing a recap next week about Burnham\u2019s death. Or we see Prime Lorca again. Or we see Riker and Troi walk on a holodeck and say, \u201cEnd program.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Star Trek: Discovery\u2019 Season 1, Episode 14: I\u2019m Captain Now", "authors": ["Sopan Deb", "Star Trek"]} {"date": "2018-02-11 00:00:00", "text": "The plot didn\u2019t make sense. The characters contradicted themselves again. And the pacing was all over the place.\n\nBut man, the \u201cDiscovery\u201d season finale \u2014 \u201cWill You Take My Hand?\u201d \u2014 was satisfying. It was one of the rare episodes of the show in which great care is given to individual characters and their story lines. We see Mary Chieffo\u2019s L\u2019Rell given some meaty material as she tries to unite the Klingon houses under her leadership. Tyler and Burnham have a torturous goodbye. We even see Tilly retaining some of the confidence she attained from her Mirror Universe stint as a diabolical leader.\n\nThere was also, thanks to Akiva Goldsman, who directed the episode, a very impressive exploration of a new world we haven\u2019t seen yet: the Orion-dominated area on Kronos. \u201cDiscovery,\u201d as a show, hasn\u2019t cared as much about exploration as most Trek voyages. Given its superb visuals, watching the buddy cop group of Tyler, Evil Georgiou, Tilly and Tyler navigate unfamiliar territory was a ride worth being on.\n\nBut more than anything, the last minute of the episode was the best moment in all of \u201cDiscovery,\u201d and totally welcome fan service. We get our first peek of the Enterprise that we have known and loved for decades (Captain Pike was in charge, but still). Hats off to Goldsman for putting together, essentially, a perfect scene. We think the episode is over \u2014 and that the Discovery is riding off into the sunset. But then a traditional Trek trope: a distress call, followed by a screen saying, \u201cNCC-17,\u201d which is the moment we realize what is coming. And then there is the Enterprise \u2014 a remastered 2018 version that looks absolutely stunning.", "title": "\u2018Star Trek: Discovery\u2019 Season Finale: Wrapping Up", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-15 00:00:00", "text": "Mr. Beale\u2019s suit, which was filed in Federal District Court in Central Islip, calls the portrait \u201ca unique and irreplaceable work of art\u201d and a stolen heirloom that the family has long been seeking.\n\nAs the plaintiff in the suit, Mr. Beale claims the painting was stolen from Grey Gardens. The estate became well known after it was featured in a 1975 documentary \u201cGrey Gardens,\u201d which depicted the two Edith Beales, a mother and daughter known respectively as Big Edie and Little Edie. The older woman was Mr. Beale\u2019s grandmother and the younger one was his aunt.\n\nMr. Bouvier, who died in 1957, hired a society portrait artist, Irwin Hoffman, to paint his then 19-year-old daughter, Jacqueline Lee Bouvier.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe portrait depicts Jackie \u2014 her head tightly framed and wearing a white embroidered blouse and a navy vest \u2014 on the eve of traveling to Paris to study at the Sorbonne several years before she would meet and marry her first husband, John F. Kennedy.\n\nThe painting remains a link between the fallen socialites and their relative, Mrs. Onassis, who became one of the most celebrated women in the world. And the suit involves a fascinating part of Bouvier family history that helped make the documentary a cult classic and later led to a Broadway musical and a 2009 HBO movie starring Jessica Lange and Drew Barrymore.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nMr. Wallace has refused the Beale family\u2019s request to provide proof of its ownership or else hand over the painting and depicts the suit as an attempt to \u201csteal\u201d the painting rather than buy it.\n\nHe called its provenance \u201cimpeccable\u201d and said he bought it legitimately in the late 1980s from \u201ca very reputable\u201d art and antiques dealer. He refused to name the dealer but said he was prepared to do so in court and give a full accounting of the painting\u2019s ownership history.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s going to be part of my defense,\u201d he said.\n\nAccording to the lawsuit, the painting was probably stolen from Grey Gardens in the late 1960s. The two women never reported the theft because of a contentious relationship with local officials over the poor condition of their home, the lawsuit claims.\n\nGrey Gardens was eventually cleaned up and somewhat restored with the help of financing by Mrs. Onassis in 1972.\n\nTwo years after Big Edie\u2019s death in 1977, Little Edie sold Grey Gardens to a Washington power couple, Ben Bradlee, then the executive editor of The Washington Post, and Sally Quinn, the journalist and author.\n\nLittle Edie\u2019s flamboyant manner in the documentary helped make her a campy icon known for her memorable description of herself as a \u201cstaunch character\u201d \u2014 \u201cThey don\u2019t weaken, no matter what.\u201d Before her death in 2002, at age 84, she asked Mr. Beale, the executor of her estate, to recover items stolen from Grey Gardens, he said.\n\nMr. Beale and his wife, Eva, who live in California, spent years after Little Edie\u2019s death going through reams of letters and documents she had left behind, \u201cin keeping with her wishes for the family to preserve her history and attend to her outstanding affairs,\u201d Mr. Beale said in a statement, through his lawyer, Megan Noh.\n\n\u201cFrom these letters, we learned that Jackie\u2019s father, \u2018Black Jack\u2019 Bouvier, had mishandled a family trust that would have provided Edie with financial security,\u201d Mr. Beale said in the statement. \u201cBefore his death, he gave his prized portrait of Jackie to Edie to make things right.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAround 2004, Eva Beale happened to see the painting at Mr. Wallace\u2019s gallery \u201cand had a feeling about it,\u201d so she asked Mr. Wallace about its provenance, Mr. Beale said. He responded that he bought it from a dealer who was now dead but would not identify the dealer.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThat feeling that the painting came from Grey Gardens was confirmed in 2016 when Mr. Beale and his wife found in Little Edie\u2019s records a 1998 article from Hamptons magazine that showed the painting and described it as having \u201cdisappeared\u201d from Grey Gardens and bought by Mr. Wallace from a dealer.\n\nThe article \u201cled us to realize that the missing painting was indeed the one at Wallace Gallery,\u201d Mr. Beale said.\n\nPhoto\n\nThe article mentioned that it was the only portrait of the future Mrs. Onassis as a teenager. The article describes it as being painted shortly after she fell off a horse and incurred a scar that is visible in the painting.\n\nThe painting \u201chas got a good story behind it,\u201d Mr. Wallace said, but is not very valuable. The painting has been appraised, he said, but he would not disclose that figure.\n\nThe lawsuit claims that the painting \u201cwell exceeds the $75,000 threshold\u201d necessary to bring a federal suit. Ms. Noh would not give an estimate but noted that memorabilia associated with the Kennedys has historically brought \u201ca significant premium above its intrinsic value.\u201d\n\nMs. Noh said that under New York State law, an owner cannot gain what is legally recognized as \u201cgood title\u201d to a work of art if there has been a theft in its chain of custody.\n\nAnd with the Beales\u2019 \u201carguable claim\u201d on the painting, \u201cthe burden shifts to the current possessor to prove that the work was not stolen,\u201d she said.\n\nBut Mr. Wallace called it \u201ca very strong possibility\u201d that the painting was never even given to Big Edie.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cThey\u2019re just assuming it must be part of their legacy \u2014 these people don\u2019t really know,\u201d said Mr. Wallace, 70, a blunt-spoken former Marine who served in the Vietnam War.\n\nHe called himself an honest dealer who had personally assisted local police and federal investigators working on theft and fraud cases over the years.\n\n\u201cI have a good clientele. Why would I risk my reputation for a painting?\u201d Mr. Wallace asked.\n\nStill, Ms. Noh said, \u201cIt is difficult to understand why Mr. Wallace refuses to disclose the provenance of the Jackie portrait.\u201d\n\nAs for the painting\u2019s provenance, which Mr. Wallace would be required to disclose for the case, if it is indeed impeccable, Ms. Noh said, \u201cIt is puzzling that he would choose to engage in that costly legal process, rather than voluntarily provide the information.\u201d\n\nMr. Wallace said he would \u201cgladly return the painting to the rightful owner, if it could be proven that the painting was stolen.\u201d\n\nOtherwise, he said, he would welcome an offer from the Beale estate to buy the painting, even while cautioning that the price might climb because \u201cI\u2019m getting more annoyed by the day.\u201d\n\n\u201cThey got a law firm to push me around, but I\u2019m not that pushable,\u201d he said. \u201cMaybe they didn\u2019t figure that into the equation.\u201d", "title": "\u2018Staunch Characters\u2019 Battle Over Painting of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis", "authors": ["Corey Kilgannon"]} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nWhat statement is this artwork making? How does it comment on society and current events? Can you relate to it personally in any way? What do you think of its message?\n\nTell us in the comments, then read the related article to find out more about the installation and the artist.", "title": "\u2018Stop Telling Women to Smile\u2019", "authors": ["Natalie Proulx", "Picture Prompts"]} {"date": "2018-02-22 00:00:00", "text": "All week long in Brady Shutt\u2019s classroom at Liberty High School, north of Iowa City, his students have been talking about school shootings.\n\nSo on Thursday, when President Trump proposed arming teachers to curb violence, Mr. Shutt posed a question to his students: What do you think of the idea of training teachers to have guns in schools?\n\nEyes bugged out. Heads vigorously shook no.\n\n\u201cThey said, \u2018You mean arming teachers? Teachers like you? Why would a teacher ever have a gun in school?\u2019\u201d Mr. Shutt recalled. \u201cIt just didn\u2019t fit into their worldview. And there were concerns about what that would do to the relationship between teacher and student.\u201d\n\nMr. Shutt said he was deeply opposed to Mr. Trump\u2019s proposal \u2014 in particular the idea that federal funds should be used to train teachers in how to use a gun, when educators, Mr. Shutt said, had so many other needs.", "title": "\u2018Teachers Are Educators, Not Security Guards\u2019: Educators Respond to Trump Proposal", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Not that the episode lacks for either. On the contrary. Kreizler\u2019s makeshift detective squad, which now appears to include Police Commissioner Teddy Roosevelt, is delivered another slain child \u2014 as we, in turn, are delivered a close-up of the victim\u2019s empty, bloody eye socket, which Lucius probes with his finger in search of clues about the murder weapon. In another scene, John Moore awakes from a nightmare in which the young prostitute who lured him into a trap in last week\u2019s episode has his eyes similarly cut out. It\u2019s the biggest jump-scare the show has served up yet.\n\nWe also learn that at least two members of Dr. Laszlo Kreizler\u2019s staff \u2014 his driver, Cyrus, and his maid, Mary \u2014 have themselves committed murder. Those murders seem to have happened under mitigating circumstances, but still. The Scooby-Doo gang this ain\u2019t.\n\nIt may sound odd given that this show\u2019s sordidness has been one of my chief obstacles to taking \u201cThe Alienist\u201d as seriously as its creators surely wish, but I found myself wishing that one of the episode\u2019s most upsetting story lines had been handled with more frankness, not less. Moore suffered more than a nightmare when he was drugged: He was sexually assaulted by the underage employees of the gangsters who own the brothel he was investigating \u2014 all under the watchful eye of their police cronies, in hopes that the resulting shame would prevent him from disclosing anything he discovered. And yet Moore and the show itself seem to shake off this traumatic event within hours; in fact, it\u2019s played primarily for laughs, with an off-color joke by Captain Connor and an \u201cIt\u2019s not what you think!\u201d gag about Kreizler\u2019s gang having found him wandering around without any pants.\n\nBefore long, the intrepid illustrator even returns with Kreizler to the scene of the crime, seemingly more concerned with having been robbed than raped. Elsewhere in the episode, he endures an awkward blind date arranged by his grandmother, and he finally makes his feelings toward Sarah clear with an unrequited kiss. The scene with his grandmother is as amusing as the other bits of comic relief; the kiss is effective in furthering the bizarre love triangle between our three principals. Both, however, feel deeply strange as part of a day in the life of a man who has been sexually assaulted no more than 48 hours before.\n\nIt\u2019s all the more baffling because the episode is so successful elsewhere in probing the inner workings of its main characters. A marvelous, complex scene at a Vassar reunion, in which Sarah is the only remaining bachelorette, hints at a possible old fling with a classmate and a definite interest in Kreizler. These revelations take place during a daring sotto voce conversation about \u201cdoing it\u201d and a party game in which the attendees are \u201cmurdered\u201d when the designated \u201ckiller\u201d winks at them. It\u2019s a game the jaded police employee reacts to with an impassive stare courtesy of Dakota Fanning, who renders her face as somehow blank and expressive at once.", "title": "\u2018The Alienist\u2019 Season 1, Episode 3: There\u2019s No Later", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "If only \u201cThe Alienist\u201d had the same faith in its audience\u2019s ability to understand the complexities of its characters\u2019 minds that Kreizler has in Sara\u2019s. Take the sequence in the park. It\u2019s not for-the-ages dialogue, but the writing is certainly clear in its emotional and intellectual intent (Daniel Br\u00fchl and Dakota Fanning\u2019s characteristically restrained performances make the gruesome details of their exchange even more memorable.) But the end of the sequence lays aside the scalpel and breaks out the sledgehammer: As Sara contemplates Kreizler\u2019s sad tale, children sing a schoolyard rhyme about putting a baby \u201cin a bathtub to see if he could swim,\u201d while a close-up practically immerses us in the waters of a nearby fountain. It could hardly be less subtle if the script had called for Ms. Fanning to turn to the camera and say, \u201cGet it?\u201d\n\nMore such unsubtle material abounds. In the opening scene, Kreizler visits a former patient, now a professional dominatrix, seeking insight into the connection between pleasure and pain. In keeping with the show\u2019s depiction of sex workers as both insatiable and lacking savvy, the dom comes onto the doc like a wolf in a Tex Avery cartoon. No doubt his discomfort is supposed to be revealing.\n\nBut the insights offered in the scene are meager, or at least simplistic, even for its era. (\u201cThe man who enjoys defiling women is usually dominated in his daily life,\u201d she tells him, \u201cwhile man who enjoys being beaten is probably a bully.\u201d) Likewise, at his institute, Kreizler comes across a boy who\u2019s in a funk because his parents didn\u2019t visit him that week. He peps the boy back up with a bit of unorthodox therapy, suggesting that the boy kick a ball for a while. \u201cLet\u2019s pretend it\u2019s someone special,\u201d Kreizler says. \u201cWho would you choose it to be?\u201d The boy chooses his mother.\n\nAfter the boy leaves, Kreizler punts the thing himself, effectively begging us to wonder whose head he imagines kicking. Considering his frustrations with local law enforcement, the triangle of tensions between him and John and Sara, his inability thus far to stop the killer, and even the story Roosevelt tells about almost coming to blows with Kreizler in college, there is no shortage of prospects, including his own. The better question, perhaps, is whether insights like these are very interesting.\n\nAnd yet the episode still manages to entertain, in part because the investigation is picking up steam. Thanks to a piton left behind at one of the crime scenes, the Isaacson brothers discover that the murderer is able to make his seemingly inexplicable locked-room escapes and scale the tall buildings because he\u2019s an experienced climber.", "title": "\u2018The Alienist\u2019 Season 1, Episode 4: Onions and Carrots", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-19 00:00:00", "text": "Roosevelt, furious both with the cops who have been keeping this information from him and with an alienist who seems to view it all as some intellectual game, blows off Kreizler\u2019s caveat and charges in anyway.\n\nThus, we\u2019re led to believe a twist on the \u201cLambs\u201d maneuver is in the offing. Perhaps the chrome-toothed creep we first saw in last week\u2019s episode (played by the \u201cGame of Thrones\u201d veteran Josef Atlin) will open the door when Roosevelt comes calling after all, and we\u2019ll be shown a second suspect while Willem is being hauled away in cuffs (in other words, perhaps Willem has a thing for drugging and bathing boy prostitutes in milk, but he doesn\u2019t have a thing for butchering them). Or perhaps the creep isn\u2019t Willem at all. Maybe he\u2019s a ringer set up by the show, and Roosevelt will arrest the real Van Bergen \u2014 someone innocent, whom we\u2019ve never seen before \u2014 while \u201cthe man with the silver smile\u201d carries on drugging and murdering the boy.\n\nWith a little help from a deeply corrupt New York Police Department, the episode takes yet another route. Roosevelt does indeed arrive at the wrong address, proffered him by the crooked Captain Connor, whom the Commissioner fires from the force for the deception. At the same time, Mrs. Van Bergen and a private investigator stop her silver-smiling son in the middle of his \u201cdate,\u201d demanding he leave the city. \u201cMy Willem,\u201d purrs Mrs. Van Bergen, attempting to comfort him. \u201cMy good, good boy.\u201d Willem\u2019s explosive reaction to her words and touch indicate that Kreizler\u2019s colleagues, Sara Howard in particular, were on to something when they suggested that a woman played a key role in the killer\u2019s abusive upbringing, a suggestion the doctor responded to with a fury on par with Willem\u2019s.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nAnd here we arrive at the beating heart of the episode. The title, \u201cHildebrandt\u2019s Starling,\u201d takes its name from an anecdote shared earlier in the episode by Kreizler and one of his Harvard professors. The old professor had assigned his then-student to study a dead bird, over and over again, with the simple instruction \u201cLook at your bird.\u201d The professor\u2019s goal was to teach Kreizler that \u201cIt wasn\u2019t what you learned in class, Laszlo, it\u2019s how you learned it.\u201d The conclusion, in other words, was of secondary importance to his process of investigation and analysis. Part of that is always taking another look. Part of it is always revising what it even means to look.\n\nWhen Kreizler confides to his old mentor that he fears he\u2019s become fixated on a particular theory of the current crimes to the exclusion of all others, the professor simply replies: \u201cLook at your bird, Laszlo. Look at your bird.\u201d During a later visit by Kreizler and John Moore to the prison where a child killer Laszlo treated earlier in his career has been kept for years in solitary confinement, the murderer serves as the bird. Laszlo discovers that perhaps his theory about the killer\u2019s motivations is wrong \u2014 that perhaps, as he confides to Moore, \u201cI don\u2019t know as much as I think I do.\u201d\n\nIt\u2019s a less discouraging sentiment than it may seem. This newfound realization that he\u2019s not infallible leads Laszlo to a rapprochement with Sara (over whiskey, her drink of choice), who had come to him armed with the identity of Willem Van Bergen. She, herself, had been set on Van Bergen\u2019s trail by Commissioner Roosevelt, thanks to an error in judgment by the city\u2019s sleazy mayor, who inadvertently tipped him that there was a high-society suspect in the first place. Thanks to her own dogged police work and a series of fortuitous events, Sara finds her suspect and gives him to a protagonist who\u2019s suddenly much more open to other people\u2019s theories than he was before. The team has never been better situated to get its man.\n\nAll of which makes that concluding fake out that much more baffling, and fun, to puzzle out. Was Kreizler wrong about the killer\u2019s relationship with his mother, and wrong that the killer comes from the same lower-class background as his victims? Was he wrong to conclude that Willem isn\u2019t their man? The writing and editing of the sequence certainly suggests he was, emphasizing Connor\u2019s deception, Roosevelt\u2019s frustration, and Willem\u2019s twisted relationship with his mother.\n\nOr was the scene with the milk bath a red herring? Have Connor and the rest of the cops been covering for the wrong man?\n\nWho knows? And as long as the results are this entertaining and the investigation this meticulously constructed, who cares? It\u2019s not what you learn, it\u2019s how you learn. I, for one, am willing to keep on looking at this particular bird.", "title": "\u2018The Alienist\u2019 Season 1, Episode 5: Look at Your Bird, Laszlo", "authors": ["Sean T. Collins", "The Alienist"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "Whatever happens next, at least we now know for a fact that the team can rule out Willem Van Bergen as a suspect \u2014 not least of all because dead men can\u2019t kill. While Kreizler and company pursued the murderer from brothel to rooftop and back, the silver-toothed scion of privilege and known pedophile \u2014 who\u2019s been protected by everyone from his mother to the mayor to J.P. Morgan to the police department brass \u2014 met his end at the barrel of the former captain Connor\u2019s gun.\n\nYes, that former captain Connor, the one who seemed so dedicated to the cover-up surrounding Van Bergen\u2019s crimes that he continued to act in concert with the conspiracy even after his involvement cost him his job.\n\nTipped off by an informant that Willem is back on the prowl \u2014 his parents had instructed him to board a ship to Buenos Aires, but the young and syphilitic dandy just can\u2019t help himself \u2014 Connor intercepts him almost immediately. A chase ensues up the scaffolding of a bridge under construction, which is when we get tentative confirmation of Kreizler\u2019s theory that Van Bergen is not the killer: The murderer routinely scales buildings to deposit the corpses of his pray; Van Bergen is clearly terrified of heights.\n\nIf only he\u2019d been as wary of ex-cops, he might have survived. When Connor and one of his minions corner Van Bergen at the edge of the structure, Willem starts whining and boasting of his immunity from prosecution, persecution and most certainly death; his family is from the 400, you see, and the likes of Connor wouldn\u2019t dare touch him. Van Bergen\u2019s sense of entitlement is so total, and so absurd, that I couldn\u2019t help but say \u201cwhoops!\u201d when a round from Connor\u2019s revolver entered his brain. Bad break, buddy.\n\nConnor\u2019s actions eliminate the story\u2019s previous prime suspect, steering the plot through a sharp left turn. But those actions also take us on a journey deeper into the villain himself. Before tonight, the Captain came across as a racist, sexist, homophobic Irish cop stereotype who followed his corrupt orders with no questions asked. Now, he\u2019s \u2026 well, he\u2019s still a racist, sexist, homophobic Irish cop stereotype. But the following-orders part of Connor\u2019s character got shot in the head and thrown off the bridge, right along with Willem Van Bergen.", "title": "\u2018The Alienist\u2019 Season 1, Episode 6: Elimination Round", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "C.T.E. has been found in the brain of one dead N.F.L. player after another. Published studies have found a correlation between the total number of years one plays tackle football and the likelihood of one\u2019s developing brain disease later in life.\n\nStill, we shrug. Last year, 111.3 million people tuned in to CBS\u2019s Super Bowl broadcast, according to Nielsen. Even with N.F.L. regular-season ratings down 12 percent this season, Eagles-Patriots on Sunday will almost certainly be the most-watched television event of the year \u2014 as the previous year\u2019s Super Bowl was.\n\n\u201cI\u2019m embarrassed how much I love football,\u201d a friend texted me recently during an afternoon of football watching. \u201cThe American Dilemma.\u201d\n\nStories of concussions do not affect viewership of the game for 77 percent of fans, according to the annual Burson-Marsteller Super Bowl survey. Alan Schwarz, the former New York Times reporter who exposed football\u2019s concussion crisis, said that the issue does not discourage him from watching the N.F.L.\n\n\u201cI have no problem watching the N.F.L. \u2014 these are grown men making grown men\u2019s decisions,\u201d said Schwarz, whose investigative articles from 2007 to 2011 compelled new safety rules for players of all ages. \u201cAfter being kept in the dark for so many years by their employers, they now know they could wind up brain-damaged. Fine. They\u2019re professional daredevils. It wasn\u2019t immoral to watch Evel Knievel. We watch stuntmen in movies.\u201d\n\nBut even a football lifer like Eagles defensive end Chris Long is troubled by the danger of his chosen profession.\n\nHis father is the N.F.L. Hall of Famer Howie Long, who now is a football analyst for Fox Sports. His brother Kyle is an offensive lineman for the Chicago Bears. Chris Long, however, sounds like parents everywhere when he says that he doesn\u2019t want his 2-year-old son, Waylon, to play tackle football before high school. He hopes that Waylon doesn\u2019t play the game at all.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nJelani Cobb, the New Yorker writer and educator, said he would not be watching on Sunday, but his reason had nothing to do with the game\u2019s violence and potential for life-threatening injury. He is not watching because he believes Colin Kaepernick, the former San Francisco 49ers quarterback, was blackballed by the N.F.L. for protesting for social justice when he chose to take a knee for the national anthem before games.\n\nMany Americans say they have been turned off by on-field protests during games (61 percent, according to the Burson-Marsteller survey), but most say they plan to watch the game even if there are protests. Huh?\n\nPhoto\n\n\u201cThe cultural power of football is part of our fabric,\u201d Cobb said, \u201cand when something is part of tradition, people adhere to them for reasons that are not entirely rational.\u201d\n\nDebbie Staab understands this better than most.\n\nWe grew up together in the Midwest and I watched as her three sons excelled in the sport, each of them on a high school program that plays all comers nationally and perennially reaches national prominence. She has watched hundreds, probably thousands, of games over the years and appreciates the athleticism of the sport.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nNow, she watches with an increasing amount of dread.\n\n\u201cWhen someone gets hit and they replay it in slow motion, I can see why these guys at 55 are rattled,\u201d she said. \u201cNobody should get hit like that. Knowing what I do now, I would have steered my boys away from football.\u201d\n\nBryan Partee is the executive director of the Boys & Girls Club of Marshall, Tex., the town that brought us the great Y. A. Tittle as well as Dennis Partee, Bryan\u2019s father, who was a kicker for the San Diego Chargers in the 1960s and 1970s. Two years ago, Partee and his board shut down their club\u2019s tackle football program. They decided the potential for head trauma, the legal exposure and the high cost of running the program were no longer worth it.\n\nDennis Partee, 70, has Parkinson\u2019s disease and is part of the N.F.L.\u2019s concussion settlement. His love for the game has been passed down through the family. Bryan Partee played football in high school; his 10-year-old son, Noah, will not. Yet they will all watch Sunday\u2019s game together.\n\n\u201cFootball is still a great sport, but on the tackling side, my wife and I are not going to engage,\u201d Bryan Partee said. \u201cI don\u2019t want to see anyone lose their memory, or be so depressed they contemplate killing themselves.\u201d\n\nSoon my wife and I, like millions of other parents, will have to make a similar decision about our own football-crazy 13-year-old. We know the long-term risks now, and that makes what used to be a simple decision far more harrowing.\n\nNo priest will be able to help us. The N.F.L. should be as worried about that as I am.", "title": "\u2018The American Dilemma\u2019: Why Do We Still Watch Football?", "authors": ["Joe Drape"]} {"date": "2018-01-31 00:00:00", "text": "Like the series over all, this week\u2019s episode is not told in chronological order. It is 1997. We follow Marilyn from a work trip in Toronto back to her home on Chicago\u2019s Gold Coast, where she quickly notices that things are not as they should be. Two passing friends dial the police. Marilyn sits in the kitchen, her polished nails dancing on the granite countertop, as a bloodcurdling scream is heard from the garage: Lee\u2019s mutilated body has been found.\n\n\u201cI knew it,\u201d Marilyn says under her breath.\n\nFlash backward, a week earlier: Marilyn and Lee are at a fund-raising luncheon for Gov. Jim Edgar, Republican of Illinois.\n\nShe introduces her husband in terms so admiring as to be gushing: \u201cSo often we are told the American dream is dead. Except I say: Look at my husband, Lee. One of seven children. The son of an Illinois coal miner. He began his career selling premixed pancake batter out of the trunk of a beat-up old car. And today Lee manages 32 million square feet of commercial property across the Midwest.\u201d\n\nLater, at home, Marilyn moisturizes her face and removes her cosmetic eyelashes. It would have been easy for the episode\u2019s writer (Tom Rob Smith) and director (Gwyneth Horder-Payton) to have this moment be the one when the mask of a happy marriage is removed, its ugly face revealed.\n\nIn some ways that happens: In a quiet moment before the mirror, Marilyn applies a drop of perfume down the front of her silk robe, her eyes hollowed out with longing. In another room, Lee takes a call from Andrew Cunanan, dialing from a pay phone, and when Marilyn asks who is calling, he lies and says it\u2019s a business call. But the marriage is not merely a sham. When Marilyn asks Lee what he plans to do while she is away on business, he sounds down. She asks him to accompany her.\n\n\u201cI like it when you\u2019re there,\u201d she says, and she means it.\n\nIt is their last meaningful encounter.\n\nWith Marilyn away, Lee opens his door to the serial killer, who happens to be in town. Lee shows him his plans to build a 125-story, 1,952-foot Sky Needle, which would have been the world\u2019s tallest building.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe conversation does not go well. Andrew thinks the main point of having a building taller than the Sears Tower (now Willis Tower) is to surpass the latter structure\u2019s observation deck. Andrew also urges Lee to name the tower for himself, something the self-effacing developer has no intention of doing.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nThey kiss \u2014 \u201cIt feels like I\u2019m alive,\u201d Lee says \u2014 and Andrew boasts: \u201cEscorts don\u2019t normally kiss, do they? I am not like most escorts. I am not like most anybody. I could almost be a husband, a partner.\u201d\n\nI found this reference to marriage anachronistic, and puzzling, and not for the first time in this series. In earlier episodes, Gianni Versace\u2019s partner, Antonio D\u2019Amico, tired of their hedonistic lifestyle, proposes, and Cunanan tells a friend \u2014 falsely, we believe \u2014 that Versace once proposed to him.\n\nI\u2019m certainly not making light of commitment or the desire for it. But I\u2019m puzzled by the use of words like \u201chusband\u201d and \u201cproposed.\u201d They don\u2019t seem true to my own memories of the late 1990s, when gay men were more likely to speak of boyfriends, partners and companions, and they seem strangely ahistoric.\n\nMy next quibble with this episode is more prosaic: the killing of Lee Miglin, in his garage, by Cunanan is so grisly and sadistic as to be difficult to watch. I\u2019ll spare the details, but the monologue Cunanan delivers before delivering the coup de gr\u00e2ce bears note:\n\nI know that you\u2019re not wearing your hearing aid, so I am going to speak very loudly and very clearly so you can understand. I want you to know that when they find your body, you will be wearing ladies\u2019 panties. Surrounded by gay porn. I want the world to see that the great Lee Miglin is a sissy. Soon the whole world will know that the great Lee Miglin, who built Chicago, built it with a limp wrist. The cops will know, the press will know, your wife will know, your children will know, the neighbors will know. Tell me something, Lee: What terrifies you more, death or being disgraced?\n\nThe monologue raises the question: Is Cunanan motivated by self-hatred, a desire to expose hypocrisy, or both? His use of homophobic language suggests self-hatred, but his focus on disgrace suggests some kind of crusade. It is not, of course, a crime to cross-dress, or to look at porn. This mutual failure of recognition \u2014 murderer and victim seem to agree on one thing, that to be gay is a disgrace \u2014 is perhaps the saddest moment in this series so far.\n\nThe rest of the episode is a tour de force by Judith Light, whose portrayal of a wife in denial is simply magnificent. She offers a brisk inventory of what\u2019s missing from the house \u2014 a Lexus, $2,000 in cash, two leather coats, two suits, \u201csome inconsequential pieces of jewelry,\u201d rare gold coins and a dozen pairs of socks \u2014 as she reaches the conclusion that the killing must have been a random and opportunistic robbery.\n\nTold by the Chicago police superintendent about the gay porn found next to the body, Marilyn surmises that \u201cthey must have belonged to the killer,\u201d but goes on to say: \u201cI\u2019m not interested in his intentions. Find him, catch him, but don\u2019t talk to me about what or might not be going through his mind.\u201d\n\nShe adds: \u201cDollars, jewelry, socks, suits \u2014 that\u2019s all I\u2019ll allow that man to steal from me. He won\u2019t steal my good name. Our good name. We worked too hard making that name, and we made it together.\u201d\n\nFor an ambitious woman born in the 1930s to have a husband who is fully supportive of her professional aspirations might indeed, as she suggests, have been \u201ca fairy tale life.\u201d \u201cHow many husbands believe in their wives\u2019 dreams?\u201d she asks her Home Shopping Network viewers \u2014 and us \u2014 later in the episode. \u201cHow many treat us as partners, as equals?\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nLeft unsaid: Perhaps his being gay allowed him to be such a supportive partner.\n\nCompared with all this, Cunanan\u2019s murderous escapades seem mundane. He flees to New Jersey, and the police failure to capture him after a radio station reveals that investigators have been tracking his movements by car phone. In search of a new car to steal, he stops at a cemetery, where he marches one of the groundskeepers into a basement and makes him get down on his knees.\n\nThe man begs for mercy, but his plea is cut short. And for the first time in this series I was so disgusted by this killer\u2019s lack of remorse that \u2014 for a moment at least \u2014 I didn\u2019t want to keep watching.\n\nAt least most of carnage is out of the way. Six more episodes, two more bodies to go.", "title": "\u2018The Assassination of Gianni Versace\u2019 Episode 3: Death or Disgrace?", "authors": ["Sewell Chan", "American Crime Story"]} {"date": "2018-02-07 00:00:00", "text": "The episode begins in Madson\u2019s warehouse-size loft apartment, which is lined with gray-metal shelves. David and Andrew have been bickering, and while their relationship isn\u2019t exactly explained, a romance gone sour is implied. The buzzer rings; downstairs is a man named Jeff, whom Andrew has asked over, much to David\u2019s irritation.\n\nAndrew sends David downstairs to let him in. In the lobby and elevator, we learn a lot:\n\n\u2022 David tells Jeff that Andrew proposed marriage, calling David \u201cthe man of his dreams\u201d and \u201chis last chance at happiness.\u201d\n\n\u2022 David says that he declined, noting that gay marriage isn\u2019t legal, but that Andrew thinks Jeff is \u201cthe reason I said no.\u201d Jeff is surprised that Andrew knows that Jeff and David have been together. \u201cHe has this feline intuition,\u201d David says.\n\n\u2022 Jeff says that Andrew took a gun from Jeff\u2019s apartment, and that he has come to get it back.\n\nAs we are processing all this, the two men enter the apartment, and what happens next is a murder with a claw hammer too vicious and grisly for me to watch.\n\nTerrified and stricken, David seems to go numb. He asks why Andrew killed Jeff; Andrew replies, \u201cI lost control.\u201d\n\nDavid calls 911, but Andrew compels him to hang up by saying that if the police arrive, they will both go to prison, disingenuously eliding the fact that it was he who set all this in motion. He goes on to argue that homophobia makes justice impossible anyway. \u201cWhen the police open the door they\u2019ll see two suspects, not two victims,\u201d he says. And when David insists he is no killer, Andrew replies: \u201cThey won\u2019t believe you. They hate us, David, they\u2019ve always hated us. You\u2019re a fag.\u201d\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\nQueer people have a term for such self-serving cynicism: Chutzpah.\n\nAs he\u2019s forced to flee with Andrew, David comes to see the journey as a symbol for a life of evasion: \u201cI\u2019m playing over everything the police are going to find out about me, and I realize I\u2019ve been doing this my whole life: playing over and over the moment that people found out about me.\u201d On the road later, he adds: \u201cWas I really afraid, when I got in this car with you, that you were going to kill me? Or was I afraid of the disgrace, the shame of it all. Is that what I\u2019m running from?\u201d\n\nIn David\u2019s hometown, Barron, Wis., his stunned parents learn from the Minneapolis detectives that a stranger named Jeffrey Trail was murdered in David\u2019s home, with 27 blows from David\u2019s steel claw hammer. The detectives tell them about another stranger, named Andrew Cunanan, whose friends in San Francisco have described as reliable, intelligent, generous. David\u2019s father insists his son is innocent.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI can see with certainty, there\u2019s a great deal you don\u2019t know about your son,\u201d the detective says. But as we soon learn in a heart-wrenching scene, he probably knows more than the detective assumes.\n\nIn one of several flashbacks, David is shown speaking with his dad in the garage. It\u2019s a workingman\u2019s garage (in an earlier flashback, the two of them had gone hunting), and David has graduated from the University of Minnesota, Duluth, at the top of his class. He tells his father he is gay.\n\n\u201cI won\u2019t lie and say that it doesn\u2019t make a difference,\u201d the father responds. \u201cYou know what I believe. And maybe this isn\u2019t what you wanted to hear. Maybe you wanted to be told I don\u2019t have a problem with it. I can\u2019t say that. But what I can say is I love you more than I love my own life.\u201d\n\nIt is a bittersweet moment, one that in its overall contours many lesbian and gay people may recognize. That someone with reasonably tolerant parents in the mid-1980s could nonetheless feel such shame and self-loathing says a lot, by implication, about those who lacked such emotional support.\n\nWe get another look at how crushing that shame and self-loathing might be, when Andrew and David stop at a roadside bar. As David ponders escaping from the bathroom, Andrew is brought to tears by a singer\u2019s rendition of the Cars\u2019 1984 song \u201cDrive,\u201d a rare moment of true emotional vulnerability from him, his pain brimming to the surface. David, whether because he feels he can\u2019t escape or won\u2019t be believed, forgoes the chance to save his own life and returns to the table with Andrew. Perhaps their need for human connection is mutual.\n\nIn a diner the next day, David recalls how Andrew dazzled him when they met at a bar in San Francisco, a year and a half earlier. \u201cWhat\u2019s this man going to see in me, a small-town boy?\u201d he remembers thinking. They ended up in a $1,000-a-night room at the Mandarin Oriental. David continues:\n\nI remember thinking: How hard do I have to work to live like him, like Andrew? \u2019Cause I\u2019ll do it. Except it was all a lie. You\u2019ve never worked for anything. It was an act. Is that why you killed Jeff? You loved him. It was so obvious. But he figured you out in the end, didn\u2019t he? It took him a few years but he finally saw the real you, and you killed him for it.\n\nAndrew tries to change the subject, promising David that they\u2019ll lead a glamorous life in Mexico. He can\u2019t stop lying.\n\nBack in the car, David arrives at a further, belated discovery \u2014 that Jeff was set up, that Andrew planned all along to kill him in David\u2019s presence. \u201cWhy are you always talking about the past?\u201d an enraged Andrew asks. \u201cWe had a plan. We had a future.\u201d\n\nThey pull over. David\u2019s fate is sealed.\n\nEpisode 3 argued that denial could be a tool of survival. Episode 4 points out that recognition \u2014 of oneself, of the true character of others \u2014 can exact a lethal price.", "title": "\u2018The Assassination of Gianni Versace\u2019 Episode 4: Feline Intuition", "authors": ["Sewell Chan", "American Crime Story"]} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "Versace shares his plans with his sister, who is worried that Versace\u2019s coming out as gay will hurt the fashion empire he has worked so hard to build. She worries that \u201cthe rock stars, the actors, the royalty whose endorsements we cherish \u2014 they might not want to be associated with us.\u201d\n\n\u201cYou live in isolation, surrounded by beauty and kindness,\u201d she tells him. \u201cYou have forgotten how ugly the world can be.\u201d Their exchange reminds us how recently spheres that now seem safely liberal \u2014 Hollywood and fashion \u2014 were still hostile to open gayness, an aversion that is far from vanished today.\n\nWe first meet Trail at the propane factory where he works. A co-worker, an ex-Marine, learns that Trail worked on an aircraft carrier that was decommissioned after the first Gulf War. Trail says he misses the military life, and regrets leaving. The Marine, who was enlisted, is startled to learn that Trail, a Naval Academy graduate with two siblings in the military, left a promising career as an officer. Trail flies into a rage, shouting, \u201cIt was my decision!\u201d\n\nTrail\u2019s back story turns out to be more complicated.\n\nIn 1995, he broke up a homophobic attack on a gay sailor who would otherwise have been beaten to death. For his valor, he was quickly suspected of being gay himself, and subjected to increasing harassment. In one cringe-inducing scene, he tries to cut off a tattoo for fear that it could be used by military investigators to identify homosexuals who have had hookups aboard the aircraft carrier; in another scene, he puts on his dress whites and comes close to hanging himself.\n\nIt was the time of Don\u2019t Ask, Don\u2019t Tell, the Clinton-era policy in which gay and lesbian service members were ostensibly tolerated as long as they did not come forward. The compromise was an uneasy and often dishonest one, embodied by a scene in which Trail is given a comic-book-style \u201ctraining guide on homosexual conduct and policy.\u201d Its title, \u201cDignity and Respect,\u201d seems like a cruel joke.\n\nTrail leaves the military and decides to give an interview to CBS News \u2014 his face is obscured \u2014 in which he comes forward about the agony of being gay in the military. If he hadn\u2019t stopped the gay-bashing attack, he says, \u201cno one would have suspected me\u201d and his life wouldn\u2019t have been ruined. \u201cI did a good thing, and I can\u2019t tell you about how many times I\u2019ve dreamed about taking that moment back and letting him die.\u201d", "title": "\u2018The Assassination of Gianni Versace\u2019 Episode 5: Dignity and Respect", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "Timepieces are examined as works of art as well as cultural barometers in the new book \u201cThe Beauty of Time,\u201d by Dominique Fl\u00e9chon and Fran\u00e7ois Chaille.\n\n\u201cEach timepiece was selected to represent the intellectual and artistic currents of a period,\u201d Mr. Fl\u00e9chon wrote in an email that was translated from French by Gr\u00e9gory Gardinetti, the expert and historian in watchmaking at the Fondation de la Haute Horlogerie, a partner in the book\u2019s publication. (Flammarion published it in Europe in January; the North American version is to be released March 6.)\n\nContemporaneous artworks are interspersed among the images of clocks and watches, selected from the Middle Ages to modern times, to \u201cshow the evolution of tastes,\u201d Mr. Fl\u00e9chon said. Here are a few examples:\n\nPhoto\n\nPlanetary perfection\n\nThe Astrarium is an example of the period that, Mr. Fl\u00e9chon said, showed how \u201cwatchmakers started from nothing, considered almost everything and pushed research beyond limits.\u201d Built between 1348 and 1364 by Giovanni de\u2019 Dondi, an Italian physician, astronomer and mechanical engineer, the clock was \u201cthe first mechanical device to display, in real time, the movement of the planets with remarkable accuracy,\u201d the author said. The original was lost in 1630 when Austrian forces sacked Mantua, Italy, so the model shown is a 1985 reproduction by Luigi Pippa, a Milanese watchmaker, now displayed in the Mus\u00e9e International d\u2019Horlogerie in La Chaux-de-Fonds, Switzerland. The three-and-a-half-foot tower has 107 moving parts and a dial on each of its seven sides showing features like the movements of the planets known in the 14th century: Venus, Mercury, Saturn, Jupiter and Mars, as well as the sun and moon.\n\n\n\nPhoto\n\nRoyal flourish\n\nThe shape, lavish decoration and refined workmanship of this 1690 oak clock with oak pedestal defines Louis XIV\u2019s grand si\u00e8cle, Mr. Fl\u00e9chon said, adding, \u201cIts brilliance, richness and commercial value breaks definitively with the use of ebony associated with the ivory used in the preceding period, particularly austere.\u201d The king\u2019s favorite artisans were involved in making the piece, giving it some of their signature touches found in other timepieces at Versailles. For example, the tortoiseshell, engraved brass and pewter marquetry were hallmarks of Andr\u00e9-Charles Boulle, the king\u2019s cabinetmaker and sculptor, and the eight-day, spring-wound brass and steel movement most likely was the work of Isaac II Thuret, the royal clockmaker. The gilded bronze dial has white enameled Arabic numerals and, like other timepieces of the late 17th century, the author said, it \u201cwas now accurate enough to indicate minutes.\u201d\n\nPhoto\n\nRevolutionary power\n\nThe watchmaker who created this elaborate automaton clock in 1799 and 1800, during the second golden age of French clockmaking, showcased the profusion of dials, automatons and columns, Mr. Fl\u00e9chon said. The eight multicolored enamel dials showed elements like sunrise and sunset, the moon\u2019s age and phase, and both the Republican calendar (created during the French Revolution) and the traditional Gregorian calendar (risking imprisonment for both the watchmaker and owner, the author said). The blue enamel that Joseph Coteau, the renowned enameler, used for the clock \u201cwas so rare and difficult to perfect that few of his contemporaries managed to copy\u201d it, he said.\n\nPhoto\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nUnderstated style\n\nThis 1815 pocket watch, Mr. Fl\u00e9chon said, illustrates the work of Abraham-Louis Breguet, who revolutionized watchmaking with elegant cases, guilloch\u00e9 dials and tourbillons. The timepiece includes a guilloch\u00e9 gold case, guilloch\u00e9 silver dial, an hour dial in appliqu\u00e9d silver with a fast-slow indicator as well as an openwork aperture indicating moon phases on midnight blue enamel. The watchmaker\u2019s off-center dial already had become a signature design element \u2014 as had the 10-millimeter depth, made possible by flat mechanisms, so the timepiece could be less detectable in the pockets of the new tight clothing. \u201cThe demand of thin watches was dictated by a change in fashion,\u201d he said. Some of these features still are found in contemporary Breguet models, like the Classique 7787 with its hollow hands and moon phase indicator.\n\nPhoto\n\nPop Art\n\n\u201cThis watch, still produced, had a great impact because it broke with the traditional codes of watchmaking by its shape, colors and crowns,\u201d Mr. Fl\u00e9chon said. The Mach 2000 chronograph was designed in 1975 for the French watchmaker Lip by Roger Tallon, who was not a watchmaker. (He was well known for designing France\u2019s T.G.V. high-speed trains.) It used aluminum to produce a lightweight case, plastic for the red, yellow and blue pushers and rubber for the strap. \u201cBy making watchmakers adapt to the directives of the designers, which until then was the opposite, aesthetics, therefore beauty, becomes as important as technique,\u201d the author said. Lip revived the model in 2008 as an analog quartz chronograph with a brushed stainless steel case, calendar at 6 o\u2019clock and a black rubber strap; variations featured Arabic numerals and stainless steel straps.\n\nPhoto\n\nRobotic future\n\nIn the 18th and 19th centuries, watchmakers looked to mythology, nature, and arts and crafts as inspiration. At MB&F, however, robotics was the spark that in 2015 produced Melchior, a table clock that stands almost a foot tall. While the robo-clock \u201cis treated in a fun way,\u201d Mr. Fl\u00e9chon said \u2014 with a rocket launcher and Gatling gun as arms and a visible escapement as the brain \u2014 it \u201ckeeps its traditional functionality.\u201d The jumping hours and sweeping minutes tell the digital time on Melchior\u2019s steel chest, his blinking eyes mark 20-second intervals and the 40-day power reserve is indicated on his shiny abs. There is even an old-school movement by the Swiss manufacturer L\u2019\u00c9p\u00e9e 1839.\n\n", "title": "\u2018The Beauty of Time\u2019", "authors": ["Melanie Abrams"]} {"date": "2018-02-26 00:00:00", "text": "The return of Mart Crowley\u2019s \u201cThe Boys in the Band\u201d after half a century has had me thinking about the very 20th-century dream of gay liberation, born around the time of that first production in 1968. The idea was that when we were \u201cdone,\u201d we could simply disappear \u2014 into the larger public. We would become ordinary queer people and we would feel unbothered by this apparent contradiction in terms.\n\nWe even imagined that one day, perhaps, there might be no need for a word for us. Today, of course, there are many words, a whole forest of words, and descriptors of sexual identity are increasingly paired with those for gender identity \u2014 gender being among the first ways you relate to yourself. \u201cI didn\u2019t have a word for it,\u201d James Baldwin said of his sexuality as a young boy growing up in Harlem in the 1930s, but now he just might \u2014 he might even have four or five.\n\nDanez Smith, 28, who curated the below selection of poems read by the cast and director of \u201cThe Boys in the Band\u201d in this video series, and who goes by the pronoun \u201cthey,\u201d is a good example of how we talk about ourselves now: They are black, queer, poz, a poet, a performer. \u201cWhen I was figuring myself out, both as a writer and a queer person, I had examples of how to do it boldly and bravely \u2014 Assotto Saint, Essex Hemphill, Carl Phillips, Mark Doty, Jericho Brown \u2014 and there was never a push toward ambiguity,\u201d Smith says. \u201cInstead, it was a push toward a queer poetics, and a queer poetics of color.\u201d\n\nSmith, whose 2017 collection, \u201cDon\u2019t Call Us Dead,\u201d was a National Book Award finalist, is a risen star in a fast-expanding galaxy of talented queer poets: Saeed Jones, Ocean Vuong, Alex Dimitrov, Hieu Minh Nguyen, Marcelo Hernandez Castillo, Max McDonough, Richie Hofmann, Julian Randall, Keenan Teddy Smith, Jameson Fitzpatrick. This band, boys or not, is making the most of our expanded vocabulary, playing with language to make work that speaks \u2014 profoundly and unapologetically \u2014 to who they are, where they come from and where they are going. As Danez Smith says of the iconic 1987 ACT UP slogan, \u201c\u2018Silence=Death\u2019 showed us that our freedom was in our visibility.\u201d", "title": "\u2018The Boys in the Band\u2019 Cast Reads Queer Poetry", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-12 00:00:00", "text": "\u2022 A review of \u201cIcarus,\u201d a documentary about Dr. Grigory Rodchenkov, who led Russia\u2019s antidoping laboratory for Olympic athletes.\n\n\u2022 Russia isn\u2019t supposed to be at these Olympic Games, yet the country\u2019s nationalist fervor is very present.\n\nTune in, and tell us what you think.
