If you\u2019re on an Android device, tap this link to listen in Stitcher or this link to listen in RadioPublic.", "title": "\u2018The Daily\u2019: Russia at the Olympics", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Ferryman,\u201d a British play about a sprawling family in rural Northern Ireland that starts to unravel in a crush of heartbreaking secrets, painful resentments and revelations of past crimes, is coming to Broadway.\n\nThe play, written by Jez Butterworth and directed by Sam Mendes, features an enormous cast for a nonmusical production (with a 30-plus member cast) as well as a live rabbit and a goose (at least in the London production).\n\nSet in 1981, it evokes the sweeping state-of-a-nation themes of Mr. Butterworth\u2019s other epic-like work that reached Broadway, \u201cJerusalem.\u201d But \u201cThe Ferryman\u201d also feels as if it\u2019s a cousin to that other memorable melodrama about a big family under one roof, \u201cAugust: Osage County.\u201d\n\nThe Broadway production, which has not yet been cast, will open in October at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, produced by Sonia Friedman and Neal Street Productions, a company whose founders include Mr. Mendes.", "title": "\u2018The Ferryman,\u2019 a Look at Anguish in Northern Ireland, Is Set for Broadway", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-01 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThe Gilded Age,\u201d the much-anticipated follow-up from the creator of the British period drama \u201cDownton Abbey,\u201d is to air in 2019 on NBC, the network confirmed on Wednesday. The 10-part series is written by the British screenwriter and director Julian Fellowes, who will also be its executive producer.\n\nThe series is set in 1880s New York and will follow the character of Marion Brook during a time of rapid social change, exploring the tension between new money and established wealth.\n\n\u201cTo write \u2018The Gilded Age\u2019 is the fulfillment of a personal dream,\u201d Mr. Fellowes said in a statement. \u201cAmerica is a wonderful country with a rich and varied history, and nothing could give me more pleasure than be the person to bring that compelling history to the screen.\u201d\n\nPlans for \u201cThe Gilded Age\u201d were first announced by NBC in 2012, while \u201cDownton Abbey\u201d was still in production. In an interview with The New York Times in 2015, Mr. Fellowes said of creating the new show, \u201cI am a big, big fan of Edith Wharton and Henry James and that period of history after the Civil War \u2014 the Vanderbilts and the Whitneys and all of those people.\u201d", "title": "\u2018The Gilded Age,\u2019 a \u2018Downton Abbey\u2019 Follow-Up, Is Slated for 2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-23 00:00:00", "text": "For five centuries, the Habsburgs dominated much of Central Europe, reaching from their ancestral base in Austria to eventually encompass a multiethnic and multilingual empire that collapsed only at the end of World War I.\n\nThe name of the dynasty that ruled the Austro-Hungarian Empire quickly became a trending topic on Friday evening, after the special counsel investigating Russian interference in the 2016 election in the United States accused Paul Manafort Jr., President Trump\u2019s former campaign chairman, of secretly paying a group of former European officials to lobby for Ukraine in 2012 and 2013, when its government was pro-Russian.\n\nAround 2012, according to the indictment released on Friday, Mr. Manafort and his colleague Rick Gates \u201csecretly retained a group of former senior European politicians to take positions favorable to Ukraine, including by lobbying in the United States.\u201d", "title": "\u2018The Hapsburg Group\u2019: Mueller Says Manafort Secretly Paid European Leaders", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-02 00:00:00", "text": "There is no crystal ball in \u201cThe Simpsons\u201d writers\u2019 room, but you\u2019d be forgiven for wondering.\n\nOver its nearly 30-year run, the series about the world\u2019s most famous animated family has alluded to many real-life events long before they\u2019ve actually happened: the Trump presidency, the discovery of the Higgs boson particle, 9/11 and, most recently, Disney\u2019s takeover of Fox. By some accounts, the coincidences \u2014 predictions, if you will \u2014 number in the 20s, or more.\n\nThis track record has led the show\u2019s legion of fans to think that \u201cThe Simpsons\u201d is, at the very least, a product of television\u2019s most intelligent writers, and, at the most, prophetic.\n\nSo is there something bigger going on?\n\nThe future can be forecast better than one might think, said Al Jean, one of the show\u2019s original writers and its showrunner since 1998. Episodes of \u201cThe Simpsons\u201d air a year after they\u2019re produced, he said, so \u201cit\u2019s just a sort of frame of mind that we\u2019ve got that we think one year ahead.\u201d\n\n\u201cI predict people will make too much of our great predictions,\u201d he joked.\n\nThe show is the product of brilliant minds, many Harvard educated, said William Irwin, whose book \u201cThe Simpsons and Philosophy\u201d has for years been taught in college courses at The University of California, Berkeley and other schools. Mr. Irwin is the chairman of philosophy at King\u2019s College in Wilkes-Barre, Pa.", "title": "\u2018The Simpsons\u2019 Has Predicted a Lot. Most of It Can Be Explained.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-25 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nSeason 8, Episode 9, \u2018Honor\u2019\n\nThe 2005 song \u201cAt the Bottom of Everything,\u201d by the indie rock band Bright Eyes, features its frontman, Conor Oberst, in a rare position of fiery sureness. While the band\u2019s music has consistently tangled with anxiety and inner conflict, the lyrics of \u201cBottom\u201d come from the perspective of a man on a crashing plane as he readies himself for oblivion. The rousing chorus goes:\n\nWhile my mother waters plants and my father loads his gun,\n\nHe says \u201cDeath will give us back to God,\n\nJust like the setting sun\n\nIs returned to the lonesome ocean\u201d\n\nAs the plane plummets into the sea, the song\u2019s narrator is not frightened; he has lived a good life, and he understands that he is submitting to an inevitable and natural cycle.\n\n\u201cThe Walking Dead\u201d doesn\u2019t often make use of modern selections for its soundtrack, so the creative choice to use \u201cAt the Bottom of Everything\u201d sticks out. The song scores a montage in which poor Carl, tainted by a zombie\u2019s infected bite before to this season\u2019s midwinter break, gets his affairs in order before succumbing to the toxins coursing through his body.\n\nCarl assumes the preternatural calm of the song\u2019s narrator as he goes about this sad work, embracing death with far more maturity and serenity than the many adults who have been in his unenviable position. Seeing that Michonne has left him a heartfelt letter, he is moved to write farewell messages to everyone in the colony he cares about, although the plot keeps most of the characters too busy to get a moment of closure with him.\n\nBut Carl does get one last beat with Rick, a poignant goodbye in which a father must grapple with his own failings as a parent. Rick sees his son\u2019s unbothered preparations as not inspiring but devastating, a sign that he has insufficiently shielded Carl from the cruelties of their new world. Carl is all grown up, but too fast for Rick\u2019s liking, and he feels tremendous guilt over the carefree youth that the boy never got to enjoy.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nIn the most affecting moment of the season to date, Rick sobs to Carl, \u201cAll those things you had to do \u2014 you were just a boy.\u201d He addresses his son as if Carl were a child soldier, which he might as well be, having been left with no choice but to gun down his innocence in order to stay alive. These are the meaningful emotional stakes for which this series has fruitlessly searched for so many weeks. Only when survivors invest themselves in another person can they \u2014 or we \u2014 truly be wounded.", "title": "\u2018The Walking Dead,\u2019 Season 8, Episode 9 Recap: A Lesson Before Dying", "authors": ["Charles Bramesco", "The Walking Dead"]} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.\n\n\u201cThere is no ice where there is almost always ice,\u201d The Washington Post\u2019s weather experts tweeted yesterday, referring to an area north of Greenland.\n\nLars Kaleschke, a German physicist, explained: \u201cThere is open water north of Greenland where the thickest sea ice of the Arctic used to be. It is not refreezing quickly because air temperatures are above\u201d freezing.\n\nHow different are this year\u2019s temperatures? \u201cIn 2018, there have already been 61 hours above freezing at Cape Morris Jesup, Greenland,\u201d writes Robert Rhode, a climate scientist. \u201cThe previous record was 16 hours before the end of April in 2011.\u201d", "title": "Opinion | \u2018There Is No Ice\u2019", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "Over the last year, Democrats have snatched away Republican seats in more than a dozen special legislative elections from Seattle and Tulsa, Okla., to Atlanta and Miami, in many cases electing female and minority candidates with strong turnout on the left.\n\nRepublicans will not be easily dislodged: In many states, Republican governors have built powerful machinery to defend their allies, and Mr. Trump remains popular enough across much of the Midwest and South to limit Democratic gains. In 31 out of 50 states, Republicans command the entire legislature; in 25 of those states, the governor is also a Republican.\n\nPhoto\n\nBut with some momentum behind Democrats \u2014 at least for now \u2014 the party appears positioned to make inroads in crucial legislatures, winning a new measure of relevance in state policy and perhaps limiting Republicans\u2019 influence on congressional redistricting after 2020.\n\nMatt Walter, president of the Republican State Leadership Committee, the party\u2019s national hub for legislative campaigns, said Republicans were on the defensive in all but a few states. Citing Democratic turnout in recent special elections, Mr. Walter said Republicans should use the next nine months to sound the \u201calarm bells\u201d for their voters.\n\n\u201cWhat we have seen in the special elections is a significant spike in the interest, engagement, spending and energy by the liberal Democrats and progressive movement,\u201d Mr. Walter said, adding: \u201cThe spending is real. The organizational prowess is real. And the energy is real.\u201d\n\nThat energy was on raucous display last weekend in the Bucks County borough of Newtown, where well over 100 Democrats packed into a red-brick tavern to cheer Steve Santarsiero, a Democrat seeking a State Senate seat left open by a Republican\u2019s unexpected retirement. Before a lively breakfast crowd, Mr. Santarsiero needled Mr. Trump and hailed his fellow Democrats running for the legislature\u2019s multiplying number of open seats.\n\nApplauding from the front was Helen Tai, an official in nearby Solebury who is running in a May special election for the State House prompted by a Republican\u2019s resignation. Democrats nearly swept local elections in four counties outside Philadelphia last November; Ms. Tai said the combination of Republican retirements and liberal enthusiasm had transformed the fight for the legislature.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\n\u201cI wish it was a presidential year,\u201d she said. \u201cPeople want to vote. They can\u2019t wait to vote.\u201d\n\nAdding to Republicans\u2019 unease are several unresolved lawsuits that could unravel carefully drawn maps in states like North Carolina and Texas. The United States Supreme Court is expected to consider a number of cases involving gerrymandered maps this year, and Jessica Post, executive director of the Democratic Legislative Campaign Committee, said the group is considering new litigation against state legislative districts in the Pennsylvania courts, which voided a Republican-drawn congressional map last month.\n\nMs. Post said special elections over the last year had revealed \u201cearly indicators of the wave.\u201d\n\nIn many of the biggest purple states, however, Democrats must overcome huge Republican majorities and forbidding legislative maps. In Pennsylvania, Republicans hold 120 seats in the 203-seat State House, and 34 of 50 in the State Senate.\n\nPhoto\n\nThough Republicans have thin majorities in a few states, like Colorado and Minnesota, the party is entrenched by gerrymandering across most of the Midwest and has long controlled Sun Belt prizes like Florida and Arizona.\n\nIn North Carolina, Republican legislators wield margins enormous enough to override a veto by Gov. Roy Cooper, a Democrat, on a party-line vote in both chambers. For 2018, Mr. Cooper and state Democrats have announced a \u201cBreak the Majority\u201d campaign, not to capture either chamber, but merely to deprive Republicans of their supermajorities.\n\nRepresentative Darren Jackson, the Democratic leader in the North Carolina House, said there had been a surge in candidate recruitment, and Democrats plan to pursue more than five-dozen seats where Mr. Cooper won about 44 percent of the vote or more in 2016. They are especially hopeful about the areas around Greensboro, Raleigh and Charlotte \u2014 the state\u2019s three largest cities \u2014 which resemble suburbs in other states that have turned on Republicans.\n\nBut Mr. Jackson takes an unromantic view of his party\u2019s prospects. A screen saver on his laptop cycles through headlines from when Mr. Trump won the presidency, as a reminder that any anticipated victory can evaporate.\n\n\u201cWe\u2019re seeing a lot of interest in challenging incumbents, even in fairly red areas,\u201d Mr. Jackson said, cautioning: \u201cYou\u2019ve got to have good candidates.\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nDemocratic legislators in several states said in interviews that they were waiting on a major trove of data related to last year\u2019s elections in Virginia, where a coalition of educated white, young and minority voters delivered the party a 15-seat gain in the House of Delegates. State leaders say they intend to use that information to hunt for targets even in areas with unfriendly district lines.\n\nRepublicans are most concerned about a collection of big states where they hold at least one legislative chamber by a narrower majority. In Florida, they hold the State Senate with 23 of 40 seats, and in Arizona both chambers tilt Republican by five seats or fewer. Mike Gardner, a former Arizona legislator who is now a Republican lobbyist, predicted Republicans would keep power in that state, but noted surging energy in the \u201chatred-toward-Trump camp.\u201d\n\nState Representative Jose R. Oliva of Miami Lakes, a Republican in line to be speaker of the Florida House, doubted Democrats could win either chamber, but said Mr. Trump might hobble Republicans in the ultra-diverse communities in and around Miami. Democrats picked off a State Senate seat there in 2017, though they have faced their own woes, including the resignation of a state party chairman amid harassment allegations.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Get the Morning Briefing by Email What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s been my experience over the last several cycles that these are national elections,\u201d Mr. Oliva said.\n\nMost telling may be Wisconsin, a traditional swing state where Republicans have governed largely with a free hand since 2010. Mr. Trump won the state in 2016 and, with the help of gerrymandered districts, Republicans began last year with 20 of 33 State Senate seats.\n\nBut that number recently shrank to 18 after the Democrats\u2019 special election upset and with another vacancy. Gov. Scott Walker, who is seeking a third term, called Republicans\u2019 defeat in a red district on the Minnesota border a \u201cwake-up call,\u201d and party strategists are monitoring the Milwaukee suburbs, a cornerstone of Mr. Walker\u2019s political coalition, for signs of unrest.\n\nState Senator Chris Larson, a Democrat, said a special election fought in below-freezing temperatures had buoyed Democrats who had grown accustomed to disappointment. \u201cA lot of skepticism by Democrats is starting to melt away,\u201d he said.\n\nIt is not Mr. Trump alone mobilizing Democrats down ballot. In some states, Republicans have been in charge long enough to generate their own cloud of fatigue. In moderate areas where Mr. Trump is toxic, some voters have also tired of Republican policies \u2014 on abortion, guns and environmental regulation \u2014 championed by rural legislators.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nAt a meeting of the liberal group Indivisible in Eagleville, Pa., last month, Democratic activists railed not just against Mr. Trump, but also against Republicans in Harrisburg, the state capital, accusing them of wringing money from suburban voters while neglecting local schools and infrastructure. Katie Muth, a leader of the group who is running for State Senate, declared from the front of a Unitarian church that 2018 was the moment to \u201csave Pennsylvania.\u201d\n\nBut Mr. Trump\u2019s unpopularity is likely to help. Pam Hacker, an electrician running for the State House, said she rarely brings up the president, but sees him alienating communities that once voted Republican.\n\n\u201cIt is a new Republican Party,\u201d she said, \u201cand I just don\u2019t think it\u2019s a friendly face.\u201d", "title": "\u2018They Can\u2019t Wait to Vote\u2019: Energized Democrats Target Dominant G.O.P. in Statehouses", "authors": ["Alexander Burns", "Alan Blinder"]} {"date": "2018-02-09 00:00:00", "text": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 The need for more diversity in Hollywood is a popular topic of conversation these days. But at least one group tends to get left out of the discussion.\n\n\u201cThere have been some deaf characters on television, but they are usually there so the hearing characters can learn something from them,\u201d Josh Feldman said. \u201cAnd then they send the deaf characters back into the shadows.\u201d\n\nHe said it with his hands. Sitting in a mellow cafe on a dilapidated strip of Melrose Avenue, he and his writing partner, Shoshannah Stern, carved shapes in the air to tell animated stories, volleys of sign language zinging across the table between them and their two interpreters.\n\nIt was at this cafe that the pair first conceived a comic web series about two deaf best friends like themselves living in Los Angeles. On a warm winter morning three years later, they returned to discuss the television show that resulted from it: \u201cThis Close,\u201d debuting Wednesday, Feb. 14, on SundanceTV\u2019s streaming platform, Sundance Now.", "title": "\u2018This Close\u2019 Is by and About Deaf People, but That\u2019s Only the Beginning", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-27 00:00:00", "text": "In the end, it all comes down to ziti.\n\nThat was the essence of the government\u2019s closing pitch to jurors in its sprawling corruption case against Joseph Percoco, formerly one of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo\u2019s top aides and closest friends, now accused of taking more than $300,000 in bribes from three executives in pursuit of state contracts.\n\nThe bribes were code-named \u201cziti,\u201d a reference to the Mafia drama \u201cThe Sopranos,\u201d and federal prosecutors seemed to relish Mr. Percoco\u2019s use of the term.\n\nIn closing arguments on Tuesday, a prosecutor, David Zhou, cited emails from Mr. Percoco to Todd R. Howe, a lobbyist with connections to the executives, in which Mr. Zhou said Mr. Percoco was \u201cbegging, requesting, demanding ziti.\u201d\n\n\u201c\u2018Where the hell is the ziti?\u2019 \u2018I have no ziti,\u2019\u201d Mr. Zhou said, quoting from emails Mr. Percoco sent from his private AOL account, adding that jurors should know \u201cexactly what Joe Percoco was demanding.\u201d", "title": "\u2018This Is How Criminals Talk\u2019: Closing Arguments Focus on Ziti", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-05 00:00:00", "text": "Did you know Dave Chappelle? He lived there, too, as a kid.\n\nI do. Not past tense.\n\nAre you homies?\n\nI have not seen him in a while, but I don\u2019t think it\u2019s controversial to say we\u2019re cool. We went to middle school together.\n\nI didn\u2019t really know him then. He\u2019s younger than I am, by like a year maybe. I just kind of knew he was this kid that everybody thought was funny or cool, and I was not. I didn\u2019t go to parties. I didn\u2019t hang out.\n\nBut when I moved to New York City, I started running into him because he lived close to my first job, which was at a publishing house. And I sometimes run into him when I\u2019m visiting Yellow Springs.\n\nYou\u2019re cool too, Monica \u2014 journalist cool.\n\nOne of your new projects is called Surfacing, which our executive and managing editors described (in their announcement to the newsroom) as \u201ca cross-platform column that will focus on subcultures around the world.\u201d You\u2019ve just hired three reporters for it. Tell me more about it.\n\nThis is a vast country, and I think it\u2019s endlessly fascinating. Because of the bubbles we\u2019re in now, you can actually exist and have a certain set of interests and not know what the people down the street are interested in and doing.\n\nThe goal of Surfacing is to really capture a slice of life and the unlikely pursuits of people from all over the world. There\u2019s a lot to mine in the United States. But there\u2019s going to be some international stories, too. The first story was on these Jamaican girls who are really into synchronized swimming.\n\nWe are planning a piece on a sport called pelota mixteca. It\u2019s about this group of Oaxacans who have moved to Southern California \u2014 some of whom have been there for generations. They\u2019re playing this game that\u2019s been played for hundreds of years.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWe also just did a piece on the culture of very fervent fans of the Browns, an Ohio N.F.L. team. We\u2019re planning stories in Turkey, Sweden and one in Brazil.\n\nThis is a chance for us to cover people and parts of the world we don\u2019t cover unless something is going wrong. So hopefully we\u2019ll have profiles of people in communities most people don\u2019t know about, people of all races and backgrounds.\n\nWhere did your passion for travel and learning about other cultures come from?\n\nIn college, I took a lot of courses that I liked. I took economics. I took a lot of math. I was going along a different path. But I always loved hearing people\u2019s stories and understanding their lives.\n\nThat\u2019s why I decided to major in anthropology. Travel and thinking about travel allows me to pursue my passion for hearing people\u2019s stories.\n\nTell us about your first job working at The New York Times.\n\nIt was early June 1998 when I started. I was interning as a copy editor on Metro.\n\nIt was a different newsroom then \u2014 copy editors were all much older than me, closer to my parents\u2019 generation than mine. My youth made me useful.\n\nI came up with playful headlines that incorporated pop culture. One of my big victories was finding a typo in a reference to Roberto Cavalli, the Italian fashion designer.\n\nBut I edited stories just like everyone else. I did the same job as everyone else. I worked my way up to front-page stories. And I just felt honored to come in every day.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nHow did you go from being an intern here to being a regular staff member?\n\nThe craziest thing is that the whole summer they kept telling us, \u201cWe do not hire interns,\u201d especially copy-editing interns. They kept saying: \u201cYou have to have a lot of experience. This is going to be great for you, but plan to leave and let\u2019s just have a good summer; that should be your goal.\u201d\n\nI was relaxed the whole summer because I didn\u2019t have to worry \u201cAre you going to make it? Are they going to keep you around?\u201d\n\nAt the end of the summer, when they asked me to keep coming in, I was like: \u201cWait, you said you didn\u2019t hire people. I was looking for my next job.\u201d I was happy, but I was really confused.\n\nThey said: \u201cYou show a lot of promise. We think you did a really good job. We want you to keep coming in.\u201d\n\nI want to ask you a question about The Times\u2019s digital transformation. In your almost 20 years of working here, you\u2019ve witnessed and helped shepherd the company\u2019s transformation from a print-only newspaper to a digital platform. When you first arrived here in 1998, what was the latest newsroom technology and what were the steepest technological learning curves?\n\nI love this question. I came to The Times when I was still in journalism school. I was an intern. I had always been this kind of tech nut. Not an expert at anything, just an early-ish adopter of a lot.\n\nI found it immensely exciting that The Times had its very own website, which was updated I think once per day. I don\u2019t remember what the art looked like. But I do remember thinking that the Times website was like space age.\n\nThe load time was really short. I just remember being really impressed by it. But there was no general awareness in the newsroom that there was a website.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nPeople knew about it, but they didn\u2019t think about it. At that time, you weren\u2019t thinking about how things were going to play on the web. It wasn\u2019t part of the way you thought about coverage or anything.\n\nThe people who did the website were in a different building for a while. It was not part of the core news operation by any stretch.\n\nWhat other technological transformations have you witnessed in the newsroom?\n\nIn those days, we didn\u2019t have Slack. People in the newsroom mostly communicated through this system called Atex. You could direct message through Atex. You had to know everyone\u2019s name. It was the first two letters of first name and first four of last name. I was \u201cmodrak.\u201d It was really easy to make mistakes and send your message to the wrong person!\n\nOver the years, The Times\u2019s website steadily got better. It went through all of the changes at the same pace as other websites. At one point, I think we realized you can\u2019t just report stories until end of day and publish them all around midnight. If stories are happening throughout the day, we need to put them up.\n\nSo we created a continuous news desk to handle that. That was a big change.\n\nSince then, we\u2019ve changed our content management system a few times. And we\u2019re getting another new system soon. The changes aren\u2019t easy. But the dedication to the mission of what we\u2019re doing means that we\u2019re all game to figure these things out.\n\nOver the years The New York Times has been criticized for failing to diversify the gender and race of its staff and leadership. In recent years, it has made significant strides in both areas. You are the first black woman to be appointed to the print masthead of The Times. How does that feel?\n\nAny barrier being broken is a signal that society and institutions have progressed, so I celebrate that.\n\nI also need to point out that this promotion \u2014 and the career that I\u2019ve had \u2014 is a result of the collective support of the people who have guided me throughout my life and career.\n\nThey include my maternal grandfather, a former sharecropper and auto factory worker; my grandmother, a former domestic worker; my mother, who raised three kids while putting herself through medical school; my twin brother, a scientist who has been a constant companion and nurturer; Dana Canedy, the former senior editor without whose guidance and mentorship I simply wouldn\u2019t be here; Janet Elder, the recently deceased deputy managing editor and the fiercest advocate anybody could hope for; Dean Baquet, our executive editor, who wears a million hats, including stealth mentor; and Greg Winter, the deputy international editor, a great journalistic mind who happens to be my husband.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nSo yes, this milestone feels great, especially because it\u2019s a reflection of the collective brilliance and generosity of these people and countless others.", "title": "\u2018This Milestone Feels Great\u2019: A Chat With the First African-American Woman on Our Print Masthead", "authors": ["Kelly Virella"]} {"date": "2018-02-03 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLuis Lora, 49, is a master tissue technician at MTF Biologics in Edison, N.J., where he processes human tissue that can be used to treat sick or injured patients.\n\nWhat does it mean to work with tissue?\n\nTissue includes cartilage, bone, ligaments and skin, and is used in reconstructive surgery and wound healing, as examples. I work for the nonprofit tissue bank formerly known as the Musculoskeletal Transplant Foundation. We\u2019re a consortium whose members are organ procurement and tissue recovery organizations and academic medical institutions such as Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. I process the tissue, preparing it for use by medical professionals.\n\nWhere do you get the tissue?\n\nAs with organ donation, a person may register to be a tissue donor such as when they get or renew their driver\u2019s license. Or, the person\u2019s family can choose to donate their tissue when they pass away. With a deceased organ donor, a number of people can receive organs, including the heart, lungs and liver. With deceased tissue donors, as many as 75 to 100 people can benefit from one donor\u2019s gift.\n\nWhat\u2019s involved in the preparation?\n\nIt depends on what it\u2019s being used for. We might hear from a doctor helping a person who has been in a car accident and has a spine injury. The doctor may send images of the patient\u2019s spine and ideas of what might be done to help. In a case like that, we can shape donated bone or combine several pieces of bone to create a bone graft that will fit that particular patient. As another example, we shape skin grafts to fit a breast implant for a woman having breast reconstruction after a mastectomy. We clean the tissue and sometimes treat it with chemicals that remove the cells \u2014 a process called decellularization. We also have it tested to make sure it can\u2019t transmit any infection to the person who receives it.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nWhat is your background?\n\nI was studying to be an architect in Colombia, where I grew up. When my family emigrated to the United States I continued my studies, but I had responsibilities that made it too difficult to finish, so I became a technician at an auto dealer. I thought I needed medical experience for this job, but I didn\u2019t. I received intensive training and had to learn about anatomy.\n\nHow did you get this job?\n\nIn 2002 I told a friend who worked here that I couldn\u2019t grow any more at my job, and he said there were openings at his company. I was reluctant about applying because I thought I\u2019d be squeamish doing this type of work, and my family was against it. My mother and grandmother are very religious and thought the soul and body should stay together after death. After I saw how this work helps the living, I had a different view of life and death. I told them God doesn\u2019t need our body, God needs our soul.", "title": "\u2018This Work Helps the Living\u2019", "authors": ["Patricia R. Olsen", "As Told To"]} {"date": "2018-02-16 00:00:00", "text": "The Fox News host Laura Ingraham on Thursday insulted LeBron James\u2019s intelligence and said he and his fellow basketball star Kevin Durant should not express their political opinions, comments that drew a strong rebuke from Mr. James, Mr. Durant, and the Miami Heat\u2019s Dwyane Wade.\n\nMs. Ingraham called recent statements Mr. James had made about President Trump \u201cbarely intelligible\u201d in a segment on her Fox News show, \u201cThe Ingraham Angle.\u201d\n\nThen, after showing a clip featuring Mr. James speaking about the president with Mr. Durant and the ESPN host Cari Champion, Ms. Ingraham asked, \u201cMust they run their mouths like that?\u201d\n\n\u201cYou\u2019re great players but no one voted for you,\u201d she said, addressing Mr. James and Mr. Durant. \u201cMillions elected Trump to be their coach. No matter what family you\u2019re a part of, you\u2019re going to see your family up there on the stage.\u201d\n\nThe Second Stage revival of \u201cTorch Song,\u201d directed by Mois\u00e9s Kaufman, opened in October at the Tony Kiser Theater with Michael Urie and Mercedes Ruehl in the starring roles as Arnold and his overbearing mother. New songs by the composer will also be included.\n\n\u201cWe start from the position of having in the show a huge collection of some of the greatest songs ever written for musical theater \u2014 and then learn more about Andrew and his way of working and how the music relates to him and his life,\u201d Mr. Curtis said in a statement.\n\nAs the maestro behind \u201cJoseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat,\u201d \u201cJesus Christ Superstar,\u201d \u201cEvita,\u201d \u201cCats\u201d and \u201cThe Phantom of the Opera,\u201d among others, Mr. Lloyd Webber has an enormous amount of work to draw from. His memoir, also titled \u201cUnmasked,\u201d will serve as the inspiration for the show\u2019s autobiographical element. It is set to be released on March 6.", "title": "\u2018Unmasked,\u2019 a Musical Celebrating Andrew Lloyd Webber, to Open at Playhouse in N.J.", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-08 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cEveryone\u2019s got their own thing,\u201d Tom Hardy growls in the newly released teaser trailer for Marvel\u2019s \u201cVenom.\u201d \u201cWhatever it is, you used to be one thing, now you\u2019re something else.\u201d\n\n\u2019Nuff said. Mr. Hardy used to be Bane, Batman\u2019s heavy-breathing foe in the DC Comics-based 2012 smash \u201cThe Dark Knight Rises.\u201d Now he\u2019s crossed over to the rival Marvel universe to play Venom in the much-anticipated spinoff of the \u201cSpider-Man\u201d franchise.\n\nThe role was previously played by Topher Grace in \u201cSpider-Man 3\u201d (2007), but Mr. Hardy looks to bring a much darker take to the character of Eddie Brock, one of the web-slinger\u2019s adversaries, who attains superpowers after being infected by an alien Symbiote.\n\nThe trailer is long on action and short on explanation, but we do get a glance at the very busy Michelle Williams, currently on screen in \u201cThe Greatest Showman\u201d and \u201cAll the Money in the World.\u201d She plays Anne Weying, who in comic-book lore is Brock\u2019s ex-wife and, ultimately, the supervillainess She-Venom.", "title": "\u2018Venom\u2019 Teaser: Tom Hardy Crosses Over to Marvel", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "Photo\n\nLOS ANGELES \u2014 In their Super Bowl tradition, the major Hollywood studios sat on the sidelines over the weekend. Only one new low-cost movie, the horror-themed \u201cWinchester,\u201d arrived in wide release, an effort by a small film company to counterprogram the big game by going after female ticket buyers.\n\nThat left two holdovers to lead the box office. \u201cJumanji: Welcome to the Jungle\u201d (Sony Pictures) reclaimed the No. 1 spot, selling about $11 million in tickets at North American theaters, for a seven-week domestic total of $352.6 million, according to comScore, which compiles box office data. It is almost unheard-of for a movie to continue to perform so strongly so late in its run.\n\n\u201cMaze Runner: The Death Cure\u201d (20th Century Fox) was second, collecting an estimated $10.2 million, for a two-week total of $39.8 million.\n\nThird was \u201cWinchester,\u201d inspired by the true story of Sarah Winchester, a firearm heiress who, in the early 1900s, came to believe that people killed by the Winchester rifle were haunting her labyrinthine house. The film took in roughly $9.3 million, a bit more than analysts were expecting before release. Critics eviscerated the movie, which stars Helen Mirren, but ticket buyers gave it a B-minus grade in CinemaScore exit polls, a relatively good result for the horror genre.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nCBS Films paid $3.5 million for the rights to \u201cWinchester,\u201d which was distributed by Lionsgate. Founded in 2007, CBS Films aims to release about four modestly priced movies a year. It focuses on counterprogramming. For instance, the last CBS Films effort, the action thriller \u201cAmerican Assassin,\u201d arrived in September, a month when competitors mostly focus on more serious genres as students return to school. \u201cAmerican Assassin,\u201d the lone CBS Films wide release in 2017, took in a soft $36.2 million. Ticket sales were likely hindered by \u201cIt,\u201d which became an unexpected blockbuster for Warner Bros.\n\n\u201cWinchester\u201d did not perform like a typical horror movie. Ticket sales increased from Friday to Saturday; horror movies often drop after opening day. Horror also tends to appeal primarily to teenage girls. But women over the age of 25 \u2014 the line that marks \u201colder\u201d ticket buyers in Hollywood\u2019s view (yes, really) \u2014 made up 64 percent of the opening-weekend audience for \u201cWinchester,\u201d CBS Films said.", "title": "\u2018Winchester\u2019 Claims No. 3 at Box Office Amid Super Bowl Slowdown", "authors": ["Brooks Barnes"]} {"date": "2018-02-04 00:00:00", "text": "LOS ANGELES \u2014 In their Super Bowl tradition, the major Hollywood studios sat on the sidelines over the weekend. Only one new low-cost movie, the horror-themed \u201cWinchester,\u201d arrived in wide release, an effort by a small film company to counterprogram the big game by going after female ticket buyers.\n\nThat left two holdovers to lead the box office. \u201cJumanji: Welcome to the Jungle\u201d (Sony Pictures) reclaimed the No. 1 spot, selling about $11 million in tickets at North American theaters, for a seven-week domestic total of $352.6 million, according to comScore, which compiles box office data. It is almost unheard-of for a movie to continue to perform so strongly so late in its run.\n\n\u201cMaze Runner: The Death Cure\u201d (20th Century Fox) was second, collecting an estimated $10.2 million, for a two-week total of $39.8 million.\n\nThird was \u201cWinchester,\u201d inspired by the true story of Sarah Winchester, a firearm heiress who, in the early 1900s, came to believe that people killed by the Winchester rifle were haunting her labyrinthine house. The film took in roughly $9.3 million, a bit more than analysts were expecting before release. Critics eviscerated the movie, which stars Helen Mirren, but ticket buyers gave it a B-minus grade in CinemaScore exit polls, a relatively good result for the horror genre.", "title": "\u2018Winchester\u2019 Claims No. 3 at Box Office Amid Super Bowl Slowdown", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-14 00:00:00", "text": "ISLAMABAD, Pakistan \u2014 When a friend told Hussain Liaquat that police officers in the Pakistani capital might be checking cars for anything red or heart-shaped the night before Valentine\u2019s Day, he decided to get creative.\n\nMr. Liaquat, 22, went to the giant Saeed Book Bank in Islamabad and found a poster from \u201cHouse of Cards,\u201d his girlfriend\u2019s favorite television show. Then he went in search of the perfect romance novel.\n\n\u201cI decided not to buy her balloons and chocolates, to avoid police confiscating them,\u201d the mathematics student said, leafing through a copy of Erich Segal\u2019s \u201cLove Story.\u201d\n\n\u201cSomeone told me this is like the \u2018Romeo and Juliet\u2019 of the 20th century,\u201d he said. \u201cI think I\u2019ll get it.\u201d", "title": "\u2018You Can\u2019t Ban Love\u2019: Pakistanis Defy a Valentine\u2019s Day Prohibition", "authors": []} {"date": "2018-02-28 00:00:00", "text": "\u201cThat\u2019s an important distinction,\u201d said Sara Sutton Fell, chief executive and founder of FlexJobs, an online service specializing in remote and flexible employment. \u201cThese are really viable professional opportunities, especially for retirees.\u201d\n\nFollowing are older adults who have found second careers in jobs in which technology is the common thread, drawing on their backgrounds and experience to flourish in rapidly changing industries.\n\nThe Virtual Assistant\n\nIn 2004, when Geri Lafferty accepted a severance package from E-Trade Financial rather than relocate, she wanted a job that gave her more flexibility. \u201cI stumbled on the idea of virtual assistant,\u201d said Ms. Lafferty, now 67, who lives in San Francisco. A new field at the time, this involves working remotely to help small, typically one-person businesses \u2014 solo-preneurs, as she calls them \u2014 with their administrative and marketing operations.\n\nPhoto\n\nMs. Lafferty figured her new job would involve doing most of the things she used to do as an executive assistant in marketing. She was wrong about that. \u201cI had to learn a lot of technology,\u201d she said.\n\nHer business now thrives. \u201cShe keeps up with the changes,\u201d said one client, Lisa Tener, a writing coach based in Saunderstown, R.I., who has worked with Ms. Lafferty since 2009. Ms. Tener said her virtual assistant had mastered \u201ca very complicated and often consuming customer-relationship management platform\u201d to help her marketing efforts. \u201cI am almost helpless with it myself,\u201d she said.\n\nMs. Lafferty, who took webinars and tutorials to learn the latest digital tools of her trade, dismisses the idea that the job is beyond the grasp of her cohort. \u201cYou can\u2019t be afraid of the tech,\u201d she said. \u201cThat\u2019s what I\u2019ve learned. You really can\u2019t break the computer by pushing the wrong button.\u201d\n\nThe Program Manager\n\nAt Manufacturers Hanover bank in the early 1980s, Ann Donnelly was a management trainee involved in the rollout of what was then a groundbreaking new technology: A.T.M.s. When the bank merged with Chemical and later Chase, she ended up becoming a higher-level program manager, involved in many tech-driven initiatives.\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nShe left the corporate world about 10 years ago and eventually took a part-time job at a Barnes & Noble bookstore in Manhasset on Long Island. Ostensibly a cashier, she has recently been lending her expertise to the store\u2019s management, looking at ways to improve efficiency during peak sales times. Right now, she says, this work \u2014 which inevitably involves technology \u2014 is on a small scale and informal. She is fine with the situation.\n\nNewsletter Sign Up Continue reading the main story Please verify you're not a robot by clicking the box. Invalid email address. Please re-enter. You must select a newsletter to subscribe to. Sign Up You agree to receive occasional updates and special offers for The New York Times's products and services. Thank you for subscribing. An error has occurred. Please try again later. View all New York Times newsletters.\n\n\u201cI certainly don\u2019t need to run big programs like I did in the past,\u201d said Ms. Donnelly, now 64 and living in Bayside, Queens. \u201cI\u2019d be more interested in helping introduce some younger people to the concept of program management.\u201d (Program managers have been defined as \u201csuper\u201d project managers, focused on the strategy and accomplishment of major organizational initiatives.)\n\nAlthough the technology has changed, she said that some of what she experienced as a young manager in a giant financial institution still applies. \u201cThere\u2019s a way to manage projects and programs that will always be usable, regardless of technology,\u201d she said. \u201cYou have to live that to learn that.\u201d\n\nThe \u2018Code Wrangler\u2019\n\nWhen he was in his 30s, Earl Fong, a San Francisco resident, returned to school to earn a graduate degree in computer science. For the next decade, he worked for software companies on the West Coast before shifting to volunteer and nonprofit work. Among other jobs, he taught basic computer skills for three years in Tanzania. Now back in San Francisco and working as a software developer for the nonprofit Kiva Microfunds, Mr. Fong, now 67, prides himself on being a \u201ccode wrangler\u201d: someone who is adept with all kinds of software code.\n\nPhoto\n\nHe may be decades older than many of his fellow wranglers, but Mr. Fong says they all face a similar challenge when it comes to staying relevant. \u201cAnybody in tech has to be constantly in learning mode,\u201d he said.\n\nThe Transcriptionist\n\nMarcy Brown, 65, retired from a career as a paralegal to become a \u201cgray nomad\u201d with her husband, touring the country in an RV. While on the road, Ms. Brown, an Indiana native, started a new career as a transcriptionist. \u201cIt was typing depositions, and I\u2019d been in a law office, so I knew the format,\u201d she said.\n\nMs. Brown was not daunted that she would need to become fluent in a professional transcription program to do the job remotely. Her business eventually expanded beyond the courts, and she now transcribes everything from oral histories to college lectures.\n\nAlthough she and her husband sold the RV and now live in what she calls a \u201csticks and bricks\u201d home in Gravois Mills, Mo., she continues doing her transcription work and has expanded her digital competencies. For one recent legal project, she had to put audio time stamps on portions of the transcription that were inaudible. This required another advanced program that she mastered.\n\nYet she is modest about her tech skills. \u201cI posted a video on Facebook the other day that I made out of photos and music, and someone said, \u2018You are so smart,\u2019\u201d she said. \u201cI said, \u2018No, it\u2019s mostly trial and error.\u2019\u201d\n\nAdvertisement Continue reading the main story\n\nThe Web Developer\n\nWilliam Jones, 55, started his computer career in the 1980s, working in mainframes for a credit card company in his native Birmingham, England. In 2005, he and his wife, Kimberly, made a radical lifestyle change for themselves and their four children. They bought a 76-acre farm in rural Virginia, where they raised free-range pigs.\n\nWhen his children grew older (they range in age from 18 to 24), Mr. Jones decided to return to the tech world. He took an online web development course at the Flatiron School in Manhattan. \u201cI thought technically I could pick it up,\u201d he said. \u201cBut I didn\u2019t think many employers would be interested in someone in their mid-50s.\u201d\n\nAfter completing the eight-month Flatiron course last year, he found a job in web development for D\u2019Artagnan, a food company based in New Jersey. Mr. Jones compares the coding he is doing in his new position, and the mainframe code he used to write, to learning German and Italian (Italian, like today\u2019s computer languages, being less formal and rule-bound).\n\nRegardless of experience, he thinks many older adults are capable of learning the skills needed for his job. \u201cIntellectually,\u201d he said, \u201cthere\u2019s no reason someone my age couldn\u2019t be doing this.\u201d", "title": "\u2018You Can\u2019t Be Afraid of the Tech\u2019", "authors": ["John Hanc"]}
